Content: All the rivers that flow through the KNP originate outside and to the west of the knp where they are highlly utilised. They are crucially important for the conservation of the unique natural environments and biodiversity of the KNP.

Sampling and analytical methods Rivers are sampled on a two-weekly basis at a number of stations. the samples are taken and analysed according to the methods applied by the Department of Water Affairs and Forestry(DWAF) fro their national Water Quality Monitoring Programme. the samples are sent to the Institute for Resource Quality Studies in pretoria for analyses.

Colophospermum mopane seems to dominate wherever it is found. We examined the life history strategy of C. mopane in an arid savanna that leads to its dominance, specifically, its herbivore defense strategies, its mechanisms to cope with fire, and its competitive ability. We also examined possible trade-offs in its ability to establish and colonize an area. Our results indicate that where C. mopane dominates, there is a drop in non-mopane species richness and biomass. Both tree and shrub forms of C. mopane occur in higher biomass in deep red Kalahari sands. There is an inverse relationship regarding biomass and soil depth for other species co-occuring with C. mopane. Our results indicate that C. mopane can attribute its dominance to its herbivore defenses, ability to cope with fire, and resource utilization.

Methods Study Site MNP is located on the banks of the Limpopo River and is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna. It is also the capital of one of the earliest known kingdoms in sub-Saharan Africa. It is located in a semi-arid area of the country with annual rainfall ranges from 350-400 mm. Characterized by mopane bushveld and savannah vegetation, it is home to 24 species of acacia tree and eight commiphora. Trees near the Limpopo flood plain grow in a dense, riparian fringe with closed canopy. MNP lies in a basin between two granite cartons with rocky outcrops of dolerite dykes (Flemminger 2006). Study species Colospermum mopane (C. mopane). Experimental design and protocol To examine life history strategy affecting distribution and dominance of C. mopane, fourteen plots were randomly selected within MNP along the main park road from 09/09/09 – 10/09/09 (Appendix 1 for GPS coordinates). After picking an initial plot, we stopped every 0.5 kilometers along the road and walked 50 meters off the road. Each plot in the park was roughly a hectare. Additionally, five plots were selected outside the park near the Southern boundary to evaluate the extent of C. mopane dominance outside of MNP (see Appendix 1). The 5 plots outside the park were not included in Figures 1 – 6, because a fence limited our ability to sample biomass. We were able to take soil augers, identify species with binoculars, and observe C. mopane in plots 15 - 19. It should be noted that we chose plots with few rocky outcrops and avoided slopes due to the limitations of the Bitterlich Wedge, which is only accurate on flat landscapes. In order to assess its competitive ability, we examined the relative biomass of C. mopane and other species using a Bitterlich wedge (W. Bond pers. comm.) to measure the biomass of the plot in square meters per hectare. The wedge is a rapid method of measuring biomass and consists of a 50 cm rope with one end attached to an 8 x 7 cm card with a 0.5 cm slit cut in the card. We counted the number of trunks or stems that were larger than the slit while the rope was held at eye level. By rotating 360 degrees with the wedge, all species that had stems or trunks larger than the slit were identified and recorded. If a tree had multiple stems that were larger than the slit, each stem was counted. The final count was multiplied by 0.25 to yield the biomass in square meters per hectare. To account for shrub biomass, we used the same Bitterlich wedge, but only counted a shrub if it was wider than the 8 cm side of the cardboard. Shrubs were defined as cagey structures with branches below the height of 1.5 meters. Overlap existed between the two groups as some trees were also counted as shrubs. In order to obtain a general understanding of landscapes that C. mopane inhabits and dominantes, landscape observations were made at each plot for soil, grass cover, species assemblage, species characteristics, and evidence of herbivory. A soil auger was used to take three soil samples at each of the 19 plots to determine the color, soil depth, and composition at different depths. All tree species within a plot were identified and their characteristics were described in order to provide a general picture of C. mopane’s competitors and the different life history strategies they employ to combat herbivory and fire. We noted architecture (cage or pole structure), defense mechanisms (spinesence and palatability), leaf presence or absence, density of undergrowth, bark thickness, herbivory (presence of dung and evidence of grazing), and grass cover. Additionally, to assess their below ground competitive ability, two C. mopane, one Combretum apiculatum, and one Boscia foetida were excavated to observe underground biomass and root structure. Bark thickness was measured in cm for five species at two plots in MNP to assess their ability to cope with fire. It was taken by measuring the width of the target stem and by measuring the thickness of bark when cut away to reveal the xylem. These two measurements were taken in relation to one another to give the relative bark thickness in comparison to stem size. We controlled for stem size between individuals by selecting stems with a diameter between 8 and 12 cm. Regression analyses were performed using Microsoft Excel 2007 for Windows and Sigma Plot was used to determine significance.

This experiment was carried out in the Shabeni and Kambeni experimental burn plots in the Pretoriuskop region of the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa. Sampling was conducted in the annually burned and control plot of each of the sites. Four 50m transects and a 200mx 200m quadrat was set up in each site to get an estimate of termite density and activity. The results show that there was a greater density of termite activity on the annually burned plot than the control plots in both sites ( Shabeni-df=1,P<.01, Kambeni- df=1,P<.01). The conclusion drawn from the results is that termites do better in fire prone areas because fires promote habitat heterogeneity. fire treatments, termite activity, Shabeni and Kambeni experimental burn plots

The experiment was carried out in the Shabeni and Kambeni burn plots in the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa (Figure 1). The Kambeni site was sampled on the 22nd - 23rd February 2004 and Shabeni site was sampled on the 24th of February 2004. The sampling times were between 0700 hrs and 1300 hrs each day. A frequently burned plot (burned annually in August) and a less frequently burned plot ( where fire is excluded as much as possible). In each of the plots a direct and indirect measure was used to determine termite activity . As an indirect method, a series of four transects of 50m each was sampled in each plot and below ground activity was recorded at every meter along the transect. The termite activity for a 1m x 1m plot from the transect was assessed by estimating the percentage of termite activity. A 200m x 200m plot was set out in each plot and the amount of termite mounds in the plot was counted as a direct measure of above ground termite activity. The number of trees with termite activity was also counted in the 200m x 200m plot. A chi squared contingency test was used to determine if there was a difference in the proportion of activity in the annually burned plots relative to the control plots.

Ficus abutilifolia and Ficus tettensis are two species of deciduous rock fig trees commonly found on the vertical faces of Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa. The demographics of the rock figs as well as the habitat features necessary for successful maturation are currently unknown. This study first aims to provide demographic data and determine the points in the fig life cycle where bottlenecks occur. Secondly, it probes the importance to growth of location and usage of cracks. From general observations, we hypothesized that seedlings would be located anywhere on the rock faces, but that larger trees would be more limited to specific areas. We also conjectured that usage of cracks by tree roots would positively correlate with tree height, due to stability and nutrient gathering arguments. Within the sampled population, there was an uneven distribution of seedlings (62.8%), saplings (21.9%) and adults (15.3%). All size classes were contagiously dispersed on the outer edges of the rock faces, despite our expectation about seedling dispersal. Lastly, the number of cracks used by the roots as well as the number of large cracks used showed some degree of positive correlation with tree height. These results suggest that (1) there are growth bottlenecks in the population, (2) the outer edges of rock faces are either popular for dispersal or essential for establishment, and (3) large cracks provide more stability and/or necessary nutrients for trees as they mature.

Bottleneck, demography, dispersal, Ficus abutilifolia, Ficus tettensis, roots

Methods Study site From September 14th to September 15th, (sampling times ranged between 6:30 AM and 5:30 PM) we collected data within MNP in the Limpopo Province of South Africa. MNP is located in the northeastern region of South Africa in the confluence of the Shashi and Limpopo rivers. Within the national park we visited five sites (1, S22º13.161 E029º21.904; 2, S22º 13.142 E029º 21. 971; 3, S22º 13.023 E029º21.692; 4, S22º12.313 E029º22.289; 5, S2211.33 E02914.20). The sites are mainly cracked sandstone cliff faces surrounding dry valleys. Within these five sites we sampled from 26 rock faces. We defined separate rock faces as being bounded by the top and bottom of the cliff face and by any vertical edges or large fissures. We then broke the face into three concentric zones with perimeters equidistant from each other (Fig. 1). In total, we sampled 137 individuals, four of which were dead. Figure 1: Example of a rock face, with defined zones and borders (in yellow). Note: there is a fig sapling positioned in zone 2. Study species We focused on the broad-leaved rock figs Ficus abutilifolia—the large-leaved rock fig—and Ficus tettensis—the small-leaved rock fig. The two species differ in leaf characteristics but are both rock-splitters and are usually found in the same areas (Burrows and Burrows 2003). Since these trees are nearly biologically equivalent, we decided to combine the data of each species. Data collection We first measured tree height (from the base of the trunk to the tallest branch), which allowed us to determine the population structure and height bottlenecks. To collect these measurements we used a hypsometer (Nikon) for the trees that had non-angled trunks. We measured trees with angled trunks using estimations calibrated by the hypsometer measurements. After measuring the height of a tree, we classified it as being a seedling, sapling, or adult, with seedlings being 0-0.5m tall, saplings being >0.5-1.5m tall, and adults being >1.5m tall. For each tree we noted the zone in which it resided in order to test our hypothesis about the effect of zone on tree height. We then estimated the distance between it and its nearest neighbor of the same size class so that we would be able to determine the dispersal pattern on the rock face. Lastly, we counted the cracks within a one-meter radius of each individual and sorted them into three categories based on width: small (0-2cm), medium (2-7cm) and large (>7cm). We counted how many cracks were occupied by the roots and how many were unused. Data analyses We organized our data and performed regressions using Microsoft Excel software (Microsoft 2003). In order to assess size-based bottlenecks, we first ranked all individuals from shortest to tallest and observed significant shifts in population structure. Using the nearest neighbor distances, we calculated dispersal indices to determine whether each size class was normally, randomly, or contagiously dispersed (Fowler et al 1998). Using tree heights and the data collected on tree location zone, we calculated the probability of finding an individual of a specific size class in a specific zone on each rock face. These probabilities were not normally distributed. We thus ran nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis tests using Statistica, v. 6, software (StatSoft 2004) in order to determine (1) whether each size class was significantly more likely to be found in a particular zone and (2) whether any class was more likely to be found in zone 3 than other size classes. In order to quantify total crack usage we created a crack index score for each tree. We summed all used cracks, giving small cracks a value of one, medium cracks a value of two, and large cracks a value of three. For example, a tree using two large cracks, one medium crack, and three small cracks received a crack index score of 11 (2*3 + 1*2 + 3*1=11). We regressed this index against tree heights. This regression illustrated the general importance of cracks in the maturation of rock figs. However, it didn’t specify whether the size of cracks is important. Therefore, in three separate analyses we regressed the number of small, medium, and large cracks used against tree heights. Regression results revealed any causal relationships between the compared variables. We excluded trees that we observed to be growing directly out of a soil patch in all of these crack use regressions, due to the possibility of this reducing dependence on root growth for nutrient gathering.

Nocturnal flying insects fly in a straight line by maintaining a constant angle with the brightest light in the sky, usually the moon. The moon is always above the horizon and therefore moonlight always strikes insects from the top and never from below. When observing whether insects would fly to a light source shining from below them in comparison to a light source shining from above, no insects flew to the light shining from below, while several flew to the lights source shining from above. Samevatting: Nagtelike vliënde insekte vlieg in ŉ reguit lyn deur ŉ konstante hoek te bly hou met die helderste lig in die hệmel, wat gewoontlik die maan is. Die maan is altyd bo die horison en daarvoor raak dit altyd die insekte van bo af en nooit van onder af nie. Terwyl my ondersoek om uit te vind of insekte verkies om na ŉ lig vanaf onder of bo te kom het ek gevind dat daar min was wat na die lig vanaf onder gekom het. Die insekte het dikwels na die lig van bo gekom.
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project

My study sites were the Skukuza and Shingwetzi camps in the Kruger National Park. I conducted two trials in Skukuza and one trial in Shingwetzi. I cut out a piece of cardboard one meter in length and .4 meters in width. In the middle of the rectangle two holes 1.5 cm in diameter were cut out. In each hole I placed a flashlight pointing in opposite directs. I then taped the barrier to a wall with equal amount of wall area above and below the barrier. For each trial I observed and tallied the insects that flew towards the light from above and below. An event would only be considered if the insects flew towards the light and either touched the light source or the barrier. Each trial was one hour long and began at 20h00. The trials were completed 23 February, 24 February, and 2 March respectively. The statistics performed was a χ2 – test.

Notes for Geelbek basic data quality checks Geelbek station : station number 0040192 4, Latitude: -33.2,Longitude:18.12, Height: 4 m Deleted a large time series for which there was no data (1990-1997) for both humidity and pressure and wind Exceptionally high rainfall in 1994, 1997, 2009 - this does not seem to correspond with the data from Langebaan Large gap in rainfall and temperature data between end 1994 and beginning 1997 - I have inserted cells to fill in the dates that span these gaps Deleted 1997 humidity as this was a short section of data followed by a 5 year gap Added several dates to the temperature series in the analysis file. May 1998 added to the rain series in the analysis file. Notes for Langebaan basic data quality checks Langebaan station: station number 0061298 8,Latitude:-32.97,Longitude:18.16, Height: 31 m Deleted a value of 1799 from the pressure records - this was clearly an outlier (DATE: 1994/03/23) On the 5th of Agust 1974 57mm of rain were recorded - is this possible? Again in 2007 I put together an unborken rainfall stretch from 1973-2009, by inserting blank rows for dates where no data existed. This allows for better viewing of trends and gaps in graph format The same 1991 gap that appears in the rainfall data also appears in the temperature data - I have inserted cells with dates for these periods as above. There is no 2003-2005 gap in the temperature data 0 degrees recorded as minimum on 24/02/1994 - this is completey outside the cycle and is probably incorrect; 0 also recorded on 1993/09/10, temperatures were generally lower at this time, but 0 is at least 7 degrees lower than other nearby lows. Data gap in wind data with discontinuity bfore and after gap (1993/10) One week of missing dates added to the temperature series in the analysis file

These data were collected as part of a monitaring programme on habitat use by large herbivores. the numbers and distribution of large herbivores were counted from the roads b the same observer (Peter Novellie). the same road was followed for all counts. the counts were conducted roughly once per mounth from the first on 15 December 2983 and the last on 4 September 1989, there being 98 counts in total. This dataset include the most common ungulate species: Cape mountain zebra, springbok, black wildebeest, blesbok,and red hartebeest. from this study it emetged that there were three areas (termed hotspots), each about 50ha in size, which consistently carried very high herbivore numbers. this dataset recodeds the number of herbivores counted in each of the three areas. follow up surveys could reveal whether these areas are still particulary favoured by large herbivores.
Three hotspots called A,B and C.
Numbers of the counts from 1 to 98
this season given as either summer (October to March) and winter ( April to September)
the total number of zebra counted
the number of black wildebeest counted

Mountain zebra are individualy recognizable from photographed individuals in the Mountain Zebra National Park were maintained from the 1950s to 1989 by a number of observers (Banie Penzhom, Anthony Hall-Martin, Hans Grobler, Peter Novellie and Achim Winkler) this database give the years of births, deaths and translocation of the known individuals from the inception of records up to 1989, when the record-keeping ceased. Note: there are gaps in the information in that the births and deaths of some individuals are unknown.
The symbol (letter and number) of each individual zebra. The foals of a known mare received the mother, but there numbered in ordr of birth.
The month of the animal was born, Number of the month of birth (0=birth mounth unknown).
The year the animal was born (0=year of birth unknown)
Symbol identifying the identity of the mother of the individual (u=dam unknown).
Symbol identifying the stallion at the estimated time of conception of the foal (u=herd stallion unknown).
the month of the dear of the individual (0=month of death unknown, 22=individual known to be alive in 1989).
Year of death of the individual (0=year of death unknown;2222=still alive in 1089)
The name of the reserve or the surname of the private individual to which/who the animal was sold or danated (n=the animal was never taken out ofthe Mountain Zebra NP).
Month in which the animal was translocated (0=the animal was not translocated).

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Knowledge of population sizes of different large herbivores is essential for thr development of management strategies and monitoring programmes. Aerial survey techniques have been used in the KNP since the early 1970's. to estimate population sizes. In the early years the entir KNP was flown resulting in population estimates perspecies. Together with the large herbivores, some birds, vegeation parameters and even later the occurnce of water was recorded.

Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa

Survey technique The technique used was documented by Joubert(1983). The technique comprised the following in the earlier years the entire park was subdivided into smaller blocks(census blocks) these areas were then flown using 800m strips with observers on both sides of the plane observing up to a distance of 400m. The census was conducetd in the early hours of the morning(08-12) in clear weather conditions. A 6 seater cessna was used up until 1985 when it was replaced by a twin engine paternavia. The animals were recorded in the earlier years(1977-1985) by plotting them in the centre of a 1/4 degree square block. between 1985 and 1993 the actual position was drawn in on the map and digitised afterwards. From 1994 the recordings were taken by an onboard garmin 100AVD GPS. The numbers recorded in all cases were the number of the entire herd/group. When the calves were recorded these numbers were included in the herd totals. Black rhino white rhino and elephant bulls were recorded here and also in an annual helicopter census. the hippo that were recorded were those that were away from rivers in dams and pans. From 1980-1996 additional subjective vegetation parameters were recorded on a 4kmsquare grid. This was replaced in 1996 by a single vegetation cover parameter. Certain years have incomplete vegeataion data and some have incomplete census data. In some years occurence of water was also recorded, however there are problems associated with this data. This was an addition to the census and so was not done as thoruoghly as the rest of the census. Also the occurence of rain before and during the census makes this data problematical Entire KNP 800m wide strips

Dung beetles have been proposed as potential bio-indicators for other invertebrates. To be effective bio-indicators, the group must exhibit sensitivity to environmental changes. We sampled the dung beetle fauna in two vegetation types near Punda Maria Camp in Kruger National Park over a two-day period in September 2010. Baited pitfall traps were used to collect dung beetle samples. We measured dung type and density, sampled soil and conducted vegetation surveys at our study sites. A total of 431 dung beetle specimens composed of seven species were collected. Species richness and the distributions of individual species differed between different vegetation and soil types. Our results suggest that dung beetle faunas differ with vegetation type and soil conditions. The family does seem to exhibit the habitat sensitivity required of a bio-indicator.

SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Methods Study site: Our study was conducted east of Punda Maria Camp in the northern region of Kruger National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa. Data was collected over a four-day period from the 10th to the 13th of September 2010. To examine if either similarity in vegetation type or the distance between sampling sites had a greater influence on the dung beetle fauna, we chose two study sites with similar vegetation, Colophospermum mopane, but far apart and one site with a mixed woodland that neighbored one of the mopane sites. Site 1 (22º 75’ S, 031º15’E) and Site 2 (22º69’S, 031º03’E) were 18 km apart and both dominated by C. mopane (Figure 1). Site 3 (22º69’ S, 031º08’E) was approximately 0.5 km from Site 2 and was a mixed woodland (Figure 1). Our decision to collect data at only three sites, two mopane-dominated and one without mopane, was influenced by the time constraints we operated under. Figure 1. Photographs of Site 1 (A), Site 2 (B) and Site 3 (C) A cold front occurred at the time of our specimen collection. Our time restrictions did not permit further sampling under more typical seasonal conditions. Beetle specimen collection and processing: To collect dung beetles, we constructed pitfall traps using soap, water, chicken wire, a funnel, a small bucket and elephant dung. We inserted a bucket filled with water and soap into a 30 cm deep hole and positioned a funnel and chicken wire over its top. A dung packet was placed over the chicken wire so beetles lured to the trap by its scent would walk, or fly, onto the wire and fall through the funnel’s hole into the bucket where we collected them the following morning (Figure 2). Figure 2. Cross-section of pitfall trap used to collect dung beetles. Five traps were set about 25 m apart at each site. Specimens were collected on two separate mornings, placed into alcohol jars and then pinned and labeled. The beetles were examined under a microscope and organized into morpho species. Several groups could not be identified to species level and were designated with a letter preceded by their genus name (See Appendix A for photographs of species). Measuring of explanatory variables: To determine environmental differences among sites, we examined three factors that contribute to dung beetle distributions (Davis et al. 2008). We measured the density of dung present, surveyed vegetation and sampled soil at each site. Dung density sampling: Dung found at the study sites was classified into one of three categories based on fiber content, bolus and size (Davis et al. 2008): 1) pellets (dung of rodents and some ungulates) 2) coarse dung of non-ruminant herbivores (i.e. elephants) 3) fine dung forming a pad, mostly of ruminant herbivores (i.e. buffalo). At each site, we employed two methods of measuring the density of dung present. The first was to collect, weigh and classify all dung found in four 8 m X 8 m quadrants, with a dung beetle trap as a center point. This method was used for the area around the two traps closest to the road at each site (Figure 3A). In the second method, we collected, weighed and classified all dung from a 20 m X 50 m transect that began near the third trap from the road at each site (Figure 3B). Figure 3. The quadrant method (A) sampled dung around one trap, while the transect method (B) sampled dung in a small rectangular section at each site. Soil sampling: Two surface and two subsurface (20 cm below the surface) soil samples were taken at each dung beetle trap for a total of 20 samples per study site. These soils were examined using the finger test for texture to determine soil type (Brown 2002). Vegetation survey: At each site we sampled two 30 m transects. All plants and that fell within 5 cm of either side of each transect and their heights were recorded. Woody plants were identified to the species level where possible, but grasses were simply recorded as poaceae. Data analysis: Species richness and abundance of dung beetles were compared among the three sites using a Kruskal-Wallis test and between sites using a Mann-Whitney test. The tests were carried out using the program Statistica. The Kruskal-Wallis and Mann-Whitney tests were then used to determine if the sites differed in their abundance of specific species. To show the difference between trap contents at each site, we displayed the auto-spatial correlation of our data after graphing S17 Bray Curtis Similarity data for all 15 traps with the program Primer v6. Site Data Site Data: Limpopo Province of South Africa, KNP, Punda Maria • Site 1: (S22.75073, E31.14937) 18 km away from sites 2 and 3, dominated by Colophospermum mopane • Site 2: (S22.69227, E31.02797) 0.5 km away from site 3, dominated by Colophospermum mopane • Site 3: (S22.68980, E31.08439) mixed woodland, (no Colophospermum mopane) • Weather conditions: The dung beetle traps were set the afternoon of 10 September 2010. By the evening a cold front moved in and it rained overnight.

Samples were taken over a two-month period (Feb-Mar 2011) during the wet season (Oct-May in Kruger National Park and Nov-May in Serengeti National Park) to maximize plant inflorescence and seed abundance for plant identification. The wet season is also the period of most intense grazing and where soil processes such as mineralization to be at a peak. Soil and plant variables were measured to quantify differences between the grazing lawns and the surrounding vegetation matrix (lawn and matrix hereafter). Foliar variables were sampled both at the community and species levels. Community-level samples were used to quantify nutritional variables (e.g., N, P, and Na) and plant structural characteristics that influence palatability (e.g., plant height, leaf to stem ratio) assayed for a bulk (composite) sample that ignores species identity. Species-level sampling was used to investigate intraspecific variation in these variables across the lawn-matrix boundary within species that are common to both lawn and matrix. In essence I ask: do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns?

Data Collection Samples were taken over a two-month period (Feb-Mar 2011) during the wet season (Oct-May in Kruger National Park and Nov-May in Serengeti National Park) to maximize plant inflorescence and seed abundance for plant identification. The wet season is also the period of most intense grazing and where soil processes such as mineralization to be at a peak. Soil and plant variables were measured to quantify differences between the grazing lawns and the surrounding vegetation matrix (lawn and matrix hereafter). Foliar variables were sampled both at the community and species levels. Community-level samples were used to quantify nutritional variables (e.g., N, P, and Na) and plant structural characteristics that influence palatability (e.g., plant height, leaf to stem ratio) assayed for a bulk (composite) sample that ignores species identity. Species-level sampling was used to investigate intraspecific variation in these variables across the lawn-matrix boundary within species that are common to both lawn and matrix. In essence I ask: do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns? Site Identification Six sites were identified in each of Kruger National Park (KNP) and Serengeti National Park (SNP). KNP candidate sites were identified using a combination of satellite imagery, on-site visual surveys (e.g., grazing intensity, dung, animal tracks), and past grazing lawn delineations (N. Owen-Smith, pers. comm.). SNP sites were identified with a combination of remote sensing and landscape features, which were used to predict candidate grazing lawn sites (Anderson et al. 2010). Pairs of 50 x 20 m plots were then established inside and outside of each site, for a total of 12 plots per study system. Candidate plots that were within intensely grazed areas were designated “lawn”, while plots outside the grazing lawn boundaries were designated “matrix”. In KNP, twelve candidate plot locations (six lawn, six matrix) were identified at each site. One plot was chosen randomly from the six possible candidates for each site. In SNP, plots were chosen at random within the designated lawn sites. Each paired matrix plot was placed in a similar species swath area that was beyond the boundaries of the corresponding lawn site. Plant Diversity and Community Composition Each plot consisted of a 1,000-m2 (50 x 20 m) modified Whittaker plot with one 100 m2, two 10 m2 and 10 nested 1-m2 subplots. A modified Whittaker plot has two distinct advantages in measuring plant communities: (1) it utilizes a systematic approach to measuring species richness in different plant communities and (2) it balances the effects of quadrat size relative to species-area (Stohlgren 1995). In other words, Whittaker plots balance the trade-offs between large-scale low-resolution surveys that capture broad landscape trends with smaller intense high-resolution surveys. Each plot’s long axis was aligned to capture maximum spatial and vegetative variation, if such variation was apparent to the observer. Both lawn and matrix plots were placed at a minimum of 25 m from the designated boundaries of the lawn to avoid edge effects. Species presence was noted in each of the 100-m2, 10-m2, and 1000-m2 plots. Within each of the 10 1-m2 subplots, plant species cover, richness, percent grazed grass (grass with visually identifiable grazing bite marks) and percent bare ground were recorded. Five of the 10 1-m2 subplots were designated as “intensive subplots” where additional soil and biomass samples were taken. The intensive 1-m2 subplots were selected to maximize coverage along the length and width 1000-m2 plot. Locations of the 1-m2 subplots within each lawn remained consistent within the 1,000 m2. Plant species were identified to the lowest taxonomic level. Plant Structural and Nutritive Characteristics Within five of the 10 intensive 1-m2 plots, standing plant biomass was destructively sampled within a 20-cm diameter ring. Bulk plant samples and leaf samples were dried (48 hours at 60 °C), weighed, and stored for later laboratory N, C, and Na analyses. Leaf-to-stem ratios (L:S) of all community-level samples were measured. L:S and specific leaf area (SLA) were also sampled at the species-level. L:S and specific leaf area (SLA) are correlated with greater nutritive quality, palatability and nutrient-use efficiency (Murray and Illius 2000). During the species-level sampling, grass species were selected that were prevalent in both the lawn and matrix 1000-m2 plots. Three species were selected for all KNP lawns (Chloris virgata, Urochloa mosambicensis, Sporobolus nitens) and five species were selected for all SNP lawns (Eragrostis tenuifolia, Themeda triandra, Sporobolus fimbriatus, Digitaria macroblephara and Sporobolus ioclados). Three replicate samples were collected per species in lawn and matrix plots for all sites where the species occurred both in both plots. Foliar N, C, P, and Na concentrations were measured in addition to SLA and L:S. SLA samples were placed beneath a glass sheet and photographed to preserve the leaf area measurements. The photographed leaves were then transported to the US for analysis. Soil Variables Soil samples were taken from each of the 1-m2 intensive subplots to a depth of 10 cm. Samples were placed in separate airtight zip-lock bags and refrigerated prior to transport to the laboratory. KNP soil samples were analyzed in the Mack lab in the Biology Department at the University of Florida (Gainesville FL, USA). SNP soils were collected and air-dried following the same protocol used in KNP, and then transported to Sokoine University of Agriculture in Morogoro, Tanzania for analysis. Laboratory Analysis In the laboratory, leaves for SLA analysis were oven-dried (48 hours, 60°C) and weighed to the nearest ten thousandth of a gram. Leaf area was calculated using an automated image analyzer (Sigma ScanTM, Systat Software, Chicago, IL). L:S samples were separated by species and bulk samples, dried (48 hours, 60°C), weighed, and then ground for total C and N concentrations analysis on an ECS 4010 elemental analyzer (Costech Analyticla, Velencia, CA, USA). KNP plant samples were also analyzed for foliar P concentrations as an additional measure of nutrient content. Foliar P subsamples were weighed into crucibles, ashed at 500° for 6 hours in a muffle furnace and extracted with 6 M HCl. Following Murphy and Riley (1962), samples were brought to volume at 0.6 M and refrigerated between extraction and analysis with a microplate reader. After ashing, SNP foliar P was determined using the same phosphomolybdate method as KNP (Murphy and Riley 1962). Na concentration was determined using flame emission photometry (AOAC Official Method 2005). KNP soil samples were passed through a 2-mm sieve and subsampled for gravimetric water content (dried at 105°C for 48 hours). Soils were air-dried and ground using a Spex mill (Spex Certiprep, Metuchen, NJ, USA) and analyzed for total N and C using an ECS 4010 elemental analyzer. Laboratory incubations over 21 days were used to determine mineralizable N fraction in the soils. Initial and final pools of inorganic N (NH4+ and NO3−) were extracted using 50ml of 2 M KCl. Incubated samples were moistened using 2 ml of DI water. Samples were shaken for 2 hours and left overnight before filtration and freezing prior to analysis. Inorganic N concentrations were determined calorimetrically on an Astoria-Pacific autoanalyser (Astoria-Pacific, Clackamas, OR, USA). Extractable P was used as an index of plant-available soil P as outlined in the Mehlich-1 procedure (Kuo 1996). SNP total soil N was determined using the Kjeldahl acid-digestion method (Lang 1958). Due to the lack of refrigeration in the area, NO3- and NH4+ were not measured separately and soil results reflect total N concentrations. Total soil organic matter (SOM) was determined using loss-on-ignition method (Sollins et al. 1999). Total soil P was determined with Bray and Kurtz (pH<7.5) and Olsen bicarbonate (pH >7.5) methods. After dry ashing, foliar P was determined by the phosphomolybdate method (Watanabe and Olsen 1965). Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi Sampling and Analysis To test the role of AMF within grazing lawns, community (SNP only) and species-level (both KNP and SNP) root samples were collected in each of the lawn and matrix plots.. Foliar P is often difficult to measure but AMF colonization rates may hint at relative amounts of plant available P in the study plots. Community root samples were taken within each of the 5 intensive 1-m2 subplots. Species-level samples were taken for each species with 3 replicates each. Whole plant samples were removed with as much fine root material and soil as possible. Upon returning to the field laboratory, roots were cleaned with water, frozen, and shipped back to the University of Missouri for laboratory analysis. Roots were then stained with the tryphan blue method (Koske and Gemma 1989) and scored (presence/absence) using the dissection microscope gridline intersection method with a minimum of 100 intersections per sample (Giovannetti 1980), i.e., each root/grid intersection was scored for the presence or absence of AMF colonization, and colonization quantified as the proportion of positive intersections out of the total number of counts. Data Analysis Statistical analyses were conducted in R (R Core Development Team 2011) using linear mixed models in the nlme package (Pinheiro and Bates 2000), with lawn-matrix pairs (sites) and plots within sites as nested random effects. For the species-level analysis, species and sites were treated as crossed random effects. Foliar bulk mass, L:S, SLA, N, P were prior to analysis to meet normal distributional assumptions. Mycorrhizal colonization rates (a proportion) were arcsine square-root transformed for the same reason (Sokal and Rohlf 1987). Plant community differences between the lawn and matrix were evaluated using three metrics: (1) species richness, (2) species diversity with the Shannon-Weiner diversity index, and (3) the Bray-Curtis (B-C) dissimilarity index. The B-C was computed using the R package vegan (Oksanen and Blanchet 2012). The B-C index measures the difference in community composition between pairs of sites (based on presence/absence or cover of species). Identical sites have a dissimilarity score of 0 and sites with zero species overlap have a B-C score of 1. The B-C was calculated from cumulative percent cover values (calculated across the 10 1-m2 subplots of the Whittaker plots) for all species occurring in each plot. The B-C index was computed for each lawn-matrix pair in each site, across all lawn sites, and across all matrix sites. Additionally, a bootstrap analysis (N=10,000) was conducted on the entire dataset (12 plots, regardless of lawn/site classification) to develop a null distribution of the dissimilarity index for each study system. The mean lawn vs. matrix dissimilarity was then compared with this null distribution to test the hypothesis that lawn plots were more dissimilar to matrix sites than expected by chance alone. To gauge the relative importance of species-level versus community-level patterns for lawn-matrix differences, the cover of species occurring in both lawn and matrix plots was calculated as a percentage of the total. If species-level differences occur but there is low species overlap between lawn and matrix plots, the former are less likely to be of ecological relevance than would be the case if most species occur in both lawn and matrix. This percentage of co-occurring species was computed in two ways: (1) by taking into account only species used for foliar analyses, and (2) by including all species found in both lawn and matrix plots.

Data Collection Samples were taken over a two-month period (Feb-Mar 2011) during the wet season (Oct-May in Kruger National Park and Nov-May in Serengeti National Park) to maximize plant inflorescence and seed abundance for plant identification. The wet season is also the period of most intense grazing and where soil processes such as mineralization to be at a peak. Soil and plant variables were measured to quantify differences between the grazing lawns and the surrounding vegetation matrix (lawn and matrix hereafter). Foliar variables were sampled both at the community and species levels. Community-level samples were used to quantify nutritional variables (e.g., N, P, and Na) and plant structural characteristics that influence palatability (e.g., plant height, leaf to stem ratio) assayed for a bulk (composite) sample that ignores species identity. Species-level sampling was used to investigate intraspecific variation in these variables across the lawn-matrix boundary within species that are common to both lawn and matrix. In essence I ask: do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns? Our study is an analysis of the aspect ratio, wing loading and call peak frequency of five species of microchiropterans in Skukuza, Kruger National Park. Bats were caught on four consecutive nights in February using mist nets erected over and around water sources. Species of bats with higher peak frequencies grouped together in our analysis and were also characterized by low wingloadings and aspect ratios as compared with those bats with lower peak frequencies. These characteristics are indicative of already observed foraging strategies. Our results therefore supported the notion that bats flying in open areas tend to have high aspect ratios and wingloadings but low peak frequencies of calls and that bats which forage in clutter have low aspect ratios and wingloadings but high peak frequencies of calls.
aspect ratio, habitat, peak frequency, microchiroptera, wing loading, wing morphology SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Project
aspect ratio, habitat, peak frequency, microchiroptera, wing loading, wing morphology SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Project

Our study period consisted of four nights in February, 2004. Mist nets of 6 and 12 meters in length were erected at three sites in Skukuza camp in the southern part of Kruger National Park. At all three sites the nets were erected over water. An artificial waterhole, a pond and a public swimming pool proved to be good sites. Bats drink about twice nightly from known water sources, usually permanent ones, and therefore one would expect a better catch rate at places where they converge to drink (Taylor 2000). Between four and six nets were put up each night. Bats were kept overnight. Whilst in hand the following measurements were taken from each bat; left and right forearm, head length, tail length, and body mass. The right wing was stretched out over graph paper and was photographed with a digital camera. The image was calibrated to actual size and analysed using SigmaScan Pro 5. Wing span and wing area were measured using this software. Bats were hand-released the night following that of their capture and echolocation calls were recorded using an Anabat 2 recorder and analysed in BatSound Pro 3.3 to obtain the peak frequency of each call. Aspect ratio and wingloading were calculated from the acquired measurements. These two indices of wing morphology were graphed against peak frequency using Microsoft Excel 2000.

Opuntia stricta is an invasive plant species that Kruger National Park (KNP) is seeking to control by using the cochineal insect Dactylopius opuntiae. We studied the dispersal ability of D. opuntiae during the crawler stage by collecting instars and observing their angle and direction of movement towards or away from O. stricta. Results show that the D. opuntiae instars disperse randomly and do not move towards O. stricta cladodes. We conclude that the current method used by KNP for controlling O. stricta is adequate, but the introduction and implementation of an Integrated Pest Management plan (IPM) would further enhance the control of O. stricta. Samevatting: Opuntia stricta is? invallende plant specie wat die Kruger Nasionale Wildtuin (KNW) wil beheer deur die verbruik van? cochenille insek Dactyloppius opuntia . Ons het die verstrooiheid vermo van D. opuntia gedurende die kruiper fase ondersoek, deur die versamelling van instars, en die hoek en rigting van hulle beweging jeen en weg van O. stricta was opgemerk. Uitslae bewys dat die D. opuntiae instars ewekansig verstrooi en hulle beweeg nie na die O. stricta cladodes nie. Ons gevolgtrekking was dat die korent manier wat gebruik is deur KNW vir die beheer van O. stricta voldoene is, maar dat die inleiding en implementasie van ? integreerde pes bestuur plan die beheer van O. stricta verder sal verbeter.
Scott Briscoe, Kyle Harris, Shannon Hatmaker SANParks, South Africa Independent Project

Biocontrol, Dactylopius opuntiae, dispersal, Opuntia stricta

The study was conducted at Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province over a period of 2 days (24-25 February 2004). Approximately 2400 D. opuntiae first instar larvae were collected from infected O. stricta, which was taken from the Alien Biota Greenhouse. The instars were removed from the plants using pipette aspirators. Twelve paper sheets were used for the study. On each sheet, 500 cm diameter circles were drawn and divided into eight 45 segments. The sheets were then divided in half with four uninfected O. stricta cladodes, collected from outside of the Skukuza camp, placed in one half of the circle and at the edge. The positioning of each equally sized cladode corresponded with four of the segments. The half of the circle with cladodes was the cladode experiment and the half without was the control. The angles and directions at which the instars moved, were measured by placing 200 instars in the center of the circle. The total number of instars in each segment was counted every 10 minutes for one hour. This was repeated 12 times on 12 different sheets, using 200 new instars each time. Once all the data had been collected, statistical analysis was conducted using the Statistica program. A t-test was performed to compare the total number of instars found on each half of the diagramed sheets (cladode experiment and control). In addition, a Kruskal-Wallis test was performed to compare the number of instars found in each of the eight segments.

Dispersal ability of the neonate instars of Dactylopius opuntiae (Homoptera: Dactylopiidae), a biological control agent of Opuntia stricta (Cactaceae) and the implicationsfor biocontrol in the Kruger National Park

Change creates uncertainty and risk. Global environmental change epitomizes several threats and risks to human livelihoods. Numerous factors associate with and drive global environmental change including climate, disease, pollution, invasive species, over-harvesting and habitat change. In many instances, protected areas are considered the holy grail of ensuring environmental sustainability, even though continental patterns challenge this. Such areas are usually embedded in matrices of different land-uses, all of which may have different consequences for the environment. In South Africa, it is not clear how protected areas combat or are affected by global patterns of environmental change. The definition of habitat change is problematic on two fronts. Firstly, habitat change can be viewed as primarily a consequence and/or indicator of the effects of other drivers of global environmental change. Secondly, desirable and undesirable habitat changes need to be separated. A range of causes of habitat change (sub-drivers) were identified across parks at a meeting of SANParks research staff at the Cape Research Centre. These include fire, absence of predators, over-grazing, mega-herbivore impact, park isolation, small park size, water abstraction, management for tourism, sedimentation, poaching and overexploitation. Two positive impacts on habitat were identified, i.e. land consolidation and restoration. One of the key conclusions from the discussion was that there is good evidence for the fact that habitat in parks is changing, but that the impact of this change on pattern and process in parks is poorly understood. Objectives were set in this context and the assessment focused on two kinds of data sets – vegetation measures (species composition) across parks as a primary index of habitat change, and large mammal abundances within parks as a broad index of a response to habitat change.

Content: 672 papers and their abstracts were extracted from the Science Citation Database using the “habitat change” and “protected area” as search words. Only the papers published since 1 January 2008 were considered. Results suggest that habitat change associated with land use change and fragmentation, processes that are limited within Parks at the scale usually used in other studies. Vegetation plot data were collated from the South African National Parks into one central database. A total of 33 data sets have been collected and converted into a standard ‘species by site’ format or a ‘presence/absence’ format. Several data sets may still be added to the total number as some researchers that were contacted need to sort their data and/or finish field plots before they can provide it. A number of hard copy data sets was also included. The 33 data sets currently collated represent 15 of the national parks. All large mammal time series data available from surveys for National Parks were collated. We reasoned that the responses of large mammals summarized by growth rates that reflect biological influences of resources, members of its own species as well as other species, will serve as good indicators of the impact of habitat change even if indicators of habitat change are limited. We thus calculated exponential growth rates in the past five years.

672 papers and their abstracts were extracted from the Science Citation Database using the “habitat change” and “protected area” as search words. Only the papers published since 1 January 2008 were considered. Results suggest that habitat change associated with land use change and fragmentation, processes that are limited within Parks at the scale usually used in other studies. Vegetation plot data were collated from the South African National Parks into one central database. A total of 33 data sets have been collected and converted into a standard ‘species by site’ format or a ‘presence/absence’ format. Several data sets may still be added to the total number as some researchers that were contacted need to sort their data and/or finish field plots before they can provide it. A number of hard copy data sets was also included. The 33 data sets currently collated represent 15 of the national parks. All large mammal time series data available from surveys for National Parks were collated. We reasoned that the responses of large mammals summarized by growth rates that reflect biological influences of resources, members of its own species as well as other species, will serve as good indicators of the impact of habitat change even if indicators of habitat change are limited. We thus calculated exponential growth rates in the past five years.

Augrabies Falls National Park, South Africa

Knowledge of population sizes of different large herbivores is essential for thr development of management strategies and monitoring programmes. Aerial survey techniques have been used in the KNP since the early 1970's. to estimate population sizes. In the early years the entir KNP was flown resulting in population estimates perspecies. Together with the large herbivores, some birds, vegeation parameters and even later the occurnce of water was recorded.

Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa

Survey technique The technique used was documented by Joubert(1983). The technique comprised the following in the earlier years the entire park was subdivided into smaller blocks(census blocks) these areas were then flown using 800m strips with observers on both sides of the plane observing up to a distance of 400m. The census was conducetd in the early hours of the morning(08-12) in clear weather conditions. A 6 seater cessna was used up until 1985 when it was replaced by a twin engine paternavia. The animals were recorded in the earlier years(1977-1985) by plotting them in the centre of a 1/4 degree square block. between 1985 and 1993 the actual position was drawn in on the map and digitised afterwards. From 1994 the recordings were taken by an onboard garmin 100AVD GPS. The numbers recorded in all cases were the number of the entire herd/group. When the calves were recorded these numbers were included in the herd totals. Black rhino white rhino and elephant bulls were recorded here and also in an annual helicopter census. the hippo that were recorded were those that were away from rivers in dams and pans. From 1980-1996 additional subjective vegetation parameters were recorded on a 4kmsquare grid. This was replaced in 1996 by a single vegetation cover parameter. Certain years have incomplete vegeataion data and some have incomplete census data. In some years occurence of water was also recorded, however there are problems associated with this data. This was an addition to the census and so was not done as thoruoghly as the rest of the census. Dr Ian Whyte SANParks Programme Manager Large herbivores Private bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa +0927 13 7354253 ianw@sanparks.org

Survey technique The technique used was documented by Joubert(1983). The technique comprised the following in the earlier years the entire park was subdivided into smaller blocks(census blocks) these areas were then flown using 800m strips with observers on both sides of the plane observing up to a distance of 400m. The census was conducetd in the early hours of the morning(08-12) in clear weather conditions. A 6 seater cessna was used up until 1985 when it was replaced by a twin engine paternavia. The animals were recorded in the earlier years(1977-1985) by plotting them in the centre of a 1/4 degree square block. between 1985 and 1993 the actual position was drawn in on the map and digitised afterwards. From 1994 the recordings were taken by an onboard garmin 100AVD GPS. The numbers recorded in all cases were the number of the entire herd/group. When the calves were recorded these numbers were included in the herd totals. Black rhino white rhino and elephant bulls were recorded here and also in an annual helicopter census. the hippo that were recorded were those that were away from rivers in dams and pans. From 1980-1996 additional subjective vegetation parameters were recorded on a 4kmsquare grid. This was replaced in 1996 by a single vegetation cover parameter. Certain years have incomplete vegeataion data and some have incomplete census data. In some years occurence of water was also recorded, however there are problems associated with this data. This was an addition to the census and so was not done as thoruoghly as the rest of the census. Also the occurence of rain before and during the census makes this data problematical Entire KNP 800m wide strips

The main objectives was to investigate the role of fire and the compnents of fire regime,as a detrmining factor for woody vegetation cover of savannas. Use was made of remote sensing and GIS to look at fire and fire regime ,as a determining factor for woody vegetation cover of savannas. Use was made of rempote sending and GIS to look at fire and fire regime over a range of conditions differing in rainfall and geology.

Surface geology structures are the foundation upon which many biotic community assemblages are based, supplying fine scale micro-habitats for floral and faunal species. Herpetofauna are one of the groups which make direct use of rupicolous habitat for various life stages such as; reproduction, food resources and shelter. The aim of this study was to determine if the geology type of the rock habitat is as important a factor for herpetofaunal biodiversity as is its functional structure. Our study was conducted in the Shingwedzi region of the Kruger National Park were we sampled rock outcrops on intrusive igneous (granite), extrusive igneous (basalt) from and sedimentary (mudstone and sandstone) geology types. The three rock type sites were compared for species richness, species abundance and species diversity. A total of 20 species were recorded from a total of 139 observations of which lizard 8 diversity was highest (10 species) and accounted for the majority of captures (n = 124). No significant differences were found for richness, abundance and diversity comparisons. Our study suggests that herpetofaunal biodiversity is not determined by geology type and that the rock type of any particular habitat does not affect the species expected to be found within that habitat.
Dax MacKay and Mary Sparks (editors) Graeme Alexander (resource person) SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Problem

Geology type, reptile diversity, Herpetofauna, richness.

Our study was conducted in the Shingwedzi region of the Kruger National Park from September 16-18, 2006. Herpetofauna were sampled from 10 rock outcrop sites occurring on three different geology types; intrusive igneous (granite) from here on referred to as intrusive, extrusive igneous (basalt) from here on referred to as extrusive and sedimentary (mudstone and sandstone). Four intrusive sites and three extrusive and sedimentary sites were selected and surveyed for herpetofauna, by a team of 21 individuals. Species for each site were recorded in three ways: 1) active collection which involved rock turning, and leaf and woody debris searching; 2) observations of species and 3) observations of remnant remains (shedding) over a 30 minute interval. Site surveys were randomly performed at different times of the day for the three geology types. Post-sampling, sites were returned to as near to pristine condition as possible. Species richness, species abundance and species diversity were compared across the three rock types. Data were input into Primer v5 to ascertain the normality distribution and run through multi-dimensional scaling at 40 ordinations to generate an output for richness (the number of different species), abundance (the number of individuals) and diversity. We used the Shannon-Weiner diversity index which describes the evenness of abundance in proportion to the species richness. Statistical analyses were computed; using Statistica 6.0, for species richness and abundance with a one-way ANOVA test and for species diversity with a Mann-Whitney U test.

Addo Elephant National Park, South Africa

Variable characteristics in the timing and extent of leaf-fall and green-up can be seen in savanna trees. This study investigated implications of these life history strategies for tree health (water stress and photosynthetic potential) in four savanna species: Afzelia quanzensis, Euclea divinorum, Colophospermum mopane and Terminalia sericea. The study took place in northern Kruger National Park, where C. mopane and T. sericea trees are abundant deciduous trees with similar strategies of the extent of leaf drop but with variation in the timing of leaf drop. C. mopane and T. sericea showed the highest measures of “water stress” and “photosynthetic potential” in comparison with A. quanzensis and E. divinorum. However, C. mopane trees were found to be able to maintain a greater leaf canopy at the same water potential range as T. sericea trees. This may play a role in the dominance of C. mopane in certain areas, but further investigation into the role of local soil and rainfall conditions would be necessary to supplement this finding.

Colophospermum mopane, competitive advantage, deciduous, life history strategy, Terminalia sericea, OTS
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Methods Study Sites Sampling took place in mid-September: the late dry to early wet season in South Africa. Two study sites (A and B) were identified in Punda Maria in northern Kruger National Park, South Africa. This part of the Kruger National Park is characteristically dominated by C. mopane shrubveld, which typically occurs on basalt soils and is the largest and most homogeneous landscape in the park. Sites A and B were located along a gradient, with Site A at the bottom of a slope and B at the top of the slope. Site A was characteristically dominated by Colophospermum mopane and Euclea divinorum, while Site B consisted of a mixture of tree species, with the most abundant species being Afzelia quanzensis and Terminalia sericea. Study species Tree species were selected based on their major leaf phenological types. E. divinorum is an evergreen species and A. quanzensis, T. sericea, and C. mopane are deciduous. A. quanzensis characteristically flushes green towards the end of the dry season before the start of the rains, and T. sericea characteristically contains little to no leaves for a large part of the lowveld winter (Sappi Tree Spotting 2007). C. mopane shows variation in its timing of leaf drop, but tends to hold on to its leaves for as long as possible during the dry season (Dekker and Smit 1996). Data Acquisition: Tree Demographics Tree height and stem diameter was recorded in individuals of each of the four tree species. The percentage leaf canopy on each tree was estimated based on the leaf abundance on the tree branches, and GPS locations were recorded for each tree. Fluorometry: Photosynthetic Capacity of leaves A fluorometer was used to estimate the photosynthetic capacity of each tree. Root estimates Five soil samples were collected below each tree canopy using a soil auger at a depth of 10cm, as well as a single soil sample at a depth of 50cm. This was done to separate shallower horizontal roots from deeper vertical roots within the substrate. Soil was classified into broad types using the hand test (Brown 2002). A proportion of each soil sample was sifted to find any roots, and these were classified as coarse live roots, coarse dead roots, fine live roots, or fine dead roots. Coarse roots were determined to be thicker than the fine roots, and live roots were determined if the root could be bent without breaking and was moist in the centre. Water Potential A Scholander pressure device was used to determine water potential of the trees.

These data were collected as part of a monitaring programme on habitat use by large herbivores. the numbers and distribution of large herbivores were counted from the roads b the same observer (Peter Novellie). the same road was followed for all counts. the counts were conducted roughly once per mounth from the first on 15 December 2983 and the last on 4 September 1989, there being 98 counts in total. This dataset include the most common ungulate species: Cape mountain zebra, springbok, black wildebeest, blesbok,and red hartebeest. from this study it emetged that there were three areas (termed hotspots), each about 50ha in size, which consistently carried very high herbivore numbers. this dataset recodeds the number of herbivores counted in each of the three areas. follow up surveys could reveal whether these areas are still particulary favoured by large herbivores.
Three hotspots called A,B and C.
Numbers of the counts from 1 to 98
this season given as either summer (October to March) and winter ( April to September)
the total number of zebra counted
the number of black wildebeest counted
Long grass grazers, the number of red hartebeest plus blesbok.
Number of sbringbok, plus wildebeest plus blesbok
Total number of large herbivores counted
The ratio of long grass grazers to total of all species.

A multiscale approach was used to study the dynamics of reed patches in a section of the Letaba River flowing through the Kruger National Park (KNP), South Africa's largest conservation area. The valley floor consists of a mosaic of patches of reeds, water, sand and rock. Reed vegetation change in space and time is closely linked to geomorphic change in the rivers of the KNP, because of reciprocal interactions between reeds, flow and sediment. Reeds are thus considered a potentially important species around which to formulate management goals for these rivers. A study of clonal growth characteristics at the scale of individual reedbeds was combined with a study of reed patch dynamics at the river reach scale. Mechanisms affecting clonal expansion across reedbed boundaries were combined with short-term patterns of reed persistence, loss and gain at the reach scale, and longer-term trends in reed cover, to produce a conceptual model of proposed relationships between flow conditions and reed cover in the Letaba River. Reed areal cover increased between 1988 and 1999. Despite this, reed persistence was low, and reeds were a dynamic element of the river landscape in the short term. Turnover of water and reed patches was high, within a matrix of sand. Complex patterns of reed gain and loss occurred at the boundaries of reed patches, with gain exceeding loss throughout the period of study. During a drier period (1988-1996), clonal expansion of patches and establishment of new patches contributed equally (50% each) to the increase in reed cover. During a wetter period (1996-1999), the relative contribution of clonal expansion increased to 90%. Reed persistence was higher in the wetter period due to less reed loss, and reed cover increased more rapidly. The relative proportions of reed, water and sand patches did not remain constant over 3 years or over 8 years in the alluvial section of the river studied. At the time and space scales of this study, therefore, the Letaba River did not display the kind of compositional stability described in other river systems. This points to the difficulty of applying equilibrium concepts of either geomorphology or vegetation dynamics to semi-arid rivers. A clear spatial patchiness was present in the distribution of sediment and nutrient resources on the macro-channel floor. Reed patches were associated with `current shadow' features, the characteristic raised elevation of the central, denser parts of reedbeds suggesting accumulation of sediment within reedbeds. Silt and clay particles accumulated preferentially within reedbeds. The results suggest that this accumulation was achieved primarily by selective retention of nes within reedbeds, and to a lesser extent by selective deposition of stones within reedbeds. Total carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus were all higher beneath reedbeds than in uncolonised sediment. The distributions of total N and total P were not correlated with that of total C, suggesting that nutrient accumulation does not simply reflect breakdown of reed organic matter. It was proposed that the nutrient accumulation recorded in this study was due primarily to interactions between reedbeds and flow, and to a lesser extent to the input of reed organic matter. The fact that surface resource distribution patterns did not always correspond to subsurface patterns illustrates the importance of viewing reed patches as three-dimensional entities. A high stem density and limited plasticity in spacer characteristics of Phragmites mauritianus in the Letaba River were consistent with a consolidation strategy of clonal growth. Physiological integration within within the clone was, however, limiteda notable departure from the consolidation strategy. While Phragmites mauritianus showed little evidence of plasticity in the horizontal spacer characteristics traditionally measured in studies of clonal growth patterns (internode length, branching pattern and bud activity), it was proposed that plasticity in rhizome characteristics related to regenerative capacity is important for reed persistence and clonal expansion in this habitat. The added vertical dimension of the rhizome system in species such as P. mauritianus limits the usefulness of horizontal spacer characteristics in explaining patterns of clonal expansion. Progressive accumulation of sediment above the rhizomes and upgrowth of reeds to the surface was proposed as a mechanism whereby the depth of the rhizome layer is increased, thus increasing the density of reed stems and enhancing the persistence of the reedbed. Rhizomes at reedbed boundaries did not show particular adaptations for rapid expansion into available space. Clonal expansion and consolidation of the space aroud established reedbeds was limited both by features of the rhizomes themselves (high proportion of dormant buds, low branching probability and shallow depth), and by external factors (flow disturbance). Management concerns over reed `encroachment' in the Letaba River appear unfounded. While rapid reed expansion may occur during favourable periods, conditions suitable for large increases in reed cover occur relatively infrequently and persist for short periods of time. It was proposed that wet periods with a high frequency of medium flows and no large floods are most likely to be associated with large increases in reed cover.
