Methods Carter and Rogers (1995) analysed changes in reed cover up until 1988. Aerial photographs from 1988, 1996 and 1999 were used to extend their work. A Geographical Information System (GIS), PCI-ILWIS, was used to analyse the aerial photographs. The GIS software made it possible to calculate not only changes in reed cover, but also changes in the distribution of reeds within the macro-channel. It was thus possible to determine the persistence of reedbeds and to assess the relative contributions of clonal expansion and establishment of new patches to changes in reed cover. Spatial and temporal relationships between reed patches, and water and sand patches, could also be investigated. Since the focus of this thesis is on the dynamics of reed patches, an alluvial section of the river was chosen for study. Alluvial channel types have a smaller diversity of patches on the macrochannel oor than other channel types, because of the absence of bedrock and woody vegetation. Reed patches could also be distinguished relatively easily on the aerial photographs. The 25 km llong study section lay between Mingerhout and Engelhard dams (Figure 2.1). The work of Carter and Rogers (1995) showed that landscape state changes taking place in this section reflect the changes taking place in the river as a whole, both in overall pattern and in relative magnitude. Eight subsections were selected from the study section, each approximately 300 m in length. These were chosen subjectively in order to cover both the length of the study section and the range of histories of reed change (increasing reed cover, decreasing reed cover, and no change). Four of the subsections included the study sites at which fieldwork was done (Chapter 5). The aerial photographs were digitized using a scanner, at a resolution of 300 dots per inch (dpi), giving a pixel size of approximately 0.8 m 0.8 m on the ground. The three photographs from each site were then cross-georeferenced using features recognisable on all three photos (mainly trees). Pixels were classified as either reeds, water or sand using unsupervised classification based on grayscale ranges. Woody vegetation could not be uniquely identified on the basis of its grayscale range, and was omitted from the analysis. This was not considered a problem as woody vegetation in this section of the Letaba occurs almost exclusively as a riparian fringe on the macrochannel banks and does not form part of the mosaic of patches on the macro-channel oor. Occasional `problem' patches of woody vegetation were masked using the GIS software and thus ommitted from the analysis. The accuracy of each classification was assessed visually from the photographs and by comparing the maps produced by the GIS with reed distribution at the study sites. The resulting maps of reed distribution for each year were then combined to produce raster maps showing the location of patches (pixels) which had undergone one of nine categories of change, as follows: 1) reeds-> reeds 4) sand-> reeds 7) water-> reeds 2) reeds-> sand 5) sand-> sand 8) water-> sand 3) reeds-> water 6) sand-> water 9) water-> water Two sets of these combined maps were produced, one for each of the two time periods (1988 to 1996, and 1996 to 1999). This made it possible to compare changes taking place over a longer and a shorter period (8 years and 3 years). 3.2.1 Short-term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, Short term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, gain and loss The GIS software was used to calculate the proportion of the macro-channel covered by each of the nine categories of change for each period. Reed cover present at the beginning of a period could then be calculated by combining categories 1, 2 and 3, and that present at the end of a period by combining categories 1, 4 and 7. Changes in the proportion of the macro-channel covered by water and sand were calculated in a similar way. Pattterns of reed persistence, appearance and disappearance were investigated by calculating the frequencies of each type of change involving reeds (categories 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7) as a percentage of the total changes involving reeds. These were compared between the two time periods using two-sample t tests. Reed persistence is a measure of what proportion of reed patches were able to maintain their position on the macro-channel floor, and thus, possibly, undergo clonal expansion. It was calculated as the proportion of reeds which were not lost or gained during a period, in other words, those that maintained their position in space (category 1). Reed turnover was therefore defined as the reciprocal of persistence: the proportion of reed patches which did not maintain their position in space. Reeds which were lost are given by the relative frequencies of categories 2 and 3, while reeds which became established are given by the frequencies of categories 4 and 7. Although this approach differs slightly from that of Arscott et al. (2002), where patch turnover was calculated as the proportional area of new patches present at the end of each time period, it allows patterns of reed loss and reed gain to be distinguished, and therefore allows for a more detailed analysis of reed dynamics. The term turnover, as used by Arscott et al. (2002), is misleading in the sense that it suggests complete removal and re-establishment of patches, whereas in fact it simply indicates the extent of new reed area, which may have arisen either by establishment of new patches or by clonal expansion of existing patches. Patch turnover was, however, also calculated as described above, to allow the results of this study to be compared with those of Arscott et al. (2002), the only other known study of patch turnover in a disturbance-driven river system. It was hypothesised that high reed persistence increases the potential for clonal expansion, and thus produces a greater increase in cover. This hypothesis was tested by relating percentage change in reed cover in each subsection to reed persistence using regression models. The response variable for regression models was always plotted against the fitted values to allow visual inspection of the fit of the model. The model fit was assessed further using the following diagnostic plots: Residuals vs fitted values, useful for identifying outliers and visualising structure in the residuals Normal quantile plot of residuals, to test the assumption that the model's errors are normally distributed Scale-location plot, for measuring spread and identifying pattern in the residuals Cook's distance plot, a measure of the inuence of individual observations on the regression coefficients To determine whether the fate of reed patches depends on their association with other patch types, the probabilities of association between reeds and all the other categories of change were calculated for each river section. This was done by calculating, for each type of reed pixel, the number of neighbouring pixels of each of the 9 categories of change. Reed pixels included reeds which remained (cagegory 1); reeds which were lost (categories 2 and 3); and new reeds which became established (categories 4 and 7). While pixels of a particular type are most likely to be surrounded by pixels of the same type, it is the relationships with neighbouring pixels of different types that can provide insight into the spatial associations between changes involving reeds, and those involving water and sand. Spatial associations between persistent reed patches and areas of reed loss were further quantified by estimating from the maps the proportion of patches of loss which lay within a 5 m radius of persistent reed patches. This made it possible to estimate what proportion of patches were removed completely, and what proportion merely became smaller. Clonal expansion vs establishment of new reed patches Patches of new reeds which are close to persistent reed patches are most probably a result of clonal expansion of the persistent patches, whereas those which are far from persistent patches must have established from seed or clonal progagules. The relative contribution of these two types of reed gain was determined by estimating the proportion of new reed patches found within a 5m radius of persistent patches, as described above for reed loss. Edge:area ratios were also calculated for all types of patches and compared between time periods using two-sample t tests. A decrease in this ratio indicates that patches have become more consolidated, suggesting clonal expansion in the case of reed patches. An increase in edge:area ratio indicates that patches have become smaller and more fragmented. Thus it was possible to determine whether a particular type of change occurred in large contiguous areas or rather in small discontinuous patches. Due to computational constraints, it was not possible to convert the raster maps of whole river subsections into vector format, necessary for calculating edge:area ratios. Instead, two randomly selected smaller areas (approximately 100 m in length) from each subsection map were converted into vector format and used to calculate edge:area ratios. The submaps converted into vector format for the calculation of edge:area ratios were also used to calculate the relative lengths of vegetated and unvegetated channel edge. The fact that new areas of water could be distinguished from older, more persistent ones made it possible to estimate the time required for channel edges to become colonised by reeds. Relationships between reed dynamics and geomorphic change Given the highly dynamic nature of the patch mosaic in semi-arid rivers generally, reed patch dynamics is likely to be related to geomorphic change, which may be quantified by the dynamics of water and sand patches. Relationships between reed patch dynamics and geomorphic change were explored by: Determining probabilities of association between reed patches, and water and sand patches with different histories (neighbour analysis) Comparing the persistence and turnover of reed and water patches in each period Relating reed cover and persistence to water cover and persistence using regression models

Instead, two randomly selected smaller areas (approximately 100 m in length) from each subsection map were converted into vector format and used to calculate edge:area ratios. The submaps converted into vector format for the calculation of edge:area ratios were also used to calculate the relative lengths of vegetated and unvegetated channel edge. The fact that new areas of water could be distinguished from older, more persistent ones made it possible to estimate the time required for channel edges to become colonised by reeds. Relationships between reed dynamics and geomorphic change Given the highly dynamic nature of the patch mosaic in semi-arid rivers generally, reed patch dynamics is likely to be related to geomorphic change, which may be quantified by the dynamics of water and sand patches. Relationships between reed patch dynamics and geomorphic change were explored by: Determining probabilities of association between reed patches, and water and sand patches with different histories (neighbour analysis) Comparing the persistence and turnover of reed and water patches in each period Relating reed cover and persistence to water cover and persistence using regression models

Every year, across each landscape type the management of Klaserie Private Nature Reserve conduct Veld Condition assessments in each of they landtypes. THe VCA's performed are done using the same methods as the orignal VCA's done in the Kruger National Park. Each VCA consists of 100 points were the nearest grass is recorded at each point and a biomass reading is taken. The grasses are identified if they belong to a list of 18 key species. If the grasses do not fall into that category they are recorded as other. All forbs are refered to as forbs. THe biomaass of the grass is recorded using a disc pasture meter

Addo Elephent National Park, South Africa

The aim of this study is to determine the effectiveness of using habitats as a surrogate for species diversity of small vertebrates in the Kruger National Park. Vegetation structure and abundance of various habitats were assessed in five different catenal units. A scoring system was used to predict which reptile species would be found in these areas and a list of species found in each area and their relative abundances was generated. The next phase of this study will be to ground-truth the results and thereby determine the effectiveness of using this surrogate. We concluded by suggesting modifications to the methodology

The data for this experiment were collected along a catenal sequence in the Skukuza area of the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province South Africa on the ninth and tenth of February 2004. Five different catena units were sampled for this experiment, i.e. the valley bottom, sodic site (this unit was sampled twice), seep-zone, mid-slope and the crest. The data collection in each of the catenal units was the same. A 100m transect was laid down to assess the general structure and the number of different habitats along the transect. The general structure includes recording the aspect, slope, soil, animal activity, signs of small vertebrates, mammal dung and termite activity. A habitat survey was done within a five meter band on both sides of the 100m transect line. Holes, rocks, standing logs, prostrate logs, live stems, brush habitats, and litter habitats were counted as potential habitats in the survey. A point survey was done at the end of the transect where the percentage grass, forbs and tree cover was recorded, number of small trees in a 15m radius (trees with a stem diameter of less than 15m are classified as small) and number of large trees in a 40m radius was counted. The height classes of the woody vegetation and the five most common tree species were recorded for each catenal unit. Another 100m transect was laid down and the process was replicated. After the 200m transect was completed we walked for another 100m to look for specialized habitats and sample them, if there were any. A scoring system designed by Andrew Deacon was used to determine the likelihood of finding a certain species in the sampled area. The scoring system works by assigning a score for each type of habitat which is determined by the frequency of the habitat along the transect. The scoring system then gives probability scores for species that are likely to be found in each of the habitats. The habitat score is then multiplied by the species probability score. The final score for species probability was compiled and a cut off score of five was chosen, we chose this number because we wanted to be conservative and prevent an underestimation of species richness. Therefore in each catenal unit, a list of species with a score higher than five was counted as present in the habitat. The species list will be used to investigate differences between the various catenal units sampled. Primer 5 was used to get the Shannon-Weiner diversity indices for each catenal unit.

We studied the effects of vegetation structure and composition on avian species, assemblages, and diversity. The study was conducted over a period of five days in the Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa. The two habitat types studied were open wooded savanna and riparian forest. Ten test sites were chosen for vegetation and avian sampling. Vegetation was sampled for visibility (at varying height levels), height profile, species composition, tree density, and canopy cover. Avian data was collected for species, abundance, and presence. This was done by monitoring 60m x 60m quadrants for 10 minutes each. Birds in the quadrant were recorded for abundance, while birds outside were recorded only for presence. Visual identification was used to identify birds within the quadrant, while auditory calls and visual identification were used for presence outside of the quadrant. Our analysis statistically reflected vegetation structure and floristic composition to determine patterns that influence avian composition rather than species diversity. Changes in structural complexity and floristic diversity do not relate to either losses or gains in avian species diversity, but do relate to a turnover in species within the communities. Increased vegetation canopy cover correlated with increased species diversity. Floristic composition appears to display the most valuable evidence of determining the bird species assembled in each habitat, although we do not undermine the importance of vegetation structure at the same level.
Borman G.D. Bewana A.L and Barnhill D.B SANParks, South Africa Independent project 2

Our study was conducted in Mapungubwe national park, located in the Limpopo province of northern South Africa. We considered the site as being appropriate based on the fact that system engineers such as elephants have just been introduced. Therefore feel that Mapungubwe can serve as base line biodiversity and ecological disturbance studies for KNP and other reserves that might have similar challenges. The park encompasses a dramatically varying environment. Much of the park is dry open woodland or shrub savanna, but along the edges of the Limpopo and Sashe rivers are mature riparian forests. We conducted a series of surveys in 10 different sites; 5 in open wooded-savanna and 5 in riparian woodland. Each site consisted of three count plots .The sites were selected based on obvious differences in vegetation structure and composition. 96 Avian surveys Our procedure involved three observers walking 60m x 60m quadrants for 10 minute increments. Each site consisted of 3 quadrants. Surveys were conducted in the early morning and late afternoon each day, from 05h00 to 08h30 and 16h00 to 18h30 respectively, on the days of 13 November 2006 to 18. November 2006. Each site was surveyed twice, once in the morning and once in the evening, for a total of 6 quadrant surveys. Avian species abundance and presence were recorded for each of the 10 sites by combining the three morning surveys and the three evening surveys. Species identified visually within the quadrant as perching were scored for abundance, whereas species outside or flying threw the quadrant, identified visually or from calls, were recorded solely for presence, not abundance. Vegetation surveys In both vegetation types, we sampled vegetation variables that might explain the bird composition, namely horizontal visibility strata, height profile, species composition, tree density and canopy cover. A vegetation biomass profile was conducted at the heights of 25cm, 50cm, 100cm, 150cm, 200cm, and 300cm from ground level. The involves quantifying the visibility at each height increment. An observer would place their head at a horizontal aspect congruent with the respective height increments whilst another, holding a white rectangular board at the same height above the ground, would move away from the observer until half of the board had disappeared behind obstructing vegetation. The distance between the observer and the other individual was recorded. The value recorded indicates the visible distance without significant obstruction by vegetation. The value was inverted to give a surrogate measure of what the respective biomass of vegetation was at each height increment (hence, the opposite measure to visibility; the distance that cannot be seen due to obstruction). Ten visibility recordings were conducted at each site at each height level. An S-score was calculated to represent each sites’ vegetation profile in a single figure. The S-score is essentially an index calculated by the division of the mean at each height increment by the sum of the means of all height levels. This proportion is then squared and the S-score is the sum of all the products at each level. Three 50m transects were conducted at each site, measuring canopy density, canopy height and floristic composition. Using a densitometer, canopy density was taken at 5m intervals along each transect. Canopy height was determined by estimating tree height for individuals within 1m to either side of transect. Thus the flora species were recorded for an area of 100m² for each transect. Statistical analyses: Our data was analysed using STATISTICA© 6-software program and primer program. For data, which came from a population that did not assume normal distribution and equal variance, non-parametric test were performed to compare the differences between variables. The non-parametric tests we conducted were the Mann- Whitney and Krustal Wallis tests. Parametric were used to test samples which assumed normal distribution in comparing differences between tested variables. In testing for 97 nominal data and proportions, we used Chi-squared. Primer © was used as an analysing tool for assemblages and examination of avian species distributions.

Notes for AGR basic data quality checks 0035334 3 AGR station Lat: -33.57 Long: 25.69 Height: 43 m C There is no data in the 20h humidity or wind series 2003/07/29, 2003/08/26, 2003/09/02, 2003/09/16 and 2003/09/23 repeated in the 8h wind and humidity series - repeated entries deleted 2003/08/31 missing from the 14h humidity and wind series - missing date added 2003/09/30, 2003/10/28 missing from the 14h wind series - repeated dates and data deleted 2003/10/20 repeated in the 8h and 14h wind series 2003/12/25 to 31 missing from the 14h wind series - dates added duplicated and missing dates in both wind series between 2003/09/28 to 30 - corrected 1999/02/01missing from Rainfall series - added Dec 2001 missing from Rainfall series - added Deleted rainfall data after September 2009 as there were too many gaps from here General comments Temperature: There are no large gaps in the data. Nov 1965 has no maximum temperatures recorded, Jan 1963 no minima and there is no data for Dec 1998. There is a strong annual cyclical pattern in temperature. Rainfall: There are no large gaps in the data, though Dec 2001 is missing and there are 26 occurences (0.14% of failed recordings). Most rainfall comes in summer, except for 1979, where 131.5mm fell in July. (Similar spike in rain on this day for other stations). Humidity: There are three small gaps of less than 1 month to a month in 1993, 1998/9 and 2003. There is strong annual pattern in humidity, with highest humidity in the 8h series in winter. There is lower humidity in the 14h series. Wind: There is no 20h data series. There are no large gaps in the 8h and 14h series, though there are a few weeks missing data in Dec 1999 and possibly elsewhere. There is a strong annual pattern in wind speed and wind direction. Notes for Alexandria Bos data quality checks 0036642 8 ALEXANDRIA - BOS Lat: -33.7 Long: 26.37 Height: 198 m RAINFALL CurOrder: 1952 had an incredibly rainy day (287.5 mm - 1952/09/25) General comments Only 59 occurences of failed readings across the 90 year period. No obvious occurences of gaps in the data. Spring to summer rainfall seems to be the most common. Notes for MentzDam basic data quality check Notes There is a large percentage of missing data (gaps) in the rainfall series General comments Rainfall: Station called Darlington Dam in the original data files. 504 occurnces (2.2%) failed readings - this includes Dec 2003 and March to July 2004 and April and October 2006 (i.e. these dates are missing). 1948/12/31 to 1949/09/01 missing; 1949/12/31 to 1951/07/01 missing; 1952, 1953, 1954 missing; Jul, Aug, Sep 1955 missing; Feb, Mar 1956 missing; 1957, 1958 missing. THis means that there is a large proportion (c.a 8 or 9 years) of missing data in this set. There is about 61 years of data spanning almost 70 years. Temperature: Called Darlington Dam in the original data files. There are no large gaps in the dataset and there is a strong annual pattern in temperature. Notes for OifantsPark basic data quality checks 0055447A7 ADDO ELEPHANT PARK Lat: -33.44 Long: 25.75 Height: 143 m CurOrder: ELEC_TEMPNotes 2005/02/01to 04 missing from the rain data series - these dates were added It seems as though data from two different (or an old and a new recording device) were spliced together at this date -- April 2005 (the fonts change here) Spike in July 1979 rainfall confirmed by other stations. General comments Temperature: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern and no obvious errors. Rainfall: July 1979 shows the same spike in rainfall to other adjecent stations. Otherwise there is generally summer rainfall and there are no apparent gaps. Humidity: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in humidity and lowest humidity in the middle of the day. Pressure: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in pressure with lowest pressure in summer (highest in winter). Wind: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in wind speed and direction data Notes for Sondagsriveiermond-Bos basic data quality check 0035643 3 SONDAGSRIVIERMOND - BOS Lat: -33.72 Long: 25.87 Height: 15 m CLOSED CurOrder: Notes There is a three month gap in 2005 where no readings were taken. Other than this, there is little apparent missing data (and only 2 other failed readings - i.e. cases of Error (No Contact)"). There is no definite pattern in rainfall seasonality. Notes for Zuurberg- Bos basic data quality checks 0055410 8 ZUURBERG - BOS Lat: -33.35 Long: 25.74 Height: 594 m RAINFALL CurOrder: General comments 337 (1%) occurences of failed readings. Most rainfall falls in summer. From 1944 to 1947 there are a large number of days where no rainfall was recorded
column7: but this was accumulated - data may be difficult to interpret. There is also a long period in 1945 of failed readings. Also a large number of accumulated days in 1974 and 1980/81. This is followed by 6 months of failed readings at the end of 1981."

Humidity: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in humidity and lowest humidity in the middle of the day. Pressure: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in pressure with lowest pressure in summer (highest in winter). Wind: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in wind speed and direction data Notes for Sondagsriveiermond-Bos basic data quality check 0035643 3 SONDAGSRIVIERMOND - BOS Lat: -33.72 Long: 25.87 Height: 15 m CLOSED CurOrder: Notes There is a three month gap in 2005 where no readings were taken. Other than this, there is little apparent missing data (and only 2 other failed readings - i.e. cases of Error (No Contact)"). There is no definite pattern in rainfall seasonality. Notes for Zuurberg- Bos basic data quality checks 0055410 8 ZUURBERG - BOS Lat: -33.35 Long: 25.74 Height: 594 m RAINFALL CurOrder: General comments 337 (1%) occurences of failed readings. Most rainfall falls in summer. From 1944 to 1947 there are a large number of days where no rainfall was recorded
column7: but this was accumulated - data may be difficult to interpret. There is also a long period in 1945 of failed readings. Also a large number of accumulated days in 1974 and 1980/81. This is followed by 6 months of failed readings at the end of 1981."

This cooperative program builds on the extensive knowledge base generated by the many decades of research conducted by the Kruger National Park Scientific Services, and the decade-long Kruger National Park River Research Program and more recent River Savanna Boundaries Program in collaboration with several South African and American universities, government departments, and research agencies. The Kruger Park has a long history of interest in the possibility of erection of formal research exclosures (rather than the “incidental exclosures” which have become available because of for instance, enclosures being built to breed up rare antelope). This interest relates 6 particularly relating to fire and elephant effects. Fortunately this historical interest, and the more recent interest of other groups in riparian and riparian-upland issues in the Kruger Park, has provided an opportunity for unified structures dealing with all these interests, to be put in place. In February 2000 the Kruger National Park was presented with a unique opportunity to develop a long-term experiment designed to examine the effects of herbivory. The largest flood since 1925 for the Sabie (7,000 to 8,000 m3 s-1) and Letaba rivers removed most of the vegetation along these rivers, primary research sites in the park, resetting the system to bedrock and sand. The vegetation before the flood was a mature riparian forest including stately fig and other majestic riparian trees. The Sabie River catchment is 7,086 km2 with a river length of 230 km and a mean discharge of 633 million m3/a. The Letaba catchment is 13400 km2 with a length of 490 km and a mean discharge of 631 million m3/a. Construction of large exclosures subsequent to this major flood event will allow us to follow the successional development and pattern formation of vegetation along riparian zones. Riparian zones are recognized as “hotspots” of activity because they integrate terrestrial and aquatic systems (Naiman and Décamps 1997). We believe the research we are conducting (viewed across aquatic, riparian and upland zones) will generate a novel understanding of savannas as integrated yet heterogeneous ecological systems. The systems approach to ecosystem study requires ecologists to expose the connections and fluxes between the elements of heterogeneity, and the feedbacks between heterogeneity and ecosystem function (Risser 1995). Therefore, boundaries in the landscape that define this heterogeneity are of particular ecological interest, and riparian corridors are perhaps the most obvious expression of boundaries in savanna regions. The emerging view of system heterogeneity emphasizes that biological richness has many facets (Noss and Cooperrider 1994). The first facet highlights the kinds of ecological systems that are present in a region. The second facet indicates the relative abundance of each kind of entity present in the area. The third facet indicates that the 7 various ecological components are dynamic in time, and that they are functionally connected with one another. Finally, the three facets of kind, relative abundance, and function are expressed in all ecological realms. Therefore, genes, species and populations, communities and ecosystems, and landscapes all can be considered as components of system heterogeneity (Kolasa and Pickett 1991, Collins and Benning 1996). Riparian systems, and their connection to in-stream processes and to interchanges with the upland components of savanna landscapes, provide a powerful test of the functional significance of spatial and temporal ecosystem heterogeneity. The development of this understanding is the overarching mission of our scientific programme.

Colophospermum mopane seems to dominate wherever it is found. We examined the life history strategy of C. mopane in an arid savanna that leads to its dominance, specifically, its herbivore defense strategies, its mechanisms to cope with fire, and its competitive ability. We also examined possible trade-offs in its ability to establish and colonize an area. Our results indicate that where C. mopane dominates, there is a drop in non-mopane species richness and biomass. Both tree and shrub forms of C. mopane occur in higher biomass in deep red Kalahari sands. There is an inverse relationship regarding biomass and soil depth for other species co-occuring with C. mopane. Our results indicate that C. mopane can attribute its dominance to its herbivore defenses, ability to cope with fire, and resource utilization.

Methods Study Site MNP is located on the banks of the Limpopo River and is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna. It is also the capital of one of the earliest known kingdoms in sub-Saharan Africa. It is located in a semi-arid area of the country with annual rainfall ranges from 350-400 mm. Characterized by mopane bushveld and savannah vegetation, it is home to 24 species of acacia tree and eight commiphora. Trees near the Limpopo flood plain grow in a dense, riparian fringe with closed canopy. MNP lies in a basin between two granite cartons with rocky outcrops of dolerite dykes (Flemminger 2006). Study species Colospermum mopane (C. mopane). Experimental design and protocol To examine life history strategy affecting distribution and dominance of C. mopane, fourteen plots were randomly selected within MNP along the main park road from 09/09/09 – 10/09/09 (Appendix 1 for GPS coordinates). After picking an initial plot, we stopped every 0.5 kilometers along the road and walked 50 meters off the road. Each plot in the park was roughly a hectare. Additionally, five plots were selected outside the park near the Southern boundary to evaluate the extent of C. mopane dominance outside of MNP (see Appendix 1). The 5 plots outside the park were not included in Figures 1 – 6, because a fence limited our ability to sample biomass. We were able to take soil augers, identify species with binoculars, and observe C. mopane in plots 15 - 19. It should be noted that we chose plots with few rocky outcrops and avoided slopes due to the limitations of the Bitterlich Wedge, which is only accurate on flat landscapes. In order to assess its competitive ability, we examined the relative biomass of C. mopane and other species using a Bitterlich wedge (W. Bond pers. comm.) to measure the biomass of the plot in square meters per hectare. The wedge is a rapid method of measuring biomass and consists of a 50 cm rope with one end attached to an 8 x 7 cm card with a 0.5 cm slit cut in the card. We counted the number of trunks or stems that were larger than the slit while the rope was held at eye level. By rotating 360 degrees with the wedge, all species that had stems or trunks larger than the slit were identified and recorded. If a tree had multiple stems that were larger than the slit, each stem was counted. The final count was multiplied by 0.25 to yield the biomass in square meters per hectare. To account for shrub biomass, we used the same Bitterlich wedge, but only counted a shrub if it was wider than the 8 cm side of the cardboard. Shrubs were defined as cagey structures with branches below the height of 1.5 meters. Overlap existed between the two groups as some trees were also counted as shrubs. In order to obtain a general understanding of landscapes that C. mopane inhabits and dominantes, landscape observations were made at each plot for soil, grass cover, species assemblage, species characteristics, and evidence of herbivory. A soil auger was used to take three soil samples at each of the 19 plots to determine the color, soil depth, and composition at different depths. All tree species within a plot were identified and their characteristics were described in order to provide a general picture of C. mopane’s competitors and the different life history strategies they employ to combat herbivory and fire. We noted architecture (cage or pole structure), defense mechanisms (spinesence and palatability), leaf presence or absence, density of undergrowth, bark thickness, herbivory (presence of dung and evidence of grazing), and grass cover. Additionally, to assess their below ground competitive ability, two C. mopane, one Combretum apiculatum, and one Boscia foetida were excavated to observe underground biomass and root structure. Bark thickness was measured in cm for five species at two plots in MNP to assess their ability to cope with fire. It was taken by measuring the width of the target stem and by measuring the thickness of bark when cut away to reveal the xylem. These two measurements were taken in relation to one another to give the relative bark thickness in comparison to stem size. We controlled for stem size between individuals by selecting stems with a diameter between 8 and 12 cm. Regression analyses were performed using Microsoft Excel 2007 for Windows and Sigma Plot was used to determine significance.

A quadrat-survey of the population structure of Aloe africana was conducted in the Colchester-section of the Addo Elephant National Park to monitor the effects of large herbivores. The current baseline-survey was conducted during October 2010, prior to the introduction of elephant. Twenty quadrats (30x10m) were permanently marked and the following variables recorded at each quadrat: (1) structural characteristics of all adult plants, (2) juvenile plant abundances, (3) impacts [1-None, 2-Herbivory, 3-Pollarding, 4-Toppling, 5-Coppicing, 6-Dead], (4) structure of the shrub community, using canopy height as an indicator, and (5) estimated intensity of elephant use. These quadrats are surveyed at regular intervals.

This experiment was carried out in the Shabeni and Kambeni experimental burn plots in the Pretoriuskop region of the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa. Sampling was conducted in the annually burned and control plot of each of the sites. Four 50m transects and a 200mx 200m quadrat was set up in each site to get an estimate of termite density and activity. The results show that there was a greater density of termite activity on the annually burned plot than the control plots in both sites ( Shabeni-df=1,P<.01, Kambeni- df=1,P<.01). The conclusion drawn from the results is that termites do better in fire prone areas because fires promote habitat heterogeneity. Samevatting: Hierdie ekperiment was uitgedra in die Shabeni en Kambeni experimentale verbrande komplotte in die Pretoriuskop gebied van die Kruger Nasionalle Park, Mpumalanga Provinsie, Suid Afrika. Toetsing was uitgedra in die jaarliks verbrand en kontrol komplot van die Shabeni en Kambeni eksperimentalle komplotte. In elke kompolt was vier 50m lyne en ŉ 200m by 200m kwadrant gestuig om ŉ idea van witmier digtheid te kry. Die uitslae duig aan dat die digtheid van witmiere in die jaarlikse verbrande komplotte hoёr is dan die digtheid in die controle komplotte vir die Shabeni en Kambeni komplotte ( Shabeni-df=1,P<.01, Kambeni- df=1,P<.01. Die gevolgtrekking wat van die utslae geskep was, is dat witmiere beter vorder in die jaarliks verbrande komplotte omdat vier woonplaas heterogeneteit bevorder.

fire treatments, termite activity, Shabeni and Kambeni experimental burn plots

The experiment was carried out in the Shabeni and Kambeni burn plots in the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa (Figure 1). The Kambeni site was sampled on the 22nd - 23rd February 2004 and Shabeni site was sampled on the 24th of February 2004. The sampling times were between 0700 hrs and 1300 hrs each day. A frequently burned plot (burned annually in August) and a less frequently burned plot ( where fire is excluded as much as possible). In each of the plots a direct and indirect measure was used to determine termite activity . As an indirect method, a series of four transects of 50m each was sampled in each plot and below ground activity was recorded at every meter along the transect. The termite activity for a 1m x 1m plot from the transect was assessed by estimating the percentage of termite activity. A 200m x 200m plot was set out in each plot and the amount of termite mounds in the plot was counted as a direct measure of above ground termite activity. The number of trees with termite activity was also counted in the 200m x 200m plot. A chi squared contingency test was used to determine if there was a difference in the proportion of activity in the annually burned plots relative to the control plots.

Broad-leaf savannas are more nutrient limited than fine-leaf savannas. Plant productivity is constrained by Nitrogen availability thus some legume plants have developed adaptations to obtain atmospheric nitrogen in a usable form by forming a symbioses with nitrogen fixing bacteria that form gall like nodules on the roots. Our study aims to determine if herbaceous leguminous plants in the nutrient limited broad leaf site have a higher occurrence of nitrogen fixing nodules in comparison to the fine leaf site. Additionally as fire causes a loss of Nitrogen to occur in the system we aimed to see if the burnt broad leaf site has a higher occurrence of nodules in the burn plot than the unburnt plot. We found the broad-leaf and burnt broad leaf sites have a similar proportion of nodulated plants (P<.834188) with fine-leaf site comparatively lower (P<.001877) in comparison to the broad-leaf site. Second Language Abstract: Breed-blaar grasvlakte is meer voedend beperk as fyn-blaar grasvlakte. Stikstof biskikbaarheid beperk die produktiwiteit van plante en toe n’ paar peuldraend plante het aanwendings ontwikkel om lugstoornis stikstof te kry wat kan gebruik wees. Bakteria wat stikstof vasmaak vorm knoesies wat soos galnote lyk op die wortels van plante. Die doel van ons studie is om te sien as die voedend beperk breed-blaar plek het n’ hoer voorval van die knossies wat stikstof vasmaak as die fyn-blaar grasflakte lokasie. As vuur kan n’ verlooring van stikstof in n’ sisteem veroorsaak ons will ook probeer sien as daar a hoer voorval van knossies in die gebrande breed-blaar lokaasie sal wees. Ons uitslae het gewys dat die breed-blaar loakasie wat nie gebrand is nie het n’ gelyksoortig eweredigheid van knossies as die gebrand lokasie (P<.834188). Ons het ook gevind dat in vergelyking die fyn-blaar lokasie n’ laaer eweredigheid van knossies gehad het.
Sally Koerner, Taryn Morris, and Justine Norman (secretaries), Laura Buckley and Kinesh Chetty (field assistants) SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Sally Koerner, Taryn Morris, and Justine Norman (secretaries), Laura Buckley and Kinesh Chetty (field assistants) SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
fine-leaf, broad-leaf, fire, legumes, nitrogen fixation, nodules

Site selection and sampling Our study was conducted in the Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa during summer. Nitrogen fixing activity has been found to be associated exclusively with nodulated legumes. It has however, been shown that the subfamily Caesalpinoidae do not contain members that fix nitrogen, Mimosoidae have few members that fix nitrogen and the majority of Papillionacae members do (Scholes pers. comm.). In a study conducted by Grobbler and Rosch (1981) in Nylsvley Nature Reserve (a typical South African savanna) it was found that N fixation was definitely predominant in certain genera of this subfamily namely: Elephantorrhiza, Tephrosia and Indigofera sp. (Scholes and Walker 1993). Thus we decided to concentrate on plants from these genera. Two transects were sampled in a fine-leaf and broad-leaf site in the Skukuza region as well the Shabeni February biannual burn site near Pretoriaskop. The biannual burn site was chosen as it approximately resembles the burning regime of uncontrolled areas. Each transect was 100m in length and 5m wide. Herbaceous Papillionaceae plants were excavated within the transect and presence and activity of nodules were noted. Species were identified into morpho-species due to lack of inflorescences making identification difficult. Analysis Data were analysed in Statistica using Chi-squared tests to determine if there was significant differences in proportional nodulation between the fine-leaf and broad-leaf sites as well as between the burnt broad-leaf site and non-burnt broad-leaf site. Chi-squared tests were also performed on two morpho-species from the broad-leaf and burn sites. Comparing morpho-species in different sites allows us to eliminate fluctuations in proportional nodulation that may be linked to the ability of certain species to form nodules more readily than others.

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Data on body temperatures and thermal niches have been collected for various odonate species (“dragonflies and damselflies”) using thermal imaging (infrared camera, or IR-camera). These data were collected in SANParks and other areas (i. e. nature reserves) during 2012 and 2013, as part of research collaboration involving Lund University (Sweden) and Stellenbosch University (Western Cape Province, South Africa). The enclosed data is part of a larger study aiming to understand the evolution of thermal adaptations and thermal plasticity in relation to phylogeny, biogeography and local microclimatic variation in odonates. Such data are of interest not only in terms of basic research questions in ecology and evolution, but might also be of relevance in conservation biology and management planning, particularly in the light of ongoing climate change and rising global temperatures that can increase extinction risk of ectothermic animals like insects.

Basic data quality checks for Mata Mata 0497019 2 GEMSBOKPARK - MATA MATA Lat: -25.81 Long: 20.02 Height: 1,000 m CurOrder: Notes 177.2mm of rain recorded on 7 March 1976 - this is likely an error as only 28mm were recorded at Twee Rivieren There is no 20h wind series January 1975 missing from the temperature and rainfall series - dates added to rainfall April and May missing from 1988 temperature series - added Oct to Dec 2001 also missing from rainfall series - dates added General comments Temperature: There is a strong annual pattern in temperature, with winter temperatures very low (minima) and summer temperatures very high. There is a large gap in the minimum temperature series (Jan 1979, April to Jul 1979 and April 1983 to April 1984) as well as a gap in both series: Jul 2005 to end Dec 2006 and several interspersed months in 2003. April and May missing from 1988. The data after the 2006 gap become patchy. Rainfall: There is a gap in the data from Aug 2005 to Feb 2006 (due to failed readings) - this excludes the rainfall season. There is a strong summer rainfall pattern. 1976 data likely contain an error - see above. January 1975 missing and Oct to Dec 2001 also missing. Wind: Data only available for 1978 and 1979 Basid cata quality checks for Nossb 0535175 5 GEMSBOKPARK - NOSSOB Lat: -25.42 Long: 20.6 Height: 1,000 m THIRD CurOrder: Notes May 1988 missing from the temperature series - added The whole of 1992 and Oct - Dec 2001 missing from the rainfall series 83mm of rain recorded on 5 Jan 1998 - possibly an error - 26mm recorded at Twee Rivieren General comments Temperature: There is a clear annual trend in temperatures and there is a fairly large difference between manima and maxima in all seasons. There are a few gaps in the data, especially towards the end of the series: Maxima: Feb-Mar 197, Sep 1980- Mar 1981, Jun-Aug 1992, Aug ; Minima: May 1990; Both series: several gaps in 1990, several gaps from Jun 1994 to May 1995, Dec 1995. There are no data for Mar-Dec 2006 and data begin again on 1 Jan 2007. Also no data from Feb-Jun 2009. There are also several other small gaps. Rainfall: There are only 14 occurences (0.1%) of failed readings. The status of small mammal populations reflects ecosystem integrity. This study focused on rodent populations in two different habitats of the Mapungubwe National Park, the mopane savanna and riverine forest. Live trapping and vegetation surveys were performed in an effort to determine a relationship between rodent population presence and habitat structure. We found that there was a greater rodent abundance in the mopane savanna, but that there were no significant differences in diversity and richness between the two habitats. The higher abundance corresponded to areas with a greater understory height, lower soil penetrability, and closer proximity to major rock outcroppings. These findings establish that there is a relationship between habitat characteristics and rodent species abundance. This information can be used by conservationists as a baseline measure to develop conservation goals and plans that reflect the interconnected nature of ecosystems.
William Boysen and Eliza Chamblin SANParks, South Africa Independent Project 2
William Boysen and Eliza Chamblin SANParks, South Africa Independent Project 2
abundance, biodiversity, mopane savanna, riverine forest, rodents, vegetation structure

We conducted our study in the Mapungubwe National Park in the Limpopo Province of South Africa. We utilized ten study sites: five in the riverine forest along the Shashi River and five in the mopane savanna (Appendix 1). We set out ten Sherman traps at each of our ten sites, putting out one hundred traps in total. Within each site, we placed five traps under cover and five in the open. A trap placed under cover, or a closed trap, was placed under tight vegetation, usually a shrub, whereas a trap placed in the open might have been placed along a log or at the bottom of a tree (never totally in the open). In addition, half of the traps were standard size (8 x 9 x 23 cm) and half were long traps (8 x 9.5 x 30 cm). Slade et al. (1993) demonstrated that long traps had a consistently greater capture rate than short traps, and thus are more effective. Due to resource limitations, we were unable to use long traps exclusively. Instead, we used an equal number of long and short traps at each site to ensure that there was an equivalent chance of catching rodents at all sites. For the safety of the animals that we caught, we made sure that all traps were well-shaded by covering them with debris. We baited each trap with a mixture of peanut butter, oats, and honey. We rebaited the traps after each catch and every afternoon, so as to ensure bait freshness. We checked the traps once in the early morning (between 5:30am and 10:30am) and once in the late afternoon (between 3:30pm and 6:30pm) for four consecutive days (Tuesday, 14 November, 2006-Friday, 18 November, 2006) in the beginning of the summer rainy season. If we did find a specimen in one of our traps, we adhered to a uniform catch procedure: We uniquely marked and then released the specimen. We also recorded species weight and sex. We analyzed our collected data using Excel, Statistica and Primer. Vegetation/Habitat Survey To see if there was any relationship between the specific rodent species present and habitat conditions, we conducted habitat/vegetation surveys at each of our ten sites. We walked two 50 meter transects at each site from North to South. The transects were approximately ten meters apart. For each transect, we evaluated and recorded the habitat 86 type at one meter intervals: grass, sand, dirt, woody debris, dung, tree, rock, or shrub. Every five meters, we also estimated the proximity to a major rock outcropping and estimated the visibility at twenty centimeters, alternating to the East and to the West. In order to measure the visibility, one researcher held their head twenty centimeters above ground, while the other moved a notebook in a straight line away from the transect, also twenty centimeters above ground. When the individual at twenty centimeters could only see half of the notebook, we recorded the distance between the two individuals. These measurements were taken with the purpose of determining the level of habitat appeal and availability of protection from predators. Finally, every ten meters within each 50 meter transect, we took a penetrometer measurement of the soil to get a sense of the level of ease with which a rodent could burrow. Additionally, we noted the presence of dung, woody debris, rocks, or live trees within one meter of each transect. We analyzed all data with Excel, Statistica, and Primer.

Methods We set up an experiment in the plant nursery in Skukuza using 8 grass species common in the Kruger National Park. After 5 weeks of establishment we exposed the plants to three different nutrient treatments for three weeks after which they were harvested. The treatments were: direct nutrient supply (D), spatially separated nutrient supply (MF), and no nutrient supply (C).We measured photosynthesis (Amax), stomatal conductance (gs), water use efficiency (WUE), with a LICOR6400XT Irga Starting 2 weeks after treatment application on the youngest fully expanded leaf. Nutrient gain and biomass of six grass species were measured after 3 weeks of treatments. Traits were analyses on extra well fertilized plants

Elephant populations in southern Africa have dramatically increased recently, impacting vegetation structure and reducing tree diversity. We observed and analyzed elephant foraging behavior to determine patterns in browsing preference for male and female elephants in three age classes in relation to forage characteristics. Elephants selectively browsed, generally preferring mechanically defended tree species to those with chemical defenses. Elephants targeted trees between 4 and 8 m tall significantly proportionally more frequently than any other size tree, lending more evidence that elephants are fundamentally changing vegetation structure. Females tended to have more selective diets due, we speculate, to their physiology than did males, and adults had a much greater impact on their environment than did juveniles or infants. Elephants have a significant effect on the vegetation structure in their environment, and the increasing populations are cause for concern. Patterns in environmental impact according to sex and age are necessary to inform decisions on elephant management, while patterns regard plant susceptibility are helpful in predicting changes in vegetation structure and composition.
Nick Cuneo, Colin Donihue, Laurence Kruger (resource person), Cassandra Nuñez SANParks, South Africa Independent Project #2
Nick Cuneo, Colin Donihue, Laurence Kruger (resource person), Cassandra Nuñez SANParks, South Africa Independent Project #2
African elephant, behavior, browsing, defenses, impact

This study was conducted in Mapungubwe National Park, part of South Africa’s National Park system (SANParks). Mapungubwe is located in northern South Africa and borders Botswana and Zimbabwe. Most of Mapungubwe is arid mopane and acacia savanna with several riparian zones around seasonal waterways. The study was conducted November 15th-17th. A table of all study sites along with their respective start times, habitats, and GPS locations is included as Appendix A. Study species. The African elephant, Loxodonta africana, is the largest mammal in Africa with adults frequently standing three meters at the shoulder and weighing over a 161 ton. Females and juveniles typically form matriarchal pods containing 8 to 12 individuals while males tend to be solitary and highly territorial, only visiting their pod for mating. Twenty elephants were reintroduced in Mapungubwe in 2005 after being excluded for approximately 50 years. A year later that population had risen to over 400 (L. Kruger pers. comm.). Park management has never culled the elephant population, so their demographics are not artificially skewed and the animals are relatively tolerant of observation. The majority of the elephants migrate seasonally and sometimes daily through holes in the fences to Botswana. It is clear from personal observation that the border fences do not hinder the flow of elephants. While they are fairly well protected from poachers in South Africa, their vulnerability to poaching across the border is unknown. There are several impoverished settlements in the area which might hunt elephants for food or to protect crops. Plot design. We defined a vegetation-sampling plot as the circle of 25 m diameter radiating around a feeding elephant. The plot incorporated all of the vegetation choices that the focus elephant had within eyesight, so a comparison could be made between vegetation available and vegetation browsed which would reflect the elephant’s foraging preferences. We defined trees as single-stem vegetation as opposed to bushes, which were multi-stemmed. We collected data from 25 plots. Classification of elephants and browsing intensity. Infant elephants were those lacking tusks and noticeably smallest in the herd. Juveniles were those elephants with small tusks and body sizes less than 50 percent the size of the largest (adult) elephant in the group. Adult elephants were those with developed tusks and massive bodies. All solitary males were considered adults. We observed two general types of browsing by elephants. The first was “mobile browsing” while the elephant was walking purposefully forward. No data were taken to quantify this. When an elephant stopped or significantly slowed its movement to browse in a limited area—hereafter referred to as “stationary browsing”—a plot was declared and data were collected on browsing impact. Low impact browsing events were defined as leaf stripping. Medium impact browsing events were defined as branch breaking, and high impact events were any that reduced the canopy of that tree by more than 25 percent. Data collection. We located elephants, either by vehicle or on foot, and then followed them on foot. We recorded GPS coordinates and time of arrival at every plot. We also conducted a vegetation survey of the plot, recording the species and height of all of trees present. The elephant or elephants were observed for the entire time they stayed within the plot, and the age class, sex, targeted tree species, individual height, and browsing event intensity were recorded. We followed elephants until they left the confines of the park, became aware of our presence (and so altered their behavior), or dusk fell. Data analyses. Data analyses were performed using the StatView® statistical package, with significance set at α = 0.05. To determine elephant preference and plant susceptibility we used χ 2 contingency tables to compare data on what species and height classes were browsed to what was available. When comparing preference among elephant age and sex groups, we were careful to exclude species not present in similar abundances during observations of all groups so as not to bias our results.

While they are fairly well protected from poachers in South Africa, their vulnerability to poaching across the border is unknown. There are several impoverished settlements in the area which might hunt elephants for food or to protect crops. Plot design. We defined a vegetation-sampling plot as the circle of 25 m diameter radiating around a feeding elephant. The plot incorporated all of the vegetation choices that the focus elephant had within eyesight, so a comparison could be made between vegetation available and vegetation browsed which would reflect the elephant’s foraging preferences. We defined trees as single-stem vegetation as opposed to bushes, which were multi-stemmed. We collected data from 25 plots. Classification of elephants and browsing intensity. Infant elephants were those lacking tusks and noticeably smallest in the herd. Juveniles were those elephants with small tusks and body sizes less than 50 percent the size of the largest (adult) elephant in the group. Adult elephants were those with developed tusks and massive bodies. All solitary males were considered adults. We observed two general types of browsing by elephants. The first was “mobile browsing” while the elephant was walking purposefully forward. No data were taken to quantify this. When an elephant stopped or significantly slowed its movement to browse in a limited area—hereafter referred to as “stationary browsing”—a plot was declared and data were collected on browsing impact. Low impact browsing events were defined as leaf stripping. Medium impact browsing events were defined as branch breaking, and high impact events were any that reduced the canopy of that tree by more than 25 percent. Data collection. We located elephants, either by vehicle or on foot, and then followed them on foot. We recorded GPS coordinates and time of arrival at every plot. We also conducted a vegetation survey of the plot, recording the species and height of all of trees present. The elephant or elephants were observed for the entire time they stayed within the plot, and the age class, sex, targeted tree species, individual height, and browsing event intensity were recorded. We followed elephants until they left the confines of the park, became aware of our presence (and so altered their behavior), or dusk fell. Data analyses. Data analyses were performed using the StatView® statistical package, with significance set at α = 0.05. To determine elephant preference and plant susceptibility we used χ 2 contingency tables to compare data on what species and height classes were browsed to what was available. When comparing preference among elephant age and sex groups, we were careful to exclude species not present in similar abundances during observations of all groups so as not to bias our results.
Diets and defenses: an examination of elephant foraging selection in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa
Diets and defenses: an examination of elephant foraging selection in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa
Mapungubwe National Park, Lim popo Province, South Africa -90.0 90.0 45.0 -45.0
African elephant, behavior, browsing, defenses, impact

Variable characteristics in the timing and extent of leaf-fall and green-up can be seen in savanna trees. This study investigated implications of these life history strategies for tree health (water stress and photosynthetic potential) in four savanna species: Afzelia quanzensis, Euclea divinorum, Colophospermum mopane and Terminalia sericea. The study took place in northern Kruger National Park, where C. mopane and T. sericea trees are abundant deciduous trees with similar strategies of the extent of leaf drop but with variation in the timing of leaf drop. C. mopane and T. sericea showed the highest measures of “water stress” and “photosynthetic potential” in comparison with A. quanzensis and E. divinorum. However, C. mopane trees were found to be able to maintain a greater leaf canopy at the same water potential range as T. sericea trees. This may play a role in the dominance of C. mopane in certain areas, but further investigation into the role of local soil and rainfall conditions would be necessary to supplement this finding.

Methods Study Sites Sampling took place in mid-September: the late dry to early wet season in South Africa. Two study sites (A and B) were identified in Punda Maria in northern Kruger National Park, South Africa. This part of the Kruger National Park is characteristically dominated by C. mopane shrubveld, which typically occurs on basalt soils and is the largest and most homogeneous landscape in the park. Sites A and B were located along a gradient, with Site A at the bottom of a slope and B at the top of the slope. Site A was characteristically dominated by Colophospermum mopane and Euclea divinorum, while Site B consisted of a mixture of tree species, with the most abundant species being Afzelia quanzensis and Terminalia sericea. Study species Tree species were selected based on their major leaf phenological types. E. divinorum is an evergreen species and A. quanzensis, T. sericea, and C. mopane are deciduous. A. quanzensis characteristically flushes green towards the end of the dry season before the start of the rains, and T. sericea characteristically contains little to no leaves for a large part of the lowveld winter (Sappi Tree Spotting 2007). C. mopane shows variation in its timing of leaf drop, but tends to hold on to its leaves for as long as possible during the dry season (Dekker and Smit 1996). Data Acquisition: Tree Demographics Tree height and stem diameter was recorded in individuals of each of the four tree species. The percentage leaf canopy on each tree was estimated based on the leaf abundance on the tree branches, and GPS locations were recorded for each tree. Fluorometry: Photosynthetic Capacity of leaves A fluorometer was used to estimate the photosynthetic capacity of each tree. Root estimates Five soil samples were collected below each tree canopy using a soil auger at a depth of 10cm, as well as a single soil sample at a depth of 50cm. This was done to separate shallower horizontal roots from deeper vertical roots within the substrate. Soil was classified into broad types using the hand test (Brown 2002). A proportion of each soil sample was sifted to find any roots, and these were classified as coarse live roots, coarse dead roots, fine live roots, or fine dead roots. Coarse roots were determined to be thicker than the fine roots, and live roots were determined if the root could be bent without breaking and was moist in the centre. Water Potential A Scholander pressure device was used to determine water potential of the trees.

African savannas are shaped by the interaction of two ecological factors: African elephants (Loxodonta africana) and fires. The response of individual Acacias to megaherbivores and fire regimes is dependent on their life history strategies. The resulting architecture of trees is a trade-off between a strategy of growing tall to escape low-lying fires or of developing thick, insulating bark to protect the internal structure from heat damage. Allometric studies suggest that there is a strong relationship between trunk diameter and average bark thickness, as well as trunk diameter and height, in Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis. When both have similar bark thicknesses, A. nigrescens tends to grow taller and burn at higher temperatures than A. tortilis. The combination of bark stripping and field burns show that elephants can have dramatic effects on the survival abilities of trees during fires and that Acacias have varied life history strategies in response. Severely debarked (over 50%) A. nigrescens have greater odds of experiencing interruptions in the water column, as reflected in increased leaf discoloration and wilting, whereas A. tortilis shows no effect within the same time period. This suggests that A. nigrescens copes with fire and megafaunal herbivory by increasing canopy height and A. tortilis copes by investing in bark with greater insular ability to protect against fire and in mechanical defences to protect against herbivory.
Anna Chu, Susan Lin, Jenn Mizen, Laurence Kruger (resource person) SANParks, South Africa Independent Project II
Anna Chu, Susan Lin, Jenn Mizen, Laurence Kruger (resource person) SANParks, South Africa Independent Project II
Acacia nigrescens, Acacia tortilis, allometry, bark stripping, elephant damage, fire

Mapungubwe National Park (S22.21850 E029.36489) is a xeric savanna with a diverse array of flora and fauna, situated in the Limpopo Province of South Africa on the borders of Botswana and Zimbabwe. Our experiment took place over the span of six days from 13-18 November 2006. We burned and collected tree samples from four sites around Leokwe Camp in Mapungubwe National Park. Study Species We performed our allometry study, field burn experiment and burn temperature study on Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis. A. nigrescens occurs from KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa northward into central Africa (Schmidt et al. 2002). In response to herbivory, A. nigrescens has both mechanical and chemical defense. The bark of A. nigrescens is covered with thorn-tipped knobs and rich with tannin. Similarly, A. tortilis is widespread throughout the bushveld biomes of South Africa with distribution ranging from the Northern Cape northward to the Limpopo Province and westward to Mpumalanga (Schmidt et al. 2002). A. tortilis is characterized by a combination of mechanical defenses manifested as hooks and thorns. Allometry Acacia tortilis versus Acacia nigrescens. Trunk diameter, average bark thickness and height data were taken from 27 A. nigrescens and 29 A. tortilis near the Leokwe camp. Individuals were chosen to represent a range of size classes. Trunk diameter was measured at 10 cm above ground. Three bark thickness measurements were taken after removing a small square of bark at this same height above ground. A clinometer was used to calculate height (see Appendix A). Log-transformed data were used in regression analyses to ensure comparability between species. Microsoft Excel was used to analyze the significance and strength of relationships between trunk diameter, average bark thickness and height. Acacia nigrescens in mesic versus xeric savannas. Allometric data of A. nigrescens from our study were compared to a similar study undertaken in Matiyani, Mpumalanga Province, in April 2006 (Bouley et al. unpublished). The Matiyani study measured 35 A. nigrescens for trunk diameter, bark thickness, and height with methods similar to our study. Field Burns Sample specimens of Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis were burned on the second and third days of the experiment between the hours of 1000 and 1500. On both days, the temperature exceeded 35ºC with humidity less than 25%. Due to heavy rain on the first day of experimentation, trees were surveyed and debarked on the first day and then burned on the second and third days. Field burns were implemented using the wick-fire technique (Uhl and Kauffman, 1990). A paraffin-soaked cotton rope was wrapped three times around the trunk and ignited. All burns were standardized to four minutes. The fires died after roughly two 138 minutes and were relit with a fresh paraffin-soaked cord. Throughout the four minutes, the upper canopy was shielded from heat convection. The burned trees were assessed four days later for visible foliage damage in the form of leaf discoloration and leaf wilting. An approximate estimation of the percent of canopy cover affected was recorded as an indictor of the fire damage to the water column. For the burning experiments, we tested 100 trees in total: 50 A. nigrescens and 50 A. tortilis. Of the 50 samples, 20 were set aside as controls and the remaining 30 tree samples were allocated to test either the effects of fire on different stem diameter or the effects of fire on trees that were debarked. Burn simulations on different stem diameters. Fifteen samples of A. nigrescens and 15 samples A. tortilis were burned to assess the effects of stem diameter on leaf discoloration and wilting. The samples of each species were evenly distributed amongst the three size classes: 20 mm, 25 mm and 30 mm. These samples were not subject to debarking and were burned as previously outlined. Effects of bark removal and burning. Twenty samples of A. nigrescens and 20 samples of A. tortilis were treated to varying degrees of bark stripping: 0%, 25%, 50% or 75%. The stem diameter on all samples was 25 mm. The five samples of 25 mm stems used in the stem diameter experiment were used as the 0% debarked samples. The stems were stripped in a segment of roughly three centimeters and wicks were wrapped under the area of debarking so that the flame would directly affect the area stripped. As a control, an additional 20 specimens of each Acacia sp. were debarked at 0%, 25%, 50% or 75% but not burned.

The aim of the study was to examine relationships between fire, grazing and grass cover in the Bontebok National Park, in October 1984 decending point surveys were conducted by Peter Novellie in eight plots, four of which were lacated in areas that had been burned in March 1984 (plot numbers 4,5,7 and 10) and four on areas burnt in March 1984 (plot number 4,5,7 and 10). the plots were marked with metal stakes, and their approximate location was indicated on a map of the park. The surveys in the plots in the plots were repeated in November 1985. this dataset gives the percentage canopy spread cover of grasses, and of the following categories of plants other than grasses: Cyperaceae, Restionaceae and all other plants. Futher details on the methodology, and the result of the 1984 surveys, are published in: Novellie, P. 1987. Interrelationships between fire, grazing and grass cover at the Bontebok National Park. Koedoe 30: 1-7. In 2003 Tineke Kraaiji searched for the plot markers and took GPS readings for the four plots for which the markers could be found ( table below ). she repeated the surveys in these marked plots un November 2005 as well as at the approximate lacations ( as judged from the map) for the remaining four plots for which the markers could not be found. Riparian ecosystems are characterised by a greater heterogeneity of vegetation structure and composition relative to other savanna communities. However, it is contested which characteristics of the vegetation are most important for predicting bird diversity. The aim of our study was to determine the relative importance of composition and structural complexity, in terms of variance in vertical and horizontal structure, as well as canopy cover and tree height, as predictors of bird diversity. Bird diversity was analysed in terms of species richness, abundance, feeding and foraging guilds. We examined eight sites of varying structural and compositional diversities along the Limpopo River in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa.
