SANParks, South Africa, Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa
Bird diversity, floristics, functional guilds, vegetation structure

Methods Site All data were collected from 14 Sept – 16 Sept 2009 along the Limpopo river riparian zone, 2211’26.21”S, 2922’23.67”E, Mapungubwe National Park (MNP), Limpopo Province, South Africa (Figure 1). MNP is situated in the North-East corner of South Africa, in the junction between Botswana, Zimbabwe and South Africa. This is a semi-arid landscape with varied geology, including archean rocks, metamorphics, karoo sandstone/conglomerate uplands, and alluvium and sands (Mapungubwe 2006). A variety of soils are represented, although sandy, lime-rich soils generally deeper than 750 mm are dominant (Mapungubwe 2006). Mean annual rainfall ranges from 350 – 400 mm and free water surface evaporation exceeds 2.5 m per year. Rainfall is highly variable (Mapungubwe 2006). While most rain falls in the summer months, where temperatures can reach 45 °C, there are extended periods of below average rainfall (Mapungubwe 2006). FIGURE 1: A satellite image of the Limpopo river, along which eight sites were selected and sampled, Mapungubwe National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa (Jones et al., unpublished) Bird diversity sampling was conducted in the 8 sites studied in September 2009. These sites were selected for vegetation structure in terms of canopy cover and the presence or absence of shrubs and tall trees (Table 1). TABLE 1: A description of the vegetation structure for each of the eight sites, MNP, South Africa (taken from Jones et al., unpublished) Site Vegetation classification GPS location 1 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.210' E 029˚ 23.889' 2 Open mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.366' E 029˚ 23.758' 3 Closed mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.340' E 029˚ 23.813' 4 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.586' E 029˚ 23.427' 5 Closed mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.496' E 029˚ 23.456' 6 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 12.099' E 029˚ 21.381' 7 Open mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 12.001' E 029˚ 21.173' 8 Open mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.763' E 029˚ 20.964' Bird surveys Data were collected daily between 6:00 to 9:30 and between 16:30 and 18:00. All eight sites were sampled in the morning every day, and each site was sampled only once in the evening. The order in which sites were sampled varied between days to control for varying activity levels during particular times of the day. The point-count method was used to sample bird diversity within each site. Individuals heard or seen within a 50 m radius around a point were recorded as ‘in’ the sampling site, while individuals between 50 m to 100 m of that point were recorded as ‘out’ of the sampling site. Additionally, birds flying over head were also counted as out. Ten minutes were allocated to sampling bird diversity in each site. Five minutes were spent recording birds in the centre of the circle, while five minutes were spent flushing (including two minutes walking into and out of the sampling site and three minutes flushing within the site). Guilds Birds sampled were divided up into both dietary and foraging guilds based on their diet (Table 2) and foraging (Table 3) methods respectively. Information on diet and feeding behaviour was obtained from Roberts Birds of Southern Africa (Hockey et al., 2006). TABLE 2: A description of classification criteria for establishing bird dietary guilds. Diet Guilds Classification Criteria Carnivore Primarily consumes non-insect animals Frugivore Primarily consumes fruit Granivore Primarily consumes seeds and nuts Herbivore Primarily consumes vegetation Insectivore Primarily consumes insects Nectivore Primarily consumes nectar Omnivore Consumes a mixture of meat and vegetable matter. Scavenger Primarily consumes carrion TABLE 3: A description of classification criteria for establishing bird foraging guilds. Criteria emphasize physical distribution of foraging rather than foraging methods within a location. Foraging Methods Guilds Classification Criteria Canopy Primarily search for food in upper, middle or lower canopy, or a mixture of these. Does not include birds which perch as a vantage point for hunting. Midstory Primarily search for food in midstory or understory. Does not include birds which perch and swoop. Perch and Hunt Primarily search for food by perch and swoop, hawk or dive. Does not include birds which hunt aerially and consume prey on the perch Aerial Hunt aerially and consume prey on perch Ground Closed Primarily search for food on ground, either in soil, grass, or leaf litter clear of any midstory. Ground Open Primarily search for food on ground, either in soil, grass, or leaf litter under a midstory Generalist Search for food in more than one guild Birds that were counted as ‘out’ were not included, and birds that do not rely on terrestrial structure as part of their foraging behaviour, such as Red-Billed Oxpecker, African Darter, Blacksmith lapwing, Brown-throated martin, and Grey Heron, were excluded. Data analysis All data collected on bird diversity in September 2009 were combined with the data collected in April 2009 by Jones et al (unpublished). The bird count data was used to calculate Bray-Curtis similarities between sites (site 1 and 2, 1 and 3, etc.) in PRIMER (Primer-E Ltd., 2001). The Bray-Curtis index is a descriptive measure of general similarity in species assemblages at different sites and is only weakly affected by rare species (Krebs, 1999). Two-dimensional Multi-Dimensional Scaling ordinations (MDS plots) were generated, visually demonstrating similarities between sites as distances on the plot. The classification of sites based on woody vegetation structure was mapped onto the MDS. To test whether the composition of a bird assemblage at a site is related to its position along the River, the Bray-Curtis similarity value for each pair of sites was correlated with geographical distance between each pair. Simpson’s index (Ds) of bird diversity was calculated in PRIMER. Simpson’s index is one of standard ways to measure diversity and puts more weight on the evenness than the richness of species in the samples (Krebs, 1999). It is therefore suitable for a study of general ecosystem function like the one conducted. The index has comparatively small errors with small sample sizes, which makes it useful for a study with a limited number of counts (Routledge 1980). Average percentage aerial canopy cover estimate was calculated for each site using Microsoft Office Excel software (Microsoft 2002). The diversity of vertical vegetation layers was estimated using Ds. Diversity was calculated treating each vegetation layer as a morphospecies and the value representing how filled a particular layer was treated as the number of individuals in the morphospecies. An MDS was plotted to demonstrate similarities in woody plant assemblages between the sites and Ds for diversity in woody species was calculated. To analyze the dependence of bird diversity on vegetation structure, the values of Ds for bird diversity were regressed against Simpson’s index of structural diversity, large tree density (no of trees/site), basal area (cm2) and the percentage canopy cover (%). A similar analysis was done to test if floristics drive bird diversity. Ds values for bird assemblages were regressed against Ds indices for woody plants. In addition, the Bray-Curtis similarity in bird assemblages was regressed against the similarity in floristics. The same steps (MDS and regression against structure and floristics characteristics) were taken to analyze the relationship between the diversity in dietary guilds and foraging guilds.

The same deletion was made in the wind data because of the same missing data problem. 1996/04/30 missing from the temperature data 1997/01/12 - 15, 1997/02/09 - 11, Jan 1998, 1998/08/01 - 7, 1998/08/17- 20 missing from temperature series General comments Temperature: There is a clear annual pattern in temperature, but the data series is very short (1993 - 2002). Two years of temperature data were deleted due to two significant gaps in the first two years. Rainfall: There is relatively low rainfall during the period measured (in agreement with the Vioolsdrift data). There are no obvious gaps, but the data series is very short. Humidity: Two years of humidity data deleted prior to 1993 because there were too many gaps in this section of the data, following this the data show an annual cycle with only one noticible gap. The remaining data show a clear trend in wind speed and direction.

Professor Norman Owen-Smith Univeristy of the Witwatesrand Research Professor School of Animal, Plant and Environmnetal Sciences Wits 2050 South Africa +27-11-7176545 Norman.Owen-Smith@wits.ac.za Content Provider

Methods The census methods and associated conditions are described in the annual reports, and for the EAS surveys by Viljoen and Retief (Koedoe No. 37, pp. 149-157, 1994). In summary they were conducted by fixed-wing aircraft flying parallel strips, generally 800 m apart, aiming at complete ground coverage. However, all regions of the Kruger Park were fully covered only over 1980-1993. When coverage was incomplete, the park total for each species was projected from the trend in the regions that were covered. Count totals for the period earlier than 1977 were adjusted for the lower visibility from the air of certain species using differential ground counts. The park perimeter was entirely fenced until 1993, when sections of the western boundary fence adjoining private nature reserves were removed. Count totals have been sub-divided among four regions: South = between Crocodile and Sabi Rivers; Central = between Sabi and Olifants Rivers; North = between Olifants and Letaba Rivers; Far North = north of Letaba River, excluding the section north of Punda Maria that was covered irregularly

Count totals have been sub-divided among four regions: South = between Crocodile and Sabi Rivers; Central = between Sabi and Olifants Rivers; North = between Olifants and Letaba Rivers; Far North = north of Letaba River, excluding the section north of Punda Maria that was covered irregularly

Nocturnal flying insects fly in a straight line by maintaining a constant angle with the brightest light in the sky, usually the moon. The moon is always above the horizon and therefore moonlight always strikes insects from the top and never from below. When observing whether insects would fly to a light source shining from below them in comparison to a light source shining from above, no insects flew to the light shining from below, while several flew to the lights source shining from above. Samevatting: Nagtelike vliënde insekte vlieg in ŉ reguit lyn deur ŉ konstante hoek te bly hou met die helderste lig in die hệmel, wat gewoontlik die maan is. Die maan is altyd bo die horison en daarvoor raak dit altyd die insekte van bo af en nooit van onder af nie. Terwyl my ondersoek om uit te vind of insekte verkies om na ŉ lig vanaf onder of bo te kom het ek gevind dat daar min was wat na die lig vanaf onder gekom het. Die insekte het dikwels na die lig van bo gekom.
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project

My study sites were the Skukuza and Shingwetzi camps in the Kruger National Park. I conducted two trials in Skukuza and one trial in Shingwetzi. I cut out a piece of cardboard one meter in length and .4 meters in width. In the middle of the rectangle two holes 1.5 cm in diameter were cut out. In each hole I placed a flashlight pointing in opposite directs. I then taped the barrier to a wall with equal amount of wall area above and below the barrier. For each trial I observed and tallied the insects that flew towards the light from above and below. An event would only be considered if the insects flew towards the light and either touched the light source or the barrier. Each trial was one hour long and began at 20h00. The trials were completed 23 February, 24 February, and 2 March respectively. The statistics performed was a χ2 – test.

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Increased biodiversity loss caused by humans underlines the importance of monitoring the health of ecosystems. One efficient way to do this is through the use of indicator species. Ants show potential as an indicator taxon, but the effect of human disturbance on their communities has not yet been well studied. In natural communities, ant species specialize to varying degrees in either discovery of food resources or aggressive domination of them, but this pattern has not been investigated in the context of human development. In order to find out whether human settlements lead to changes in ant community composition and discovery/dominance dynamics, we set 38 baited traps in matched pairs inside and outside of human settlements. We identified the responding ant genera, recorded activity levels every 10 minutes for one hour, recorded time of discovery and aggressive dominance interactions. “Discoverer” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites outside human settlements, and “Dominant” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites inside human settlements. Across all genera, ants arrived to bait traps faster outside of settlements than in them. High beta diversity was observed between inside and outside experimental sites, therefore human settlement at the level of the Leokwe Camp in Mapungubwe National Park appears to change the composition of ant communities. In resource-rich human areas there seems to be less pressure to discover food resources quickly, but increased pressure to defend resources from competitors.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungibwe National Park, South Africa

Methods Study area Our study was conducted in Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site located in the Limpopo Province of South Africa (Figure 1). The park is situated along the Limpopo River within the Limpopo basin bordered by Botswana and Zimbabwe. The geology primarily consists of granitic basement rocks which over millions of years eroded to produce present day sandstone formations (Huffman 2005). Tectonic activity caused magma from the earth’s core to rise to the surface resulting in basalt sheets and dolerite dykes. The park is within a savanna biome, consisting of a high diversity of Acacia and Commiphora species; other vegetation in the area includes short, dense, shrubby Mopanes, fever trees, Ana trees, leadwoods, fig trees and sparse tufted grassveld. There are also some very large baobabs scattered in the area (http://www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/conservation/ff/vegetation.php). The Mapungubwe National Park was established recently in 2004 (www.southafrica.info/ess_info/sa_glance/fauna_flora/mapungubwe-nationalpark.htm), with a tourist resort containing 20 huts for accommodation and an entertainment and dining facility in the Leokwe Camp. FIGURE 1: Location of Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site (www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/images/maps/map2.png) Observation and collection To establish if there were differences in ant communities inside and outside of human settlements, we used bait traps of canned chunk-light tuna in water. To ensure that vegetation type remained constant throughout our experiment, nineteen paired tests consisting of traps positioned inside and outside of human settlements were conducted at six sites. The sites selected for our baited traps are subject to frequent human utilization and therefore commonly contain human-derived food sources. The kitchen garbage is probably the most resource-rich site, as substantial quantities of new food are added daily when groups are present at the camp, and the food may remain in place for up to a week before removal. The dining and entertainment area is almost as rich in resources, as visitors to the camp often consume meals or snacks at the pool or on the lookout deck. A often-used path to the kitchen and entertainment area was also used for one of the sites representing human settlements. The huts represent the highest variability in human utilization, as it is unclear how often each hut is inhabited. Sites outside settlements were paired to an adjacent inside site by being placed approximately 20 – 30 meters away from the inside site. Traps were set 6 times daily over a period of four days, each test lasting for duration 60 minutes. To determine the ant genera that used or approached the food resource, specimens were collected in vials for identification. We monitored the interactions between genera and temporal differences in the use of food resources inside and outside of human settlements to investigate if certain genera displayed dominance over the resource. The arrival time of each ant genus and the time it took for a genus to swarm the bait was noted. A swarm was considered a high level of activity and movement maintained by a large number of ants on the bait. The changes in resource utilization over 60 minutes were determined by qualitatively rating activity levels as high, medium, or low at 10 minute intervals for each genus. Further, to establish if certain genera display dominance by aggressive behavior, we continuously monitored and noted any aggressive incidental behaviors and recorded all interactions with other genera while recording activity levels. To establish which ant genera were present but not necessarily seen at our trial stations we determined the taxonomic composition around the study sites using a grid network of bait traps spaced 15 meters apart. After the traps had been set for one hour, specimens at each trap were collected for identification and a GPS location recorded. Data analysis To determine if significantly different ant communities exist between areas inside and outside of human settlements an ANOSIM analysis was run in Primer (Primer- E ltd. 2001). A Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test whether the common “Dominant” (pheidone, tapinoma) and “Discoverer” (monomordium) genera were evenly distributed inside and outside of human settlements. Another Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test the null hypothesis that genus did not affect resource utilization over time. A series of t-tests were used to test for significant differences in the arrival time of common genera. A paired t-test was used to compare the arrival time inside and outside for all trials in which a genus arrived both inside and outside in order to determine if human settlements were responsible for changes in arrival time. Finally, a Pearson’s chi-squared analysis was used to determine if aggressive dominance interactions were distributed evenly across sites inside and outside human settlements.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungibwe National Park, South Africa

Ficus sycomorus is a keystone species on a macro level but yet is highly dependent on the fig wasps for its reproductive success. The relationship between F. sycomorus and fig wasps has been largely studied in ecology. More importantly, the relationship is an ideal model for co-evolutionary processes. It is thus essential to study what fig characteristics facilitate wasp populations inside figs. In this study, the influence of ripeness and size of the fig as well as location and human influence on the figsâ habitat were examined as possible determinants of wasp diversity in figs. After surveying 13 crops of F. sycomorus inflorescence, a total of 12 morphospecies were identified. We found that ripeness, location, and human disturbance are the key characteristics for species diversity. Fruit diameter did not show any relation with wasp diversity or abundance. Ripeness, at a micro scale, is an effective tool for selecting figs with high wasp morphospecies diversity. We found that F. sycomorus occurring in riparian areas and non-human impacted areas have higher species diversity.

Site Site. Trees were collected from two locations: the riparian area around the Sabie River and the Skukuza village of the Pretoriaskop area (Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa) between October 10th and October 12th (Sabie River GPS: 24.99008S, 31.45679E; Skukuza village GPS: 24.79372S, 31.59014E). Tree Selection Thirteen trees were selected from two habitat types: seven riparian trees along the Sabie River and six non-riparian trees within the Skukuza Camp (Figure 1). Fig collection and assesment Samples of 10-13 figs were selected from each tree at random. Figs were individually placed into vials with mesh tops to allow the wasps to breathe.Fig color, softness, and diameter were measured. Fig color score was assessed on a scale of 1-5; 1=light green, 5=yellowish-tan. Softness score was assessed by touch on a scale of 1-5; 1=hard, 5=soft. Softness and color scores were added to form a ripeness score of 1-10. Wasp collection The wasps were allowed to emerge for a total of three days in the presence of ethyl acetate in a large closed box to kill the wasps as they emerged. Wasps were collected from individual vials at time >24, >48, and >72 hours. After the emergence period, wasps were individually counted and sorted based on morphology under a dissecting scope. Morphological features were used to assess the morphospecies identified. A morphospecies is a simple classification to categorize communities based on morphology. Morphologies were distinguished based on body color, leg color, body size, ovipositor length, jaw-size, and antenna shape. Analyses In order to organize the data, the ripeness score of figs was categorized in order to simplify the analysis process. Using this score, a regression analysis was used to separate the data into three groups: Group 1 (under ripe with ripeness score of 2-3), Group 2 (ripe with ripeness score 4-9), and Group 3 (overripe with ripeness score 10) (Figure 2). The analysis of morphospecies diversity for all characteristics was performed on Group 2 because members of this group encompassed the majority of figs surveyed. Mann-Whitney U tests and Kruskal-Wallis tests were applied to the collected data to determine the differences in the number of morphospecies for the ripeness, location, and human influence factors. A correlation statistic was used to compare the diameter of the fig to both the number of wasps present in the fig and the number of morphospecies. Multidimensional scale ordination (MDS) was used to show degrees of similarity in a graphical depiction. Simpsonâs index of diversity, a nonparametric indication of diversity, was used to calculate morphospecies diversity amongst the fig wasps (Krebs, 1989). Chi-squared tests were used to calculate significance in the presence of parasitoids amongst the different characteristics. Yateâs correction was applied to the chi-squared value as there was only one degree of freedom

The wetlands of the Cape Floristic Region, South Africa are a hotspot of species diversity. The aquatic invertebrates of this region are so diverse mainly because of the varying geomorphology and hydrology of the realm, which affect water chemistry. We hypothesized that there would be a significant difference between the suite of invertebrate species of a closed, permanent and sandstone-based wetland (Potberg Vlei) and a relatively open, temporary, calcareous wetland (De Hoop Vlei). The water chemistry of each area is vastly different, but there is no significant difference in species richness of the wetlands, though there has been an increase in species richness since the fall. However, there does seem to be a difference in the species diversity of the two vleis. These differences could be quite important in determining conservation areas.
Eliza Chamblin and Anna Chu (editors) Jenny Day (resource person) SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Problem
Eliza Chamblin and Anna Chu (editors) Jenny Day (resource person) SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Problem
aquatic invertebrates, geology, wetland, Cape Floristic Region, inundation frequency

We collected data from two sites in the De Hoop Nature Reserve of the Cape Floristic Region on 24-25 October 2006. One of these sites has a calcareous parent rock (De Hoop Vlei) and the other has a sandstone parent rock (Potberg Vlei). The De Hoop Vlei is a relatively open vlei that experiences flooding every several years. In contrast, the Potberg Vlei is a closed vlei that has perennial flooding. To sample from the De Hoop Vlei, we divided the waters into three distinct biotopes based on vegetation. The first area, the Cladophora region, was closest to the shore. This section was largely characterized by a cover of the green algae, Cladophora. The second sampling region was the area of water containing the Potamogeton pectinatous plant. The third sampling site was the open water farthest from the shore. The Potberg Vlei contained only two of our designated divisions: the Potamogeton and open water areas. In these sections, we used the same sampling methods as in the De Hoop Vlei. We took three water samples from each of the regions in each of the biotopes in the De Hoop and Potberg Vleis. We then identified and classified (on a log scale) the number of invertebrates found within each sample. We also measured the pH and conductivity levels in all biotopes in each vlei. Using the program, Primer, we were able to create an ordination chart to spatially represent the diversity differences among our sampling sites. We then made another ordination chart to compare the differences in our sites to those of the same sites seven months ago. We used a one-way ANOVA to determine if there was a statistical difference between the species richness values of the biotopes of the De Hoop Vlei and the Potberg Vlei and t-tests and an ANOVA to find any statistical differences in the pH and conductivity levels within and between each vlei.

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Change creates uncertainty and risk. Global environmental change epitomizes several threats and risks to human livelihoods. Numerous factors associate with and drive global environmental change including climate, disease, pollution, invasive species, over-harvesting and habitat change. In many instances, protected areas are considered the holy grail of ensuring environmental sustainability, even though continental patterns challenge this. Such areas are usually embedded in matrices of different land-uses, all of which may have different consequences for the environment. In South Africa, it is not clear how protected areas combat or are affected by global patterns of environmental change. The definition of habitat change is problematic on two fronts. Firstly, habitat change can be viewed as primarily a consequence and/or indicator of the effects of other drivers of global environmental change. Secondly, desirable and undesirable habitat changes need to be separated. A range of causes of habitat change (sub-drivers) were identified across parks at a meeting of SANParks research staff at the Cape Research Centre. These include fire, absence of predators, over-grazing, mega-herbivore impact, park isolation, small park size, water abstraction, management for tourism, sedimentation, poaching and overexploitation. Two positive impacts on habitat were identified, i.e. land consolidation and restoration. One of the key conclusions from the discussion was that there is good evidence for the fact that habitat in parks is changing, but that the impact of this change on pattern and process in parks is poorly understood. Objectives were set in this context and the assessment focused on two kinds of data sets – vegetation measures (species composition) across parks as a primary index of habitat change, and large mammal abundances within parks as a broad index of a response to habitat change.
Dr Nicola van Wilgen SANParks nicola.vanwilgen@sanparks.org
Dr Nicola van Wilgen SANParks nicola.vanwilgen@sanparks.org

Concept: Author / Originator World Wide Web Address

Content: 672 papers and their abstracts were extracted from the Science Citation Database using the “habitat change” and “protected area” as search words. Only the papers published since 1 January 2008 were considered. Results suggest that habitat change associated with land use change and fragmentation, processes that are limited within Parks at the scale usually used in other studies. Vegetation plot data were collated from the South African National Parks into one central database. A total of 33 data sets have been collected and converted into a standard ‘species by site’ format or a ‘presence/absence’ format. Several data sets may still be added to the total number as some researchers that were contacted need to sort their data and/or finish field plots before they can provide it. A number of hard copy data sets was also included. The 33 data sets currently collated represent 15 of the national parks. All large mammal time series data available from surveys for National Parks were collated. We reasoned that the responses of large mammals summarized by growth rates that reflect biological influences of resources, members of its own species as well as other species, will serve as good indicators of the impact of habitat change even if indicators of habitat change are limited. We thus calculated exponential growth rates in the past five years.

Nile crocodile (Crocodilus niloticus) mass mortality events in the Olifants River between the Letaba River confluence in South Africa and Lake Massingir in Mozambique have been attributed to pansteatitis: a disease that affects fat depots of the animals. The disease is also found in sharptooth catfish (Clarias gariepinus) in the same area, and the cause of the disease is attributed to pollution. Although the Olifants River Valley is polluted, the impact of interventions such as dam construction on biodiversity receives little attention. We show that the onset of the pansteatitis epidemic in crocodiles and sharptooth catfish at the Olifants/Letaba confluence coincided with back-flooding of Lake Massingir that changed the Olifants River from a rock and sand substrate river to a clay substrate lake. Isotopic analysis shows that sharptooth catfish shifted from a predominantly vegetarian to a piscivorous diet that is highly correlated with pansteatitis prevalence, and crocodiles and tiger fish (Hydrocynus vittatus) show coincident trophic level increases. The evidence suggests that the ecosystem change altered the structure of the lotic foodweb and that an exotic or extralimital fish has invaded the confluence and is the vector of the pansteatitis epidemic. The invasive fish species is yet to be identified. The pansteatitis epidemic is an unintended ecological consequence of damming this river.

Natural Resources and the Environment, CSIR,

Sampling Fish samples were collected for histopathological and stomach content analysis in June 2009, August 2009, November 2009, July 2010, January 2011 and June 2011 from rivers and dams in the Kruger National Park (Fig. 1). Sample sites include the confluence of the Letaba and Olifants Rivers (23859021.800 S, 31849035.600 E) and from 1.3km upstream of the confluence in the Letaba River (23855057.900 S, 31849002.100 E) (for sharptooth catfish and tiger fish it can be assumed that these two locations represent a single population) (site OL). Further samples were taken from the Olifants River at Ngotso located 28.5 km upstream of the Letaba confluence (24803010.800 S, 31843050.600 E) (site ON), the headwaters of Lake Massingir near the Mozambique border (2385704800 S, 03185209700 E) (site OM) and Mamba Weir (2480303200 S, 03181401400 E) (site MW). Samples were also taken from Ree¨nvoe¨l Dam (23858037.200 S, 031819038.400 E) (site RV) and van Ryssen Dam (24800013.600 S, 31805036.900 E) (site FK) located on tributaries of the Olifants River. The Letaba River was sampled upstream of the confluence at Klipkoppies Bridge (2385605800 S, 03184308900 E) (site LKB) and from Engelhard Dam (2385001900 S, 3182802800 E) (site ED) located 17km upstream of the Olifants River confluence. Other river systems that were sampled include the Sabie River in the Sabiepoort (25810025.4100 S, 3282023.4200 E) (site SP), the Levuvhu River (22825051.000 S, 31818004.400 E) (site LR) and the Crocodile River (25823057.100 S, 31857029.900 E) (site CR). Sharptooth catfish and tiger fish were caught on baited hooks or artificial lures, while other species were sampled using an electrofisher (Samus). The fish that were subject to isotopic analysis comprise a subsample of the June 2011 collection from the OL, LR and CR sites.Invertebrates, diatoms, riparian and aquatic vegetation, sediments and organic detritus were also sampled for isotopic analysis. On 4–7 September 2011 tiger fish samples were collected from the Crocodile River, and both sharptooth catfish and tiger fish were sampled from below the Engelhard Dam wall (considered the same as site ED).Fish were euthanized in a benzocaine solution. The protocol was approved under the University of Pretoria Animal Care and Use Protocol V013/ 10 and sanctioned by South African National Parks (SANParks). Crocodile claws were collected from animals that were euthanized as part of the SANParks research into pansteatitis in 2010. Isotopic Analyses Fish muscle tissues for isotopic analyses were taken from the abdominal area and were degreased in a 2:1 chloroform:ethanol mixture and dried overnight at 708C. Invertebrates and organic samples were reacted with a 1% HCl solution to remove any trace of carbonates, rinsed to pH neutral in distilled water and dried overnight at 708C. Analyses were performed on homogenised whole invertebrate samples (Pinnegar and Polunin 1999), and on a time series of samples taken from the dorsal aspect of the crocodile claws extending from the base to the tip of the claw. Claw samples were cleaned by boiling in distilled water during the extraction process but were not further pre-treated. Carbon and nitrogen isotope analyses were undertaken on 0.5–1.0 mg aliquots, while sulphur isotope analyses required 5 mg aliquots. Analyses were done on a Flash EA 1112 Series elemental analyser coupled to a Delta V plus isotope ratio mass spectrometer by a ConFloIV interface (all v www.esajournals.org 4 October 2012 v Volume 3(10) v Article 87.equipment supplied by ThermoFisher, Bremen, Germany). Each sample was measured in duplicate with laboratory standards and blanks run after every 12 unknown samples. Precision was ,0.1% for all analyses.The degreasing process influences both d13C and d15N values. The effect on d15N values is in the order of 0.25% (Post et al. 2007) which is considered negligible in the context of this study, while the effect on d13C values is more substantial and a correction based on the C/N ratio (derived from the mass spectrometer measurement) was applied (Post et al. 2007). Carbon and nitrogen isotope values were corrected against an in-house standard (Merck Gel) while sulphur isotopes were referenced against sulphanilamide and NIST bovine liver (Fry et al. 2002). Results are reported using the standard delta notation for stable light isotopes using the equation d13C or d15N ¼ [(Rsample/ Rstandard) 1]/1000, where R is 13C/12C or 15N/14N, respectively. The reference standards against which results are reported are Vienna PeeDee belemnite (VPDB) for d13C, atmospheric nitrogen (Air) for d15N and Vienna Canyon Diablo Troilite (VCDT) for d34S. Statistical Analyses The statistical test for significance for the association of pansteatitis with stomach content excluded fish that had empty stomachs. The fish sample was divided into three populations: those that had pansteatitis (Pþþ), those that were sampled at a site at which pansteatitis prevalence was recorded, but did not show any symptoms (Pþ), and those sampled at sites from which no pansteatitis was recorded (P). Stomach contents of fish were classified into three categories: fish, vegetation and mixed. The null hypothesis assumed that the three stomach content categories would be equally sampled in a random selection strategy by the fish populations. The chi-squared test value of 63.9 is significant (P , 0.0001) using 4 degrees of freedom and the null hypothesis is rejected implying that there is preferential dietary selection in the three populations.

The study species represented two broad types of shoot morphology, which affected the way in which some data were collected. A. grandicornuta, A. exuvialis and D. cinerea can increase leaf area without increasing internode length. They therefore produce most of their new leaves in discrete clusters (whorls or tufts) of leaves at the nodes of old shoots or branches. The nodes are usually raised into short-shoots or spurs. Conversely, C. apiculatum, G. flavescens and E. divinorum cannot increase leaf area without extending the internodes of new long-shoots. All their new leaves are therefore arranged in either alternate or opposite positions on new shoots. The wet seasons occurring between August 2005 and July 2008 were divided into early (late November/early December), middle (late January/early February) and late (late March/early April) phases. Mature leaves above 1.5 m on randomly selected trees taller than 2 m were sampled in each phase of each wet season. The amount of canopy removed by browsing was estimated for each sampled tree. Concentrations of N, P, condensed tannins, total polyphenols, neutral detergent fibre, acid detergent fibre and acid detergent lignin ([N], [P], [CT], [TP], [NDF], [ADF] and [ADL]) were analysed. Shoot length, leaf length and photosynthesis parameters were measured each time leaves were sampled for chemical analysis in either one or two of the wet seasons. We also explored low-molecular-weight phenolics (LMWPs) in the study species in February/March 2007. Lastly, we fitted dendrometers to the study species in 2006 to measure relative growth rates of stems, which continued until 2012.

SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Chemical composition Data on chemical composition were collected in two main phases from the areas protected by fire-breaks. The preliminary phase was aimed at determining general trends across two wet seasons (2005/2006 and 2006/2007) that could be used to focus sampling in the final phase (2007/2008 wet season). The preliminary phase was characterized by collecting samples of each species at 6 random sites per soil type per treatment (18 sites per soil type) during the early, middle and late stages of each wet season (i.e., late November/early December, late January/early February and late March/early April). Samples of two species were also collected in one dry season (June 2007) during the preliminary phase (the other species could not be sampled because they had no leaves). The number of species sampled for chemical analysis in the final phase was reduced from six to four (A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum) for logistical and technical reasons (i.e., sampling fewer species would allow the opportunity to increase sample size per species). The four species were selected because (1) it was not always possible to know the ages of mature leaves on E. divinorum (<1 year or 1-2 years) and therefore it was difficult to control the age of samples collected, and (2) the small, sparse leaves on A. exuvialis were difficult to harvest. The final phase had two objectives. The first objective was to determine herbivore effects on these four species in the middle of the 2007/2008 wet season. It was characterized by collecting samples at 18 random sites per soil type per treatment (54 sites per soil type) in late January 2008. An exception was G. flavescens, which could not be found at 13 of the 54 sites visited on the crest and midslope. The second aim of the final phase was to continue our study of seasonal variations by sampling at different times of the 2007/2008 wet season, but sampling was restricted to 6 plants per species in the total exclusion plot. A 30x30 m grid based on the “UTM WGS 84” coordinate system was imposed on a LIDAR image of the study area and the X and Y coordinates at the centre of each grid cell were determined. The sample sites were selected by sorting the central coordinates of each cell in random order and using a Garmin® GPS 72 to navigate to each of the selected sites. Grid cells that occurred on an anomalous basaltic outcrop covering about 15% of the partial exclusion plot were not included in sampling. One tree of each study species was sampled in each grid cell on condition that it was (1) closest to the grid cell centre, (2) taller than 2 m, and (3) neither obviously stressed by disease or neighbours nor obviously growing in a nutrient enriched patch such as a termite mound or localized depression. The minimum height of selected G. flavescens plants was 1.5 m because it seldom grows taller than 2 m. If any of the conditions failed to be met for the closest tree, then the next closest tree that met the conditions was sampled. No tree was sampled if the closest suitable tree was further than 15 m from the grid-cell centre because a neighbouring cell would be entered. Leaf samples were collected by clipping branches 3-8 mm in diameter from the northern, sunlit half of the canopy between 1.5 and 2.2 m above ground, which was within the range of most browsers in the study area. For G. flavescens, branches were collected above 1.0 m. Branches were collected between 1 and 4 hours after sunrise. Mature (fully expanded) leaves that did not show signs of severe insect herbivory were removed until a fresh mass of 30-50 g was obtained for drying in an oven for 24 hours at 60 °C. The only time we deviated from this approach was at the start of the project in November 2005 when sampling was done at an early stage of leaf growth. Dried leaf samples were milled to pass a sieve with 1.0 mm apertures and were analysed for concentrations of condensed tannins (CT) (Porter et al. 1986; Hattas et al. 2005), total polyphenols (TP) (Price & Butler 1977), Kjeldahl-N (AOAC 1984) and P (Murphy & Riley 1962). Sorghum tannin and gallic acid were used as standards for [CT] and [TP]. Concentrations of neutral detergent fibre (NDF), acid detergent fibre (ADF) and acid detergent lignin (ADL) were determined according to Van Soest et al. (1991). All concentrations were expressed as mg g-1 dry mass. All analyses were conducted at the Department of Botany, University of Cape Town. Because the impact of browsing was variable on sampled trees outside the total exclusion plot, estimates of the proportion (%) of productive (potentially leaf- or shoot-bearing) canopy volume below or above 1.5 m deemed to be missing because of (1) leaf removal, (2) biting of current wet season’s shoots, (3) recent browsing of twigs (previous seasons’ shoots), and (4) accumulated browsing of twigs, was recorded for each tree sampled in January 2008. This method was a subjective method, but it was developed and tested by four observers over the course of four sampling occasions between November 2006 and March 2007. Only one of the four observers who calibrated each other during the development stage did the observations in January 2008. Thirty mature leaves were collected from three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot and control plot in early February 2007 and late March 2007 to identify and quantify specific low molecular weight phenolics (LMWPs). The samples were frozen in liquid N and kept frozen until they were freeze-dried. They were later analysed at the Natural Products Laboratories at Joensuu University, Finland, using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) and HPLC coupled to Mass Spectrophotometry (HPLC-MS) (Julkunen Tiitto et al. 1996; Keski-Saari et al. 2005). LMWP concentrations were determined individually, which allowed later combining into functional groups (phenolic glycosides, flavone aglycosides and hydrolysable tannins). Shoot length Lengths of marked new shoots and new leaves on each species were measured each time leaves were sampled for chemical analysis in the 2006/2007 wet season. Up to 10 new shoots and 10 new leaves on the new shoots were selected on five trees per species in each treatment in the third week of November 2006. The new shoots were selected by randomly locating 10 old shoots (from a previous wet season) per tree. Each selected old shoot was 2-8 mm in basal diameter and 1.5-2.5 m above ground (>1 m for G. flavescens). Old shoots were marked by loosely twisting short pieces of thin “telephone” wire around the shoot base. Colour combinations were used to differentiate individual shoots. The most distal new shoot on each old shoot was marked by painting a small spot of white “correction fluid” (Tippex) at the base. The length of each marked new shoot was measured to the nearest 0.1 cm. Shoots were measured from the base of the shoot to the base of the apical bud. In addition to marking new shoots on A. exuvialis, A. grandicornuta and D. cinerea, which had very few new shoots in November 2006, one leaf cluster was marked on each marked old shoot. The leaf cluster with the longest leaf was marked with a small spot of Tippex painted on the old shoot. The length of the longest leaf on each marked new shoot of all species and the longest leaf in each marked leaf cluster of the “short-shoot” species was measured to the nearest 0.1 mm. Leaves were measured from the base of the petiole to the apex of the midrib (simple leaves) or rachis (compound leaves). None of the A. grandicornuta trees selected for measuring shoot and leaf length had >2 new shoots and the total number of marked new shoots ended up being only 3-5 per treatment. The total number of new shoots marked per treatment for the remaining species was 5-7 on A. exuvialis (1-5 per tree), 1-9 on E. divinorum (1-6 per tree), 40-49 on C. apiculatum (4-10 per tree), 49-50 on G. flavescens (9-10 per tree) and 14-23 on D. cinerea (1-8 per tree). The range in lengths of new shoots was 2.1-6.9 cm in A. exuvialis, 1.0-3.4 cm in E. divinorum, 1.2-3.9 cm in C. apiculatum, 1.2-4.6 cm in G. flavescens and 0.7-6.2 cm in D. cinerea at the time of marking. The low number of new shoots on E. divinorum at the start of the wet season was because of its phenological pattern of producing new shoots later in the season. Each marked shoot that still had an intact apical bud in the first week of December, last week of January and last week of March was re-measured. The longest leaf on each marked shoot was also re-measured. Shoots found to be dead, browsed or missing from the sample population were not replaced. In the first week of November 2007, the lengths of up to 10 randomly selected, unmarked new shoots were measured on each of the trees used for growth measurements in 2006/2007. This time, the objective was to test if there was an effect of herbivore exclusion on shoot length. We did this early in the wet season because as the season progresses many current season’s shoots become damaged and therefore cannot be used to measure effects on growth rate. The early wet season is the best time to find abundant intact new shoots. Photosynthesis. Maximum (light saturated) photosynthesis rate (Amax) was estimated in the total exclusion plot when leaves were sampled for chemical analysis and shoot lengths were measured in the 2006/2007 wet season. Specific leaf area (SLA, m2 g-1) was estimated each time for calculating Amax per unit mass (Amass). Our focus was on two broad-leaf species (C. apiculatum and G. flavescens) because of technical and logistical constraints (i.e., broad leaves are simpler to measure than fine leaves and both species occurred at each sample site on the crest). Amax was estimated using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system (LI-COR, Nebraska, USA). The leaf chamber was fitted with an internal red-blue light source and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) was kept at 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. On each sampling day in the early wet season (7 December 2006), mid wet season (6 February 2007) and late wet season (26 March 2007) we estimated the photosynthetic rate of three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot between 06:30 and 08:30 and assumed that the observations approximated Amax. Preliminary observation in April 2006 had indicated that Amax was likely to be achieved between 06:30 and 08:30. The sampled trees were selected from those used for growth measurements. Each time an individual was observed 3-5 fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. Each individual was observed once during sampling and therefore the observations were instantaneous “snapshots”. Amax was also measured in the control plot (no exclusion) in February 2007 using the same methods. Amax of C. apiculatum and G. flavescens was estimated again in the total exclusion plot and the control plot in November 2007 (early wet season), February 2008 (mid wet season) and December 2008 (early wet season) using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system. The dry conditions that characterised the 2007/2008 wet season resulted in measurements of Amax in March 2008 being abandoned. The main aim on these occasions was to test the exclosure effect, but we used different methods. In November 2007 we collected diurnal data to make sure we measured Amax at the correct time of day. This required us to observe trees close to each other (<15 m apart) so that we could easily obtain a sequence of observations during the day, which meant that we could not observe the trees used for growth measurements because they were about 100 m apart from each other. The LI-6400 was fitted with a clear leaf chamber for diurnal measurements, which required sunny weather. Only C. apiculatum was observed in November because cloudy conditions limited the available time for measurements on G. flavescens. Whenever the leaf chamber was clamped on a leaf, it was positioned at an angle that would permit maximum sunlight to reach the leaf surface. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. Each time an individual was observed three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. On two pairs of successive days photosynthetic rates (A) were measured on three individuals 1-2 m tall (19-20 November) and three individuals 2-5 m tall (26-27 November) in close proximity to each other within each plot throughout most of each day starting between 05:30 and 06:00 (30-60 minutes after sunrise). PAR on 26 and 27 November reached saturating levels before 06:30. The shorter trees served as a pilot study before observing the taller trees. In the first week of February 2008 and first week of December 2008 we collected photosynthesis data inside and outside the total exclusion plot by modeling [CO2] response curves. This method gives insights into how internal, biochemical regulators of photosynthesis are responding to external factors by allowing the calculation of carboxylation rates (Vcmax) and electron transport rates (Jmax). The method is also more efficient than estimating Amax on a number of trees during a specific observation period when Amax is assumed to be achieved. Light saturated Amax (at a specific temperature and [CO2]) can be estimated, although values may not be directly comparable to those obtained under ambient conditions when light or temperature are not controlled. The method is not dependent on weather conditions or time of day, which means that more trees can be sampled per day regardless of cloud cover (except in wet weather). In the week of 4-8 February 2008 four individuals of each species were observed in the total exclusion plot and four in the control plot. Three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement on each tree. Measurements on each leaf took approximately 15 minutes and four trees could be observed per day between 06:30 and 09:30. The “A-CiCurve” program of the LI-6400 was used to expose each leaf to variable [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 400, 600 and 800 μmol m-2 s-1 (LI-COR 2004). Each leaf was allowed at least 1 minute (but not more than 2) to stabilize after each change in [CO2] before A was logged. [CO2] flow rate was kept at 400 μmol m-2 s-1. PAR was kept at 1500 μmol m-2 s-1 for C. apiculatum and 1100 μmol m-2 s-1 for G. flavescens, while leaf temperature was set at 30 °C, based on light response curves done previously at 25, 30 and 35 °C. Actual leaf temperature averaged 30.8 °C (27.9-34.0 °C). The same procedure was used during the period 4-11 December 2008, except that each leaf was exposed this time to [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 600, 800, 1000 and 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. Two calibrated LI-6400 instruments were used simultaneously each day in the total exclusion plot and control plot. Although the aim was to observe a total of 12 trees per species per plot (8 per day across both plots), technical problems resulted in fewer trees being observed per plot. Actual leaf temperature averaged 29.2 °C (23.7-32.6 °C). Dendrometers Manual dendrometers (Agricultural Electronics Corp., Arizona, USA) were fitted to 90 individuals of 6 species in August 2006 and February 2007 (5 trees per exclusion plot per species). Most of these were the same individuals on which shoot growth was measured in 2006/2007. A few individuals fitted in February 2007 were not the same because new trees were selected at some sites if the original tree selected was found to be not ideal. Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Dendrometer bands were fitted at a height of 20 cm on the dominant stem (usually the tallest) because a preliminary survey indicated that stems were often fused or unevenly shaped below 20 cm. Circumferences at 20 cm were roughly 10-20 cm for G. flavescens, A. exuvialis and D. cinerea, 15-25 cm for E. divinorum, 25-35 cm for C. apiculatum, and 40-50 cm for A. grandicornuta. Low tension dendrometers were used except on the largest A. grandicornuta stems, which had high tension dendrometers fitted. The dendrometers were observed (nearest 0.1 mm) whenever other fieldwork was being done. Dendrometers were adjusted and circumferences re-measured whenever the reading was 0 or >25.0. Up to July 2008, two G. flavescens shrubs (sites 10011 and 10013) in the control plot were uprooted and the dendrometers damaged, a third G. flavescens shrub (site 10014) was partially uprooted (but the dendrometer was undamaged and the stem remained rooted), one A. grandicornuta tree was felled (site 10020) in the control plot, one A. exuvialis tree in the control plot died (site 10013) and a replacement tree was fitted at the same site in November 2006, and two dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were damaged in the partial exclusion plot. Apart from fitting one replacement of A. exuvialis (site 10013) in November 2006, no replacement trees were fitted and no damaged dendrometers were repaired until November 2008. The slow growth rate expected of trees in semi-arid climates and the high variation in circumferences at 20 cm among randomly selected trees led us to presume that exclusion effects could not really be tested until a long-term series of data on relative growth rate becomes available. A further 147 new dendrometers were fitted and 3 repaired or replaced in November 2008 with a view to monitoring a total of 237 dendrometers for the next 4-5 years (Tables 1 and 2). Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Two damaged dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were repaired and a replacement A. grandicornuta tree was fitted at site 10020. The two uprooted G. flavescens shrubs were not replaced. Seven new trees were fitted per species in each of the two exclusion plots, making the total of 12 per species in each of those plots. Extra dendrometers were fitted in the control plot to allow for estimated losses over the next 5 years. Ten new dendrometers were fitted per species in the control, except for G. flavescens for which 15 new dendrometers were fitted because it seemed to be most susceptible to uprooting (at five sites in the control plot only G. flavescens was fitted). At two sites (10082 and 10087) in the partial exclusion plot no G. flavescens was fitted because no suitable plants were found, but at two sites (10081 and 10083) two G. flavescens were fitted to make up the shortfall. In December 2008, it was found that one of the original five A. exuvialis in the total exclusion plot (site 10004) and two in the partial exclusion plot (sites 10021 and 10022) had died. It was also found that of the new trees fitted in November 2008 two A. exuvialis in the control plot (sites 10054 and 10058) and one in the partial exclusion plot (site 10083) had died. Whether they died as a result of the dendrometers being fitted or as a result of low rainfall in 2008 (or a combination thereof) is unclear. The fact that three trees out of nine that had dendrometers on them since late 2006 did not die for two years, and that other A. exuvialis trees without dendrometers were dead in December 2008 indicates that low rainfall was the main cause of death, but the presence of dendrometers cannot be discounted as a contributing factor. Replacement trees were fitted in March 2009. Table 1. Number of individuals per species that had dendrometers on them in November 2008.
