data collection The main focus of all the above research was on individuals 2-5 m tall, but other projects were added to the main project in 2007/2008 to focus on various aspects of individuals shorter than 1.5 m at the exclusion plots (see report submitted to SANParks in September 2007). These projects on short trees were done to study (1) chemical defences, nutrients, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum in relation to season and browsing, (2) population structure, and community composition in relation to exclusion and soil type, and (3) physical defences of A. grandicornuta and A. exuvialis in relation to exclusion. The study on the chemistry, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum followed basically the same procedures as the “main” study, except for the following differences. Leaves were collected from 10 randomly selected plants (40-50 leaves per plant) per treatment plot per species during the periods 25- 31 Oct 2007, 13-16 Nov 2007, 31 Jan 2008, and 17-19 March 2008. No plants of A. grandicornuta were sampled in November 2007 because suitable individuals were not found at most of the random points visited. The leaves were oven-dried at 60 °C and analysed for concentrations of N, P and condensed tannins. Ten plants per treatment plot were randomly selected in September 2007 and their heights and stem circumferences (at 10cm) were measured. New shoots were marked and their lengths measured on these plants (5 shoots per plant) during the period 23-24 Oct 2007. The lengths of the marked shoots were re-measured during the periods 29-30 Oct 2007, 6 Dec 2007, 1 Feb 2008 and 17-19 Mar 2008. The heights and stem circumferences were re-measured in March 2008. The trees used for shoot growth measurements were used for leaf sampling in March 2008, as well as for photosynthesis measurements in November, February and March. Photosynthesis rate was measured for 3 leaves on each marked C. apiculatum and G. flavescens plant in the total exclusion plot and the control plot between 06:00 and 09:30 on 13-14 November 2007. Responses of photosynthesis to a range of [CO2] were measured for C. apiculatum in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the period 28-30 November 2007 (PAR=1500; Temp = 30 °C), and again for both C. apiculatum and G. flavescens in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the periods 6-13 February 2008 and 20-21 March 2008. Measurements were for three plants per treatment per species, except in March when two plants were measured per treatment per species. For the other studies of plants <1.5 m, transects were surveyed in November and December 2007. Thirty 2x40m transects were randomly placed in each of the three treatments (15 on crest and 15 on footslope) using the same 30x30 m grid mentioned previously. The starting point for each transect was the centre of each grid cell, which was located using a GPS. All transects were placed north of the fire break in the total exclusion plot and south of the fire break in the partial exclusion plot, and well within the borders of each vegetation type. No transects were placed within 30 m of firebreaks or fences. The anomalous area of vegetation in the partial exclusion plot mentioned above was excluded. Between crest and footslope a 30 m zone was observed where no transects were placed. At each starting point, a magnetic compass was used to drag a 20-m chain in a straight line towards magnetic north. At every 1-m mark on the chain we recorded whether or not a line projected up or down intercepted either woody or herbaceous canopy to estimate canopy cover. The species, height (cm), number of stems <1 cm diameter, number of stems >1 cm diameter, and the diameter of the largest stem of every woody plant within 1 m of the chain was recorded. Stem diameters were estimated at 1 cm above ground (i.e., immediately above the basal swelling of the stem). Stems more than 50 cm apart were considered separate individuals. Browsing of individuals shorter than 150 cm was estimated using a method based on the one described above. Browsing estimations included leaf herbivory (% of total leaf area lost), number of unbrowsed/browsed shoots (except where there were too many shoots to count, in which case proportion shoots browsed was estimated) and accumulated browsing (% total biomass above ground lost). Evidence of browsing by black rhino (angular bites) was also recorded. Only browsing by mammals was recorded and shoots were only recorded as browsed when the apex had been removed. For the accumulated browsing no distinction was made between actual browsing and breakage, since elephants can break branches and stems to gain access to certain parts of a plant. There are problems with browsing estimations such as these. First there can be differences depending on who does the estimation, which was avoided by ensuring that the same people did the estimates in all treatments. Secondly a plant may have been browsed in the past but in such a way that it is very difficult to see, and as a result there might be over estimation of unbrowsed individuals. The first individual of Acacia exuvialis or Acacia grandicornuta in each transect was chosen for shoot measurements. Individuals were not chosen if taller than 150 cm or if the accumulated browsing exceeded 50 %, because taller trees would be difficult to measure, and very heavily browsed trees could be too damaged to respond to treatment effects. The selected plants also had to have at least five measurable annual shoots. In cases where no such tree could be found within a transect, the closest suitable tree to the transect starting point (without entering the vicinity of another point) was selected. On the chosen individual, 5-10 annual shoots were selected randomly (the number depending on how many could be found). On these shoots, measurements of shoot length, longest leaf, number of spines and the longest spine in each pair of spines were taken. All spines shorter than 2 mm were excluded. Shoot length was measured from the shoot base to the base of the apical bud, and spine length from spine base to spine tip. The length of each leaf was measured from the base of the petiole to the base of the terminal pinnae.

Chemical composition Data on chemical composition were collected in two main phases from the areas protected by fire-breaks. The preliminary phase was aimed at determining general trends across two wet seasons (2005/2006 and 2006/2007) that could be used to focus sampling in the final phase (2007/2008 wet season). The preliminary phase was characterized by collecting samples of each species at 6 random sites per soil type per treatment (18 sites per soil type) during the early, middle and late stages of each wet season (i.e., late November/early December, late January/early February and late March/early April). Samples of two species were also collected in one dry season (June 2007) during the preliminary phase (the other species could not be sampled because they had no leaves). The number of species sampled for chemical analysis in the final phase was reduced from six to four (A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum) for logistical and technical reasons (i.e., sampling fewer species would allow the opportunity to increase sample size per species). The four species were selected because (1) it was not always possible to know the ages of mature leaves on E. divinorum (<1 year or 1-2 years) and therefore it was difficult to control the age of samples collected, and (2) the small, sparse leaves on A. exuvialis were difficult to harvest. The final phase had two objectives. The first objective was to determine herbivore effects on these four species in the middle of the 2007/2008 wet season. It was characterized by collecting samples at 18 random sites per soil type per treatment (54 sites per soil type) in late January 2008. An exception was G. flavescens, which could not be found at 13 of the 54 sites visited on the crest and midslope. The second aim of the final phase was to continue our study of seasonal variations by sampling at different times of the 2007/2008 wet season, but sampling was restricted to 6 plants per species in the total exclusion plot. A 30x30 m grid based on the “UTM WGS 84” coordinate system was imposed on a LIDAR image of the study area and the X and Y coordinates at the centre of each grid cell were determined. The sample sites were selected by sorting the central coordinates of each cell in random order and using a Garmin® GPS 72 to navigate to each of the selected sites. Grid cells that occurred on an anomalous basaltic outcrop covering about 15% of the partial exclusion plot were not included in sampling. One tree of each study species was sampled in each grid cell on condition that it was (1) closest to the grid cell centre, (2) taller than 2 m, and (3) neither obviously stressed by disease or neighbours nor obviously growing in a nutrient enriched patch such as a termite mound or localized depression. The minimum height of selected G. flavescens plants was 1.5 m because it seldom grows taller than 2 m. If any of the conditions failed to be met for the closest tree, then the next closest tree that met the conditions was sampled. No tree was sampled if the closest suitable tree was further than 15 m from the grid-cell centre because a neighbouring cell would be entered. Leaf samples were collected by clipping branches 3-8 mm in diameter from the northern, sunlit half of the canopy between 1.5 and 2.2 m above ground, which was within the range of most browsers in the study area. For G. flavescens, branches were collected above 1.0 m. Branches were collected between 1 and 4 hours after sunrise. Mature (fully expanded) leaves that did not show signs of severe insect herbivory were removed until a fresh mass of 30-50 g was obtained for drying in an oven for 24 hours at 60 °C. The only time we deviated from this approach was at the start of the project in November 2005 when sampling was done at an early stage of leaf growth. Dried leaf samples were milled to pass a sieve with 1.0 mm apertures and were analysed for concentrations of condensed tannins (CT) (Porter et al. 1986; Hattas et al. 2005), total polyphenols (TP) (Price & Butler 1977), Kjeldahl-N (AOAC 1984) and P (Murphy & Riley 1962). Sorghum tannin and gallic acid were used as standards for [CT] and [TP]. Concentrations of neutral detergent fibre (NDF), acid detergent fibre (ADF) and acid detergent lignin (ADL) were determined according to Van Soest et al. (1991). All concentrations were expressed as mg g-1 dry mass. All analyses were conducted at the Department of Botany, University of Cape Town. Because the impact of browsing was variable on sampled trees outside the total exclusion plot, estimates of the proportion (%) of productive (potentially leaf- or shoot-bearing) canopy volume below or above 1.5 m deemed to be missing because of (1) leaf removal, (2) biting of current wet season’s shoots, (3) recent browsing of twigs (previous seasons’ shoots), and (4) accumulated browsing of twigs, was recorded for each tree sampled in January 2008. This method was a subjective method, but it was developed and tested by four observers over the course of four sampling occasions between November 2006 and March 2007. Only one of the four observers who calibrated each other during the development stage did the observations in January 2008. Thirty mature leaves were collected from three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot and control plot in early February 2007 and late March 2007 to identify and quantify specific low molecular weight phenolics (LMWPs). The samples were frozen in liquid N and kept frozen until they were freeze-dried. They were later analysed at the Natural Products Laboratories at Joensuu University, Finland, using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) and HPLC coupled to Mass Spectrophotometry (HPLC-MS) (Julkunen Tiitto et al. 1996; Keski-Saari et al. 2005). LMWP concentrations were determined individually, which allowed later combining into functional groups (phenolic glycosides, flavone aglycosides and hydrolysable tannins). Shoot length Lengths of marked new shoots and new leaves on each species were measured each time leaves were sampled for chemical analysis in the 2006/2007 wet season. Up to 10 new shoots and 10 new leaves on the new shoots were selected on five trees per species in each treatment in the third week of November 2006. The new shoots were selected by randomly locating 10 old shoots (from a previous wet season) per tree. Each selected old shoot was 2-8 mm in basal diameter and 1.5-2.5 m above ground (>1 m for G. flavescens). Old shoots were marked by loosely twisting short pieces of thin “telephone” wire around the shoot base. Colour combinations were used to differentiate individual shoots. The most distal new shoot on each old shoot was marked by painting a small spot of white “correction fluid” (Tippex) at the base. The length of each marked new shoot was measured to the nearest 0.1 cm. Shoots were measured from the base of the shoot to the base of the apical bud. In addition to marking new shoots on A. exuvialis, A. grandicornuta and D. cinerea, which had very few new shoots in November 2006, one leaf cluster was marked on each marked old shoot. The leaf cluster with the longest leaf was marked with a small spot of Tippex painted on the old shoot. The length of the longest leaf on each marked new shoot of all species and the longest leaf in each marked leaf cluster of the “short-shoot” species was measured to the nearest 0.1 mm. Leaves were measured from the base of the petiole to the apex of the midrib (simple leaves) or rachis (compound leaves). None of the A. grandicornuta trees selected for measuring shoot and leaf length had >2 new shoots and the total number of marked new shoots ended up being only 3-5 per treatment. The total number of new shoots marked per treatment for the remaining species was 5-7 on A. exuvialis (1-5 per tree), 1-9 on E. divinorum (1-6 per tree), 40-49 on C. apiculatum (4-10 per tree), 49-50 on G. flavescens (9-10 per tree) and 14-23 on D. cinerea (1-8 per tree). The range in lengths of new shoots was 2.1-6.9 cm in A. exuvialis, 1.0-3.4 cm in E. divinorum, 1.2-3.9 cm in C. apiculatum, 1.2-4.6 cm in G. flavescens and 0.7-6.2 cm in D. cinerea at the time of marking. The low number of new shoots on E. divinorum at the start of the wet season was because of its phenological pattern of producing new shoots later in the season. Each marked shoot that still had an intact apical bud in the first week of December, last week of January and last week of March was re-measured. The longest leaf on each marked shoot was also re-measured. Shoots found to be dead, browsed or missing from the sample population were not replaced. In the first week of November 2007, the lengths of up to 10 randomly selected, unmarked new shoots were measured on each of the trees used for growth measurements in 2006/2007. This time, the objective was to test if there was an effect of herbivore exclusion on shoot length. We did this early in the wet season because as the season progresses many current season’s shoots become damaged and therefore cannot be used to measure effects on growth rate. The early wet season is the best time to find abundant intact new shoots. Photosynthesis. Maximum (light saturated) photosynthesis rate (Amax) was estimated in the total exclusion plot when leaves were sampled for chemical analysis and shoot lengths were measured in the 2006/2007 wet season. Specific leaf area (SLA, m2 g-1) was estimated each time for calculating Amax per unit mass (Amass). Our focus was on two broad-leaf species (C. apiculatum and G. flavescens) because of technical and logistical constraints (i.e., broad leaves are simpler to measure than fine leaves and both species occurred at each sample site on the crest). Amax was estimated using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system (LI-COR, Nebraska, USA). The leaf chamber was fitted with an internal red-blue light source and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) was kept at 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. On each sampling day in the early wet season (7 December 2006), mid wet season (6 February 2007) and late wet season (26 March 2007) we estimated the photosynthetic rate of three individuals per species in the total exclusion plot between 06:30 and 08:30 and assumed that the observations approximated Amax. Preliminary observation in April 2006 had indicated that Amax was likely to be achieved between 06:30 and 08:30. The sampled trees were selected from those used for growth measurements. Each time an individual was observed 3-5 fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. Each individual was observed once during sampling and therefore the observations were instantaneous “snapshots”. Amax was also measured in the control plot (no exclusion) in February 2007 using the same methods. Amax of C. apiculatum and G. flavescens was estimated again in the total exclusion plot and the control plot in November 2007 (early wet season), February 2008 (mid wet season) and December 2008 (early wet season) using a LI-6400 photosynthesis system. The dry conditions that characterised the 2007/2008 wet season resulted in measurements of Amax in March 2008 being abandoned. The main aim on these occasions was to test the exclosure effect, but we used different methods. In November 2007 we collected diurnal data to make sure we measured Amax at the correct time of day. This required us to observe trees close to each other (<15 m apart) so that we could easily obtain a sequence of observations during the day, which meant that we could not observe the trees used for growth measurements because they were about 100 m apart from each other. The LI-6400 was fitted with a clear leaf chamber for diurnal measurements, which required sunny weather. Only C. apiculatum was observed in November because cloudy conditions limited the available time for measurements on G. flavescens. Whenever the leaf chamber was clamped on a leaf, it was positioned at an angle that would permit maximum sunlight to reach the leaf surface. [CO2] in the chamber was maintained at 400 μmol CO2 m-2 s-1. Each time an individual was observed three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement. On two pairs of successive days photosynthetic rates (A) were measured on three individuals 1-2 m tall (19-20 November) and three individuals 2-5 m tall (26-27 November) in close proximity to each other within each plot throughout most of each day starting between 05:30 and 06:00 (30-60 minutes after sunrise). PAR on 26 and 27 November reached saturating levels before 06:30. The shorter trees served as a pilot study before observing the taller trees. In the first week of February 2008 and first week of December 2008 we collected photosynthesis data inside and outside the total exclusion plot by modeling [CO2] response curves. This method gives insights into how internal, biochemical regulators of photosynthesis are responding to external factors by allowing the calculation of carboxylation rates (Vcmax) and electron transport rates (Jmax). The method is also more efficient than estimating Amax on a number of trees during a specific observation period when Amax is assumed to be achieved. Light saturated Amax (at a specific temperature and [CO2]) can be estimated, although values may not be directly comparable to those obtained under ambient conditions when light or temperature are not controlled. The method is not dependent on weather conditions or time of day, which means that more trees can be sampled per day regardless of cloud cover (except in wet weather). In the week of 4-8 February 2008 four individuals of each species were observed in the total exclusion plot and four in the control plot. Three fully expanded new leaves between 1 and 2 m were selected for measurement on each tree. Measurements on each leaf took approximately 15 minutes and four trees could be observed per day between 06:30 and 09:30. The “A-CiCurve” program of the LI-6400 was used to expose each leaf to variable [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 400, 600 and 800 μmol m-2 s-1 (LI-COR 2004). Each leaf was allowed at least 1 minute (but not more than 2) to stabilize after each change in [CO2] before A was logged. [CO2] flow rate was kept at 400 μmol m-2 s-1. PAR was kept at 1500 μmol m-2 s-1 for C. apiculatum and 1100 μmol m-2 s-1 for G. flavescens, while leaf temperature was set at 30 °C, based on light response curves done previously at 25, 30 and 35 °C. Actual leaf temperature averaged 30.8 °C (27.9-34.0 °C). The same procedure was used during the period 4-11 December 2008, except that each leaf was exposed this time to [CO2] following a sequence of 400, 300, 200, 100, 50, 400, 600, 800, 1000 and 1200 μmol m-2 s-1. Two calibrated LI-6400 instruments were used simultaneously each day in the total exclusion plot and control plot. Although the aim was to observe a total of 12 trees per species per plot (8 per day across both plots), technical problems resulted in fewer trees being observed per plot. Actual leaf temperature averaged 29.2 °C (23.7-32.6 °C). Dendrometers Manual dendrometers (Agricultural Electronics Corp., Arizona, USA) were fitted to 90 individuals of 6 species in August 2006 and February 2007 (5 trees per exclusion plot per species). Most of these were the same individuals on which shoot growth was measured in 2006/2007. A few individuals fitted in February 2007 were not the same because new trees were selected at some sites if the original tree selected was found to be not ideal. Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Dendrometer bands were fitted at a height of 20 cm on the dominant stem (usually the tallest) because a preliminary survey indicated that stems were often fused or unevenly shaped below 20 cm. Circumferences at 20 cm were roughly 10-20 cm for G. flavescens, A. exuvialis and D. cinerea, 15-25 cm for E. divinorum, 25-35 cm for C. apiculatum, and 40-50 cm for A. grandicornuta. Low tension dendrometers were used except on the largest A. grandicornuta stems, which had high tension dendrometers fitted. The dendrometers were observed (nearest 0.1 mm) whenever other fieldwork was being done. Dendrometers were adjusted and circumferences re-measured whenever the reading was 0 or >25.0. Up to July 2008, two G. flavescens shrubs (sites 10011 and 10013) in the control plot were uprooted and the dendrometers damaged, a third G. flavescens shrub (site 10014) was partially uprooted (but the dendrometer was undamaged and the stem remained rooted), one A. grandicornuta tree was felled (site 10020) in the control plot, one A. exuvialis tree in the control plot died (site 10013) and a replacement tree was fitted at the same site in November 2006, and two dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were damaged in the partial exclusion plot. Apart from fitting one replacement of A. exuvialis (site 10013) in November 2006, no replacement trees were fitted and no damaged dendrometers were repaired until November 2008. The slow growth rate expected of trees in semi-arid climates and the high variation in circumferences at 20 cm among randomly selected trees led us to presume that exclusion effects could not really be tested until a long-term series of data on relative growth rate becomes available. A further 147 new dendrometers were fitted and 3 repaired or replaced in November 2008 with a view to monitoring a total of 237 dendrometers for the next 4-5 years (Tables 1 and 2). Trees were selected according to the same criteria used to select trees for leaf sampling. Two damaged dendrometers on A. exuvialis trees (sites 10023 and 10024) were repaired and a replacement A. grandicornuta tree was fitted at site 10020. The two uprooted G. flavescens shrubs were not replaced. Seven new trees were fitted per species in each of the two exclusion plots, making the total of 12 per species in each of those plots. Extra dendrometers were fitted in the control plot to allow for estimated losses over the next 5 years. Ten new dendrometers were fitted per species in the control, except for G. flavescens for which 15 new dendrometers were fitted because it seemed to be most susceptible to uprooting (at five sites in the control plot only G. flavescens was fitted). At two sites (10082 and 10087) in the partial exclusion plot no G. flavescens was fitted because no suitable plants were found, but at two sites (10081 and 10083) two G. flavescens were fitted to make up the shortfall. In December 2008, it was found that one of the original five A. exuvialis in the total exclusion plot (site 10004) and two in the partial exclusion plot (sites 10021 and 10022) had died. It was also found that of the new trees fitted in November 2008 two A. exuvialis in the control plot (sites 10054 and 10058) and one in the partial exclusion plot (site 10083) had died. Whether they died as a result of the dendrometers being fitted or as a result of low rainfall in 2008 (or a combination thereof) is unclear. The fact that three trees out of nine that had dendrometers on them since late 2006 did not die for two years, and that other A. exuvialis trees without dendrometers were dead in December 2008 indicates that low rainfall was the main cause of death, but the presence of dendrometers cannot be discounted as a contributing factor. Replacement trees were fitted in March 2009. Table 1. Number of individuals per species that had dendrometers on them in November 2008. data collection The main focus of all the above research was on individuals 2-5 m tall, but other projects were added to the main project in 2007/2008 to focus on various aspects of individuals shorter than 1.5 m at the exclusion plots (see report submitted to SANParks in September 2007). These projects on short trees were done to study (1) chemical defences, nutrients, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum in relation to season and browsing, (2) population structure, and community composition in relation to exclusion and soil type, and (3) physical defences of A. grandicornuta and A. exuvialis in relation to exclusion. The study on the chemistry, growth and photosynthesis of A. grandicornuta, D. cinerea, G. flavescens and C. apiculatum followed basically the same procedures as the “main” study, except for the following differences. Leaves were collected from 10 randomly selected plants (40-50 leaves per plant) per treatment plot per species during the periods 25- 31 Oct 2007, 13-16 Nov 2007, 31 Jan 2008, and 17-19 March 2008. No plants of A. grandicornuta were sampled in November 2007 because suitable individuals were not found at most of the random points visited. The leaves were oven-dried at 60 °C and analysed for concentrations of N, P and condensed tannins. Ten plants per treatment plot were randomly selected in September 2007 and their heights and stem circumferences (at 10cm) were measured. New shoots were marked and their lengths measured on these plants (5 shoots per plant) during the period 23-24 Oct 2007. The lengths of the marked shoots were re-measured during the periods 29-30 Oct 2007, 6 Dec 2007, 1 Feb 2008 and 17-19 Mar 2008. The heights and stem circumferences were re-measured in March 2008. The trees used for shoot growth measurements were used for leaf sampling in March 2008, as well as for photosynthesis measurements in November, February and March. Photosynthesis rate was measured for 3 leaves on each marked C. apiculatum and G. flavescens plant in the total exclusion plot and the control plot between 06:00 and 09:30 on 13-14 November 2007. Responses of photosynthesis to a range of [CO2] were measured for C. apiculatum in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the period 28-30 November 2007 (PAR=1500; Temp = 30 °C), and again for both C. apiculatum and G. flavescens in the total exclusion plot and the control plot during the periods 6-13 February 2008 and 20-21 March 2008. Measurements were for three plants per treatment per species, except in March when two plants were measured per treatment per species. For the other studies of plants <1.5 m, transects were surveyed in November and December 2007. Thirty 2x40m transects were randomly placed in each of the three treatments (15 on crest and 15 on footslope) using the same 30x30 m grid mentioned previously. The starting point for each transect was the centre of each grid cell, which was located using a GPS. All transects were placed north of the fire break in the total exclusion plot and south of the fire break in the partial exclusion plot, and well within the borders of each vegetation type. No transects were placed within 30 m of firebreaks or fences. The anomalous area of vegetation in the partial exclusion plot mentioned above was excluded. Between crest and footslope a 30 m zone was observed where no transects were placed. At each starting point, a magnetic compass was used to drag a 20-m chain in a straight line towards magnetic north. At every 1-m mark on the chain we recorded whether or not a line projected up or down intercepted either woody or herbaceous canopy to estimate canopy cover. The species, height (cm), number of stems <1 cm diameter, number of stems >1 cm diameter, and the diameter of the largest stem of every woody plant within 1 m of the chain was recorded. Stem diameters were estimated at 1 cm above ground (i.e., immediately above the basal swelling of the stem). Stems more than 50 cm apart were considered separate individuals. Browsing of individuals shorter than 150 cm was estimated using a method based on the one described above. Browsing estimations included leaf herbivory (% of total leaf area lost), number of unbrowsed/browsed shoots (except where there were too many shoots to count, in which case proportion shoots browsed was estimated) and accumulated browsing (% total biomass above ground lost). Evidence of browsing by black rhino (angular bites) was also recorded. Only browsing by mammals was recorded and shoots were only recorded as browsed when the apex had been removed. For the accumulated browsing no distinction was made between actual browsing and breakage, since elephants can break branches and stems to gain access to certain parts of a plant. There are problems with browsing estimations such as these. First there can be differences depending on who does the estimation, which was avoided by ensuring that the same people did the estimates in all treatments. Secondly a plant may have been browsed in the past but in such a way that it is very difficult to see, and as a result there might be over estimation of unbrowsed individuals. The first individual of Acacia exuvialis or Acacia grandicornuta in each transect was chosen for shoot measurements. Individuals were not chosen if taller than 150 cm or if the accumulated browsing exceeded 50 %, because taller trees would be difficult to measure, and very heavily browsed trees could be too damaged to respond to treatment effects. The selected plants also had to have at least five measurable annual shoots. In cases where no such tree could be found within a transect, the closest suitable tree to the transect starting point (without entering the vicinity of another point) was selected. On the chosen individual, 5-10 annual shoots were selected randomly (the number depending on how many could be found). On these shoots, measurements of shoot length, longest leaf, number of spines and the longest spine in each pair of spines were taken. All spines shorter than 2 mm were excluded. Shoot length was measured from the shoot base to the base of the apical bud, and spine length from spine base to spine tip. The length of each leaf was measured from the base of the petiole to the base of the terminal pinnae.

browse, catena, dendrometer, elephants, forage quality, herbivores, nutrients, phenolics, photosynthesis, plant community, plant population, shoot growth, shrubs, spines, stem growth, tannins, trees
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Fire in savannas is instrumental in creating heterogeneous vegetation structures and a patchwork landscape in savannas. The frequency and season of fire have a direct effect on plant community composition and vegetation structure. In turn this has implications for faunal composition and diversity, since vegetation provides both habitat and food for herbivores. This study found that burn regime has a marked effect on both the structure and composition of the floral components. Infrequently burnt sites have a higher proportion of larger trees and denser tree and grass cover. These sites were dominated by climax, decreaser and mostly palatable grasses. More frequently burned sites have fewer large trees and more small trees. Frequent fires continually knock back woody vegetation to small sizes. This fire trap results in a high proportion of seedlings and gullivers. Grass communities mainly comprise pioneer increasers of moderate to low palatability. Ant species richness increased with increasing canopy cover, possibly because more canopy results in a greater diversity of thermal niches. Bird communities closely followed variation in vegetation due to differing burn regiments. Bird communities in more frequently burned sites were more closely related to each other than less frequently burned sites. These findings support the policy of managers of Kruger National Park with respect to promoting patch heterogeneity. Heterogeneity of ecosystems does indeed promote biodiversity of fauna in all its natural facets and fluxes. Fire is a powerful tool for managers hoping to drive this heterogeneity.
Carla Staver and Taryn Morris SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Problem
Carla Staver and Taryn Morris SANParks, South Africa Faculty Field Problem
Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa

Kruger National Park management established a series of experimental burn plots (EBPs) in 1954. These burn plots are found in four areas of the park and within each of the four areas includes four burn strings. Each string consists of twelve burn treatments of various burn frequency and season (Van Wilgen et al. 2003). Our study was conducted in three of the four strings in the Pretoriuskop EBPs. Where possible we sampled the same burn season and frequency treatments across the three strings but due to herbivore exclusion experiments, access to some of the plots was restricted (Table 1). In each plot we ran one transect of 150 m, collecting a variety of vegetation structure and animal presence data. Within two meters of the transect, we the height and species of each tree. Every two meters along the transect, we noted the closest species of grass to the transect, with species, from which we calculated relative species abundance. Every fifteen meters along the transect, we calculated canopy cover and determined foliage profiles using boards 2m high and 10cm wide, divided into height classes of 25cm. We measured the distance from the point at which 50% of each height class (25 cm, 50 cm, 75 cm, 1 m, 1.5 m, and 2 m) on the board was obscured. The reciprocal of this distance is directly proportional to foliage density and is thus an approximation of the vertical distribution of biomass. Evidence of large herbivores (dung) was also assessed within 2m2 of the transect line. To determine butterfly species richness, all butterfly species within sight of the transect line were counted to yield a count of butterfly species richness. Bird species richness and ant diversity were determined independent of the transect. Bird species seen or heard were recorded for each site visited over a period of 1.5 hrs. Only the data from the first three samples were used, as activity of birds decreased in the warmer periods later in the morning. Ant diversity was determined using pitfall traps set out overnight in each of four burn plots (Numbi and Shabeni no burn and August annual burn plots). We set out two pitfall traps every 10 m along a 40 m transect, giving 8 replicates for each site. Data analysis Foliage profiles, size class distributions and grass characteristics were graphed using Microsoft Excel 2002. Multi-dimensional scaling community analyses were generated using Primer 5. Primer 5 was also used to determine the Shannon wiener indices. The relationship between time of day and bird diversity was generated in Statistica 6.1.

The effects of fire on vegetation structure and habitat in broadleaf savannas
The effects of fire on vegetation structure and habitat in broadleaf savannas
Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa

The Phugwane River in the northern Kruger National Park is flanked by bare sodic sites, of which Salvadora angustifolia Turril var. australis (Schweik.) Verdoon is the dominant woody species which grows in characteristic islands associated with undercanopy vegetation. Little vegetation grows between these islands, and this has led to the hypothesis that Salvadora australis is an ecosystem engineer of sodic sites, modulating soil properties which allows other vegetation to grow. A differential browsing response on these trees across sites also occurs. An investigation was undertaken to assess differences in physical and chemical properties of the soil under the canopy of trees and away from trees. Foliar chemistry, browsing response and tree physiognomy across sites was also assessed. Soil under trees showed significantly decreased sodicity, concentrations of extractable sodium and magnesium and increased concentrations of calcium, C: N ratio and proportions of larger soil particles. Trees also increase in size and possibly age towards the riparian and upland boundaries of sites. Size was not correlated to a salinity gradient in the soil under trees or in the leaves of trees. This species has been shown to be a halophyte that accumulates sodium in the leaves at increasing concentrations with higher external salinity concentrations. It also performs selective portioning of ions as a tolerance strategy where old leaves have higher sodium concentrations and lower potassium concentrations than younger leaves. Browsing preference was not correlated with higher sodium concentrations of trees or leaves. By inferring mechanisms of solute and water movement, this species has been shown to be an ecosystem engineer of the soil properties underneath it, which results in a better growing environment for other plants. This increases habitat heterogeneity across sites and species richness under canopies of trees. The increased biodiversity this species engineers has important managerial implications for Kruger National Park and demonstrates the importance of ecosystem engineers in semi-arid savanna ecosystems.

Content: Soil and Leaf Sample Collection Ten trees were sampled at each site along a transect running the length of the bare patch perpendicular to the river to establish a gradient across the site to the river. The boundaries of the bare patch were characterised by vegetation and soil change from bare hard crusty soils to darker, more vegetated looser soils. The transect started from the riparian boundary of the bare area (characterised by occurrence of Colophospermum mopane and riparian vegetation) to the upland boundary (characterised by increasing frequency of C. mopane trees and decreasing frequency of S. australis. Two soil cores were dug with an auger for each tree, with one at the base of the tree under the canopy and the other in bare soils, 1.5m from the edge of the canopy. Soil samples were taken every 20cm till one metre deep (0-20cm; 20-40cm; 40-60cm; 60-80cm; 80-100cm) with a total of 10 samples per tree. Soil was placed in brown paper bags, sifted through a 2mm sieve to mix the sample, and remove roots and gravel and dried at 65°C. The auger holes were back-filled with surrounding soil after the samples were removed. Leaf samples were taken as a bulked sample from the whole canopy for each tree. This was then separated into young and old leaves, based on position on the stem and size of the leaf. The leaves were then dipped in deionized water to remove dust on the surface. Care was taken to avoid salt contamination by the use of latex gloves and minimal handling of leaves. The leaves were then dried at 55 °C until dry and easily broken. Three additional trees of different size classes were sampled for texture analysis: 1 small, heavily browsed shrub (height =39cm), a medium shrub with a definite browse line (height =210cm), and a large tree that shows evidence of relatively little browsing (height =340cm). A trench was dug from the base of the tree to ~1.5m away from the edge of the canopy. Soil samples were taken in horizons to a depth of 60cm, at intervals every 50cm along the trench for the small and medium trees and every 100cm for the large tree. Soil was investigated in the field for texture, colour, frequency of roots and occurrence of soil biota. For these samples, texture analysis was performed in the laboratory by hydrometer method. This method uses sodium hexametamosphate to separate particles of different sizes from each other in a soil solution. The solution thoroughly mixed with an electrical stirrer and then left to settle for different periods when readings on the hydrometer are taken (40 seconds for %silt (20-50µm); 4 minutes for %silt (<2-20µm) and 2 hours for % clay (<2 µm)). % sand (50-2000µm) was calculated as the remaining percent. Calculations are corrected for temperature and moisture of the soil. pH and electroconductivity were also measured using hand-held field pH and E.C. meters in a 20g soil: 50ml deionised water solution (Anderson and Ingram, 1996). Soil was sent to the Agricultural Research Council where it was analysed for total nitrogen by automated Kjedahl method, and carbon by modified Walkley-Black method. Tree physiognomy Tree physiognomy data were collected for each tree: - tree height - canopy diameter at the longest length - Average stem circumference - Browse height if actively browsed tree Tree height was measured using a tape measure and/or ranging rod and taken from the base of the tree. Average stem circumference was determined from individual stem circumferences measured above the basal swelling of the tree. Browse height was taken as the height of very short trees that are browsed low, and from the ground to the bottom of a browse line on other trees. Trees that showed no browse line were given a score of 0. The distance from each tree to the centre of the transect and sodic site was also estimated using a hand-held Garmin G.P.S. (with accuracy of ~1m). Undercanopy Species Composition Undercanopy woody and grass species were collected for each tree to asses species richness and composition. The species were pressed and identified in the Wits herbarium. Some specimens could not be conclusively identified as they were collected in the dry season and exhibited few taxonomic features. Large Herbivore Exclosure Experiment An exclosure experiment was set up in order to determine if herbivores are selecting for leaves with particular nutrient concentrations such as higher sodium on individual trees. Actively browsed trees from each site along the transect were selected with 2 near the outer edge of the site and one in the centre (n =9). Leaves were removed from branches that showed evidence of herbivory (leaves removed or ends of stems nipped) representing leaves that had not been selected by herbivores (pre-exclosure sample). The branches from which, these leaves had been removed, were marked with pink plastic ribbon. An exclosure was then constructed of 5mm green wire mesh, metal fence droppers and cable ties or coated flexible wire. For very small bushes, the entire bush was fenced off using the fencing droppers hammered into the ground (see figure 4 in the appendix). Individual browsed branches on larger trees were exclosed. Here the mesh was wrapped around the branch to bag the branch and tied using cable ties and wire (see figure 5 in the appendix). Where the wire bag was hard to see, white latex gloves were tied to it to prevent danger to any animals. Care was taken on all exclosures to ensure that the wire did not touch the growing shoots. Nine weeks later I sampled leaves that had grown on the marked branches subsequent to the exclosure being erected (post-exclosure sample) as leaves that would have been browsed had herbivores not been prevented from feeding. Old leaves were also collected from within the exclosure to compare to the new post-exclosure leaves. Some exclosures were damaged by elephants and on one (44/5), the exclosure was removed and the tree appeared to have been subsequently browsed, therefore no sample was taken. Some branches also did not have sufficient leaf growth to sample for old leaves (68/5; 44/8). The exclosures were then dismantled and removed. Leaf samples were dried and milled for further analysis. Soil and Leaf Chemistry Determination Electrical conductivity and pH measurements were taken in the laboratory. The soil was sent to the Agricultural Research Council (ARC) in Pretoria for cation and SAR analysis. Soil samples from the first 8 trees from the upland side of site 83 were analysed for SAR as they showed high E.C. values in comparison with other trees. SAR was determined from a saturated paste extract using the Dumas method. The same soil samples from site 83 and samples from the exclosure trees from each site were analysed for selected extractable cations (Na+; Ca2+; Mg2+) and cation exchange capacity (CEC). Extractable cation analysis was by ammonium acetate extraction method (Anderson and Ingram, 1996), and determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy. The dried leaf samples were milled to 0.5mm using a plant mill and sent to the Agricultural Research Council for selected nutrient analysis. The samples were analysed for Na+; Ca2+; Mg2+; K+; P using a mixed acid digestion and determined on an atomic absorption spectrophotometer.

An open-access article in the journal Koedoe introducing and describing the supersites can be downloaded from: http://www.koedoe.co.za/index.php/koedoe/article/viewFile/1107/1488 This article is accompanied by an online appendix providing further useful information regarding the supersites (see below), which can be downloaded from: http://www.koedoe.co.za/index.php/koedoe/article/viewFile/1107/1480 In the article the following information is provided: • Rational for supersites • Selection criteria for supersites • Process followed for selecting supersites • Management of supersites and management of research projects on supersites • Data access for supersites Furthermore, the following background data and description for each supersite is provided: • Map showing location, drainage network, and access routes • Phenology/seasonality • Long-term average: o Rainfall o Herbivore biomass (per feeding guild) o Herbaceous biomass o Woody cover o Fire history In addition, the online appendix provides the following information: • Morphometric features of land types in which supersites occur • Landforms, soils and dominant vegetation associated with the landsystems in which the supersites occur • Hydrogeological characteristics for the regions within which the supersites occur • Annual rainfall for the supersites since 1940 • Historical average herbivore density for supersites (per species) • Job-row-image codes for historical NGI (formerly CD:SM) aerial photography • Aerial and ground photos for supersites (examples) • Maps, showing supersites in relation to park-wide: o Infrastructure (roads and camps) o Long-term average annual rainfall o Physiographic zones o Geology o Altitude and large rivers o Mean annual A-pan equivalent evaporation o Long-term fire return period o Woody cover o Herbivore (grazer, browser, mixed feeder and total herbivore) biomass o Long-term dry-season elephant density o Site locations and site identification numbers of Venter (1990) and VCA surveys on our within 5 km from supersites.

Method The method for determining the number of animals and species utilizing the EBP is a relatively simple one and will consist of driving along the plots on a daily basis at differing but rotational times and recording the number of animals, the activity the animal is undertaking,(either resting grazing or unknown.ie passing through, and finally recording the species of animals on each plot.(see fig 1). The distance to each animal or group of animals will also be determined by means of a laser rangefinder, to enable the observers to calculate animal density per unit area.Some of the plots differ in that they lay on both sides of the road. In this scenario the sides that are furthest away from the road will be monitored. Seeing that an experiment in a specific vegetation type consists of four replications of 12 treatments, e.g. four blocks of plots lying some distance apart, the route travelled for making observations will have to go along all four blocks. To avoid visiting the same plots or blocks at the same time every day the route taken each day will be varied, thus ensuring some degree of randomisation as far as time of observation at a specific plot can be obtained. Figure 2 illustrates a route covering all the plots and replicates of specific vegetation type in a randomised fashion. Skukuza Blocks: 1.Skukuza 2.Napi 3.Mbyamiti 4.Nwaswitshaka ? ? ? ? Vegetation and Soil type: Mixed Bushwillow Woodlands, Thorn Thickets On granite Pretoriuskop Blocks: 1.Kambeni 2.Fayi 3.Shabani 4.Numbi ? ? ? ? Vegetation and Soil type: Sourveld on Granite Satara Blocks: 1.Lindanda 2.Marhaya 3.Nwanedzi 4.Satara Vegetation and Soil type: Knob Thorn / Marula Savannah on Basalt Method that we will use to ensure randomisation of the observations. For the Skukuza and the Pretoriuskop blocks there will be a simple method of rotation. The observations will begin between 7.30am and 8.00am and the final observations will be made between 4.30pm and 5.00pm. The observations for these two plots will take place over two days the first day starting from the Skukuza end and finishing at the Pretoriuskop plots. The second days observing will start at the Pretoriuskop plots and finish at the Skukuza Blocks, whilst following a strict rotation aswell, to ensure randomisation. This is illustrated below. Each plot has a number, as shown above and these will rotate as follows: Block 1 2 3 4 Observation route: 1 2 3 4 2 3 4 1 3 4 1 2 4 1 2 3 This system cannot apply to the Satara Blocks since distance is much greater between the blocks. These plots will follow a system of observation in a system always following the path of two routes. First route: Starting from Skukuza and monitoring Block 1 (Lindanda) from there to blocks 2,3 and 4 in succession, monitoring the last block between 4.30pm and 5.00pm. The second route is the exact reverse of this however the final block, Lindanda, will be monitored at around 3.00pm in order for there be time to return to Skukuza. Blocks 3 and 4, the Satara and Nwanedzi blocks will be rotated within themselves since they are not too far apart from each other. Once rain has made an impact on the plots then the vegetation change will also be monitored. Rain gauges? will monitor the rainfall on all the blocks. This will also be recorded.

The study investigates the effects that changing herbivory patterns in the Northern Plains of Kruger National Park have had on vegetation structure and composition and on soil characteristics, both chemical and physical. Type I herbivores such as zebra and buffalo have encroached into the area, which has been historically inhabited by type II herbivores such as roan and sable. The study found that the more intense and less selective grazing associated with type I herbivores has had a marked effect on vegetation and soil chemical characteristics. Overall grass and tree cover has decreased, and the size of the remaining trees is reduced. Colophospermum mopane seems to thrive especially under disturbance conditions. Calcium, available phosphorus, salinity, and pH have homogenized under the influence of type I grazers, while organic carbon and total nitrogen have diversified. Differential land use patterns and grazing habits of type I and type II herbivores may drive these changes. However, until these patterns are better understood, their role in determining vegetation and soil properties will remain unclear.
Carla Staver SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Carla Staver SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
herbivory, Northern Plains, soil nutrients, vegetation

The roan enclosure directly north of Shingwedzi provides an ideal location in which to examine the effects of herbivory and vegetation structure on soil characteristics in the Northern Plains. The enclosure lies on olivine-rich basalt in the Karoo geologic sequence and receives between 350 and 450 mm of rainfall per year. The enclosure was established in 1968 in an area upslope from a river; riparian and fluvial zones were added to the enclosure in 1985. This study examined upslope areas, where vegetation structure and soils have had more time to adjust to the exclusion of herbivory. The roan enclosure is divided into four quarters. One lies on black soil, which is dominated by marula (Sclerocarya birrea) and knobthorn (Acacia nigrescens), and was burnt 4-5 years ago. Fifteen sites were sampled in this quarter of the roan enclosure. The remainder of the enclosure lies on mopane-veld (dominated by Colophospermum mopane), characterized by red soils, which extends beyond the fence of the enclosure. Fifteen plots were sampled in the south-west corner of the enclosure, an area dominated by C. mopane, which was burned 4-5 years ago. Corresponding plots were sampled outside the enclosure on each soil type (see Figure 1 for a map of the enclosure with sampling layout). The fifteen plots in each site lie every 30 meters along three transects. These transects run parallel to the slope of the hill in order to minimize bias from effects of down-slope water, nutrient, and small particle flow on soil properties. The following parameters were sampled in each plot: • Trees within 400m2 circle (r=11.3): species, height, DBH • Grasses within circle of 2m radius: species, abundance, total cover • Soil samples at the center of these circles Soil nutrients (total N, available P, Ca) were analyzed at a soil lab according to the standard method. Soil pH was determined using the method outlined by Rowell (1994), using a 1:2.5 ratio of soil to 0.01 M CaCl2 solution. Conductivity was determined with a 1:5 ratio of soil to water and converted to standard-scale conductivity (ECe) using the method outlined by Landon (1991). Volumetric soil moisture content was determined by weighing soil moisture samples and then drying them at 105oC for 24 hours. Porosity was determined in the field using a surrogate measure; I measured the absorption time of 100 mL of water over an area of ~20 cm2. I used a field method for determining soil texture outlined by Tongway and Hindley (1995).

The roan enclosure directly north of Shingwedzi provides an ideal location in which to examine the effects of herbivory and vegetation structure on soil characteristics in the Northern Plains. The enclosure lies on olivine-rich basalt in the Karoo geologic sequence and receives between 350 and 450 mm of rainfall per year. The enclosure was established in 1968 in an area upslope from a river; riparian and fluvial zones were added to the enclosure in 1985. This study examined upslope areas, where vegetation structure and soils have had more time to adjust to the exclusion of herbivory. The roan enclosure is divided into four quarters. One lies on black soil, which is dominated by marula (Sclerocarya birrea) and knobthorn (Acacia nigrescens), and was burnt 4-5 years ago. Fifteen sites were sampled in this quarter of the roan enclosure. The remainder of the enclosure lies on mopane-veld (dominated by Colophospermum mopane), characterized by red soils, which extends beyond the fence of the enclosure. Fifteen plots were sampled in the south-west corner of the enclosure, an area dominated by C. mopane, which was burned 4-5 years ago. Corresponding plots were sampled outside the enclosure on each soil type (see Figure 1 for a map of the enclosure with sampling layout). The fifteen plots in each site lie every 30 meters along three transects. These transects run parallel to the slope of the hill in order to minimize bias from effects of down-slope water, nutrient, and small particle flow on soil properties. The following parameters were sampled in each plot: • Trees within 400m2 circle (r=11.3): species, height, DBH • Grasses within circle of 2m radius: species, abundance, total cover • Soil samples at the center of these circles Soil nutrients (total N, available P, Ca) were analyzed at a soil lab according to the standard method. Soil pH was determined using the method outlined by Rowell (1994), using a 1:2.5 ratio of soil to 0.01 M CaCl2 solution. Conductivity was determined with a 1:5 ratio of soil to water and converted to standard-scale conductivity (ECe) using the method outlined by Landon (1991). Volumetric soil moisture content was determined by weighing soil moisture samples and then drying them at 105oC for 24 hours. Porosity was determined in the field using a surrogate measure; I measured the absorption time of 100 mL of water over an area of ~20 cm2. I used a field method for determining soil texture outlined by Tongway and Hindley (1995).
Biotic determinants of soil characteristics in the Northern Plains of Kruger National Park
Biotic determinants of soil characteristics in the Northern Plains of Kruger National Park
herbivory, Northern Plains, soil nutrients, vegetation

Given the detrimental effects of the artificial watering program in the Kruger National Park, a number of artificial watering points have been closed. This study examined the effect of waterhole closures in the Shingwedzi area on rodent populations through live trapping methods, with particular attention paid to abundance, richness, and diversity. In contrast to similar studies conducted near Punda Maria, we did not find a significant difference between the populations around closed versus open waterholes. As rodents can be used as environmental indicators, this suggests that closure of waterholes alone is not enough to improve the biodiversity of these disturbed sites. Further studies should consider seasonality, as this was a winter assessment.
Jennifer Mizen and Bryan Barnhill SANParks, South Africa Independent Project I
Jennifer Mizen and Bryan Barnhill SANParks, South Africa Independent Project I
artificial waterholes, biodiversity, rodents, Sherman traps

The study sites consisted of two open and two closed artificial watering holes. The sites were chosen by soil type, absence of recent burning from wildfire, and operational status. The soil type at all of the sites was basalt, in order to control for differences in resource availability due to vegetation. Thirty Sherman traps were used at each site, arranged in two 3 x 5 arrays with traps set 10 meters apart. Approximately equal numbers of short and long Sherman traps were used in each array. The arrays were positioned on opposite sides of the watering troughs at sites 1, 2, and 3, and on adjacent 69 sides of the trough at site 4. At sites 1, 2 and 3 the arrays began 20 meters from watering trough, as measured from the short sides of the trough at the first two sites and the long sides of the trough at the third site. The arrays at site 4 began 50 meters from the water trough. The traps were placed under bushes and/or in long grass and covered with grass or leaves for camouflage as well as protection from the heat of the sun. The traps were positioned and baited on the morning of September 21, and checked for the next three mornings. A mixture of peanut butter, honey, and oats was used as bait. The bait was then changed to a mixture of peanut butter with oats and honey for the remainder of the trapping time. Individuals captured were uniquely marked with hair dye or permanent marker, in order to note recapture. Each rodent’s weight, sex and species were recorded before release in the proximity of the trap. Data were compiled and analyzed using Microsoft Excel and Primer 5. The capture rate was calculated by dividing the number of successful captures by the total trapping effort (“trap days”), taking into account the loss of several traps during the course of the study due to trampling. G-tests were preformed to determine the significance of the open versus closed sites in terms of trap success and on short versus long trap use on trap success. Richness and abundance were also calculated for each site as measures of number of species found and numbers of individuals captured, respectively. Data from the 2004 and 2005 studies were rendered comparable to this study, then all three studies were analyzed in reference to each other. Shannon-Weiner tests were used to determine diversity indices for all eight sites studied between 2004 and 2006. Data were log-transformed before multidimensional scaling (MDS) ordination.

Is the reduction of the water provisioning program accomplishing desired goals?: The influence of waterhole closure near Shingwedzi on small mammal diversity
Is the reduction of the water provisioning program accomplishing desired goals?: The influence of waterhole closure near Shingwedzi on small mammal diversity
artificial waterholes, biodiversity, rodents, Sherman traps

The issue of waterholes is a critical one for Kruger Park management. Though initially constructed to boost numbers of antelope and other animal species, many studies have demonstrated the negative effects of artificial waterholes, which create a zone of decreased biodiversity known as a piosphere (Gaylard et al.). One year prior to our study, students from the Organization of Tropical Studies did a rodent trapping study to examine the effects of artificial waterholes on rodent diversity by comparing rodent communities at an open waterhole and one that had been inactive for two years. We used similar live-trapping methods to examine the effects of one more year of inactivity at the closed waterhole, as well as the effects of a burn that had occurred at the closed waterhole within the past year. Similar to the previous study, we found significantly greater rodent and grass diversity at the closed waterhole. The overall rodent abundance was lower for our study than the previous study, likely due to the decreased grass cover at both sites. We also found dramatically increased numbers of the bushveld gerbil, Tatera leucogaster, at the burned site, supporting the notion that burning has an effect on rodent species composition.

Live trapping method Live trapping study. In order to compare our trapping data to those from the previous year, we used the same open and closed waterholes as our study sites (open: 22°42’18" S, 31°09’43" E; closed: 22°49’40" S, 31°14’21" E, see Figure 1). Live trapping was conducted over 4 days (April 9-12, 2005). Two trapping grids were laid out on either side of the water troughs. We attempted to replicate the orientation and exact location of the grids in last year’s study, which had been placed approximately 20m from the waterholes to avoid severe overgrazing and trampling. Each grid included 30 traps (5 × 6) spaced 10 m apart. Within each line of traps we used two long Sherman traps (8 × 9.5 × 30 cm) and four short (8 × 9 × 23 cm). The distribution of the long traps within each row was randomized. To prevent any animals from experiencing hypothermia due to the damp conditions at the beginning of the study, pieces of synthetic stuffing were placed in each trap to absorb water and provide additional insulation. Traps were baited with seed each evening and were checked each morning. The traps were left open throughout the day and night. We identified each trapped individual with a unique marking using black hair dye. We used a single numbering system for both grids at each site in case individuals crossed between the grids. The mass, sex, approximate age class and species was recorded for each individual. vegetation survey . During our initial assessment of the study sites, it was noted that the vegetation was considerably sparser and drier than the previous year, and that the closed waterhole site had burned recently (see Figure 2). We assessed the vegetation at each grid along 100 m transects, which were laid out from the periphery of the water trough through the center of the grid. At 10 m intervals we estimated visibility perpendicular to the transect at heights of 10 and 50 cm. This was done by measuring the distance at which >50 percent of an object was obscured when viewed from each of the two heights. We used these heights as a representation of the effects of grass cover on rodent visibility, assuming that visibility plays a role in habitat preference. Percent grass cover was estimated every ten meters within a 50 cm × 50 cm quadrat. We measured grass species composition by identifying the grass species closest to the transect line every 2 m along the transect. Startistical analyses We used Microsoft Excel to compile our data and Stats Alive to perform ratio analyses to determine whether there was a significantly higher trap success rate in long versus short traps or any significant edge effect. All other statistical analyses were performed using Primer and Statistica. Using Primer, we calculated species similarity values for the vegetation transects and rodent trapping gridsand we calculated the Simpson’s diversity index for the grass community at each grid. We used Simpson’s measure of alpha diversity because it produces a weighted species richness measure using the probability of selecting two individuals of the same species at random from the same community. We used Statistica to perform t-tests to look for significant differences between the open and closed transects in terms of the percent grass cover and visibility. We used the Peterson method to estimate the population of rodents at each site, which uses the unbiased estimator equation: N = (((M+1)(C+1))/(R+1)) -1, where M = number of individuals marked in the first sample, C = total number of individuals captured in the second sample and R = number of individuals in second sample that are marked (Krebs 1999). We combined the capture numbers for both grids within each site to avoid overestimating the population since there had been crossover of individuals between grids.

In this study, we examined whether leaf presence affected ant abundances on Acacia grandicornuta, and how the presence of scale insects on Acacia robusta affected ant species abundance. In order to asses the benefits accrued by the plants, we also tested attack times of three genera of ants following a disturbance to the host tree. It was determined that both ant species richness and concentration were significantly greater on A. grandicornuta containing leaves. This result suggests that the presence of leaves drives the mutualism between A. grandicornuta and ants, and when leaves are not present, ant concentrations decrease. We also determined that Black Sugar Ants (Lepisiota capensis) exist in greater abundance on A. robusta when scale insects are present, and this populace of L. capensis correlates to a reduction in the abundance of other ant species. Finally, our results show that L. capensis attack significantly quicker than other ant genera following a disturbance to the host tree. This demonstrates the ability of L. capensis to colonize and dominate a host tree, causing a significant decrease in the abundance of other ant genera. These results convey that a facultative mutualism exists among A. robusta, L. capensis, and scale insects; L. capensis provides protection for both A. robusta and scale insects, while scale insects offer nutritional benefits to the resident ants.

Site selection and Field sampling This study was conducted in and around the Skukuza rest camp of Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga province, South Africa (24°98” S 31°60” E). We conducted and performed all field work for our study and subsequent experiment over the course of a three day period from October 10, 2005 to October 12, 2005, near the end of the dry season. Our study species were Acacia grandicornuta and Acacia robusta. A. grandicornuta is a medium-sized tree with deep fissured bark and paired, short thorns, and is often found on either sodic or clay soils throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa. A. grandicornuta is tolerant of dry conditions and is normally leafless from August to October. A. robusta is a single-stemmed tree with paired, straight, modified stipules as thorns and an annual leaf presence. A. robusta tends to grow throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa, typically near a water source and it rarely occurs in homogeneous stands. Neither A. grandicornuta nor A. robusta are known to produce extra floral nectaries, food bodies or beltian bodies (Smit 1999). We examined 26 Acacia grandicornuta individuals—12 possessing leaves and 14 lacking leaves—all located in and around the staff village of the Skukuza main camp, primarily near the golf course. We chose to observe A. grandicornuta in order to compare the status of this facultative ant-plant mutualism when leaves were present and absent. This was possible as A. grandicornuta loses its leaves from late August to early October, thus yielding a sufficient abundance of individuals with and without leaves. We then examined 14 Acacia robusta individuals—all of which possessed leaves. For each A. grandicornuta and A. robusta individual encountered, we recorded a number of observations: the average abundance of ants, ant species composition, the presence or absence of scale insects, and the degree of defensive behavior of the ants on each tree. The abundance of ants on each tree was obtained by selecting two .25m by .5m sections, estimating the number of ants per section, and averaging the two abundance measures. We identified our ant samples down to genus, and in one instance down to species. Following our initial study, we conducted a subsequent experiment in which we generated an artificial disturbance. To mimic natural herbivory processes we scratched the trunk of the tree while simultaneously shaking a branch. Analysis Mann-Whitney U-tests were performed to test for significant differences in ant abundance dependent on leaf presence and scale insect presence in A. grandicornuta and A. robusta respectively. A Kruskal-Wallis test was conducted to determine differences in attack time among three ant genera.

Addo Elephent National Park, South Africa

Herbaceous biomass is a dynamic feature in the Kruger National Park (KNP), changing across space and over time. Rainfall, geology, herbivory and fire are four of the main drivers influencing the large-scale distribution of herbaceous biomass in semi-arid savanna systems like Kruger. Knowing how herbaceous biomass are distributed in the landscape is important since it (i) act as fuel load for fires, (ii) serve as forage for grazers, and (iii) create patches and habitats for different components of biodiversity. The rangers and field rangers collect disc pasture meter readings annually throughout the KNP at Veld Condition Assessment (VCA) sites (Appendix A). Making use of a calibration equation, these readings are translated into herbaceous biomass estimates (Appendix B) which are then used by SANParks’ Fire Ecologist (Navashni Govender) to set fire targets for the different ranger sections.

Female Platysaurus rhodesianus are brown and vertically striped, while males are brightly coloured. Though Platysaurus are generally considered ambush foragers, P. broadleyi exhibit plastic foraging behaviour. Further, vertical stripes are generally indicative of active foraging, suggesting that female P. rhodesianus might be active foragers. We investigate whether male and female P. rhodesianus differ in foraging strategy, using a focal animal analysis to measure both the proportion of time spent moving (PTM) and the proportion of attacks made while moving (PAM). No significant difference was found between the proportions of time that males and females spent moving. When compared with the traditional critical value of PTM that distinguishes active foragers from ambush foragers, both males and females were found to be active foragers.

Methods Focal animal analysis was used to observe the behaviour of male and female P. rhodesianus individuals in Mapungubwe National Park, located on the north-east border of South Africa. Several observations were made within Leokwe Camp (S 22°13.06’, E 29°21.81’), where lizards were found on large boulders, bare rock surfaces, and a wooden decking bordering a swimming pool. Observations on these lizards were recorded as habituated to the presence of humans. The other observations were performed on bare rocky faces in the cliffs around Leokwe camp and a variety of slopes and aspects were present at these sites. Different areas within the three sites were used for each observation session to ensure that the same lizards were not observed twice. Behaviours were categorised as either moving or still; if the subject paused for less than 10 seconds between movements the pause was ignored. “Still” included basking, remaining stationary for more than 10 seconds, hiding in a rock crevice (only if the lizard remained in sight), and any other action that did not involve translation to a new position (i.e. posture changes or looking around). Any feeding event was recorded, with no distinction between successful and attempted feeding events. Time of day at each change in activity was recorded. Any interactions with other lizards were recorded as well. Observations were done by groups of two individuals, with one observer and one scribe and terminated after either 15 or 30 minutes. Observations were made on the 8th and 9th of September, in the morning from 9.00 am to 12.00 pm, and in the afternoon from 3.00 pm to 6.00 pm. The proportion of time spent moving (PTM) was calculated for each animal, as was proportion of attacks made while moving (PAM). We calculated PTM both including and excluding movement for social interaction Statistica (© Statsoft) was used to test for a difference in PTM between habituated and non-habituated females, both including and excluding time spent in social interactions. The PTM comparison between habituated and non-habituated males was not performed due to a very small sample size (N=2). Differences between PTM for all males and females including and excluding social interactions were also tested. Due to low sample sizes, nonparametric Mann-Whitney U tests were performed. Spearman rank correlations were used to test for a relationship between time of day (measured as minutes from noon) and PTM. This was done for males and females of both habituated and non-habituated populations, including and excluding social interactions from PTM.

This cooperative program builds on the extensive knowledge base generated by the many decades of research conducted by the Kruger National Park Scientific Services, and the decade-long Kruger National Park River Research Program and more recent River Savanna Boundaries Program in collaboration with several South African and American universities, government departments, and research agencies. The Kruger Park has a long history of interest in the possibility of erection of formal research exclosures (rather than the “incidental exclosures” which have become available because of for instance, enclosures being built to breed up rare antelope). This interest relates 6 particularly relating to fire and elephant effects. Fortunately this historical interest, and the more recent interest of other groups in riparian and riparian-upland issues in the Kruger Park, has provided an opportunity for unified structures dealing with all these interests, to be put in place. In February 2000 the Kruger National Park was presented with a unique opportunity to develop a long-term experiment designed to examine the effects of herbivory. The largest flood since 1925 for the Sabie (7,000 to 8,000 m3 s-1) and Letaba rivers removed most of the vegetation along these rivers, primary research sites in the park, resetting the system to bedrock and sand. The vegetation before the flood was a mature riparian forest including stately fig and other majestic riparian trees. The Sabie River catchment is 7,086 km2 with a river length of 230 km and a mean discharge of 633 million m3/a. The Letaba catchment is 13400 km2 with a length of 490 km and a mean discharge of 631 million m3/a. Construction of large exclosures subsequent to this major flood event will allow us to follow the successional development and pattern formation of vegetation along riparian zones. Riparian zones are recognized as “hotspots” of activity because they integrate terrestrial and aquatic systems (Naiman and Décamps 1997). We believe the research we are conducting (viewed across aquatic, riparian and upland zones) will generate a novel understanding of savannas as integrated yet heterogeneous ecological systems. The systems approach to ecosystem study requires ecologists to expose the connections and fluxes between the elements of heterogeneity, and the feedbacks between heterogeneity and ecosystem function (Risser 1995). Therefore, boundaries in the landscape that define this heterogeneity are of particular ecological interest, and riparian corridors are perhaps the most obvious expression of boundaries in savanna regions. The emerging view of system heterogeneity emphasizes that biological richness has many facets (Noss and Cooperrider 1994). The first facet highlights the kinds of ecological systems that are present in a region. The second facet indicates the relative abundance of each kind of entity present in the area. The third facet indicates that the 7 various ecological components are dynamic in time, and that they are functionally connected with one another. Finally, the three facets of kind, relative abundance, and function are expressed in all ecological realms. Therefore, genes, species and populations, communities and ecosystems, and landscapes all can be considered as components of system heterogeneity (Kolasa and Pickett 1991, Collins and Benning 1996). Riparian systems, and their connection to in-stream processes and to interchanges with the upland components of savanna landscapes, provide a powerful test of the functional significance of spatial and temporal ecosystem heterogeneity. The development of this understanding is the overarching mission of our scientific programme.
