Vegetation Survey As the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment surveys only measure the herbaceous vegetation at a very coarse level, I conducted a separate vegetation survey to answer specific questions. The two main objectives of this vegetation survey were: 1) to compare vegetation inside and outside an enclosure to determine the general condition of the herbaceous layer in the roan’s range, and 2) to determine the effects that the artificial waterholes have had on the composition and abundance in the herbaceous layer. The vegetation survey was conducted in January 1994. Comparison of vegetation inside and outside the enclosure The enclosure used for this survey is known as Nwashitsumbe and is situated in the northeast of the roan’s range (refer to Figure 2.1). It is a square, 256 ha. Enclosure and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan between 1970 and 1978, and 40 Lichtenstein’s hartebeest between 1991 and the time of the study. The eastern fence of the enclosure runs through an alluvial grassland, while the remaining three sides of the enclosure run through non-alluvial grassland. Specific attributes that were measured included: composition, abundance, cover and height of the herbaceous layer. Sampling sites were located on both the outside and the inside of the four fence lines of the enclosure. Sampling sites were positioned ten meters from the fence as the Lichtensstein’s hartebeest present at the time of the study may have concentrated in these areas. At each sampling site a point quadrate survey of 225 random points (by means of a step-point method) was conducted to determine the botanical composition of the herbaceous layer. Tree rows of 75 points were located on each side of the enclosure fence and the nearest grass species to each point and the grass species height was recorded (see Figure 2.3 for schematic representation). If there was not an herbaceous species within the 25 cm of the point this was recorded as "bare ground". Cover of the herbaceous layer was determined using a quadrate method in which and 8-point scale with uneven class intervals was used, as described by Anderson and Walker (1974). Walker 1976) demonstrated that this scale was the most accurate and repeatable method for measuring herbaceous cover. The scale is as follows: Class intervals Rank 0 1-10 1 11-25 2 26-50 3 51-75 4 76-90 5 91-99 6 100 The above mentioned were chosen as they are the same methods used during the veld condition assessment surveys (Trollope et al, 1989) and so enabled comparison of results. Vegetation surrounding artificial waterholes As well sampling inside and outside the enclosure, there waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes included Hlamalala-south, Papanyane and Boyela-north as they all occurred in vleis. Roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands (Heitkoning, 1993, Joubert, 1976), so only waterholes occurring in vleis were examined. This allowed of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer in both the vleis and the grassland. Eight transects were placed at each waterhole, two replicate transects in each of the four major directions leading away from the waterhole. As all three waterholes sampled occurred within vleis, four transects occurred within the vlei (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole), while the remaining four transects occurred in the grassland (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole) (see Figure 2.4 from schematic representation). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 metres, although transects were continued until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. This figure was used at it was thought that the natural proportion of increaser II grass species in this area was somewhere between 40 and 50% (Abates, pers.comm). The grass species were classified according Trollope (1990) with respect to their response to different grazing intensities (see Appendix 1). In addition to the three waterholes sampled, two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for composition with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. This was to determine whether there were differences between vleis which contained waterholes with those that did not. The vlei system were Hlamala and Papanyane. The sampling methods were identical to those used to sample Nwashitsumbe enclosure, except that transects were extended beyond 150 metres until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. A point-step method was used where points were located every two metres on the transect. At each point the nearest grass species was identified and its height measured, while the herbaceous cover was measured using a 1X1 meter quadrant at every third point along the transect (i.e. every six metres). Vegetation survey Where more detail was needed to supplement the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment survey, a vegetation survey was conducted. This compared the grassland inside and outside the Nwashitsumbe enclosure which is 256 ha. In area and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan in the 1970’s and 40 Lichtentein’s hartebeest since 1991. Specific attributes that were measured included composition, abundance, cover, and height of the herbaceous layer, using a point-step method. Composition of the herbaceous layer was determined according to the dry weight rank method described by Mannetje and Haydock (1963), while abundance, cover and height was determined using a quadrant method described by Walker (1976). On each side of the enclosure three 150 m transects were run (i.e. 4 * 3 transects) along which the grass species was identified and its height measured every 2 meters and the basal cover was measured every 6 meters. Transects were replaced mid way down the enclosures fence line, and care was taken that they were not placed near the fence or drinking troughs as the animals have concentrated in these areas(The transects were placed next to the road, on the bottom side) As well as sampling inside and outside the enclosure, three waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes sampled included Hlamalala-south, Papayane and Boyela-north. As roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands, only waterholes occurring in vlei's were examined. This allowed comparison of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer between the vlei’s and the grassland. Eight transects were run at each waterhole, four into the vlei (two replicate transects on each side of the waterhole). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 meters, although transects were run until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped to approximately 50%. There are 44 waterholes in this compartment, so the three waterholes were chosen so that a large proportion of the roan range was represented. This was to ensure that the observed vegetation changes have occurred at waterholes in all the areas in which roan occur. Two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for comparison with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. The vlei system sampled were Hlamalala and Papanyane. This work was conducted during December 1993 and January 1994.

Vegetation Survey As the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment surveys only measure the herbaceous vegetation at a very coarse level, I conducted a separate vegetation survey to answer specific questions. The two main objectives of this vegetation survey were: 1) to compare vegetation inside and outside an enclosure to determine the general condition of the herbaceous layer in the roan’s range, and 2) to determine the effects that the artificial waterholes have had on the composition and abundance in the herbaceous layer. The vegetation survey was conducted in January 1994. Comparison of vegetation inside and outside the enclosure The enclosure used for this survey is known as Nwashitsumbe and is situated in the northeast of the roan’s range (refer to Figure 2.1). It is a square, 256 ha. Enclosure and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan between 1970 and 1978, and 40 Lichtenstein’s hartebeest between 1991 and the time of the study. The eastern fence of the enclosure runs through an alluvial grassland, while the remaining three sides of the enclosure run through non-alluvial grassland. Specific attributes that were measured included: composition, abundance, cover and height of the herbaceous layer. Sampling sites were located on both the outside and the inside of the four fence lines of the enclosure. Sampling sites were positioned ten meters from the fence as the Lichtensstein’s hartebeest present at the time of the study may have concentrated in these areas. At each sampling site a point quadrate survey of 225 random points (by means of a step-point method) was conducted to determine the botanical composition of the herbaceous layer. Tree rows of 75 points were located on each side of the enclosure fence and the nearest grass species to each point and the grass species height was recorded (see Figure 2.3 for schematic representation). If there was not an herbaceous species within the 25 cm of the point this was recorded as "bare ground". Cover of the herbaceous layer was determined using a quadrate method in which and 8-point scale with uneven class intervals was used, as described by Anderson and Walker (1974). Walker 1976) demonstrated that this scale was the most accurate and repeatable method for measuring herbaceous cover. The scale is as follows: Class intervals Rank 0 1-10 1 11-25 2 26-50 3 51-75 4 76-90 5 91-99 6 100 The above mentioned were chosen as they are the same methods used during the veld condition assessment surveys (Trollope et al, 1989) and so enabled comparison of results. Vegetation surrounding artificial waterholes As well sampling inside and outside the enclosure, there waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes included Hlamalala-south, Papanyane and Boyela-north as they all occurred in vleis. Roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands (Heitkoning, 1993, Joubert, 1976), so only waterholes occurring in vleis were examined. This allowed of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer in both the vleis and the grassland. Eight transects were placed at each waterhole, two replicate transects in each of the four major directions leading away from the waterhole. As all three waterholes sampled occurred within vleis, four transects occurred within the vlei (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole), while the remaining four transects occurred in the grassland (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole) (see Figure 2.4 from schematic representation). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 metres, although transects were continued until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. This figure was used at it was thought that the natural proportion of increaser II grass species in this area was somewhere between 40 and 50% (Abates, pers.comm). The grass species were classified according Trollope (1990) with respect to their response to different grazing intensities (see Appendix 1). In addition to the three waterholes sampled, two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for composition with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. This was to determine whether there were differences between vleis which contained waterholes with those that did not. The vlei system were Hlamala and Papanyane. The sampling methods were identical to those used to sample Nwashitsumbe enclosure, except that transects were extended beyond 150 metres until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. A point-step method was used where points were located every two metres on the transect. At each point the nearest grass species was identified and its height measured, while the herbaceous cover was measured using a 1X1 meter quadrant at every third point along the transect (i.e. every six metres). Vegetation survey Where more detail was needed to supplement the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment survey, a vegetation survey was conducted. This compared the grassland inside and outside the Nwashitsumbe enclosure which is 256 ha. In area and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan in the 1970’s and 40 Lichtentein’s hartebeest since 1991. Specific attributes that were measured included composition, abundance, cover, and height of the herbaceous layer, using a point-step method. Composition of the herbaceous layer was determined according to the dry weight rank method described by Mannetje and Haydock (1963), while abundance, cover and height was determined using a quadrant method described by Walker (1976). On each side of the enclosure three 150 m transects were run (i.e. 4 * 3 transects) along which the grass species was identified and its height measured every 2 meters and the basal cover was measured every 6 meters. Transects were replaced mid way down the enclosures fence line, and care was taken that they were not placed near the fence or drinking troughs as the animals have concentrated in these areas(The transects were placed next to the road, on the bottom side) As well as sampling inside and outside the enclosure, three waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes sampled included Hlamalala-south, Papayane and Boyela-north. As roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands, only waterholes occurring in vlei's were examined. This allowed comparison of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer between the vlei’s and the grassland. Eight transects were run at each waterhole, four into the vlei (two replicate transects on each side of the waterhole). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 meters, although transects were run until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped to approximately 50%. There are 44 waterholes in this compartment, so the three waterholes were chosen so that a large proportion of the roan range was represented. This was to ensure that the observed vegetation changes have occurred at waterholes in all the areas in which roan occur. Two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for comparison with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. The vlei system sampled were Hlamalala and Papanyane. This work was conducted during December 1993 and January 1994.

Herpetofauna diversity encompasses a range of environmental habitats from fossorial to aquatic to arboreal, linking the richness and abundance of herpetofauna community assemblages to characteristics in vegetation and habitat structure. Many herpetofauna species rely upon restricted (i.e. micro-habitat) components within their environment. The aims of this study are: 1) to determine if there are differences in herpetofauna diversity between riparian forest and xeric savanna habitat types; 2) to determine which habitat characteristics define the species assemblages and; 3) to assess the accuracy of the 118 herpetofauna sampling methodology. Fieldwork was conducted within Mapungubwe National Park (MNP) located in the Limpopo Province. The structure of the habitat types were assessed along 50m transects for the following characteristics; vegetation height (cm), soil penetration (pressure per cm^2), proximity to rock outcrop (m), woody debris, live trees, burrows, and rocks. Species richness (S), abundance (N) and diversity (H’) within each habitat type were analyzed as well as habitat structure and put into specific species guilds. Overall our results showed that herpetofauna species richness was significantly different when comparing between riparian forest and xeric savanna habitat types.

Dax Mackay, Mary Sparks SANParks, South Africa Independent Research Project 2
Herpetofauna diversity, conservation, habitat structure, vegetation

Fieldwork was conducted within Mapungubwe National Park (MNP) located in the Limpopo Province during the dates of the eleventh to the nineteenth of November. Trapping was carried out in the summer season to optimize catch rates of Herpetofauna. Two habitat types were selected for the installation of ten trap site arrays; five were placed in riparian habitats and five were placed in xeric savanna (Table A). The riparian habitat type is characterized by its’ close proximity to the Limpopo River, the presence of large trees which provided a closed canopy, a more patchy undergrowth cover and a sparse ground cover. The dominant woody vegetation is composed of Acacia xanthophloea, Faidherbia aldiba, Ficus sycomorus and Xanthocercis zambesiaca, while the understory is made up of patches of shrub vegetation dominated by Croton megalobotrys (0.5m to 2.5m). The soil within this habitat has a high clay content giving it a grey colour as well as a high organic material component. Conversely, the xeric savanna ecotype was characterized as having a patchy distribution of vegetation, both ground cover and canopy cover, which was dominated by Boscia albitrunca, Colophospermum mopane, Combretum mossambicense, Commiphora glandulosa and Dichrostachys cinerea. Sites were in close proximity to sand stone outcroppings which shared approximately 50 % of the landscape. The soil within this habitat type consists of 120 fine grain red sand with low organic materials. Elevation between sites ranged from 504 to 513 meters (m) within the riparian habitat and from 521 to 538 within the savanna habitat. Distances between trap sites within each habitat type were approximately 500m. Herpetofauna sampled The herpetofauna (amphibians and reptiles grouped together) sampled during this survey were analyzed as three separate groups; herpetofauna, amphibians and reptiles combined and; amphibians and reptiles as separate groups. Each of the ten sites contained a trap array, consisting of three arms of drift fencing, four pitfall and six funnel traps (Figure 1). All trap arrays were constructed from three ten meter drift fences of black damp-proofing plastic (30 cm X 40 m) stapled to stakes and with one-third of its width buried. Pitfall traps (plastic buckets) were buried flush with the ground at the end of each drift fence (4 in total). Two different size buckets were used, ten 20 litre (centre) and thirty 9 litre (at ends of each arm). Vegetation from each site and cardboard was used to provide shade for specimens caught in the pitfall traps, while still allowing access to the trap. We used a new technique to construct funnel traps from a single sheet of green mosquito mesh and with a flat base provided more stability for traps to remain flush against each side of each drift fence were. Zippers were also installed in the top of each trap to facilitate easier specimen removal. These funnel traps were also covered with vegetation to provide shade for captured specimens. Trap arrays were checked once per day and both types of trap were successful in collecting small mammals (rodents) and invertebrates (insects, scorpions and arachnids). All captured specimens were identified to species level, classified as adult or juvenile and released 10 metres from the trap array. Habitat structure The structure of the riparian and the savanna habitat types were assessed along 50m transects through the following characteristics; vegetation height (cm), soil penetration (pressure per cm^2), proximity to rock outcrop (m), woody debris, live trees, burrows, and rocks. Soil penetration measures, using a soil penetrometer, were used to relate habitat type soil compactness to the facilitation of fossorial species. Trap site proximity to rock outcroppings and number of live trees were used to impart suitable, stable herpetofauna microhabitat. Woody-debris, burrows and rocks were considered as microhabitats if they were of sufficient size for reptiles (lizards and small snakes) and amphibians to take refuge. Vegetation height was used to characterize the available cover present at each trap site. Transects were walked along a north-south orientation within each trapping area, soil penetration measures were taken every ten meters and the number of live trees, woody debris, burrows, rocks and vegetation height measures were taken every meter along each transect. Data analysis The data collected from the two sets of replicate plots were pooled to determine the herpetofaunal species richness (S), abundance (N) and diversity (H’) within each habitat type. The Shannon-Wiener diversity index (H’) was used in this case as it allows for the incorporation of the number of species as well as the number of individuals of each species in calculating community information. Herpetofaunal measures as well as 121 the measures of habitat structure were run through Primer (v5) to generate similarity matrices. The ordination outputs provided a graphic perspective characterizing the two habitat types based on the species assemblage similarity between the trap sites. Each of the three herpetofaunal groups in addition to the seven habitat structure measures were tested for normality and then compared individually, if normal, between different habitat types using a one-way ANOVA analysis in Statistica (6.0). The richness, abundance and diversity for the three herpetofaunal groups were then compared individually against the seven habitat characters in a regression analysis to determine whether any of the habitat structures measures explained herpetofaunal patterns. Finally the herpetofaunal species list for both habitat types were divided into guilds based on genus similarity and preference for micro-habitat. Amphibian species were grouped into three guilds and reptile species were grouped into four guilds and the abundances were compared in a multi-factorial ANOVA analysis, again in Statistica (6.0).

PROJECT GOALS & OBJECTIVES In my initial project registration, I outlined several main objectives as follows: Short-term To quantify demographic data collected within the Klaserie Private Nature Reserve (KPNR) by Christianne Knechtel and create a life-history model with climate sensitive parameters. To create a GIS of movement data collected by C. Knechtel to quantify daily movement rates, direction, route and range; to analyze and compare this data with ongoing data collection in the Satara region of KNP (P.Cross). To create comparable databases of climatic data for both KPNR and KNP; monthly rainfall and daily temperature data will be used. To compile databases of GIS information regarding habitat (satellite imagery, vegetation analyses, soil type, slope and aspect, hydrology) for both KPNR and KNP. Long-term To create a GIS model of buffalo response to climate and habitat, incorporating demographically driven age-structured disease transmission. Assess management strategies (vaccination, culling, exclusion zones) within this GIS modeled environment of Kruger National Park. To provide Kruger National Park with information and data regarding modeled strategies, habitat data and crucial demographic data for African Buffalo. In pursuing these goals and objectives, I sought to complement ongoing monitoring of bovine tuberculosis in the Satara region with studies of buffalo ranging and demography. Several studies of buffalo ranging, habitat selection and demography were undertaken with the overarching goal of describing the relationship between buffalo and their resources in a spatially explicit and temporally dynamic way.

Arundo donax is an invasive weed which was recently discovered on the Sabie River in Kruger National Park and like many invasives it is thought to reduce biodiversity in its invaded environment. In this experiment we looked at the effects of the invasive weed on insect biodiversity in a riparian environment. We compared the species richness of A. donax to the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus and to a mixed vegetation environment. We found that A. donax did not significantly decrease the number of individuals or number of species found in pitfall traps. Biological diversity indices showed, however, that there was in fact a higher diversity in the A. donax insect populations. We also took measurements of the insect diversity of the three vegetation types by beating the reeds and analyzing the insects that fell out. We found a lower species richness in A. donax than in P. mauritianus. This can be explained by the fact that one species of ant is dominating P. mauritianus on the ground but dominating A. donax in the upper layers of the reed. This, in turn, says that the dominating species is pushing out other species accounting for a lowered diversity that might otherwise be found. In our study, A. donax did not significantly affect the biodiversity of insects overall found on P mauritianus within a riparian ecosystem.

methods In order to determine the effects of invasion by A. donax on insect biodiversity, we conducted a study on the Sabie River (24. 97978 0S, 31. 48186 0 E) in Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, on 10 October 2005. We laid pitfall traps to assess insect abundance within three different sites, viz. stands of the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus, stands of the invasive reed Arundo donax as well as mixed stands of the two reed types. We chose two sites of the native, P. mauritianus, big enough to sufficiently cover a 2m by 2m matrix of pitfall traps, two sites of the invasive reed, A. donax and two sites of mixed vegetation. 2 different sized pitfall traps were used- the larger pitfall traps were 10 cm in diameter and 10 cm in depth, and the smaller traps were 4 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep. At each site, we laid nine pitfall traps in a 2m by 2m matrix, with alternating sized traps 1m apart. (Figure 1) Each vegetation type had one of each matrix type shown in Figure 1 A and B. This gave us 4 small and 5 big traps at one site and 5 small and 4 big at the other site for each vegetation type. Once all the traps were laid, we filled them each ¼ of the way full with anti-freeze to kill any insects that fell into the trap that could possibly climb or fly out. Insects were collected 2 days later from the traps, and were identified by morphospecies back at the laboratory. On the same day that the pitfall traps were cleared, in order to collect another type of data, we collected insects from all 3 vegetation types by beating the vegetation. We placed a round tray with a 50cm diameter on the ground and repeatedly beat the vegetation with a 1 meter stick for 20 seconds. We then placed all the insects that fell out of the reeds onto the tray into vials and labelled them. This was repeated 10 times at each vegetation type (A. donax, mixed vegetation and P.mauritianus). These individuals were also taken back to the lab and identified to morphospecies. In order to determine whether the diversity of insects was significantly different in the three sites, data for the number of individuals per trap, and the number of species per trap were analysed using Kruskal-Wallis, multiple comparison of means tests. (Statistica version. 6) When certain values were not considered significant we then did a post-hoc test to determine which, if any, of the relationships were significant. Similarities or differences in the insect communities were then determined using Primer to do a Multi Dimensional Scaling (MDS) plot, a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the number of individuals and species we collected in each trap. Next, we used Stastica again to do a Kruskal-Wallis test on the number of individuals collected per beating and the number of species per beating. Primer was then used to calculate a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the beating samples
Judith Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 SA +0927 13 7354309 +0927 13 7354055 judithk@sanparks.org

methods In order to determine the effects of invasion by A. donax on insect biodiversity, we conducted a study on the Sabie River (24. 97978 0S, 31. 48186 0 E) in Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, on 10 October 2005. We laid pitfall traps to assess insect abundance within three different sites, viz. stands of the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus, stands of the invasive reed Arundo donax as well as mixed stands of the two reed types. We chose two sites of the native, P. mauritianus, big enough to sufficiently cover a 2m by 2m matrix of pitfall traps, two sites of the invasive reed, A. donax and two sites of mixed vegetation. 2 different sized pitfall traps were used- the larger pitfall traps were 10 cm in diameter and 10 cm in depth, and the smaller traps were 4 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep. At each site, we laid nine pitfall traps in a 2m by 2m matrix, with alternating sized traps 1m apart. (Figure 1) Each vegetation type had one of each matrix type shown in Figure 1 A and B. This gave us 4 small and 5 big traps at one site and 5 small and 4 big at the other site for each vegetation type. Once all the traps were laid, we filled them each ¼ of the way full with anti-freeze to kill any insects that fell into the trap that could possibly climb or fly out. Insects were collected 2 days later from the traps, and were identified by morphospecies back at the laboratory. On the same day that the pitfall traps were cleared, in order to collect another type of data, we collected insects from all 3 vegetation types by beating the vegetation. We placed a round tray with a 50cm diameter on the ground and repeatedly beat the vegetation with a 1 meter stick for 20 seconds. We then placed all the insects that fell out of the reeds onto the tray into vials and labelled them. This was repeated 10 times at each vegetation type (A. donax, mixed vegetation and P.mauritianus). These individuals were also taken back to the lab and identified to morphospecies. In order to determine whether the diversity of insects was significantly different in the three sites, data for the number of individuals per trap, and the number of species per trap were analysed using Kruskal-Wallis, multiple comparison of means tests. (Statistica version. 6) When certain values were not considered significant we then did a post-hoc test to determine which, if any, of the relationships were significant. Similarities or differences in the insect communities were then determined using Primer to do a Multi Dimensional Scaling (MDS) plot, a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the number of individuals and species we collected in each trap. Next, we used Stastica again to do a Kruskal-Wallis test on the number of individuals collected per beating and the number of species per beating. Primer was then used to calculate a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the beating samples

The overarching aim of this research is to describe patterns of soils, vegetation and hydrology in the savanna landscapes in Kruger National Park (KNP) that are spatially organised at various scales by the configuration of drainage networks. Specific objectives were to: Develop a hierarchical conceptual framework within which the structure, function and dynamics of water-controlled ecosystems can be described, explained and predicted. The framework will include both drainage networks and hillslopes, so that linkages can be described and explored in a holistic manner across the entire landscape. Construct a spatially explicit, scaled and hierarchically nested classification of Kruger National Park landscapes, based on the conceptual framework. Explore the hydrological, geomorphological and ecological implications of the diversity and spatial arrangement of elements at each scale (representing an organisational level in the hierarchical model). Integrate the framework and classification into the Kruger Park management system as a test case for broader application.
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa
Carola Cullum University of the Witwatesrand
Kevin Rogers University of the Witwatesrand
Report: A Framework for the Classification of Drainage Networks in Savanna Landscapes

The African elephant, Loxodonta africana, is a species of great importance in Kruger National Park because of the extensive impact it has on ecological processes. In this study, we focused on the effects of time of day, gender and age on time budgets in elephants. We sought to determine whether there were any activities that were performed more frequently at different times of the day or by elephants of a certain age or gender. Using focal observation, we determined the proportion of total time spent performing various activities. We found that the time budgets did not vary statistically with gender or age, but that there were significant differences in time spent standing still between the morning and afternoon (p=0.0143). More time was spent eating in the afternoon than the morning (p=0.002183), but overall time spent eating was less than previous studies have found. Despite the fact that elephant populations in Kruger are growing, the destruction of trees was not observed in any of our focal studies, indicating elephants in our study did not appear to impact the ecosystem as much as reported in previous literature.
Billy Boysen, Wren Larson, Jodie Reed SANParks, South Africa Independent Field Project 1
Billy Boysen, Wren Larson, Jodie Reed SANParks, South Africa Independent Field Project 1
activity budgets, African elephant (Loxodonta africana), age differences, behavior, gender differences, Kruger National Park

The study focused on the African Elephant, Loxodonta africana, the largest of all land mammals. Adult males can weigh over 6000 kg, with 200 kg contributing to the ivory tusks. When protected, an elephant can live to be over 70 years, constrained only by the irreplaceable six molar pairs that wear down over time (Frandsen 1998). For this behavioral study, we actively searched for elephants twice a day in Open Air Game Viewing Vehicles from September 21-24, 2006. Weather conditions were dry and hot, with temperatures around 30° C. Searching was held in the morning, 7:00 AM-12:00 PM, and afternoon, 12:00 PM-6:00 PM. All searching and observations were conducted along the Shingwedzi River within 30 km of the Shingwedzi Research Camp in Kruger National Park, South Africa (S 23.05682; E 031.34634). The majority of elephants were studied along the riverbank, with observation occurring from the opposite bank. Some individuals were encountered along the road and were observed there. When an elephant was observed, a GPS locator was used to pinpoint the location of the animal. The time of observation was noted and the elephant was classified in terms of age and gender. Three distinct age classes were used to categorize elephants: infant, juvenile, and adult. An infant was defined as any small elephant that had not yet 51 developed tusks. A juvenile was any tusked individual in the herd not yet fully grown, generally 75% or less of the size of the largest animals (adults). Ambiguity in the sexes prevented the identification of genders in the infants and juveniles. As a result, only the adult elephants were classified as male or female. After gender and age classification, activity budgets were determined through observation in focal studies (Altmann 1974). During the ten-minute focal observation, the activity of one elephant was carefully described and timed. One person observed the elephant through binoculars while a second recorded all of the reported observation. These descriptions were used to later classify the behavior into seven categories: eating, standing, drinking, traveling (walking or running), vigilance (looking around, head shaking, ears out), playing (trunk wrestling, shoving, butting, splashing, etc.), and other (mating, scratching, rolling around in the mud, nursing) (Estes 1999). Data were collected from 64 elephants. Because the elephants were observed from a distance, we assumed that our presence did not have an effect on their behavior. We calculated our statistics using Statistica 7.0 (StatSoft, Inc. © 1984-2004). The data were tested for normality using the Lilliefors test and found to be non-normally distributed; therefore we used nonparametric statistical tests in the analysis of our data. To analyze the effect of gender and age on time budgets we used a Kruskal-Wallis oneway ANOVA. If significant differences were detected, a Mann-Whitney U test was performed between adult males and adult females. If no significant differences were detected, these two groups were combined and reclassified as adults. The Kruskal-Wallis test was then performed on the three age groups and if significant differences were detected, this was followed by Mann-Whitney U tests of pairs of age groups per activity, along with a Bonforoni correction. The variability in the activity budgets due to the effect of time of day was analyzed using Mann-Whitney U tests.

Ficus abutilifolia and Ficus tettensis are two species of deciduous rock fig trees commonly found on the vertical faces of Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa. The demographics of the rock figs as well as the habitat features necessary for successful maturation are currently unknown. This study first aims to provide demographic data and determine the points in the fig life cycle where bottlenecks occur. Secondly, it probes the importance to growth of location and usage of cracks. From general observations, we hypothesized that seedlings would be located anywhere on the rock faces, but that larger trees would be more limited to specific areas. We also conjectured that usage of cracks by tree roots would positively correlate with tree height, due to stability and nutrient gathering arguments. Within the sampled population, there was an uneven distribution of seedlings (62.8%), saplings (21.9%) and adults (15.3%). All size classes were contagiously dispersed on the outer edges of the rock faces, despite our expectation about seedling dispersal. Lastly, the number of cracks used by the roots as well as the number of large cracks used showed some degree of positive correlation with tree height. These results suggest that (1) there are growth bottlenecks in the population, (2) the outer edges of rock faces are either popular for dispersal or essential for establishment, and (3) large cracks provide more stability and/or necessary nutrients for trees as they mature.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa
Bottleneck, demography, dispersal, Ficus abutilifolia, Ficus tettensis, roots

Methods Study site From September 14th to September 15th, (sampling times ranged between 6:30 AM and 5:30 PM) we collected data within MNP in the Limpopo Province of South Africa. MNP is located in the northeastern region of South Africa in the confluence of the Shashi and Limpopo rivers. Within the national park we visited five sites (1, S22º13.161 E029º21.904; 2, S22º 13.142 E029º 21. 971; 3, S22º 13.023 E029º21.692; 4, S22º12.313 E029º22.289; 5, S2211.33 E02914.20). The sites are mainly cracked sandstone cliff faces surrounding dry valleys. Within these five sites we sampled from 26 rock faces. We defined separate rock faces as being bounded by the top and bottom of the cliff face and by any vertical edges or large fissures. We then broke the face into three concentric zones with perimeters equidistant from each other (Fig. 1). In total, we sampled 137 individuals, four of which were dead. Figure 1: Example of a rock face, with defined zones and borders (in yellow). Note: there is a fig sapling positioned in zone 2. Study species We focused on the broad-leaved rock figs Ficus abutilifolia—the large-leaved rock fig—and Ficus tettensis—the small-leaved rock fig. The two species differ in leaf characteristics but are both rock-splitters and are usually found in the same areas (Burrows and Burrows 2003). Since these trees are nearly biologically equivalent, we decided to combine the data of each species. Data collection We first measured tree height (from the base of the trunk to the tallest branch), which allowed us to determine the population structure and height bottlenecks. To collect these measurements we used a hypsometer (Nikon) for the trees that had non-angled trunks. We measured trees with angled trunks using estimations calibrated by the hypsometer measurements. After measuring the height of a tree, we classified it as being a seedling, sapling, or adult, with seedlings being 0-0.5m tall, saplings being >0.5-1.5m tall, and adults being >1.5m tall. For each tree we noted the zone in which it resided in order to test our hypothesis about the effect of zone on tree height. We then estimated the distance between it and its nearest neighbor of the same size class so that we would be able to determine the dispersal pattern on the rock face. Lastly, we counted the cracks within a one-meter radius of each individual and sorted them into three categories based on width: small (0-2cm), medium (2-7cm) and large (>7cm). We counted how many cracks were occupied by the roots and how many were unused. Data analyses We organized our data and performed regressions using Microsoft Excel software (Microsoft 2003). In order to assess size-based bottlenecks, we first ranked all individuals from shortest to tallest and observed significant shifts in population structure. Using the nearest neighbor distances, we calculated dispersal indices to determine whether each size class was normally, randomly, or contagiously dispersed (Fowler et al 1998). Using tree heights and the data collected on tree location zone, we calculated the probability of finding an individual of a specific size class in a specific zone on each rock face. These probabilities were not normally distributed. We thus ran nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis tests using Statistica, v. 6, software (StatSoft 2004) in order to determine (1) whether each size class was significantly more likely to be found in a particular zone and (2) whether any class was more likely to be found in zone 3 than other size classes. In order to quantify total crack usage we created a crack index score for each tree. We summed all used cracks, giving small cracks a value of one, medium cracks a value of two, and large cracks a value of three. For example, a tree using two large cracks, one medium crack, and three small cracks received a crack index score of 11 (2*3 + 1*2 + 3*1=11). We regressed this index against tree heights. This regression illustrated the general importance of cracks in the maturation of rock figs. However, it didn’t specify whether the size of cracks is important. Therefore, in three separate analyses we regressed the number of small, medium, and large cracks used against tree heights. Regression results revealed any causal relationships between the compared variables. We excluded trees that we observed to be growing directly out of a soil patch in all of these crack use regressions, due to the possibility of this reducing dependence on root growth for nutrient gathering.

These data were collected as part of a monitaring programme on habitat use by large herbivores. the numbers and distribution of large herbivores were counted from the roads b the same observer (Peter Novellie). the same road was followed for all counts. the counts were conducted roughly once per mounth from the first on 15 December 2983 and the last on 4 September 1989, there being 98 counts in total. This dataset include the most common ungulate species: Cape mountain zebra, springbok, black wildebeest, blesbok,and red hartebeest. from this study it emetged that there were three areas (termed hotspots), each about 50ha in size, which consistently carried very high herbivore numbers. this dataset recodeds the number of herbivores counted in each of the three areas. follow up surveys could reveal whether these areas are still particulary favoured by large herbivores.
Three hotspots called A,B and C.
Numbers of the counts from 1 to 98
this season given as either summer (October to March) and winter ( April to September)
the total number of zebra counted
the number of black wildebeest counted

This cooperative program builds on the extensive knowledge base generated by the many decades of research conducted by the Kruger National Park Scientific Services, and the decade-long Kruger National Park River Research Program and more recent River Savanna Boundaries Program in collaboration with several South African and American universities, government departments, and research agencies. The Kruger Park has a long history of interest in the possibility of erection of formal research exclosures (rather than the “incidental exclosures” which have become available because of for instance, enclosures being built to breed up rare antelope). This interest relates 6 particularly relating to fire and elephant effects. Fortunately this historical interest, and the more recent interest of other groups in riparian and riparian-upland issues in the Kruger Park, has provided an opportunity for unified structures dealing with all these interests, to be put in place. In February 2000 the Kruger National Park was presented with a unique opportunity to develop a long-term experiment designed to examine the effects of herbivory. The largest flood since 1925 for the Sabie (7,000 to 8,000 m3 s-1) and Letaba rivers removed most of the vegetation along these rivers, primary research sites in the park, resetting the system to bedrock and sand. The vegetation before the flood was a mature riparian forest including stately fig and other majestic riparian trees. The Sabie River catchment is 7,086 km2 with a river length of 230 km and a mean discharge of 633 million m3/a. The Letaba catchment is 13400 km2 with a length of 490 km and a mean discharge of 631 million m3/a. Construction of large exclosures subsequent to this major flood event will allow us to follow the successional development and pattern formation of vegetation along riparian zones. Riparian zones are recognized as “hotspots” of activity because they integrate terrestrial and aquatic systems (Naiman and Décamps 1997). We believe the research we are conducting (viewed across aquatic, riparian and upland zones) will generate a novel understanding of savannas as integrated yet heterogeneous ecological systems. The systems approach to ecosystem study requires ecologists to expose the connections and fluxes between the elements of heterogeneity, and the feedbacks between heterogeneity and ecosystem function (Risser 1995). Therefore, boundaries in the landscape that define this heterogeneity are of particular ecological interest, and riparian corridors are perhaps the most obvious expression of boundaries in savanna regions. The emerging view of system heterogeneity emphasizes that biological richness has many facets (Noss and Cooperrider 1994). The first facet highlights the kinds of ecological systems that are present in a region. The second facet indicates the relative abundance of each kind of entity present in the area. The third facet indicates that the 7 various ecological components are dynamic in time, and that they are functionally connected with one another. Finally, the three facets of kind, relative abundance, and function are expressed in all ecological realms. Therefore, genes, species and populations, communities and ecosystems, and landscapes all can be considered as components of system heterogeneity (Kolasa and Pickett 1991, Collins and Benning 1996). Riparian systems, and their connection to in-stream processes and to interchanges with the upland components of savanna landscapes, provide a powerful test of the functional significance of spatial and temporal ecosystem heterogeneity. The development of this understanding is the overarching mission of our scientific programme.

Nearest plant point surveys were conducted in six matched paires of plots, one member of each pair being inside, and the other outside the botanical Reserve. Plots inside the botanical Reserve were protected against grazing by fences, the plots outside were exposed to grazing. In each plot 100 points were examined and the plant rooted nearest to each point was recorded.The surveys were conducted in the years 1987,1990,1995, and 1997. This data gives the results only for the most common plant species. Further details on the methodology are given in: 1, Novellie,P. 1988. The impact of large herbivores on the grassveld in the Addo Elephant National Park. South African Journal of Wildlife Research 18(1): 6-10. 2. Novellie,P. Hall-Martin, A.J and Joubert,D.1991. The problem of maintaining large herbivores in small conservation areas: deterioration of the grassveld in the Addo Elephant National Park. Koedoe 3(1):41-50.

Increased biodiversity loss caused by humans underlines the importance of monitoring the health of ecosystems. One efficient way to do this is through the use of indicator species. Ants show potential as an indicator taxon, but the effect of human disturbance on their communities has not yet been well studied. In natural communities, ant species specialize to varying degrees in either discovery of food resources or aggressive domination of them, but this pattern has not been investigated in the context of human development. In order to find out whether human settlements lead to changes in ant community composition and discovery/dominance dynamics, we set 38 baited traps in matched pairs inside and outside of human settlements. We identified the responding ant genera, recorded activity levels every 10 minutes for one hour, recorded time of discovery and aggressive dominance interactions. “Discoverer” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites outside human settlements, and “Dominant” genera occurred at higher frequencies at sites inside human settlements. Across all genera, ants arrived to bait traps faster outside of settlements than in them. High beta diversity was observed between inside and outside experimental sites, therefore human settlement at the level of the Leokwe Camp in Mapungubwe National Park appears to change the composition of ant communities. In resource-rich human areas there seems to be less pressure to discover food resources quickly, but increased pressure to defend resources from competitors.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungibwe National Park, South Africa

Methods Study area Our study was conducted in Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site located in the Limpopo Province of South Africa (Figure 1). The park is situated along the Limpopo River within the Limpopo basin bordered by Botswana and Zimbabwe. The geology primarily consists of granitic basement rocks which over millions of years eroded to produce present day sandstone formations (Huffman 2005). Tectonic activity caused magma from the earth’s core to rise to the surface resulting in basalt sheets and dolerite dykes. The park is within a savanna biome, consisting of a high diversity of Acacia and Commiphora species; other vegetation in the area includes short, dense, shrubby Mopanes, fever trees, Ana trees, leadwoods, fig trees and sparse tufted grassveld. There are also some very large baobabs scattered in the area (http://www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/conservation/ff/vegetation.php). The Mapungubwe National Park was established recently in 2004 (www.southafrica.info/ess_info/sa_glance/fauna_flora/mapungubwe-nationalpark.htm), with a tourist resort containing 20 huts for accommodation and an entertainment and dining facility in the Leokwe Camp. FIGURE 1: Location of Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site (www.sanparks.org/parks/mapungubwe/images/maps/map2.png) Observation and collection To establish if there were differences in ant communities inside and outside of human settlements, we used bait traps of canned chunk-light tuna in water. To ensure that vegetation type remained constant throughout our experiment, nineteen paired tests consisting of traps positioned inside and outside of human settlements were conducted at six sites. The sites selected for our baited traps are subject to frequent human utilization and therefore commonly contain human-derived food sources. The kitchen garbage is probably the most resource-rich site, as substantial quantities of new food are added daily when groups are present at the camp, and the food may remain in place for up to a week before removal. The dining and entertainment area is almost as rich in resources, as visitors to the camp often consume meals or snacks at the pool or on the lookout deck. A often-used path to the kitchen and entertainment area was also used for one of the sites representing human settlements. The huts represent the highest variability in human utilization, as it is unclear how often each hut is inhabited. Sites outside settlements were paired to an adjacent inside site by being placed approximately 20 – 30 meters away from the inside site. Traps were set 6 times daily over a period of four days, each test lasting for duration 60 minutes. To determine the ant genera that used or approached the food resource, specimens were collected in vials for identification. We monitored the interactions between genera and temporal differences in the use of food resources inside and outside of human settlements to investigate if certain genera displayed dominance over the resource. The arrival time of each ant genus and the time it took for a genus to swarm the bait was noted. A swarm was considered a high level of activity and movement maintained by a large number of ants on the bait. The changes in resource utilization over 60 minutes were determined by qualitatively rating activity levels as high, medium, or low at 10 minute intervals for each genus. Further, to establish if certain genera display dominance by aggressive behavior, we continuously monitored and noted any aggressive incidental behaviors and recorded all interactions with other genera while recording activity levels. To establish which ant genera were present but not necessarily seen at our trial stations we determined the taxonomic composition around the study sites using a grid network of bait traps spaced 15 meters apart. After the traps had been set for one hour, specimens at each trap were collected for identification and a GPS location recorded. Data analysis To determine if significantly different ant communities exist between areas inside and outside of human settlements an ANOSIM analysis was run in Primer (Primer- E ltd. 2001). A Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test whether the common “Dominant” (pheidone, tapinoma) and “Discoverer” (monomordium) genera were evenly distributed inside and outside of human settlements. Another Pearson’s chi-square test was used to test the null hypothesis that genus did not affect resource utilization over time. A series of t-tests were used to test for significant differences in the arrival time of common genera. A paired t-test was used to compare the arrival time inside and outside for all trials in which a genus arrived both inside and outside in order to determine if human settlements were responsible for changes in arrival time. Finally, a Pearson’s chi-squared analysis was used to determine if aggressive dominance interactions were distributed evenly across sites inside and outside human settlements.

A multiscale approach was used to study the dynamics of reed patches in a section of the Letaba River flowing through the Kruger National Park (KNP), South Africa's largest conservation area. The valley floor consists of a mosaic of patches of reeds, water, sand and rock. Reed vegetation change in space and time is closely linked to geomorphic change in the rivers of the KNP, because of reciprocal interactions between reeds, flow and sediment. Reeds are thus considered a potentially important species around which to formulate management goals for these rivers. A study of clonal growth characteristics at the scale of individual reedbeds was combined with a study of reed patch dynamics at the river reach scale. Mechanisms affecting clonal expansion across reedbed boundaries were combined with short-term patterns of reed persistence, loss and gain at the reach scale, and longer-term trends in reed cover, to produce a conceptual model of proposed relationships between flow conditions and reed cover in the Letaba River. Reed areal cover increased between 1988 and 1999. Despite this, reed persistence was low, and reeds were a dynamic element of the river landscape in the short term. Turnover of water and reed patches was high, within a matrix of sand. Complex patterns of reed gain and loss occurred at the boundaries of reed patches, with gain exceeding loss throughout the period of study. During a drier period (1988-1996), clonal expansion of patches and establishment of new patches contributed equally (50% each) to the increase in reed cover. During a wetter period (1996-1999), the relative contribution of clonal expansion increased to 90%. Reed persistence was higher in the wetter period due to less reed loss, and reed cover increased more rapidly. The relative proportions of reed, water and sand patches did not remain constant over 3 years or over 8 years in the alluvial section of the river studied. At the time and space scales of this study, therefore, the Letaba River did not display the kind of compositional stability described in other river systems. This points to the difficulty of applying equilibrium concepts of either geomorphology or vegetation dynamics to semi-arid rivers. A clear spatial patchiness was present in the distribution of sediment and nutrient resources on the macro-channel floor. Reed patches were associated with `current shadow' features, the characteristic raised elevation of the central, denser parts of reedbeds suggesting accumulation of sediment within reedbeds. Silt and clay particles accumulated preferentially within reedbeds. The results suggest that this accumulation was achieved primarily by selective retention of nes within reedbeds, and to a lesser extent by selective deposition of stones within reedbeds. Total carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus were all higher beneath reedbeds than in uncolonised sediment. The distributions of total N and total P were not correlated with that of total C, suggesting that nutrient accumulation does not simply reflect breakdown of reed organic matter. It was proposed that the nutrient accumulation recorded in this study was due primarily to interactions between reedbeds and flow, and to a lesser extent to the input of reed organic matter. The fact that surface resource distribution patterns did not always correspond to subsurface patterns illustrates the importance of viewing reed patches as three-dimensional entities. A high stem density and limited plasticity in spacer characteristics of Phragmites mauritianus in the Letaba River were consistent with a consolidation strategy of clonal growth. Physiological integration within within the clone was, however, limiteda notable departure from the consolidation strategy. While Phragmites mauritianus showed little evidence of plasticity in the horizontal spacer characteristics traditionally measured in studies of clonal growth patterns (internode length, branching pattern and bud activity), it was proposed that plasticity in rhizome characteristics related to regenerative capacity is important for reed persistence and clonal expansion in this habitat. The added vertical dimension of the rhizome system in species such as P. mauritianus limits the usefulness of horizontal spacer characteristics in explaining patterns of clonal expansion. Progressive accumulation of sediment above the rhizomes and upgrowth of reeds to the surface was proposed as a mechanism whereby the depth of the rhizome layer is increased, thus increasing the density of reed stems and enhancing the persistence of the reedbed. Rhizomes at reedbed boundaries did not show particular adaptations for rapid expansion into available space. Clonal expansion and consolidation of the space aroud established reedbeds was limited both by features of the rhizomes themselves (high proportion of dormant buds, low branching probability and shallow depth), and by external factors (flow disturbance). Management concerns over reed `encroachment' in the Letaba River appear unfounded. While rapid reed expansion may occur during favourable periods, conditions suitable for large increases in reed cover occur relatively infrequently and persist for short periods of time. It was proposed that wet periods with a high frequency of medium flows and no large floods are most likely to be associated with large increases in reed cover.

Reeds, clonal expansion, Letaba River, Kruger National Park

Methods Carter and Rogers (1995) analysed changes in reed cover up until 1988. Aerial photographs from 1988, 1996 and 1999 were used to extend their work. A Geographical Information System (GIS), PCI-ILWIS, was used to analyse the aerial photographs. The GIS software made it possible to calculate not only changes in reed cover, but also changes in the distribution of reeds within the macro-channel. It was thus possible to determine the persistence of reedbeds and to assess the relative contributions of clonal expansion and establishment of new patches to changes in reed cover. Spatial and temporal relationships between reed patches, and water and sand patches, could also be investigated. Since the focus of this thesis is on the dynamics of reed patches, an alluvial section of the river was chosen for study. Alluvial channel types have a smaller diversity of patches on the macrochannel oor than other channel types, because of the absence of bedrock and woody vegetation. Reed patches could also be distinguished relatively easily on the aerial photographs. The 25 km llong study section lay between Mingerhout and Engelhard dams (Figure 2.1). The work of Carter and Rogers (1995) showed that landscape state changes taking place in this section reflect the changes taking place in the river as a whole, both in overall pattern and in relative magnitude. Eight subsections were selected from the study section, each approximately 300 m in length. These were chosen subjectively in order to cover both the length of the study section and the range of histories of reed change (increasing reed cover, decreasing reed cover, and no change). Four of the subsections included the study sites at which fieldwork was done (Chapter 5). The aerial photographs were digitized using a scanner, at a resolution of 300 dots per inch (dpi), giving a pixel size of approximately 0.8 m 0.8 m on the ground. The three photographs from each site were then cross-georeferenced using features recognisable on all three photos (mainly trees). Pixels were classified as either reeds, water or sand using unsupervised classification based on grayscale ranges. Woody vegetation could not be uniquely identified on the basis of its grayscale range, and was omitted from the analysis. This was not considered a problem as woody vegetation in this section of the Letaba occurs almost exclusively as a riparian fringe on the macrochannel banks and does not form part of the mosaic of patches on the macro-channel oor. Occasional `problem' patches of woody vegetation were masked using the GIS software and thus ommitted from the analysis. The accuracy of each classification was assessed visually from the photographs and by comparing the maps produced by the GIS with reed distribution at the study sites. The resulting maps of reed distribution for each year were then combined to produce raster maps showing the location of patches (pixels) which had undergone one of nine categories of change, as follows: 1) reeds-> reeds 4) sand-> reeds 7) water-> reeds 2) reeds-> sand 5) sand-> sand 8) water-> sand 3) reeds-> water 6) sand-> water 9) water-> water Two sets of these combined maps were produced, one for each of the two time periods (1988 to 1996, and 1996 to 1999). This made it possible to compare changes taking place over a longer and a shorter period (8 years and 3 years). 3.2.1 Short-term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, Short term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, gain and loss The GIS software was used to calculate the proportion of the macro-channel covered by each of the nine categories of change for each period. Reed cover present at the beginning of a period could then be calculated by combining categories 1, 2 and 3, and that present at the end of a period by combining categories 1, 4 and 7. Changes in the proportion of the macro-channel covered by water and sand were calculated in a similar way. Pattterns of reed persistence, appearance and disappearance were investigated by calculating the frequencies of each type of change involving reeds (categories 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7) as a percentage of the total changes involving reeds. These were compared between the two time periods using two-sample t tests. Reed persistence is a measure of what proportion of reed patches were able to maintain their position on the macro-channel floor, and thus, possibly, undergo clonal expansion. It was calculated as the proportion of reeds which were not lost or gained during a period, in other words, those that maintained their position in space (category 1). Reed turnover was therefore defined as the reciprocal of persistence: the proportion of reed patches which did not maintain their position in space. Reeds which were lost are given by the relative frequencies of categories 2 and 3, while reeds which became established are given by the frequencies of categories 4 and 7. Although this approach differs slightly from that of Arscott et al. (2002), where patch turnover was calculated as the proportional area of new patches present at the end of each time period, it allows patterns of reed loss and reed gain to be distinguished, and therefore allows for a more detailed analysis of reed dynamics. The term turnover, as used by Arscott et al. (2002), is misleading in the sense that it suggests complete removal and re-establishment of patches, whereas in fact it simply indicates the extent of new reed area, which may have arisen either by establishment of new patches or by clonal expansion of existing patches. Patch turnover was, however, also calculated as described above, to allow the results of this study to be compared with those of Arscott et al. (2002), the only other known study of patch turnover in a disturbance-driven river system. It was hypothesised that high reed persistence increases the potential for clonal expansion, and thus produces a greater increase in cover. This hypothesis was tested by relating percentage change in reed cover in each subsection to reed persistence using regression models. The response variable for regression models was always plotted against the fitted values to allow visual inspection of the fit of the model. The model fit was assessed further using the following diagnostic plots: Residuals vs fitted values, useful for identifying outliers and visualising structure in the residuals Normal quantile plot of residuals, to test the assumption that the model's errors are normally distributed Scale-location plot, for measuring spread and identifying pattern in the residuals Cook's distance plot, a measure of the inuence of individual observations on the regression coefficients To determine whether the fate of reed patches depends on their association with other patch types, the probabilities of association between reeds and all the other categories of change were calculated for each river section. This was done by calculating, for each type of reed pixel, the number of neighbouring pixels of each of the 9 categories of change. Reed pixels included reeds which remained (cagegory 1); reeds which were lost (categories 2 and 3); and new reeds which became established (categories 4 and 7). While pixels of a particular type are most likely to be surrounded by pixels of the same type, it is the relationships with neighbouring pixels of different types that can provide insight into the spatial associations between changes involving reeds, and those involving water and sand. Spatial associations between persistent reed patches and areas of reed loss were further quantified by estimating from the maps the proportion of patches of loss which lay within a 5 m radius of persistent reed patches. This made it possible to estimate what proportion of patches were removed completely, and what proportion merely became smaller. Clonal expansion vs establishment of new reed patches Patches of new reeds which are close to persistent reed patches are most probably a result of clonal expansion of the persistent patches, whereas those which are far from persistent patches must have established from seed or clonal progagules. The relative contribution of these two types of reed gain was determined by estimating the proportion of new reed patches found within a 5m radius of persistent patches, as described above for reed loss. Edge:area ratios were also calculated for all types of patches and compared between time periods using two-sample t tests. A decrease in this ratio indicates that patches have become more consolidated, suggesting clonal expansion in the case of reed patches. An increase in edge:area ratio indicates that patches have become smaller and more fragmented. Thus it was possible to determine whether a particular type of change occurred in large contiguous areas or rather in small discontinuous patches. Due to computational constraints, it was not possible to convert the raster maps of whole river subsections into vector format, necessary for calculating edge:area ratios. Instead, two randomly selected smaller areas (approximately 100 m in length) from each subsection map were converted into vector format and used to calculate edge:area ratios. The submaps converted into vector format for the calculation of edge:area ratios were also used to calculate the relative lengths of vegetated and unvegetated channel edge. The fact that new areas of water could be distinguished from older, more persistent ones made it possible to estimate the time required for channel edges to become colonised by reeds. Relationships between reed dynamics and geomorphic change Given the highly dynamic nature of the patch mosaic in semi-arid rivers generally, reed patch dynamics is likely to be related to geomorphic change, which may be quantified by the dynamics of water and sand patches. Relationships between reed patch dynamics and geomorphic change were explored by: Determining probabilities of association between reed patches, and water and sand patches with different histories (neighbour analysis) Comparing the persistence and turnover of reed and water patches in each period Relating reed cover and persistence to water cover and persistence using regression models

Notes for AGR basic data quality checks 0035334 3 AGR station Lat: -33.57 Long: 25.69 Height: 43 m C There is no data in the 20h humidity or wind series 2003/07/29, 2003/08/26, 2003/09/02, 2003/09/16 and 2003/09/23 repeated in the 8h wind and humidity series - repeated entries deleted 2003/08/31 missing from the 14h humidity and wind series - missing date added 2003/09/30, 2003/10/28 missing from the 14h wind series - repeated dates and data deleted 2003/10/20 repeated in the 8h and 14h wind series 2003/12/25 to 31 missing from the 14h wind series - dates added duplicated and missing dates in both wind series between 2003/09/28 to 30 - corrected 1999/02/01missing from Rainfall series - added Dec 2001 missing from Rainfall series - added Deleted rainfall data after September 2009 as there were too many gaps from here General comments Temperature: There are no large gaps in the data. Nov 1965 has no maximum temperatures recorded, Jan 1963 no minima and there is no data for Dec 1998. There is a strong annual cyclical pattern in temperature. Rainfall: There are no large gaps in the data, though Dec 2001 is missing and there are 26 occurences (0.14% of failed recordings). Most rainfall comes in summer, except for 1979, where 131.5mm fell in July. (Similar spike in rain on this day for other stations). Humidity: There are three small gaps of less than 1 month to a month in 1993, 1998/9 and 2003. There is strong annual pattern in humidity, with highest humidity in the 8h series in winter. There is lower humidity in the 14h series. Wind: There is no 20h data series. There are no large gaps in the 8h and 14h series, though there are a few weeks missing data in Dec 1999 and possibly elsewhere. There is a strong annual pattern in wind speed and wind direction. Notes for Alexandria Bos data quality checks 0036642 8 ALEXANDRIA - BOS Lat: -33.7 Long: 26.37 Height: 198 m RAINFALL CurOrder: 1952 had an incredibly rainy day (287.5 mm - 1952/09/25) General comments Only 59 occurences of failed readings across the 90 year period. No obvious occurences of gaps in the data. Spring to summer rainfall seems to be the most common. Notes for MentzDam basic data quality check Notes There is a large percentage of missing data (gaps) in the rainfall series General comments Rainfall: Station called Darlington Dam in the original data files. 504 occurnces (2.2%) failed readings - this includes Dec 2003 and March to July 2004 and April and October 2006 (i.e. these dates are missing). 1948/12/31 to 1949/09/01 missing; 1949/12/31 to 1951/07/01 missing; 1952, 1953, 1954 missing; Jul, Aug, Sep 1955 missing; Feb, Mar 1956 missing; 1957, 1958 missing. THis means that there is a large proportion (c.a 8 or 9 years) of missing data in this set. There is about 61 years of data spanning almost 70 years. Temperature: Called Darlington Dam in the original data files. There are no large gaps in the dataset and there is a strong annual pattern in temperature. Notes for OifantsPark basic data quality checks 0055447A7 ADDO ELEPHANT PARK Lat: -33.44 Long: 25.75 Height: 143 m CurOrder: ELEC_TEMPNotes 2005/02/01to 04 missing from the rain data series - these dates were added It seems as though data from two different (or an old and a new recording device) were spliced together at this date -- April 2005 (the fonts change here) Spike in July 1979 rainfall confirmed by other stations. General comments Temperature: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern and no obvious errors. Rainfall: July 1979 shows the same spike in rainfall to other adjecent stations. Otherwise there is generally summer rainfall and there are no apparent gaps. Humidity: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in humidity and lowest humidity in the middle of the day. Pressure: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in pressure with lowest pressure in summer (highest in winter). Wind: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in wind speed and direction data Notes for Sondagsriveiermond-Bos basic data quality check 0035643 3 SONDAGSRIVIERMOND - BOS Lat: -33.72 Long: 25.87 Height: 15 m CLOSED CurOrder: Notes There is a three month gap in 2005 where no readings were taken. Other than this, there is little apparent missing data (and only 2 other failed readings - i.e. cases of Error (No Contact)"). There is no definite pattern in rainfall seasonality. Notes for Zuurberg- Bos basic data quality checks 0055410 8 ZUURBERG - BOS Lat: -33.35 Long: 25.74 Height: 594 m RAINFALL CurOrder: General comments 337 (1%) occurences of failed readings. Most rainfall falls in summer. From 1944 to 1947 there are a large number of days where no rainfall was recorded
column7: but this was accumulated - data may be difficult to interpret. There is also a long period in 1945 of failed readings. Also a large number of accumulated days in 1974 and 1980/81. This is followed by 6 months of failed readings at the end of 1981."
