Notes for MentzDam basic data quality check Notes There is a large percentage of missing data (gaps) in the rainfall series General comments Rainfall: Station called Darlington Dam in the original data files. 504 occurnces (2.2%) failed readings - this includes Dec 2003 and March to July 2004 and April and October 2006 (i.e. these dates are missing). 1948/12/31 to 1949/09/01 missing; 1949/12/31 to 1951/07/01 missing; 1952, 1953, 1954 missing; Jul, Aug, Sep 1955 missing; Feb, Mar 1956 missing; 1957, 1958 missing. THis means that there is a large proportion (c.a 8 or 9 years) of missing data in this set. There is about 61 years of data spanning almost 70 years. Temperature: Called Darlington Dam in the original data files. There are no large gaps in the dataset and there is a strong annual pattern in temperature. Notes for OifantsPark basic data quality checks 0055447A7 ADDO ELEPHANT PARK Lat: -33.44 Long: 25.75 Height: 143 m CurOrder: ELEC_TEMPNotes 2005/02/01to 04 missing from the rain data series - these dates were added It seems as though data from two different (or an old and a new recording device) were spliced together at this date -- April 2005 (the fonts change here) Spike in July 1979 rainfall confirmed by other stations. General comments Temperature: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern and no obvious errors. Rainfall: July 1979 shows the same spike in rainfall to other adjecent stations. Otherwise there is generally summer rainfall and there are no apparent gaps. Humidity: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in humidity and lowest humidity in the middle of the day. Pressure: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in pressure with lowest pressure in summer (highest in winter). Wind: Besides March 2008, there are no gaps in the data. There is an annual pattern in wind speed and direction data Notes for Sondagsriveiermond-Bos basic data quality check 0035643 3 SONDAGSRIVIERMOND - BOS Lat: -33.72 Long: 25.87 Height: 15 m CLOSED CurOrder: Notes There is a three month gap in 2005 where no readings were taken. Other than this, there is little apparent missing data (and only 2 other failed readings - i.e. cases of Error (No Contact)"). There is no definite pattern in rainfall seasonality. Notes for Zuurberg- Bos basic data quality checks 0055410 8 ZUURBERG - BOS Lat: -33.35 Long: 25.74 Height: 594 m RAINFALL CurOrder: General comments 337 (1%) occurences of failed readings. Most rainfall falls in summer. From 1944 to 1947 there are a large number of days where no rainfall was recorded
column7: but this was accumulated - data may be difficult to interpret. There is also a long period in 1945 of failed readings. Also a large number of accumulated days in 1974 and 1980/81. This is followed by 6 months of failed readings at the end of 1981."

Sites surveyed Data were collected from 9 sites. three of the sites where at open waterholes(Boyela, Nkulumbeni South and Nwarihlangari South) and three were at sites closed in 1994(Boyela North, Hlamalala South and Nwarihlangari North). The 3 forb sites were areas that had a high abundance of forbs, and were relatively open with respect to vegetation. they were all within 2-5km of an open waterhole, and were in the vicinity of the windmills Hlamalala South, nwaswitshumbe and Boyela North. Sampling procedure Within each hectare site 1000 points were distributed in a grid. sampling was based on the contact sampling procedure initiated by Yarranton(1996) and modified by Turkington et al 1977. At each point the closest individual to the sampling point was identified and recorded. The next closest individual which was in aerial contact with the first individual was also identified and recorded. This individual was referred to as the contact species. If the individual at the samplingpoint was not in contact with any other individual, it was ecorded as having no contact. The basal diameter of both the individual at the point and the conatct species was recorded. the contacts species data for the open waterholes is not in this data

The studied the seasonal and daily movement patterns and livestock (pastoralists) in the Richtersveld National Park (RNP) to suggest management strategies that would support and balance between biodivesity conservation and living stock grazing. livestock movement patterns indicated that forageis the motivation for winter movements and water is the motivation of summer. The movement followed a predecteble direction from grazing areas in the wet season toward the orange river riparia area with permanent water during periods of low rainfall. the latter can be considered as a ''key reasourse'' area to sustain animals number through critical periods of low rainfall. overall, seasonal movement pattens were in transect of approximately 10km in distance. however,these patterns varied amongst the pastoralists which sugest diverse approaches to tracking reasouse. on averange, a pastoralist move hi animals six time a year between stock posts in a network of grazing routes. the grazing area around a stock post was 2.49km comprising an area of ca. 1950ha. herds walker much more quicky in the morning (1.25km hr) than in the afternoon (0.82km hr) and thus covered more grazing group per unit time. on the basis of the grazing area and travelling rate ( particulary in the morning), all the 36 identified conservation-worthy sites in the National Park were threatened by livestock grazing. Effective management strategies may possibly include zonic, closing some stock posts and careful consideration for opening new roads.

The movement patterns of 20 individual herds of livestock monitored between 1995 and 2001. table 5.1 shows the profile of each pastoralists.Patoralists do not have permanent base in the RNP: they take all their provisions with them as they move their livestock. rock reservoirs, seepage and Orange River) throughout they year. all stock post locations and water point in the RNP were verified to metre accurancy using a trimble Geographical Global Position model. for the seasonal movement patterns, two periods of livestock movement data collection were folowed: quarterly and weekly. the quarterly movement data covers a period of six years and hard location was recorded during January,April, July, and October each year. the weekly movement data were recoded every week by RNP field rangers for three years (1999-2001). The local scale for diunal move,ent patterns was defined as the area around a stock post that is foraged within one day (foraging orbit) in the 'buiteveld' betweeen (1999-2001). This data was collected by accompanying herds on foot during 50 day-long excursions between May and September. I use a Garmin Plus2 GPS to record the movement of the livestock from the time the animal left the stock post until they returned i the evening. The recording involved a GPS location every 30 minites from the time the animals left the stock post unitil noon and every 60 minutes thereafter. the data for 40 herding days (417 telemetry locations) were analysed for the size of foraging area and speed of travelling when grazing away from the stock post. days in which herding was interrupted by pastroralling management practices such as stock sales, vaccination, maintenance and movement between stock posts were not analysed.

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

We collected demographic data on 104 live and a number of dead A dichotoma trees along a transect. We measured height and circumference, categorized them according to a number of live history stages (see attached table ‘categories of live and dead aloes.csv’), and an index of health. We also counted the number of rosettes and inflorescences, and the number of flowers per inforescence.

Ecosystem services and ecotourism are two primary sources of generating revenue for communities in South Africa today. Ecotourism has been an effective method of resource management in generating viable economic development in rural South African Communities. Ecotourism concentrates on conserving the environment while at the same time assisting in sustaining the best interests of local people. Ecosystem services include, but are not limited to, fuelwood, medicinal plants, river sand and industrial timber, provide rural employment and cash income through sales. In investigating the total projected revenue generation of both practices, I have concluded that by combining the two methods South African rural communities can ensure economic diversity and economic, social, political and psychological empowerment.
Scott Briscoe SANParks,South Africa Independent Project
Scott Briscoe SANParks,South Africa Independent Project
ecosystem services, ecotourism, natural resource management, revenue generation

In researching ecotourism as a source for revenue generation, the Makuleke model for ecotourism was used. A personal interview with Tinyeko Maluleke, from the Makuleke community was held at the Outpost Lodge in the Makuleke region in KNP. Tinyeko Maluleke is a current employee at the Outpost and holds a managerial position. A personal interview was also conducted with Livingston Maluleke, the spokesperson for the CPA and the a chairperson who sits on the Joint Management Board (JMB). The JMB handles decisions regarding land and conservation and is comprised of three members from South African National Parks (SANP) and three members from the Makuleke community. The interviews consisted of a list of questions (fig 1) regarding employment generated income, the allocation of funds generated from ecotourism ventures, methods of reassuring conservation principles, average mean incomes, sources of household incomes. Because of the sensitivity surrounding the Makuleke land claim with SANP and the South African government, collecting specific income numbers was a timely process and not all the data needed for an effective comparison was gathered. In investigating the revenue generating possibilities of ecosystem services, several previously written papers were used as sources. I then compared the two income projections, i.e. ecotourism and ecosystem services, to help in determining the best possible practice for a South African rural community.

In December 2006, seven prime bulls (35-55 years of age) were collared on the eastern border of the Kruger National Park (KNP) in collaboration with SANParks, the objective being to identify movement routes between the KNP and Limpopo National Park. All study animals were fitted with GPS satellite collars due to the possible lack of cell reception in Mozambique. Field testing of the satellite tracking devices (model AWT SM2000E, African Wildlife Tracking, South Africa, Pretoria) had a root mean square error of <30 m with expected location success between 88-96% when tested in the field. The final elephant tracking data set was obtained via a “data downloader” supplying near real-time entry of data into a geodatabase while a data filter removed obviously erroneous GPS fixes, based on a maximum rate of travel. Data gaps due to field conditions such as thick vegetation, topography, satellite positioning or improper collar angles were also filtered until a cleaned dataset was imported.

From the late 1970's the KNP made use of aerial surveys to estimate ungulate populations in the KNP. In the beginning the entire KNP was subdivided in smaller blocks and the entire area was covered. This method was very time and labour intensive, expensive and the estimates had no confidence intervals associated with them. It was also suspected that this technique resulted in an undercount bias. For these reasons in 1997 it was decided to change to a sample count using transects placed from east to west and use the distance statistical method to analyse the data. There was no survey in 2009 or in 2011

Survey design A systematic survey design using parallel transects starting at a random point were used. Transects were placed from east to west across the entire width of the knp obtaining transectlines of different lengths and spaced far enough apart so as not to detect the same object on more than one transect. From the random starting pin transect lines were placed every thrid minute resulting in 64 lines and a coverage of 15%. Before the 2001 survey it was thought that the 15% sample may be too small so the lines were increased to 95 which increased the percentage to 22% Field methods A six seater paternavia was used for the surveys with two observers on either side of the plane and the pilot and the datta capturer in the front. A distance of 400m on both sides of the aircraft was covered by the observers. AS there is a zone directly beneath the aircraft that can not be seen by any of the observers this area was excluded from the area covered. the detection area was further subdivided into 4 bands, 0-50m, 50-100m, 100-200m and 200-400m. When an animal was observed the obsever indicated into which band this observation fell by alligning the animal with the lines on the window. these sightings were then recorded by the data capturer and an automatic GPS position was taken. Any animal seen further than 400m were excluded. Entire KNP 15% up until 2000 22% from 2001-2003

Nocturnal flying insects fly in a straight line by maintaining a constant angle with the brightest light in the sky, usually the moon. The moon is always above the horizon and therefore moonlight always strikes insects from the top and never from below. When observing whether insects would fly to a light source shining from below them in comparison to a light source shining from above, no insects flew to the light shining from below, while several flew to the lights source shining from above. Samevatting: Nagtelike vliënde insekte vlieg in ŉ reguit lyn deur ŉ konstante hoek te bly hou met die helderste lig in die hệmel, wat gewoontlik die maan is. Die maan is altyd bo die horison en daarvoor raak dit altyd die insekte van bo af en nooit van onder af nie. Terwyl my ondersoek om uit te vind of insekte verkies om na ŉ lig vanaf onder of bo te kom het ek gevind dat daar min was wat na die lig vanaf onder gekom het. Die insekte het dikwels na die lig van bo gekom.

My study sites were the Skukuza and Shingwetzi camps in the Kruger National Park. I conducted two trials in Skukuza and one trial in Shingwetzi. I cut out a piece of cardboard one meter in length and .4 meters in width. In the middle of the rectangle two holes 1.5 cm in diameter were cut out. In each hole I placed a flashlight pointing in opposite directs. I then taped the barrier to a wall with equal amount of wall area above and below the barrier. For each trial I observed and tallied the insects that flew towards the light from above and below. An event would only be considered if the insects flew towards the light and either touched the light source or the barrier. Each trial was one hour long and began at 20h00. The trials were completed 23 February, 24 February, and 2 March respectively. The statistics performed was a χ2 – test.

Herbaceous biomass is a dynamic feature in the Kruger National Park (KNP), changing across space and over time. Rainfall, geology, herbivory and fire are four of the main drivers influencing the large-scale distribution of herbaceous biomass in semi-arid savanna systems like Kruger. Knowing how herbaceous biomass are distributed in the landscape is important since it (i) act as fuel load for fires, (ii) serve as forage for grazers, and (iii) create patches and habitats for different components of biodiversity. The rangers and field rangers collect disc pasture meter readings annually throughout the KNP at Veld Condition Assessment (VCA) sites (Appendix A). Making use of a calibration equation, these readings are translated into herbaceous biomass estimates (Appendix B) which are then used by SANParks’ Fire Ecologist (Navashni Govender) to set fire targets for the different ranger sections.

Colophospermum mopane seems to dominate wherever it is found. We examined the life history strategy of C. mopane in an arid savanna that leads to its dominance, specifically, its herbivore defense strategies, its mechanisms to cope with fire, and its competitive ability. We also examined possible trade-offs in its ability to establish and colonize an area. Our results indicate that where C. mopane dominates, there is a drop in non-mopane species richness and biomass. Both tree and shrub forms of C. mopane occur in higher biomass in deep red Kalahari sands. There is an inverse relationship regarding biomass and soil depth for other species co-occuring with C. mopane. Our results indicate that C. mopane can attribute its dominance to its herbivore defenses, ability to cope with fire, and resource utilization.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa

Methods Study Site MNP is located on the banks of the Limpopo River and is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna. It is also the capital of one of the earliest known kingdoms in sub-Saharan Africa. It is located in a semi-arid area of the country with annual rainfall ranges from 350-400 mm. Characterized by mopane bushveld and savannah vegetation, it is home to 24 species of acacia tree and eight commiphora. Trees near the Limpopo flood plain grow in a dense, riparian fringe with closed canopy. MNP lies in a basin between two granite cartons with rocky outcrops of dolerite dykes (Flemminger 2006). Study species Colospermum mopane (C. mopane). Experimental design and protocol To examine life history strategy affecting distribution and dominance of C. mopane, fourteen plots were randomly selected within MNP along the main park road from 09/09/09 – 10/09/09 (Appendix 1 for GPS coordinates). After picking an initial plot, we stopped every 0.5 kilometers along the road and walked 50 meters off the road. Each plot in the park was roughly a hectare. Additionally, five plots were selected outside the park near the Southern boundary to evaluate the extent of C. mopane dominance outside of MNP (see Appendix 1). The 5 plots outside the park were not included in Figures 1 – 6, because a fence limited our ability to sample biomass. We were able to take soil augers, identify species with binoculars, and observe C. mopane in plots 15 - 19. It should be noted that we chose plots with few rocky outcrops and avoided slopes due to the limitations of the Bitterlich Wedge, which is only accurate on flat landscapes. In order to assess its competitive ability, we examined the relative biomass of C. mopane and other species using a Bitterlich wedge (W. Bond pers. comm.) to measure the biomass of the plot in square meters per hectare. The wedge is a rapid method of measuring biomass and consists of a 50 cm rope with one end attached to an 8 x 7 cm card with a 0.5 cm slit cut in the card. We counted the number of trunks or stems that were larger than the slit while the rope was held at eye level. By rotating 360 degrees with the wedge, all species that had stems or trunks larger than the slit were identified and recorded. If a tree had multiple stems that were larger than the slit, each stem was counted. The final count was multiplied by 0.25 to yield the biomass in square meters per hectare. To account for shrub biomass, we used the same Bitterlich wedge, but only counted a shrub if it was wider than the 8 cm side of the cardboard. Shrubs were defined as cagey structures with branches below the height of 1.5 meters. Overlap existed between the two groups as some trees were also counted as shrubs. In order to obtain a general understanding of landscapes that C. mopane inhabits and dominantes, landscape observations were made at each plot for soil, grass cover, species assemblage, species characteristics, and evidence of herbivory. A soil auger was used to take three soil samples at each of the 19 plots to determine the color, soil depth, and composition at different depths. All tree species within a plot were identified and their characteristics were described in order to provide a general picture of C. mopane’s competitors and the different life history strategies they employ to combat herbivory and fire. We noted architecture (cage or pole structure), defense mechanisms (spinesence and palatability), leaf presence or absence, density of undergrowth, bark thickness, herbivory (presence of dung and evidence of grazing), and grass cover. Additionally, to assess their below ground competitive ability, two C. mopane, one Combretum apiculatum, and one Boscia foetida were excavated to observe underground biomass and root structure. Bark thickness was measured in cm for five species at two plots in MNP to assess their ability to cope with fire. It was taken by measuring the width of the target stem and by measuring the thickness of bark when cut away to reveal the xylem. These two measurements were taken in relation to one another to give the relative bark thickness in comparison to stem size. We controlled for stem size between individuals by selecting stems with a diameter between 8 and 12 cm. Regression analyses were performed using Microsoft Excel 2007 for Windows and Sigma Plot was used to determine significance.

Methods Study Site MNP is located on the banks of the Limpopo River and is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna. It is also the capital of one of the earliest known kingdoms in sub-Saharan Africa. It is located in a semi-arid area of the country with annual rainfall ranges from 350-400 mm. Characterized by mopane bushveld and savannah vegetation, it is home to 24 species of acacia tree and eight commiphora. Trees near the Limpopo flood plain grow in a dense, riparian fringe with closed canopy. MNP lies in a basin between two granite cartons with rocky outcrops of dolerite dykes (Flemminger 2006). Study species Colospermum mopane (C. mopane). Experimental design and protocol To examine life history strategy affecting distribution and dominance of C. mopane, fourteen plots were randomly selected within MNP along the main park road from 09/09/09 – 10/09/09 (Appendix 1 for GPS coordinates). After picking an initial plot, we stopped every 0.5 kilometers along the road and walked 50 meters off the road. Each plot in the park was roughly a hectare. Additionally, five plots were selected outside the park near the Southern boundary to evaluate the extent of C. mopane dominance outside of MNP (see Appendix 1). The 5 plots outside the park were not included in Figures 1 – 6, because a fence limited our ability to sample biomass. We were able to take soil augers, identify species with binoculars, and observe C. mopane in plots 15 - 19. It should be noted that we chose plots with few rocky outcrops and avoided slopes due to the limitations of the Bitterlich Wedge, which is only accurate on flat landscapes. In order to assess its competitive ability, we examined the relative biomass of C. mopane and other species using a Bitterlich wedge (W. Bond pers. comm.) to measure the biomass of the plot in square meters per hectare. The wedge is a rapid method of measuring biomass and consists of a 50 cm rope with one end attached to an 8 x 7 cm card with a 0.5 cm slit cut in the card. We counted the number of trunks or stems that were larger than the slit while the rope was held at eye level. By rotating 360 degrees with the wedge, all species that had stems or trunks larger than the slit were identified and recorded. If a tree had multiple stems that were larger than the slit, each stem was counted. The final count was multiplied by 0.25 to yield the biomass in square meters per hectare. To account for shrub biomass, we used the same Bitterlich wedge, but only counted a shrub if it was wider than the 8 cm side of the cardboard. Shrubs were defined as cagey structures with branches below the height of 1.5 meters. Overlap existed between the two groups as some trees were also counted as shrubs. In order to obtain a general understanding of landscapes that C. mopane inhabits and dominantes, landscape observations were made at each plot for soil, grass cover, species assemblage, species characteristics, and evidence of herbivory. A soil auger was used to take three soil samples at each of the 19 plots to determine the color, soil depth, and composition at different depths. All tree species within a plot were identified and their characteristics were described in order to provide a general picture of C. mopane’s competitors and the different life history strategies they employ to combat herbivory and fire. We noted architecture (cage or pole structure), defense mechanisms (spinesence and palatability), leaf presence or absence, density of undergrowth, bark thickness, herbivory (presence of dung and evidence of grazing), and grass cover. Additionally, to assess their below ground competitive ability, two C. mopane, one Combretum apiculatum, and one Boscia foetida were excavated to observe underground biomass and root structure. Bark thickness was measured in cm for five species at two plots in MNP to assess their ability to cope with fire. It was taken by measuring the width of the target stem and by measuring the thickness of bark when cut away to reveal the xylem. These two measurements were taken in relation to one another to give the relative bark thickness in comparison to stem size. We controlled for stem size between individuals by selecting stems with a diameter between 8 and 12 cm. Regression analyses were performed using Microsoft Excel 2007 for Windows and Sigma Plot was used to determine significance.
The dominance of Colophospermum mopane in an arid savanna: An analysis of life history strategy

Methods We studied insect pollinator activity on flowers of 29 species of trees and shrubs in the Skukuza Ranger District, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, Republic of South Africa, during the late dry season and/or early rainy seasons in the years 2009-2012 (inclusive). Floral visitor sampling was conducted under optimal temperature (greater than 20° C) and precipitation (non-rainy, usually clear skies to partly cloudy) conditions for insect activity. We recorded lists of pollinator species observed on each plant species for further food web analysis.

A ground-based survey of Pel's Fishing Owl Scotopelia peli along the Olifants River in the Kruger National Park was conducted from the 22nd-25th of June 2008 by two teams of observers from SAN-Parks, staff and volunteers from EWT-BoPWG. This ground survey was the second to be conducted for the Pel's Fishing Owl and other selected species occurring along the Olifants River in the Kruger National Park since the detailed surveys conducted by Keith Begg (unpubl. data) in the early 1990's. It was preceded by a similar survey being conducted over the corresponding week in 2007 and forms part of the registered research project focused on this species within the Kruger National Park.
SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa
SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa
Judith Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 SA +0927 13 7354309 +0927 13 7354055 judithk@sanparks.org Custodian/Steward

Survey methods The ground survey was conducted over a period of four days by two separate teams (see acknowledgements), with preference being given to the early morning, from shortly after sunrise until the survey was completed for the day. Each team consisted of 6 observers with 3 observers on the northern- and 3 on the southern bank of the river walking downstream and recording what they see.Only avifauna was recorded once it/they had flown passed in a westerly direction thus avoiding duplication. However, due to the high levels of the river and the inaccessibility of certain sites on the southern bank in the western half of the survey area, very little physical coverage of the southern bank in this area could be obtained. It is likely that some owls may have been missed due to this limitation.The teams walked along the riverbank, scouring suitable looking trees for the presence (flushed birds or confirmed sightings) or signs of Pel's Fishing Owl being present. The Eastern team was divided into two to cover both the northern and southern banks of the river walking in a straight line at times extending to approximately 50-150 metres from the river banks on both sides depending on the extent of riparian vegetation. Tributaries with suitable vegetation were also covered for at least 100-500m from the main river depending on the nature of the vegetation. Regular radio contact was maintained between the teams and all relevant information was recorded on a CyberTracker device or Dictaphone carried by each team leader. Standard information recorded for all sightings or signs of Pel's Fishing Owl were the following: 1. Time 2. GPS Coordinates 3. North or South Bank 4. Species of tree/s (if relevant) and description of site 5. Nature of sighting or signs (feathers, faeces, prey remains, roost, potential nesting site) 6. Number of birds In addition to Pel's Fishing Owl, sightings of other waterbirds, raptors and hippopotamus were also recorded along the survey area. All relevant species of birds flying or moving past the teams in an easterly direction were recorded. No birds flying to the east or ahead of the direction of movement of the teams were recorded to prevent potential double counts. Field rangers accompanying the teams also took the opportunity of recording any sightings and spoor of certain game species, the presence of alien vegetation and other information The survey was conducted in the riparian vegetation along the Olifants River in the central area of the Kruger National Park, stretching from the western boundary fence of the Park, known as Mamba Picket (2402"025'S 031"12"545'E) to the eastern boundary fence beyond Bangu Gorge (23"57"651'S 031"52"850'E)
column7: a distance of approximately 93km along the river. The riparian vegetation in this area is dominated by tree species such as Jackalberry Diospyros mespiliformis
column10: Anatree Acacia albida and Weeping Boer-bean Schotia brachypetala. Shrubby vegetation of the lower stratum consists mainly of species such as Red Spike-thorn Maytenus senegalensis and Large Fever Berry Croton megalobotrys spp. Vegetation suited to the requirements of Pel's Fishing Owl occurs sporadically along the course of the river. Each team consisted of 6 observers with 3 observers on the northern- and 3 on the southern bank of the river walking downstream and recording what they see."

Content: Andre Botha Endangered Wildlife Trust Private Bag X11 Parkview 2122 (011) 486-1102 andreb@ewt.org.za

Arundo donax is an invasive weed which was recently discovered on the Sabie River in Kruger National Park and like many invasives it is thought to reduce biodiversity in its invaded environment. In this experiment we looked at the effects of the invasive weed on insect biodiversity in a riparian environment. We compared the species richness of A. donax to the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus and to a mixed vegetation environment. We found that A. donax did not significantly decrease the number of individuals or number of species found in pitfall traps. Biological diversity indices showed, however, that there was in fact a higher diversity in the A. donax insect populations. We also took measurements of the insect diversity of the three vegetation types by beating the reeds and analyzing the insects that fell out. We found a lower species richness in A. donax than in P. mauritianus. This can be explained by the fact that one species of ant is dominating P. mauritianus on the ground but dominating A. donax in the upper layers of the reed. This, in turn, says that the dominating species is pushing out other species accounting for a lowered diversity that might otherwise be found. In our study, A. donax did not significantly affect the biodiversity of insects overall found on P mauritianus within a riparian ecosystem.

Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 South Africa
Arundo donax, biodiversity, invasive species, alien species, Phragmites mauritianus,

methods In order to determine the effects of invasion by A. donax on insect biodiversity, we conducted a study on the Sabie River (24. 97978 0S, 31. 48186 0 E) in Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, on 10 October 2005. We laid pitfall traps to assess insect abundance within three different sites, viz. stands of the native reed, Phragmites mauritianus, stands of the invasive reed Arundo donax as well as mixed stands of the two reed types. We chose two sites of the native, P. mauritianus, big enough to sufficiently cover a 2m by 2m matrix of pitfall traps, two sites of the invasive reed, A. donax and two sites of mixed vegetation. 2 different sized pitfall traps were used- the larger pitfall traps were 10 cm in diameter and 10 cm in depth, and the smaller traps were 4 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep. At each site, we laid nine pitfall traps in a 2m by 2m matrix, with alternating sized traps 1m apart. (Figure 1) Each vegetation type had one of each matrix type shown in Figure 1 A and B. This gave us 4 small and 5 big traps at one site and 5 small and 4 big at the other site for each vegetation type. Once all the traps were laid, we filled them each ¼ of the way full with anti-freeze to kill any insects that fell into the trap that could possibly climb or fly out. Insects were collected 2 days later from the traps, and were identified by morphospecies back at the laboratory. On the same day that the pitfall traps were cleared, in order to collect another type of data, we collected insects from all 3 vegetation types by beating the vegetation. We placed a round tray with a 50cm diameter on the ground and repeatedly beat the vegetation with a 1 meter stick for 20 seconds. We then placed all the insects that fell out of the reeds onto the tray into vials and labelled them. This was repeated 10 times at each vegetation type (A. donax, mixed vegetation and P.mauritianus). These individuals were also taken back to the lab and identified to morphospecies. In order to determine whether the diversity of insects was significantly different in the three sites, data for the number of individuals per trap, and the number of species per trap were analysed using Kruskal-Wallis, multiple comparison of means tests. (Statistica version. 6) When certain values were not considered significant we then did a post-hoc test to determine which, if any, of the relationships were significant. Similarities or differences in the insect communities were then determined using Primer to do a Multi Dimensional Scaling (MDS) plot, a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the number of individuals and species we collected in each trap. Next, we used Stastica again to do a Kruskal-Wallis test on the number of individuals collected per beating and the number of species per beating. Primer was then used to calculate a similarity matrix and a biodiversity index for the beating samples

Given the detrimental effects of the artificial watering program in the Kruger National Park, a number of artificial watering points have been closed. This study examined the effect of waterhole closures in the Shingwedzi area on rodent populations through live trapping methods, with particular attention paid to abundance, richness, and diversity. In contrast to similar studies conducted near Punda Maria, we did not find a significant difference between the populations around closed versus open waterholes. As rodents can be used as environmental indicators, this suggests that closure of waterholes alone is not enough to improve the biodiversity of these disturbed sites. Further studies should consider seasonality, as this was a winter assessment.
Jennifer Mizen and Bryan Barnhill SANParks, South Africa Independent Project I
Jennifer Mizen and Bryan Barnhill SANParks, South Africa Independent Project I
artificial waterholes, biodiversity, rodents, Sherman traps

The study sites consisted of two open and two closed artificial watering holes. The sites were chosen by soil type, absence of recent burning from wildfire, and operational status. The soil type at all of the sites was basalt, in order to control for differences in resource availability due to vegetation. Thirty Sherman traps were used at each site, arranged in two 3 x 5 arrays with traps set 10 meters apart. Approximately equal numbers of short and long Sherman traps were used in each array. The arrays were positioned on opposite sides of the watering troughs at sites 1, 2, and 3, and on adjacent 69 sides of the trough at site 4. At sites 1, 2 and 3 the arrays began 20 meters from watering trough, as measured from the short sides of the trough at the first two sites and the long sides of the trough at the third site. The arrays at site 4 began 50 meters from the water trough. The traps were placed under bushes and/or in long grass and covered with grass or leaves for camouflage as well as protection from the heat of the sun. The traps were positioned and baited on the morning of September 21, and checked for the next three mornings. A mixture of peanut butter, honey, and oats was used as bait. The bait was then changed to a mixture of peanut butter with oats and honey for the remainder of the trapping time. Individuals captured were uniquely marked with hair dye or permanent marker, in order to note recapture. Each rodent’s weight, sex and species were recorded before release in the proximity of the trap. Data were compiled and analyzed using Microsoft Excel and Primer 5. The capture rate was calculated by dividing the number of successful captures by the total trapping effort (“trap days”), taking into account the loss of several traps during the course of the study due to trampling. G-tests were preformed to determine the significance of the open versus closed sites in terms of trap success and on short versus long trap use on trap success. Richness and abundance were also calculated for each site as measures of number of species found and numbers of individuals captured, respectively. Data from the 2004 and 2005 studies were rendered comparable to this study, then all three studies were analyzed in reference to each other. Shannon-Weiner tests were used to determine diversity indices for all eight sites studied between 2004 and 2006. Data were log-transformed before multidimensional scaling (MDS) ordination.

In this study, we examined whether leaf presence affected ant abundances on Acacia grandicornuta, and how the presence of scale insects on Acacia robusta affected ant species abundance. In order to asses the benefits accrued by the plants, we also tested attack times of three genera of ants following a disturbance to the host tree. It was determined that both ant species richness and concentration were significantly greater on A. grandicornuta containing leaves. This result suggests that the presence of leaves drives the mutualism between A. grandicornuta and ants, and when leaves are not present, ant concentrations decrease. We also determined that Black Sugar Ants (Lepisiota capensis) exist in greater abundance on A. robusta when scale insects are present, and this populace of L. capensis correlates to a reduction in the abundance of other ant species. Finally, our results show that L. capensis attack significantly quicker than other ant genera following a disturbance to the host tree. This demonstrates the ability of L. capensis to colonize and dominate a host tree, causing a significant decrease in the abundance of other ant genera. These results convey that a facultative mutualism exists among A. robusta, L. capensis, and scale insects; L. capensis provides protection for both A. robusta and scale insects, while scale insects offer nutritional benefits to the resident ants.

Site selection and Field sampling This study was conducted in and around the Skukuza rest camp of Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga province, South Africa (24°98” S 31°60” E). We conducted and performed all field work for our study and subsequent experiment over the course of a three day period from October 10, 2005 to October 12, 2005, near the end of the dry season. Our study species were Acacia grandicornuta and Acacia robusta. A. grandicornuta is a medium-sized tree with deep fissured bark and paired, short thorns, and is often found on either sodic or clay soils throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa. A. grandicornuta is tolerant of dry conditions and is normally leafless from August to October. A. robusta is a single-stemmed tree with paired, straight, modified stipules as thorns and an annual leaf presence. A. robusta tends to grow throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa, typically near a water source and it rarely occurs in homogeneous stands. Neither A. grandicornuta nor A. robusta are known to produce extra floral nectaries, food bodies or beltian bodies (Smit 1999). We examined 26 Acacia grandicornuta individuals—12 possessing leaves and 14 lacking leaves—all located in and around the staff village of the Skukuza main camp, primarily near the golf course. We chose to observe A. grandicornuta in order to compare the status of this facultative ant-plant mutualism when leaves were present and absent. This was possible as A. grandicornuta loses its leaves from late August to early October, thus yielding a sufficient abundance of individuals with and without leaves. We then examined 14 Acacia robusta individuals—all of which possessed leaves. For each A. grandicornuta and A. robusta individual encountered, we recorded a number of observations: the average abundance of ants, ant species composition, the presence or absence of scale insects, and the degree of defensive behavior of the ants on each tree. The abundance of ants on each tree was obtained by selecting two .25m by .5m sections, estimating the number of ants per section, and averaging the two abundance measures. We identified our ant samples down to genus, and in one instance down to species. Following our initial study, we conducted a subsequent experiment in which we generated an artificial disturbance. To mimic natural herbivory processes we scratched the trunk of the tree while simultaneously shaking a branch. Analysis Mann-Whitney U-tests were performed to test for significant differences in ant abundance dependent on leaf presence and scale insect presence in A. grandicornuta and A. robusta respectively. A Kruskal-Wallis test was conducted to determine differences in attack time among three ant genera.

Methods The census methods and associated conditions are described in the annual reports, and for the EAS surveys by Viljoen and Retief (Koedoe No. 37, pp. 149-157, 1994). In summary they were conducted by fixed-wing aircraft flying parallel strips, generally 800 m apart, aiming at complete ground coverage. However, all regions of the Kruger Park were fully covered only over 1980-1993. When coverage was incomplete, the park total for each species was projected from the trend in the regions that were covered. Count totals for the period earlier than 1977 were adjusted for the lower visibility from the air of certain species using differential ground counts. The park perimeter was entirely fenced until 1993, when sections of the western boundary fence adjoining private nature reserves were removed. Count totals have been sub-divided among four regions: South = between Crocodile and Sabi Rivers; Central = between Sabi and Olifants Rivers; North = between Olifants and Letaba Rivers; Far North = north of Letaba River, excluding the section north of Punda Maria that was covered irregularly

Method step Carcasses of dead animals were located opportunistically by section rangers or other field staff, with cause of death assigned either from the presence of the predator or from signs associated with the carcass. Smaller species and the young of larger species tend to be under-recorded because their carcasses may be consumed completely by predators and scavengers and are thus less likely to be found. Those for the period up to 1985 were submitted in rangers’ diary reports, and subsequently entered into an electronic database. Those from 1987 onwards were submitted electronically on computer sheets. Records for 1986 were missing. The original records are on file at the Scientific Services Division at Skukuza in the Kruger National Park. An assessment of the potential biases in these records is presented in Owen-Smith and Mills (Journal of Animal Ecology in press 2008) and supplementary data files. The attached data list the number of individuals of each prey species recorded as killed by lions in each calendar year, sub-divided between the two halves of the Kruger National Park. “South” represents the section south of the Olifants River, and “North” the section north of this river. The actual localities of these kills are recorded by place name in the original files

Climate change has significant implications for biodiversity, ecosystem functioning and consequently human well-being. It is also recognized that climate change impacts do not occur in isolation, and that it is the interaction between climate change and other key drivers of environmental change that are altering the world as we know it. The six main direct drivers of Global Environmental Change (GEC) are climate change, habitat change, invasive alien species, disease, pollution, and unsustainable harvesting. What are the implications of global environmental change for protected areas, and more specifically for SANParks? This question has been raised and recognized within SANParks at various levels, evidenced for example by the fact that the completion of a climate change assessment and response strategy is a milestone in SANParks’ 2009- 2010 Business Plan. In November 2009, Conservation Services Division conducted a preliminary 2-day Assessment of Global Environmental Change in South African National Parks. The objectives of the GEC Workshop were to (i) improve the shared rationality andunderstanding on global environmental change within CSD, (ii) initiate a research agenda for global change in parks, and (iii) to deliver a preliminary report on global environmental change in parks with suggestions on a way forward. This document provides a summary of the outcome and outlines recommendations for a way forward and lead to the initiation of a more thorough quantiative assessment.

The African savanna is a biome driven by many ecological factors. While each has their own part to play, the most observable of these ecosystem drivers are the herbivores. The utilization of the savanna by herbivores results in a variety of patches within the landscape. These patches run the gauntlet from woodland to open grassland and everything in between. The bulk feeders such as elephants (Loxodonta africana) and white rhinos (Ceratotherium simum) are the most obvious and impactful of the herbivores, due to their generalist feeding habits and large size. Elephants greatly reduce vertical diversity of woody plant species by knocking down medium-sized trees and stripping the bark from others, exposing the vulnerable xylem to the periodic fires that rage through the savanna. White rhino crop the grasses of the savanna short, creating wide grazing lawns that often result in a shift of species composition in the area (Scholes et al. 2003).

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa

Methods Study Sites The study took place within Mapungubwe National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa. Specific sites were restricted to within 100 meters of the roads within the park. This savanna landscape is dominated by grasses but tree species like Acacia, Commiphora, and Mopane are also commonly found there. Annual rainfall ranges from 350-400 mm. Prevalent herbivores include eland (Tragelaphus oryx), kudu, wildebeest, zebra, waterbuck (Kobus ellipsiprymnus), impala, bushbuck (Tragelaphus scriptus), klipspringer (Oreotragus oreotragus), duiker (Sylvicapra grimmia), steenbok, gemsbok (Oryx gazella), giraffe (Giraffa camelopardalis), and elephant (SANParks 2009). Experimental Design Observations took place for three mornings from September 14 to 16, 2009. We drove along the same six loops of approximately 15 km over the three day observation period between the hours of 5:45 and 11:00am. We recorded eating events witnessed from the vehicle on our loops. An eating event was defined as real-time observation of herbivore(s) feeding on plant or grass biomass. GPS coordinates, distance and direction from the GDV, time, species type, and number of individuals were recorded for each eating event observed. Time spent observing each event varied, depending on the amount of time the animals remained within view or took to acclimate to our presence. It never surpassed 10 minutes (except for Event 10 when an injured elephant blocked the road for roughly 30 minutes). When multiple species of herbivores were observed foraging together, we recorded those species of which individuals were grazing or browsing. We later chose seven 20x20m sites where we had repeatedly observed foraging events and/or large groups of herbivores. We visited these sites in the afternoon when there were no herbivores present in order to measure various characteristics of these foraging locations. We divided each site into four 5mx5mx4m subplots alternating along a 20m central line. Within each subplot, we recorded tree species (and height/leaf cover when present), dung presence, and grass cover. For each subplot, we also collected a soil sample of about 175 g for later analysis. We also measured visibility for each site using Cody’s vegetation analysis model from the center of the plot (Cody’s vegetation analysis model, L. Kruger, personal communication). Cody’s model involves one person who stands at the center of the plot and another that holds a blank sheet of 8.5” x 11” paper. The individual with the paper walks in a straight line away from the center towards the edge of the plot and stops when only 50% of the sheet is visible from the center. The distance between the individuals is then measured. Biomass index was calculated as the inverse of our visibility measurements; lower visibility index was analogous to less plant biomass and therefore more visibility. For each plot we chose, we paired it with a random plot of the same size two kilometers away and across the road. There, we collected data on the same variables as the foraging plots. To further investigate the soil characteristics of preferred foraging sites, we performed three tests on each soil sample collected. The first was a measure of conductivity using a conductivity meter. We used conductivity as a proxy indicator of nutrient content for each soil sample because it is a measure of ion content and would reflect the concentration of ions such as sodium found in the soil. In addition, we left the soil samples out to dry for 24 hours and compared the pre- and post-drying weights. The difference in weights can be attributed to water moisture, so this value can be used to assess the amount of moisture in the soil. Foraging plots were hypothesized to have higher soil moisture content due to the high amount of vegetation there. The final test we used on the soil samples was qualitative “finger test” to determine soil type to see if there was a correlation between foraging plot soil types. Data Analyses To support our hypothesis that nutrients are the driving factor in herbivore forage site selection, we would expect to find higher conductivity, higher soil moisture and more clayey soils in the foraging plots than the random plots. We would expect biomass index to be random across both sets of plots and not be statistically significant. To evaluate visibility, soil moisture, and conductivity, we performed a Mann-Whitney U-test to compare medians between sample types and determine if a significant difference exists between the two plot types. A chi-square test was utilized to assess the difference between soil types. We also summed all the environmental factors (grass cover, conductivity, water moisture, visibility) and performed a Bray-Curtis similarity matrix. Woody vegetation was omitted from these factors because it did not play a determining role in herbivore patch selection. We then plotted similarity based on the Bray-Curtis matrix in a Multi-Dimensional Scale (MDS) plot, which renders each plot in a three-dimensional field where distance between plots is indicative of similarity. We expected the foraging plots to be placed closer together in the MDS than the random plots, thereby expressing a high degree of similarity. To perform the chi-square and Mann-Whitney U statistical analyses, we utilized Statistica version 6 2004. For the Bray-Curtis matrix and MDS plot, we used the program PRIMER version 5.12 2000.

SANParks, South Africa, Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa

In this study, we examined whether leaf presence affected ant abundances on Acacia grandicornuta, and how the presence of scale insects on Acacia robusta affected ant species abundance. In order to asses the benefits accrued by the plants, we also tested attack times of three genera of ants following a disturbance to the host tree. It was determined that both ant species richness and concentration were significantly greater on A. grandicornuta containing leaves. This result suggests that the presence of leaves drives the mutualism between A. grandicornuta and ants, and when leaves are not present, ant concentrations decrease. We also determined that Black Sugar Ants (Lepisiota capensis) exist in greater abundance on A. robusta when scale insects are present, and this populace of L. capensis correlates to a reduction in the abundance of other ant species. Finally, our results show that L. capensis attack significantly quicker than other ant genera following a disturbance to the host tree. This demonstrates the ability of L. capensis to colonize and dominate a host tree, causing a significant decrease in the abundance of other ant genera. These results convey that a facultative mutualism exists among A. robusta, L. capensis, and scale insects; L. capensis provides protection for both A. robusta and scale insects, while scale insects offer nutritional benefits to the resident ants.

Site selection and Field sampling This study was conducted in and around the Skukuza rest camp of Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga province, South Africa (24°98” S 31°60” E). We conducted and performed all field work for our study and subsequent experiment over the course of a three day period from October 10, 2005 to October 12, 2005, near the end of the dry season. Our study species were Acacia grandicornuta and Acacia robusta. A. grandicornuta is a medium-sized tree with deep fissured bark and paired, short thorns, and is often found on either sodic or clay soils throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa. A. grandicornuta is tolerant of dry conditions and is normally leafless from August to October. A. robusta is a single-stemmed tree with paired, straight, modified stipules as thorns and an annual leaf presence. A. robusta tends to grow throughout the north-eastern region of South Africa, typically near a water source and it rarely occurs in homogeneous stands. Neither A. grandicornuta nor A. robusta are known to produce extra floral nectaries, food bodies or beltian bodies (Smit 1999). We examined 26 Acacia grandicornuta individuals—12 possessing leaves and 14 lacking leaves—all located in and around the staff village of the Skukuza main camp, primarily near the golf course. We chose to observe A. grandicornuta in order to compare the status of this facultative ant-plant mutualism when leaves were present and absent. This was possible as A. grandicornuta loses its leaves from late August to early October, thus yielding a sufficient abundance of individuals with and without leaves. We then examined 14 Acacia robusta individuals—all of which possessed leaves. For each A. grandicornuta and A. robusta individual encountered, we recorded a number of observations: the average abundance of ants, ant species composition, the presence or absence of scale insects, and the degree of defensive behavior of the ants on each tree. The abundance of ants on each tree was obtained by selecting two .25m by .5m sections, estimating the number of ants per section, and averaging the two abundance measures. We identified our ant samples down to genus, and in one instance down to species. Following our initial study, we conducted a subsequent experiment in which we generated an artificial disturbance. To mimic natural herbivory processes we scratched the trunk of the tree while simultaneously shaking a branch. Analysis Mann-Whitney U-tests were performed to test for significant differences in ant abundance dependent on leaf presence and scale insect presence in A. grandicornuta and A. robusta respectively. A Kruskal-Wallis test was conducted to determine differences in attack time among three ant genera.

Riparian ecosystems are characterised by a greater heterogeneity of vegetation structure and composition relative to other savanna communities. However, it is contested which characteristics of the vegetation are most important for predicting bird diversity. The aim of our study was to determine the relative importance of composition and structural complexity, in terms of variance in vertical and horizontal structure, as well as canopy cover and tree height, as predictors of bird diversity. Bird diversity was analysed in terms of species richness, abundance, feeding and foraging guilds. We examined eight sites of varying structural and compositional diversities along the Limpopo River in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa.

Bird diversity, floristics, functional guilds, vegetation structure

Methods Site All data were collected from 14 Sept – 16 Sept 2009 along the Limpopo river riparian zone, 2211’26.21”S, 2922’23.67”E, Mapungubwe National Park (MNP), Limpopo Province, South Africa (Figure 1). MNP is situated in the North-East corner of South Africa, in the junction between Botswana, Zimbabwe and South Africa. This is a semi-arid landscape with varied geology, including archean rocks, metamorphics, karoo sandstone/conglomerate uplands, and alluvium and sands (Mapungubwe 2006). A variety of soils are represented, although sandy, lime-rich soils generally deeper than 750 mm are dominant (Mapungubwe 2006). Mean annual rainfall ranges from 350 – 400 mm and free water surface evaporation exceeds 2.5 m per year. Rainfall is highly variable (Mapungubwe 2006). While most rain falls in the summer months, where temperatures can reach 45 °C, there are extended periods of below average rainfall (Mapungubwe 2006). FIGURE 1: A satellite image of the Limpopo river, along which eight sites were selected and sampled, Mapungubwe National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa (Jones et al., unpublished) Bird diversity sampling was conducted in the 8 sites studied in September 2009. These sites were selected for vegetation structure in terms of canopy cover and the presence or absence of shrubs and tall trees (Table 1). TABLE 1: A description of the vegetation structure for each of the eight sites, MNP, South Africa (taken from Jones et al., unpublished) Site Vegetation classification GPS location 1 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.210' E 029˚ 23.889' 2 Open mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.366' E 029˚ 23.758' 3 Closed mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.340' E 029˚ 23.813' 4 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 11.586' E 029˚ 23.427' 5 Closed mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.496' E 029˚ 23.456' 6 Closed mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 12.099' E 029˚ 21.381' 7 Open mid-story, closed canopy S 22˚ 12.001' E 029˚ 21.173' 8 Open mid-story, open canopy S 22˚ 11.763' E 029˚ 20.964' Bird surveys Data were collected daily between 6:00 to 9:30 and between 16:30 and 18:00. All eight sites were sampled in the morning every day, and each site was sampled only once in the evening. The order in which sites were sampled varied between days to control for varying activity levels during particular times of the day. The point-count method was used to sample bird diversity within each site. Individuals heard or seen within a 50 m radius around a point were recorded as ‘in’ the sampling site, while individuals between 50 m to 100 m of that point were recorded as ‘out’ of the sampling site. Additionally, birds flying over head were also counted as out. Ten minutes were allocated to sampling bird diversity in each site. Five minutes were spent recording birds in the centre of the circle, while five minutes were spent flushing (including two minutes walking into and out of the sampling site and three minutes flushing within the site). Guilds Birds sampled were divided up into both dietary and foraging guilds based on their diet (Table 2) and foraging (Table 3) methods respectively. Information on diet and feeding behaviour was obtained from Roberts Birds of Southern Africa (Hockey et al., 2006). TABLE 2: A description of classification criteria for establishing bird dietary guilds. Diet Guilds Classification Criteria Carnivore Primarily consumes non-insect animals Frugivore Primarily consumes fruit Granivore Primarily consumes seeds and nuts Herbivore Primarily consumes vegetation Insectivore Primarily consumes insects Nectivore Primarily consumes nectar Omnivore Consumes a mixture of meat and vegetable matter. Scavenger Primarily consumes carrion TABLE 3: A description of classification criteria for establishing bird foraging guilds. Criteria emphasize physical distribution of foraging rather than foraging methods within a location. Foraging Methods Guilds Classification Criteria Canopy Primarily search for food in upper, middle or lower canopy, or a mixture of these. Does not include birds which perch as a vantage point for hunting. Midstory Primarily search for food in midstory or understory. Does not include birds which perch and swoop. Perch and Hunt Primarily search for food by perch and swoop, hawk or dive. Does not include birds which hunt aerially and consume prey on the perch Aerial Hunt aerially and consume prey on perch Ground Closed Primarily search for food on ground, either in soil, grass, or leaf litter clear of any midstory. Ground Open Primarily search for food on ground, either in soil, grass, or leaf litter under a midstory Generalist Search for food in more than one guild Birds that were counted as ‘out’ were not included, and birds that do not rely on terrestrial structure as part of their foraging behaviour, such as Red-Billed Oxpecker, African Darter, Blacksmith lapwing, Brown-throated martin, and Grey Heron, were excluded. Data analysis All data collected on bird diversity in September 2009 were combined with the data collected in April 2009 by Jones et al (unpublished). The bird count data was used to calculate Bray-Curtis similarities between sites (site 1 and 2, 1 and 3, etc.) in PRIMER (Primer-E Ltd., 2001). The Bray-Curtis index is a descriptive measure of general similarity in species assemblages at different sites and is only weakly affected by rare species (Krebs, 1999). Two-dimensional Multi-Dimensional Scaling ordinations (MDS plots) were generated, visually demonstrating similarities between sites as distances on the plot. The classification of sites based on woody vegetation structure was mapped onto the MDS. To test whether the composition of a bird assemblage at a site is related to its position along the River, the Bray-Curtis similarity value for each pair of sites was correlated with geographical distance between each pair. Simpson’s index (Ds) of bird diversity was calculated in PRIMER. Simpson’s index is one of standard ways to measure diversity and puts more weight on the evenness than the richness of species in the samples (Krebs, 1999). It is therefore suitable for a study of general ecosystem function like the one conducted. The index has comparatively small errors with small sample sizes, which makes it useful for a study with a limited number of counts (Routledge 1980). Average percentage aerial canopy cover estimate was calculated for each site using Microsoft Office Excel software (Microsoft 2002). The diversity of vertical vegetation layers was estimated using Ds. Diversity was calculated treating each vegetation layer as a morphospecies and the value representing how filled a particular layer was treated as the number of individuals in the morphospecies. An MDS was plotted to demonstrate similarities in woody plant assemblages between the sites and Ds for diversity in woody species was calculated. To analyze the dependence of bird diversity on vegetation structure, the values of Ds for bird diversity were regressed against Simpson’s index of structural diversity, large tree density (no of trees/site), basal area (cm2) and the percentage canopy cover (%). A similar analysis was done to test if floristics drive bird diversity. Ds values for bird assemblages were regressed against Ds indices for woody plants. In addition, the Bray-Curtis similarity in bird assemblages was regressed against the similarity in floristics. The same steps (MDS and regression against structure and floristics characteristics) were taken to analyze the relationship between the diversity in dietary guilds and foraging guilds.

Ecological Aerial Census The methods used for this census were described by Joubert (1983). Briefly, the method was as follows. The method was standardised to ensure repeatability. The team consisted of the pilot, a data recorder and four observers. Parallel strips 800m apart (with observers covering 400m on either side of the aircraft) were flown to achieve total coverage of the area. Flying was limited to the cooler parts of the morning (08h00 - 12h00) in clear weather conditions. Data was initially recorded directly on to a 1:100 000 map and later "digitised" onto a computer, giving both population numbers and distribution for each species. Later surveys utilised a computer connected to a Global Positioning System for data capture (Viljoen & Retief 1993). These counts were initially conducted from a six-seater high winged Cessna 206, but in 1980 a remarkable incident occurred when this aircraft suffered engine failure and the pilot, Dr Salomon Joubert, managed to land it safely without loss of life or further damage to the aircraft. Faith was lost in single engined aircraft after this and it was replaced by the twin engined Partenavia. The study extent was the entire northern plains Lines were flown in an East West direction to ensure 100% of the area was covered.
Judith Kruger SANParks Private Bag x402 Skukuza 1350 SA +0927 13 7354309 +0927 13 7354055 judithk@sanparks.org

The ‘Nwashitsumbe vlei in the Kruger National Park is separated from a mopane matrix by the vlei/upland boundary. The boundary has been delineated in terms of grass species and soil characteristics, but not woody vegetation, which is an integral component of savanna ecosystems. A large exclosure provided the opportunity to study the effects of large mammalian browser exclusion on boundary dynamics and woody vegetation characteristics. The vlei/upland boundary differs from the surrounding patch types in species composition, slope, electrical conductivity and pH characteristics. Each characteristic has a slightly different spatial distribution pattern across the boundary, probably resulting from differential responses to different or the same vectors and disturbance agents. These characters should be viewed holistically as they overlap to form a complex three-dimensional boundary. Woody species distribution is more patchy than that of the grasses. Life-history strategy responses are suggested as possible causes for differences in distribution pattern. Browsing disturbance has altered the structure, composition and possibly the function of the woody vegetation boundary. This study suggests that the vlei/upland boundary is more sensitive to large mammalian herbivore impact than the surrounding patch types. Such changes and differences are of concern to managers who aim to maintain biodiversity. Current monitoring, in the Kruger National park, of woody vegetation responses to herbivore impact occurs at too coarse a scale to detect change in either the boundary or the species guild-specific responses identified in this study. It is recommended that they be used as indicators of herbivore mediated change in the landscape.

Assessing temporal change in percentage aerial cover of woody vegetation Aerial photographs from 1987 and 2001 were used to assess temporal changes, resulting from the exclusion of large herbivores, in the percentage aerial cover of woody vegetation. The photographs were taken in June and May respectively so little variation due to seasonality would have occurred. The 1987 photograph was chosen for analysis as it was taken a few months after the exclosure was extended into the vlei. Photographs of the 2 study sites (inside and outside of the exclosure) from each year were enlarged to the same scale using ArcView. A grid containing 1mm X 1mm squares was placed over each site. Each square represented 16m2 on the ground. Squares with more than 50% woody vegetation cover were recorded to gain an estimate of the percentage aerial cover of woody vegetation. 5.2.1 Environmental variables and vegetation characteristics Line transects were placed inside and outside of the exclosure to detect differences in vegetation and environmental variables resulting from the exclusion of large herbivores. Transects started in the deepest channel of the vlei and ran up the horizontal slope, perpendicular to the vlei, until homogenous stands of Colophospermum mopane (a recognised upland species) were encountered. The same transect placement pattern as Kroger used was used in this study to permit comparisons with his study of the boundary as defined by grass species distribution. Transects were placed in a stratified manner, moving away from the exclosure fence in opposite directions, with the gap between transects increasing by 50m each time. The stratified placement was originally used in Kroger’s study to capture the gradient of grazing away from the water holes on either side of the fence. Five transects inside and five transects outside of the exclosure covered a significant proportion of the vlei and were all that time allowed. Inside the exclosure, the stratified placement used by Kroger could not be followed exactly as area of woody vegetation was cleared in the upland for game release/capture. An extra transect was placed between transects four and five to compensate. Sampling was conducted at a fine scale; every 2.5m along each transect, to detect small changes in vegetation and environmental variables and aid in boundary detection. A theodolite was used to measure both vertical and horizontal distance every 2.5m along each transect so that slope could be accurately determined. Soil was collected from the top 15cm of the profile with a soil auger. Samples were placed in plastic bags to avoid moisture loss, weighed, oven dried at 80ºC until constant mass was achieved and then weighed again. Percentage soil moisture was determined from a wet soil mass versus dry soil mass calculation. Samples were mixed in distilled water (one part soil : three parts water) with an electric grinder for one minute. The electrical conductivity (mS) and pH of this solution were measured with a HANNA (H1-991301) electronic meter. Contiguous plots along transects remain the most effective technique for providing baseline system descriptions along gradients (Olsvig-Whittaker 1988) and quadrats that are much wider than they are long, are sensitive to boundary detection (Fortin 1999). Woody vegetation was, therefore, sampled in 2.5m X 20m contiguous quadrats. Species, height and stem circumference were recorded for each woody plant occurring in a quadrat. Tree height was measured with a ranging rod and a tape measure was used to determine stem circumference. A two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnoff test was used to test differences in height and stem diameter class distributions inside and outside of the exclosure. Determination of environmental variable-species associations Species distribution is determined by a number of complex interrelated factors. A direct canonical correspondence analysis (CCA) was used to establish the relationship between environmental variables and species distribution across the vlei/upland boundary (Canoco for Windows Ver.4). Grouping species according to their environmental preferences can aid the identification of patches and therefore boundaries in a landscape. Slope, elevation, horizontal distance, longitudinal distance, pH, electrical conductivity, percentage soil moisture and were used in the analysis as they were considered possible determinants of woody species distribution. Identifying discontinuities in the environment Boundaries are locations where the rates or magnitudes of ecological transfers change abruptly in relation to those within the surrounding patch types (Harrod 1988). Boundaries can therefore be identified though discontinuities or regions of high variation in environmental or vegetation characteristics. Locations of high variance can be determined using a moving split-window technique (Ludwig ∓amp; Cornelis 1987). Window size refers to the number of samples or quadrats for which a change in variance is evaluated. The mean for each half-window is subtracted from the mean of the other half-window to determine variance between the two-half windows in terms of Euclidean distance. The window is then moved one quadrat or sample point along a transect and the process repeated until the entire transect has been sampled. Various half-window sizes were experimented with. A size of three quadrats or sample points (i.e. 7.5m) was selected for the scale of the study. Euclidean distance =   {((x1+ x2+ x3)/3) – ((x4+ x5+ x6)/3)} 2 The Euclidean distance measure for slope, pH, electrical conductivity, soil moisture and the frequency of woody species occurrence was plotted against distance from the vlei for each transect. Consistently low variance values indicate areas of relative homogeneity or patches. Peaks in Euclidean distance, however, indicate areas of high variation and, therefore, boundaries. Small peaks in Euclidean distance represent small-scale background variance in the data (Ludwig ∓amp; Cornelis 1987). Larger peaks were used to identify the number and locations of boundaries for each variable. 2 Representing boundaries spatially Spatial representation of boundaries is essential for the identification of environmental variable-vegetation relationships and differences arising from large mammalian herbivore exclusion. The boundary locations for each variable were linked across all ten transects to provide a spatial representation of boundary position, relative to the vlei and firebreak road that runs roughly parallel to the vlei. 3.1 ‘Nwashitsumbe vlei and exclosure The ‘Nwashitsumbe vlei occurs on the Northern Plains of the Kruger National Park (S22°431-S22°591; E31°121-E31°221) and lies on a flat basaltic landscape. The upland areas are dominated by Mopane/Combretum woodland. Grasses dominate the low-lying, seasonally inundated vlei. The ‘Nwashitsumbe exclosure was constructed in 1968 and extended into the vlei in 1986. It currently encloses 309 hectares. All browsers have been excluded from the upland for 33 years and from the vlei/upland boundary for 15 years. The average fire return period has been 4.3 years inside the exclosure and 4 years outside (Trollope et. al. 1998). See methods
Prof Kevin Rogers Wits University School of Animal, Plant ∓amp; Environmental Sciences University of the Witwatersrand

Locations of high variance can be determined using a moving split-window technique (Ludwig ∓amp; Cornelis 1987). Window size refers to the number of samples or quadrats for which a change in variance is evaluated. The mean for each half-window is subtracted from the mean of the other half-window to determine variance between the two-half windows in terms of Euclidean distance. The window is then moved one quadrat or sample point along a transect and the process repeated until the entire transect has been sampled. Various half-window sizes were experimented with. A size of three quadrats or sample points (i.e. 7.5m) was selected for the scale of the study. Euclidean distance =   {((x1+ x2+ x3)/3) – ((x4+ x5+ x6)/3)} 2 The Euclidean distance measure for slope, pH, electrical conductivity, soil moisture and the frequency of woody species occurrence was plotted against distance from the vlei for each transect. Consistently low variance values indicate areas of relative homogeneity or patches. Peaks in Euclidean distance, however, indicate areas of high variation and, therefore, boundaries. Small peaks in Euclidean distance represent small-scale background variance in the data (Ludwig ∓amp; Cornelis 1987). Larger peaks were used to identify the number and locations of boundaries for each variable. 2 Representing boundaries spatially Spatial representation of boundaries is essential for the identification of environmental variable-vegetation relationships and differences arising from large mammalian herbivore exclusion. The boundary locations for each variable were linked across all ten transects to provide a spatial representation of boundary position, relative to the vlei and firebreak road that runs roughly parallel to the vlei. 3.1 ‘Nwashitsumbe vlei and exclosure The ‘Nwashitsumbe vlei occurs on the Northern Plains of the Kruger National Park (S22°431-S22°591; E31°121-E31°221) and lies on a flat basaltic landscape. The upland areas are dominated by Mopane/Combretum woodland. Grasses dominate the low-lying, seasonally inundated vlei. The ‘Nwashitsumbe exclosure was constructed in 1968 and extended into the vlei in 1986. It currently encloses 309 hectares. All browsers have been excluded from the upland for 33 years and from the vlei/upland boundary for 15 years. The average fire return period has been 4.3 years inside the exclosure and 4 years outside (Trollope et. al. 1998). See methods
Effects of large mammalian herbivore exclusion on the physiognomy, species composition and boundary dynamics of woody vegetation, across a vlei/upland boundary
