Basic data checks for Augrabies Notes 0281760 1 AUGRABIES Lat: -28.67 Long: 20.44 Height: 640 m RAINFALL CurOrder: This region appears incredibly arid, though summer/autumn rains fall annually. 1978 and 1979 were exceptionally dry years. There are no apparent gaps in the data, and there is only one occurrence of a failed reading, though there were some instances were data were accumulated. 1952 had an incredibly rainy day (287.5 mm - 1952/09/25). Basic data checks for Augrabies Falls Notes 0281606A5 AUGRABIES FALLS Lat: -28.6 Long: 20.34 Height: 635 m CurOrder: ELEC_TEMP Different number of days missing between 8h, 14h and 20h in the humidity, pressure and wind data series between 2001/09/04 and 2001/09/12 and again between 2001/09/21 and 2001/0924 - this was corrected There is a 2 month gap in humidity data in Oct/Nov 2006 after which all humidity values seem to be lower by a consistent margin (i.e. a similar annual pattern to the one observed prior to 2006 is seen, but all the values appear to be lower) No records for Nov 2002 (humidity) Questionable temperature records for 2008/10/26 and 27 - min on 26th was 26 with max 38, while the min on 27th was 18 with max 26 - this is out of character with the rest of the data, but I am not sure which of the value(s) would be the incorrect ones Likely change in instrumentation for humidity in 2006: Following data gap in 2006 there is an inconsistency in pattern 2001/09/11 repeated in 14h pressure series - deleted General comments Temperature: There is a strong annual pattern in temperature with a large difference in temperature between the min and max for all seasons. The same gaps occur as for other variables measured at this station (2002 and 2006 have the largest gaps = 2months). Rainfall: There are 219 occurrences of failed readings which equate to 7% of the total data. The period between 2006 and 2009 is particularly poor and it appears that all significant rainfall events have gone unrecorded. Dataset potentially not useful for analysis. Humidity: There is a 2 month gap in humidity data in Oct/Nov 2006 after which all humidity values seem to be lower by a consistent margin (i.e. a similar annual pattern to the one observed prior to 2006 is seen, but all the values appear to be lower). There is also a 2 month gap in data in Nov/Dec 2002. Pressure: The same 2002 and 2006 gaps that are present in the humidity data are present here. The pattern in pressure does not however appear to change after the 2006 gap. There are also some other smaller gaps present in the data as well as some areas with much higher variation in them than is the trend (often in winter) Wind: Gaps present in 2002 and 2006 as in other data series provided by this station, though the length of these gaps is slightly different. The 2006 gap extends from beg Oct 2006 until begin Feb 2007 (4 months). There is an annual pattern in wind speed with highest speed in summer, but wind speed is never particularly high.

Addo Elephant National Park, South Africa

The strong influence of fire on vegetation structure and floristics in savannas make it an important tool for managers of preserved areas. Currently, Kruger National Park (KNP) uses a heterogeneous fire regime to promote biodiversity; however the effects of variance in fire return period on vegetation structural and compositional diversity have never been studied. This study recorded structural and floristic data at 16 sites within KNP in order to explore the relationship between variance in fire return period and structural and compositional vegetation diversity. We found variance in fire return period to have little influence over floristic and structural diversity. Average fire return period explained more differences in diversity, and we observed that a fire return period of around 6 years fostered the greatest structural and floristic diversity. These findings may be useful in informing future fire policy in KNP.

vegetation structural diversity, fire regime, floristic diversity, pyrodiversity
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Methods Methods Study Site Sixteen sites were selected in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of KNP in South Africa (Figure 1). GIS fire history data provided by Izak Smit of the park’s Scientific Services were used to select sites. Fire scar data from 1941 to 2008 were overlayed in a GIS map, dividing the park into polygons, with each polygon consisting of an area of identical fire history. We selected sites within two kilometers of a road for accessibility. Using the known fire history of each site provided by the GIS data, we selected 16 sites paired by the same average fire return period in order to control for the effects of fire frequency. While each pair had the same overall fire frequency through the past 69 years, one site in each pair had high variance in fire return period and the other had low variance (Table 1). FIGURE 1: Map of the 16 sites selected in Kruger National Park, with pairs labeled 1 through 8. Sites are paired by the same average fire return period, but one site in each pair has high variance in fire return period (shaded dark grey) and the other site has low variance in fire return period (shaded light grey). TABLE 1: Summary of fire history data of the 16 sites evaluated in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of Kruger National Park in South Africa. Sites are arranged in pairs with sites labeled with an A representing the high variance site of each pair and sites labeled with a B representing the low variance site of each pair. Pair Number Number of Fires 1941 – 2006 Average Fire Return Period (years) Maximum Fire Return Period (years) Variance in Fire Return Period (years) Area (hectares) Difference in Variance Between Pairs (years) 1A 16 3.941 23 25.231 2.25323 22.911 1B 25 2.577 8 2.320 32.35122 2A 14 4.467 33 60.109 28.02452 51.330 2B 14 4.467 10 8.779 28.46588 3A 13 4.786 33 63.171 70.66326 54.574 3B 13 4.786 10 8.597 623.39243 4A 10 6.091 36 91.547 20.73223 76.740 4B 10 6.091 17 14.807 45.51266 5A 9 6.700 36 102.820 754.74734 88.810 5B 9 6.700 17 14.010 150.60097 6A 7 8.375 34 100.481 26.73789 84.457 6B 8 7.444 17 16.024 27.37966 7A 8 7.444 36 109.349 40.13838 95.990 7B 8 7.444 17 13.359 4.50639 8A 3 16.750 56 514.700 21.33613 433.520 8B 3 16.750 27 81.180 218.39858 All sites had granitic soil, moderate rainfall (590-640mm per year), and knobthorn/scicklebush thorn thicket vegetation dominated by Grewias, Dichrostachys, Acacias and Combretums. Within each site, a specific study plot was selected on the midslope of a catena, as defined by relative elevation and vegetation type, because vegetation type and structure is known to vary substantially between the crest and valley of a catena (Venter et al. 2003). Experimental Design and Protocol To examine the structural and floristic diversity at each site, we first defined four height classes for woody vegetation. Height class one included all individuals less than one meter to account for recent recruitment of seedlings. Although seedlings may not have experienced fire in their lifetime, the fire history of each site may influence their demographics and species composition. Height class two included all individuals between one and three meters. These individuals represent plants that have made it past the seedling stage, but are still vulnerable to fire. Height classes three and four included individuals greater than three meters to account for trees that have escaped the ‘fire trap.’ Height class three included all individuals greater than three meters and less than six meters, and height class four included trees six meters and greater. We separated height classes three and four to distinguish tall trees from tall shrubs and small trees. In addition to height classes, we identified each individual to species and noted structural characteristics. Each individual was classified as single-stemmed or multi-stemmed based on visual observation. Multi-stemmed individuals are likely to be sprouters, while single-stemmed individuals may be non-sprouters. Sprouters are better equipped to persist through fire (Bond and Midgley 2003), thus a higher number of multi-stemmed individuals relative to single-stemmed may indicate high selective pressure from fire. We also classified the structure of each individual as cage or pole architecture in order to test our hypothesis that sites with more frequent, less variable fires in the past would have more individuals with pole architecture because of the pressure to escape the ‘fire trap.’ Cage architecture was defined as woody vegetation that appeared to be investing in growth by sending stems outward instead of upward. We surveyed vegetation using a modified version of the Walker Transect method (Figure 2; L. Kruger pers. comm.). The transect consisted of a 100 meter straight-line transect running along the catenal mid-slope in order to control for vegetation type because distinct species assemblages dominate different catenal zones (Venter et al. 2003). In zone one, we identified every woody plant to species and recorded its height class and structural characteristics. In zone two, we recorded data for only those woody plants that were one meter or greater in height, and in zone three, we recorded only trees above three meters in height. We used this sampling method instead of identifying all individuals of all sizes in a smaller plot in order to cover a greater area and account for spatial variation in large individuals. FIGURE 2: Structure of the 50 meter x 100 meter Walker Transect used to measure floristic and structural diversity within each of the 16 sites. All woody individuals of all height classes were recorded in Zone 1. Only woody individuals taller than one meter were recorded in Zone 2 and only taller individuals greater than three meters were recorded in Zone 3. Zones 1 – 3 are on both sides of the center line (a 100 meter straight-line transect). For each site, we also recorded horizontal and vertical profiles in order to assess the overall spatial structure of the vegetation, including all plant biomass. We recorded information on horizontal visibility, vertical vegetation biomass, and canopy cover every 10 meters along each transect. A Cody’s vegetation index was used to evaluate horizontal visibility (K. Vickers, pers. comm.). We assessed the visibility of a white sheet of paper held at 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.5 meters above the ground by recording the distance at which 50% of the sheet of paper was no longer visible. This measure allowed us to compare vegetation biomass between sites beyond woody vegetation and to construct an idea of what each site looks like in terms of vegetation density. To establish a vertical vegetation profile, we estimated the percentage of space within a 2 m x 2 m x 2m box that was filled by vegetation at 0-2 m, 2-4 m, 4-6 m, 6-8 m, and so on, as high as was necessary in order to contrust a descriptive measure of the vertical density of biomass. Both the horizontal and vertical profiles were taken to supplement the height class values because height class data does not provide a complete picture of density and distribution of vegetation within each site. Finally, a densiometer was used to asses canopy cover. Analysis The objective of our study was to determine the effects of variance in fire return period on the floristics and structure of sites with similar average fire return periods. In order to make these comparisons, it was necessary to simplify complex measures such as horizontal and vertical profiles and the relative abundance of woody individuals of each species within each site. We used PRIMER–E 5.2.2 (Ltd, 2001) to calculate Shannon-Weiner diversity indices for floristics and for the following measures of structural diversity: height class, vertical profile, horizontal profile, cage and pole architecture, and multi-stemmed and single-stemmed architecture. The Shannon-Weiner Diversity Index was favored over the Simpson’s Index because it places emphasis on evenness rather than rarity. We expected that sites with high variance in fire return period would have higher diversity index scores than sites with low variance in fire return period. Paired T-tests were run on all diversity indices between matched sites using STATISTICA 6.1 (StatSoft, Inc. 1984-2004) in order to discern differences in diversity between sites of high and low variance. Bi-variate regression analyses were conducted to different explanatory factors for structural and floristic diversity across the 16 sites. For regressions of average fire return period against the number of woody individuals in each height class, one site (site 8b) was removed from the dataset due to uncertainty about the accuracy of the fire history (N. Govender, pers. comm.). Between each pair, we also found the difference in the number of woody individuals and calculated an average difference in woody individuals across the eight pairs of sites. We then compared the difference between individuals in each height class, the number of individuals that displayed cage and pole architecture, and the number of single-stemmed and multi-stemmed individuals. Paired t-tests were performed in order to test if the mean difference between pairs was zero.

Methods Methods Study Site Sixteen sites were selected in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of KNP in South Africa (Figure 1). GIS fire history data provided by Izak Smit of the park’s Scientific Services were used to select sites. Fire scar data from 1941 to 2008 were overlayed in a GIS map, dividing the park into polygons, with each polygon consisting of an area of identical fire history. We selected sites within two kilometers of a road for accessibility. Using the known fire history of each site provided by the GIS data, we selected 16 sites paired by the same average fire return period in order to control for the effects of fire frequency. While each pair had the same overall fire frequency through the past 69 years, one site in each pair had high variance in fire return period and the other had low variance (Table 1). FIGURE 1: Map of the 16 sites selected in Kruger National Park, with pairs labeled 1 through 8. Sites are paired by the same average fire return period, but one site in each pair has high variance in fire return period (shaded dark grey) and the other site has low variance in fire return period (shaded light grey). TABLE 1: Summary of fire history data of the 16 sites evaluated in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of Kruger National Park in South Africa. Sites are arranged in pairs with sites labeled with an A representing the high variance site of each pair and sites labeled with a B representing the low variance site of each pair. Pair Number Number of Fires 1941 – 2006 Average Fire Return Period (years) Maximum Fire Return Period (years) Variance in Fire Return Period (years) Area (hectares) Difference in Variance Between Pairs (years) 1A 16 3.941 23 25.231 2.25323 22.911 1B 25 2.577 8 2.320 32.35122 2A 14 4.467 33 60.109 28.02452 51.330 2B 14 4.467 10 8.779 28.46588 3A 13 4.786 33 63.171 70.66326 54.574 3B 13 4.786 10 8.597 623.39243 4A 10 6.091 36 91.547 20.73223 76.740 4B 10 6.091 17 14.807 45.51266 5A 9 6.700 36 102.820 754.74734 88.810 5B 9 6.700 17 14.010 150.60097 6A 7 8.375 34 100.481 26.73789 84.457 6B 8 7.444 17 16.024 27.37966 7A 8 7.444 36 109.349 40.13838 95.990 7B 8 7.444 17 13.359 4.50639 8A 3 16.750 56 514.700 21.33613 433.520 8B 3 16.750 27 81.180 218.39858 All sites had granitic soil, moderate rainfall (590-640mm per year), and knobthorn/scicklebush thorn thicket vegetation dominated by Grewias, Dichrostachys, Acacias and Combretums. Within each site, a specific study plot was selected on the midslope of a catena, as defined by relative elevation and vegetation type, because vegetation type and structure is known to vary substantially between the crest and valley of a catena (Venter et al. 2003). Experimental Design and Protocol To examine the structural and floristic diversity at each site, we first defined four height classes for woody vegetation. Height class one included all individuals less than one meter to account for recent recruitment of seedlings. Although seedlings may not have experienced fire in their lifetime, the fire history of each site may influence their demographics and species composition. Height class two included all individuals between one and three meters. These individuals represent plants that have made it past the seedling stage, but are still vulnerable to fire. Height classes three and four included individuals greater than three meters to account for trees that have escaped the ‘fire trap.’ Height class three included all individuals greater than three meters and less than six meters, and height class four included trees six meters and greater. We separated height classes three and four to distinguish tall trees from tall shrubs and small trees. In addition to height classes, we identified each individual to species and noted structural characteristics. Each individual was classified as single-stemmed or multi-stemmed based on visual observation. Multi-stemmed individuals are likely to be sprouters, while single-stemmed individuals may be non-sprouters. Sprouters are better equipped to persist through fire (Bond and Midgley 2003), thus a higher number of multi-stemmed individuals relative to single-stemmed may indicate high selective pressure from fire. We also classified the structure of each individual as cage or pole architecture in order to test our hypothesis that sites with more frequent, less variable fires in the past would have more individuals with pole architecture because of the pressure to escape the ‘fire trap.’ Cage architecture was defined as woody vegetation that appeared to be investing in growth by sending stems outward instead of upward. We surveyed vegetation using a modified version of the Walker Transect method (Figure 2; L. Kruger pers. comm.). The transect consisted of a 100 meter straight-line transect running along the catenal mid-slope in order to control for vegetation type because distinct species assemblages dominate different catenal zones (Venter et al. 2003). In zone one, we identified every woody plant to species and recorded its height class and structural characteristics. In zone two, we recorded data for only those woody plants that were one meter or greater in height, and in zone three, we recorded only trees above three meters in height. We used this sampling method instead of identifying all individuals of all sizes in a smaller plot in order to cover a greater area and account for spatial variation in large individuals. FIGURE 2: Structure of the 50 meter x 100 meter Walker Transect used to measure floristic and structural diversity within each of the 16 sites. All woody individuals of all height classes were recorded in Zone 1. Only woody individuals taller than one meter were recorded in Zone 2 and only taller individuals greater than three meters were recorded in Zone 3. Zones 1 – 3 are on both sides of the center line (a 100 meter straight-line transect). For each site, we also recorded horizontal and vertical profiles in order to assess the overall spatial structure of the vegetation, including all plant biomass. We recorded information on horizontal visibility, vertical vegetation biomass, and canopy cover every 10 meters along each transect. A Cody’s vegetation index was used to evaluate horizontal visibility (K. Vickers, pers. comm.). We assessed the visibility of a white sheet of paper held at 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.5 meters above the ground by recording the distance at which 50% of the sheet of paper was no longer visible. This measure allowed us to compare vegetation biomass between sites beyond woody vegetation and to construct an idea of what each site looks like in terms of vegetation density. To establish a vertical vegetation profile, we estimated the percentage of space within a 2 m x 2 m x 2m box that was filled by vegetation at 0-2 m, 2-4 m, 4-6 m, 6-8 m, and so on, as high as was necessary in order to contrust a descriptive measure of the vertical density of biomass. Both the horizontal and vertical profiles were taken to supplement the height class values because height class data does not provide a complete picture of density and distribution of vegetation within each site. Finally, a densiometer was used to asses canopy cover. Analysis The objective of our study was to determine the effects of variance in fire return period on the floristics and structure of sites with similar average fire return periods. In order to make these comparisons, it was necessary to simplify complex measures such as horizontal and vertical profiles and the relative abundance of woody individuals of each species within each site. We used PRIMER–E 5.2.2 (Ltd, 2001) to calculate Shannon-Weiner diversity indices for floristics and for the following measures of structural diversity: height class, vertical profile, horizontal profile, cage and pole architecture, and multi-stemmed and single-stemmed architecture. The Shannon-Weiner Diversity Index was favored over the Simpson’s Index because it places emphasis on evenness rather than rarity. For regressions of average fire return period against the number of woody individuals in each height class, one site (site 8b) was removed from the dataset due to uncertainty about the accuracy of the fire history (N. Govender, pers. comm.). Between each pair, we also found the difference in the number of woody individuals and calculated an average difference in woody individuals across the eight pairs of sites. We then compared the difference between individuals in each height class, the number of individuals that displayed cage and pole architecture, and the number of single-stemmed and multi-stemmed individuals. The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Opuntia stricta is an invasive plant species that Kruger National Park (KNP) is seeking to control by using the cochineal insect Dactylopius opuntiae. We studied the dispersal ability of D. opuntiae during the crawler stage by collecting instars and observing their angle and direction of movement towards or away from O. stricta. Results show that the D. opuntiae instars disperse randomly and do not move towards O. stricta cladodes. We conclude that the current method used by KNP for controlling O. stricta is adequate, but the introduction and implementation of an Integrated Pest Management plan (IPM) would further enhance the control of O. stricta. Samevatting: Opuntia stricta is? invallende plant specie wat die Kruger Nasionale Wildtuin (KNW) wil beheer deur die verbruik van? cochenille insek Dactyloppius opuntia . Ons het die verstrooiheid vermo van D. opuntia gedurende die kruiper fase ondersoek, deur die versamelling van instars, en die hoek en rigting van hulle beweging jeen en weg van O. stricta was opgemerk. Uitslae bewys dat die D. opuntiae instars ewekansig verstrooi en hulle beweeg nie na die O. stricta cladodes nie. Ons gevolgtrekking was dat die korent manier wat gebruik is deur KNW vir die beheer van O. stricta voldoene is, maar dat die inleiding en implementasie van ? integreerde pes bestuur plan die beheer van O. stricta verder sal verbeter.

The study was conducted at Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province over a period of 2 days (24-25 February 2004). Approximately 2400 D. opuntiae first instar larvae were collected from infected O. stricta, which was taken from the Alien Biota Greenhouse. The instars were removed from the plants using pipette aspirators. Twelve paper sheets were used for the study. On each sheet, 500 cm diameter circles were drawn and divided into eight 45 segments. The sheets were then divided in half with four uninfected O. stricta cladodes, collected from outside of the Skukuza camp, placed in one half of the circle and at the edge. The positioning of each equally sized cladode corresponded with four of the segments. The half of the circle with cladodes was the cladode experiment and the half without was the control. The angles and directions at which the instars moved, were measured by placing 200 instars in the center of the circle. The total number of instars in each segment was counted every 10 minutes for one hour. This was repeated 12 times on 12 different sheets, using 200 new instars each time. Once all the data had been collected, statistical analysis was conducted using the Statistica program. A t-test was performed to compare the total number of instars found on each half of the diagramed sheets (cladode experiment and control). In addition, a Kruskal-Wallis test was performed to compare the number of instars found in each of the eight segments.

Addo Elephant National Park, South Africa

A survey of plant community structure was conducted in two large-herbivore exclosures (200x200m) located in the Darlington-section of the Addo Elephant National Park. The exclosures were established in Sundays Noorsveld and Sunday Spekboomveld habitats, respectively, and each were divided into two sections, i.e. excluding all medium- and large-sized herbivores (full exclosure) and excluding only large-sized herbivores (partial exclosure). The current baseline-survey was conducted during 2009, and comprised the following: (1) recording the cover of all plant forms along four 50m line-transects located at each exclosure treatment, and (2) recording the structural characteristics of key plant species, including Euclea undulata, Schotia afra, Boscia oleoides, Pappea capensis and Euphorbia caerulescens. Individual plants were permanently marked and the following variables recorded: maximum canopy height, canopy dimensions, and degree of branching. These quadrats are surveyed at regular intervals.

Commensalism with humans has advantaged many animals, including Hemidactylus mabouia which has spread in association with human settlements. What factors or resources increase fitness for H. mabouia in association with humans? We sampled populations of commensal H. mabouia geckos inside the Punda Maria rest camp in the Kruger National Park and compared body condition and abundance with populations of the same species sampled outside the camp. Association with humans resulted in greater densities supported in campsite buildings and body condition was improved. Insect presence was confirmed to be positively related to proximity to light source and thus prey abundance was enhanced compared with geckos outside the rest camp. Body condition variability in the human-associated population was best explained by bite force controlled for body size; we found no significant role for measured environmental variables. No evidence for sexual dimorphism was obtained and in contrast to current knowledge no evidence of male territoriality was found. Since tail loss was equal in males and females, this was ascribed to predation rather than territoriality.

Methods Study site and species Moreau’s Tropical House Gecko (Hemidactylus mabouia) was sampled for three days from 11 to 13 September 2010 around the Punda Maria campsite, KNP, South Africa. The campsite is located in the more arid north of the KNP, with a mean annual precipitation of 532 mm (Venter et al. 2003). The underlying geology is complex and unique to the park, overlain by. mopane woodland (Colophospermum mopane) which dominates the vegetation (Venter et al. 2003). In order to compare human-associated geckos with those found outside settlements, two study regions were delineated: nine sites (comprising three campsite bathrooms, three kitchens, a laundry, a restaurant and petrol station) within the rest camp [31.018130S; -22.691900E] and two sites outside the camp [31.03818S; -22.70517E]. The body mass of our test species ranged from 1.14 grams – 5.8 grams. Experimental protocol Three sessions of active searching of approximately three hours were conducted outside the camp to sample wild populations of H. mabouia. Nighttime active searching took place for three consecutive evenings and consisted of two phases. Phase 1: two evenings were spent actively searching for two hours from 20h00 to 22h00 with the intention to capture, measure and mark individuals within and outside camp buildings. We measured snout-vent length (SVL) in mm (sensu Quinn and Jones 1974), head width (mm), head height (mm) and head length (mm) using a digital caliper. Mass (g) was determined using a 30 g Pesola scale. Tail status (intact, lost or regrown), scarring and injuries were noted and anecdotally recorded. Geckos were sexed based on the presence or absence of eggs: females of H. mabouia generally carry eggs throughout the year (Branch 1998). Geckos were uniquely numbered at each site on their dorsal surface using a permanent pen before release. Behavioural observations were conducted on the first evening. We drew ten 1 x 1 m chalk quadrats around seven light sources and observed insect abundance and gecko location within the quadrats at 5 minute intervals. Phase 2: a two hour “recapture” period (again between 20h00 and 22h00) took place on the third evening. New individuals were captured, measured and marked as for phase 1, already marked individuals were not recaptured. Predetermined abiotic variables were recorded in association with each individual, whether previously marked or not, including distance to nearest light source (cm), distance to nearest refuge (cm), spot surface temperature (⁰C) and insect presence or absence within a 50 cm radius. Data analyses Individuals with a SVL of less than 45mm were classified as juveniles and discarded from further analysis to ensure only fully grown individuals were used for body condition analyses. An index of body condition was created by dividing body mass by SVL. Bite force may act as a proxy for feeding ability and was considered likely to allometrically scale with SVL. That is, as body length increased, so would head area. Bite force was calculated as the product of head width and head length in mm2.. As SVL was a component of body condition, bite force was controlled for the scaling effect of increased body length by dividing bite force by SVL. Tests of assumptions and statistical and graphical analyses were performed in Statistica 9.0 (StatSoft Inc. 2009). Differences in variables between sexes and between individuals with and without tail loss histories were tested with Student’s t tests. Differences in variables between sample sites were tested using a single factor analysis of variance (ANOVA, test statistic F). The strength of the relationship between two continuous variables was tested using Pearson’s product moment correlation (correlation coefficient r). A general linear model (GLM) was run to test how temperature , distance to nearest light source , distance to nearest refuge , bite force controlled for SVL and insect presence affected body condition.

Nocturnal flying insects fly in a straight line by maintaining a constant angle with the brightest light in the sky, usually the moon. The moon is always above the horizon and therefore moonlight always strikes insects from the top and never from below. When observing whether insects would fly to a light source shining from below them in comparison to a light source shining from above, no insects flew to the light shining from below, while several flew to the lights source shining from above. Samevatting: Nagtelike vliënde insekte vlieg in ŉ reguit lyn deur ŉ konstante hoek te bly hou met die helderste lig in die hệmel, wat gewoontlik die maan is. Die maan is altyd bo die horison en daarvoor raak dit altyd die insekte van bo af en nooit van onder af nie. Terwyl my ondersoek om uit te vind of insekte verkies om na ŉ lig vanaf onder of bo te kom het ek gevind dat daar min was wat na die lig vanaf onder gekom het. Die insekte het dikwels na die lig van bo gekom.
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Michael Chazan SANParks, South Africa Independent Project

My study sites were the Skukuza and Shingwetzi camps in the Kruger National Park. I conducted two trials in Skukuza and one trial in Shingwetzi. I cut out a piece of cardboard one meter in length and .4 meters in width. In the middle of the rectangle two holes 1.5 cm in diameter were cut out. In each hole I placed a flashlight pointing in opposite directs. I then taped the barrier to a wall with equal amount of wall area above and below the barrier. For each trial I observed and tallied the insects that flew towards the light from above and below. An event would only be considered if the insects flew towards the light and either touched the light source or the barrier. Each trial was one hour long and began at 20h00. The trials were completed 23 February, 24 February, and 2 March respectively. The statistics performed was a χ2 – test.

Basic data quality checks for RICHTERSVELD KOEROEGAB 0309041 5 RICHTERSVELD KOEROEGAB Lat: -28.19 Long: 17.05 Height: 498 m RAINFALL CurOrder: Notes and general comments There were no obvious gaps in the data and 0 occurences of failed readings Reading of 84mm recorded on 17 February 2000 is likely erroneous - no rain recorded at Vioolsdrift Basic data quality checks for Vioolsdrift 0276072 8 VIOOLSDRIFT Lat: -28.71 Long: 17.58 Height: 245 m RAINFALL CurOrder: Notes and general comments 80mm of rain recorded on 18 December 1953 appears unlikely as does 75mm recorded on 24 March 1981 There are no obvious gaps and only two occurences of failed data readings Basic data quality checks for Vioolsdrif that was closed 0276162 9 VIOOLSDRIF Lat: -28.7 Long: 17.6 Height: 167 m CLOSED CurOrder: Notes Two years of humidity data deleted prior to 1993 because there were too many gaps in this section of the data Two years of temperature data were also deleted due to two significant gaps in the first two years which would have made extrapolation of missing data very difficult. The same deletion was made in the wind data because of the same missing data problem. 1996/04/30 missing from the temperature data 1997/01/12 - 15, 1997/02/09 - 11, Jan 1998, 1998/08/01 - 7, 1998/08/17- 20 missing from temperature series General comments Temperature: There is a clear annual pattern in temperature, but the data series is very short (1993 - 2002). Two years of temperature data were deleted due to two significant gaps in the first two years. Rainfall: There is relatively low rainfall during the period measured (in agreement with the Vioolsdrift data). There are no obvious gaps, but the data series is very short. Humidity: Two years of humidity data deleted prior to 1993 because there were too many gaps in this section of the data, following this the data show an annual cycle with only one noticible gap. Wind: The same deletion (as in the humidity and temperature data) was made in the wind data because of the same missing data problem. The remaining data show a clear trend in wind speed and direction.

A survey of plant community structure was conducted in two large-herbivore exclosures (200x200m) located in the Darlington-section of the Addo Elephant National Park. The exclosures were established in Sundays Noorsveld and Sunday Spekboomveld habitats, respectively, and each were divided into two sections, i.e. excluding all medium- and large-sized herbivores (full exclosure) and excluding only large-sized herbivores (partial exclosure). The current baseline-survey was conducted during 2009, and comprised the following: (1) recording the cover of all plant forms along four 50m line-transects located at each exclosure treatment, and (2) recording the structural characteristics of key plant species, including Euclea undulata, Schotia afra, Boscia oleoides, Pappea capensis and Euphorbia caerulescens. Individual plants were permanently marked and the following variables recorded: maximum canopy height, canopy dimensions, and degree of branching. These quadrats are surveyed at regular intervals.

The principal objective of SANParks’ Global Environmental Change Project is to improve our understanding of the status of, and trends in, environmental change in parks and using this information to produce science-based policy and management recommendations. Aquatic ecosystems were included as one of six drivers of environmental change, with alien species, climate change, habitat change, resource use/overexploitation, and disease. For the aquatic ecosystem assessment we largely made use of data produced by two national developments: the identification of Freshwater Ecosystem Priority Areas (FEPAs) for South Africa (Nel et al., 2011); and the second National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) for South Africa (Driver et al., 2012). Drawing extensively on the products from these two initiatives, this report aims to: Provide an overview of the: ecological state of, and main pressures on, aquatic ecosystems in South Africa; and conservation status and protection levels (through the national park system) of aquatic ecosystems in South Africa; Assess the contribution of each national park to the achievement of national conservation targets for aquatic ecosystems; and Propose general management/response guidelines for SANParks in context of its mandate to conserve aquatic ecosystems; Moreover, we aimed to answer specific questions that are of particular relevance to SANParks: (a) To what degree does the National Parks (NPs) contribute to aquatic conservation targets in South Africa? (b) What is the contribution of each of the 19 NPs to aquatic conservation? (c) What can SANParks do to promote effective conservation of aquatic ecosystems?

Content: Complemented by numerous method developments and several conservation planning exercises, two recent developments have in particular advanced our understanding of the status of aquatic ecosystems across South Africa. These developments are:(1) Identification of Freshwater Ecosystem Priority Areas (FEPAs) for South Africa (Driver et al., 2011, Nel et al., 2011). FEPA’s constitute strategic areas for conserving rivers, wetlands and estuaries and comprise 22% of South Africa’s river length, 38% of wetland area and 41% of estuaries. (2) Publication of a second National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) for South Africa (Driver et al., 2012). The freshwater, estuarine and marine components of NBA 2011 build on work that has been undertaken since NSBA 2004 and addresses several of the limitations highlighted in NSBA 2004. Data associated with the above national assessments and aquatic priority areas allow us to answer a few questions that are of particular relevance to SANParks: (a) To what degree does the national park system of SANParks – henceforth referred to as National Parks (NPs) – contribute to aquatic conservation targets in South Africa? (b) What is the contribution of each of the 19 NPs to aquatic conservation? (c) What can SANParks do to promote effective conservation of aquatic ecosystems? In view of the above, the objectives of this report are to: Provide an overview of the: o ecological state of, and main pressures on, aquatic ecosystems in South Africa; and o conservation status and protection levels (through the national park system) of aquatic ecosystems in South Africa; Assess the contribution of each national park to the achievement of national conservation targets for aquatic ecosystems; Propose general management/response guidelines for SANParks in context of its mandate to conserve aquatic ecosystems; Propose a process for effectively incorporating aquatic conservation priorities into the management plans of each NP.

During January 2011, a transect-survey of the impacts of elephant on canopy trees - Pappea capensis, Schotia afra and Boscia oleoides - was conducted in the Kuzuko-section of the Addo Elephant National Park. The survey was conducted along 17 belt-transects (1000x10m). Each tree encountered was characterised using the following variables: (1) driver of the impact [E-Elephant, O-Other, U-Unknown, N-No impact], and (2) intensity of the impact [1-Broken branches, 2-Pushed-over/trunk borken, but alive, 3-Dead].

As seasons change so do the characteristics of plants, such as amount foliage and density of grasses, which affects the populations of mammals dependent on the food and cover provided by the vegetation. By comparing data collected between 14 and 16 September 2009 to previously collected data between 11 and 14 April 2009, we were able to explore the effect of seasonality on small mammal populations within three study zones in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa. The three study zones represented three different habitats and were a camp dominated by man-made structures interspersed with Mopane trees, an open grassy area with some shrub cover, and a cliff area consisting of bare rock face and grass cover. Comparison of the data revealed a significant drop in abundance of rodents in the winter at the human disturbed and grassy sites but not in the rocky site. It was also noted that although abundance decreased overall from winter to summer, both species diversity and richness increased. Finally, differences in community structure were noted, in particular an increase from summer to winter in Mastomys natalensis and Tatera leucogaster. Possible explanations for these differences involve a combination of: (1) differences in vegetative cover brought on my changes in season; (2) food scarcity bringing out trap shy rodents; (3) a decrease in inter-species competition due to decreased species dominance in winter.

Method Study site The location of this study was in Mapungubwe National Park, Limpopo Province South Africa. We resurveyed sites based on the work conducted between 11 and 14 April 2009 by Breed et al. The study zones were described as Leokwe Rest Camp (Figures 1a and 1b) (S22º13.056’;E29º21.846’); Mopane Bushveld (Figure 2) (S22º12.909’;E29º21.819’); and the Rocky Outcrops (Figure 3) (S22º13.002’;E29º21.941’)). The Leokwe Rest Camp was a human establishment consisting of chalets and dirt roads transecting an arid open savanna interspersed with Mopane trees. Even though Mopane Bushveld was also an arid open savanna scattered with Mopane trees, it differed from the Rest Camp as it lacked any human disturbances and was dominated by Acacia tortilis, Acacia nigrescens and Combrium apiculatas. The final site, the Rocky Outcrops, was bare rock-face patchily covered with grass and a few dispersed shrubs and trees (Boscia albitrunca and Crotan gratissusi). A common feature of all three study sites was their sandstone substrate. FIGURE 1a. Image of Leokwe Rest Camp study site FIGURE 1b. Image of Leokwe Rest Camp study site FIGURE 2. Image of Mopane Bushveld study site FIGURE 3. Image of Rocky Outcrops study site Experimental design and protocol Trapping We used a total of 90 Sherman© live traps, 30 at each study site, in our experiment. Each site had 24 large traps and six small traps laid out in three rows ten meters apart. In the Leokwe Rest Camp the traps were laid out in three parallel rows, two on either side of the main road (Figure 1a) and one in the valley behind the swimming pool (Figure 1b). It is important to note that while the row behind the swimming pool was still considered a part of the Leokwe Rest Camp, the area probably experienced fewer disturbances. Similar parallel layouts were used in the other two sites. The traps were partially concealed (under grass, trees, shrubs, logs) and additional vegetation was placed on top of the traps. The vegetation provided additional cover and shading and to reduce the amount of direct sunlight hitting the trap. The traps were first laid out on the 13th of September 2009 and were baited in the evening and closed during the day. The staple ingredients of the bait were peanut butter and oats. In order to achieve the ideal consistency—being able to be rolled into balls with a diameter of 2.5cm—additional oil and golden syrup were added to the mixture. This baiting was completed on the 13th, 14th, and 15th of November, starting at 16:30 and was finished by 17:30. The traps were checked the next mornings at 06:30. Every trap was emptied and closed by 08:00 to ensure no rodents would be captive during the hottest parts of the day. After capture, rodents were scruffed in cloth bags and the following measurements were taken: sex, identification using Smithers’ Mammals of Southern Africa and The mammals of the southern African subregion, weight, as well as measurements of body length and tail length. In order to manage recaptures, we took a photograph of each new individual and gave them a unique marking with a black permanent marker (Apendix A). Rodents were released at the trap in which they were caught. Structural Habitat Analysis In each of the three sites, ten 4x4 meter plots, 20 meters apart, were used to determine percent grass cover and visibility. Data from each plot was averaged to account for variation and to give an overall site description. To measure visibility, we performed a vegetative profile analysis. One member of the team placed his head 10cm off of the ground while another member vertically dragged a binder away from the observer. When the observer could no longer see 50% of the binder, the distance was recorded. Statistical Analysis We analyzed our data using 2008 Microsoft Excel Version 12.1.0 to calculate total populations, calculate averages, and perform chi-square tests. Total populations were broken up by species and capture location and used to determine site popularity by species. Species richness, abundance, diversity (Shannon-Weiner diversity index), and an MDS diagram were created using Primer 5 version 5.1.2 (2000). Species richness, abundance, and diversity were found by site. These same stats were drawn from summer, 2009, using population estimates from Breed et al 2009. Chi-square tests were used to compare winter and summer date and determine significant differences. The MDS diagram was used to compare site and season clusters. For grass cover data, we used information collected by Chetty et al 2009. This data was compared with our collected data from winter, 2009 to assist in making conclusions about changes in vegetative structure. Image of Mopane Bushveld study site FIGURE 3. Image of Rocky Outcrops study site Experimental design and protocol Trapping We used a total of 90 Sherman© live traps, 30 at each study site, in our experiment. Each site had 24 large traps and six small traps laid out in three rows ten meters apart. In the Leokwe Rest Camp the traps were laid out in three parallel rows, two on either side of the main road (Figure 1a) and one in the valley behind the swimming pool (Figure 1b). It is important to note that while the row behind the swimming pool was still considered a part of the Leokwe Rest Camp, the area probably experienced fewer disturbances. Similar parallel layouts were used in the other two sites. The traps were partially concealed (under grass, trees, shrubs, logs) and additional vegetation was placed on top of the traps. The vegetation provided additional cover and shading and to reduce the amount of direct sunlight hitting the trap. The traps were first laid out on the 13th of September 2009 and were baited in the evening and closed during the day. The staple ingredients of the bait were peanut butter and oats. In order to achieve the ideal consistency—being able to be rolled into balls with a diameter of 2.5cm—additional oil and golden syrup were added to the mixture. This baiting was completed on the 13th, 14th, and 15th of November, starting at 16:30 and was finished by 17:30. The traps were checked the next mornings at 06:30. Every trap was emptied and closed by 08:00 to ensure no rodents would be captive during the hottest parts of the day. After capture, rodents were scruffed in cloth bags and the following measurements were taken: sex, identification using Smithers’ Mammals of Southern Africa and The mammals of the southern African subregion, weight, as well as measurements of body length and tail length. In order to manage recaptures, we took a photograph of each new individual and gave them a unique marking with a black permanent marker (Apendix A). Rodents were released at the trap in which they were caught. Structural Habitat Analysis In each of the three sites, ten 4x4 meter plots, 20 meters apart, were used to determine percent grass cover and visibility. Data from each plot was averaged to account for variation and to give an overall site description. To measure visibility, we performed a vegetative profile analysis. One member of the team placed his head 10cm off of the ground while another member vertically dragged a binder away from the observer. When the observer could no longer see 50% of the binder, the distance was recorded. Statistical Analysis We analyzed our data using 2008 Microsoft Excel Version 12.1.0 to calculate total populations, calculate averages, and perform chi-square tests. Total populations were broken up by species and capture location and used to determine site popularity by species. Species richness, abundance, diversity (Shannon-Weiner diversity index), and an MDS diagram were created using Primer 5 version 5.1.2 (2000). Species richness, abundance, and diversity were found by site. These same stats were drawn from summer, 2009, using population estimates from Breed et al 2009. Chi-square tests were used to compare winter and summer date and determine significant differences. The MDS diagram was used to compare site and season clusters. For grass cover data, we used information collected by Chetty et al 2009. This data was compared with our collected data from winter, 2009 to assist in making conclusions about changes in vegetative structure.
Effects of seasonality and changes in vegetation structure on small mammal populations in three distinct habitats

The allometric patterns of an insect body are shaped by an insect’s functional ecology. In particular, we believe that different guilds of dung beetles practicing different life history strategies will exhibit varying flight accuracy. We hypothesized that these constraints would result in accurate flyers displaying generally lower wing aspect ratios. Additionally, we expected to see a positive correlation between body size and aspect ratio, signifying a decline in flight accuracy with increasing body size. To capture and differentiate between inaccurate and accurate flying insects, we used a modified pitfall trap, entitled the Byrne Pitfall Trap. The aspect ratios of the insects collected in the inner and outer traps were not significantly different and did not support our predicted correlation between body size and aspect ratio. These results may not be representative of actual allometric patterns in insects due to our small sample size. They nonetheless indicate that, for an insect, functional ecology and the demands of flight have no bearing upon wing shape.
Wren Larson, Edie Dooley, Amanda Gibson SANParks, SOuth Africa Faculty Field Problem
Wren Larson, Edie Dooley, Amanda Gibson SANParks, SOuth Africa Faculty Field Problem
Aspect Ratio, Dung Beetles, Scarabidae, Flying Accuracy, Pitfall trapping

Our experiment was conducted at De Hoop Nature reserve in South Africa’s Western Cape from October 27-29, 2006. The reserve, situated on the coast of the Indian Ocean, is dominated by the fynbos vegetation. We set our pitfall traps on the southern side of the road in an area of the reserve that is known to be frequented by several large ungulates, such as bontebok and eland. We hypothesized that the higher concentrations of ungulates in this area would correspond to more dung and thus more dung beetles. Materials To construct our pitfall traps, we dug ten holes and placed a large bucket in each hole with a smaller bucket in the inside. The outer buckets were intended to catch the hypothetically inaccurate flyers, insects that land at some distance from the bait and walk towards it, falling over the rim. We placed a smaller trap in the center of the large bucket to catch accurate flyers, the insects that fly directly onto the bait. Inner traps were bated with bovine dung wrapped in gauze and placed on a wire holder in the center. Since no part of the inner bucket touched the rim of the outer bucket, insects could not walk into the inner bucket; they could only land in the inner bucket if they flew directly onto it. Collection Technique We checked our traps twice each day, at 7:00 and 18:00, for three days. To collect the insects we poured the water from the inner bottle trap through a strainer and collected the insects from the strainer. The outer buckets actually consisted of two nested buckets, the lower to hold the shape of the hole in the ground, and the upper to be pulled out and strained. Each time we collected the insects from the traps, we re-baited the trap with fresh dung. The soapy water was usually reused after sieving, though occasionally replaced if particularly dirty. Additionally, we collected several specimens at a variety of random locations within the reserve. We labeled these as “general” insects and identified their family and functional ecology. The majority of these specimens were identified as generalist plant feeders and presumed to be inaccurate flyers (pers. Comm. Marcus Byrne). We separated the insects into three categories: the “accurate” insects collected in the inner trap, the “inaccurate” insects collected in the outer bucket, and the general collection insects. Wing Analysis After each collection, we made measurements of the body size and the wing size of the specimens. To examine wing size, we removed the insect’s elytra, the hard outer covering of the wings characteristic of beetles, if present, and removed its wings. We placed the wings in drops of water on microscope slides and carefully unfolded them. Using a microscope under constant magnification, we measured the length and chord of each wing. We averaged the values from the insect’s two wings and divided the average length by the average width to obtain a value for the insect’s wing aspect ratio. Body size was determined by measuring the width of the 24 specimen’s pronotum, the middle segment of the insect body. Pronotum width scales isometrically with body length in insects and is therefore a good measure of overall body size (Kelly unpublished data). Statistical Analysis We calculated our statistics using Statistica 7.0 (StatSoft Inc. 2004). We used parametric tests (Anova, T Test, and the Tukey’s Post-Hoc test) to analyze relationships between collection locations within the trap and wing aspect ratios. The analyses were considered significant if the p-value was less than 0.05.

Many studies have demonstrated a causal relationship between disturbance and species diversity and furthermore between losses in diversity and declines in ecosystem function, resilience and resistance. Our study supports this and additionally the notion that monitoring of small mammal diversity can be used as a quick and inexpensive indicator of ecosystem integrity. The movement of herbivores to and from waterholes results in an increasing gradient in their grazing, browsing and trampling impacts towards waterholes, creating circular zones of impact known as piospheres. An increase in artificial waterholes in the past has resulted in an overlap in these impacted areas, creating a homogenised, disturbed habitat. The aim of our study was to determine if the vegetation structure and composition is indeed impacted in the piosphere and whether this affects rodent diversity and abundance. We tested an open waterhole and one which had been closed for about two years. We found similar number of rodents at both waterholes. However the open waterhole had a lower diversity of rodents than the closed waterhole and was dominated by the multimammate mouse, Mastomys natalensis, which in other studies has been associated with disturbed areas.
Tammy Baudains, Taryn Morris and Govan Pahad SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Tammy Baudains, Taryn Morris and Govan Pahad SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Disturbance, diversity, Kruger Park, monitoring, piospheres, rodents, Sherman traps

Sampling was undertaken on four consecutive nights from 21 to 24 March 2004. March is considered near the end of the breeding season of small mammals (Monadjem and Perrin 1997). Two waterholes were sampled in the Punda Maria region of the Kruger National Park (Figure 1). One waterhole, which we named Elephant waterhole, had been closed approximately two years prior to our study. The other, Elandskuil waterhole, had remained open since construction. The vegetation was sampled along two transects of 50m in each of the two grids at each waterhole to investigate correlations with rodent diversity. Percentage grass cover was assessed every 10m along the transect by randomly placing a 0.5x0.5m quadrate on the ground and estimating the percentage grass cover within. Vegetation composition was determined by recording the species present at points every 2m along each transect. Structure was sampled by determining foliage profiles using boards 1.5m high and 10cm wide, divided into height classes of 25cm. At five points (every 10m) along each transect, we measured the distance from the point at which 50% of each height class on the board was obscured. The reciprocal of this distance is directly proportional to foliage density and is thus an approximation of the vertical distribution of biomass. From these values, a foliage profile of each site was constructed. Sherman traps were set in two 5 by 6 grids of 30 traps spaced ten metres apart on opposite sides of each waterhole. At the open waterhole, grids were laid approximately 20m away from the waterhole so that the absence of vegetative cover due to excessive over grazing and trampling would not affect our results. Traps were left open day and night and were checked and rebaited in the early mornings and late afternoons. Traps were baited using a mixture of peanut butter, rolled oats, and whole seeds including corn and sorghum. Rodents trapped were identified to species level, sexed, weighed and were marked on the third day by cutting a patch of fur off the belly), before being released in the same area. Reproductive status was assessed by males either being scrotal or not scrotal and females being nulliperous or sexually active. This was checked by feeling whether or not the pubic symphasis was open or closed (many females were pregnant or suckling and so were easily identified as sexually active). Data were analyzed using Microsoft Excel 2000, Primer 5, JMP IN 5.1 and Statistica 6. The mean percentage vegetation cover was derived for the open and closed waterhole and graphed. Additionally a student’s ttest for independent samples was performed in Statistica 6 to determine whether the difference in percentage cover was significant or not. The vegetation species composition at the four open waterhole transects and four closed waterhole transects were compared by producing a cluster analysis in Primer 5. A foliage density graph was created to illustrate the vertical distribution of biomass at each waterhole. Additionally student t-tests for independent samples were performed on 0.25m, 0.5m and 0.75m height classes to determine if there was significant difference in the amount of foliage at those heights. The rodent captures were summed and divided by the number of trap days to determine percentage trap success at 231 each waterhole. All calculations took into account the loss of two traps at the open waterhole due to damage by an elephant, and the disappearance of one trap. Species data were graphed using Microsoft Excel so that graphical comparisons could be made i.e. what were the most common species at each of the two sites A Shannon-Wiener diversity test was performed in Primer 5 on the species data to see whether either site was more diverse in rodent species than the other. It is a measure of both the number of species and the equality of representation of the individuals of all the species i.e. evenness. The Peterson method was used to obtain an estimation of the population size using the unbiased estimator equation: N = (((M+1)(C+1))/(R+1)) -1, where M= number of individuals marked in the first sample, C = Total number of individuals captured in the second sample and R = Number of individuals in second sample that are marked (Krebs 1999). G-tests were performed to compare male versus female ratios, perimeter versus interior trap success and trap success in long model Sherman traps versus short model ones, in JMP IN 5.1. Lastly mean weights per species were determined.

Preference of large herbivores for waterholes of varying size and vegetation cover was investigated. Nine waterholes were sampled by identifying and counting tracks in 1m2 quadrates every fifth meter around the waterhole’s perimeter. Waterholes were compared in terms of percentage individual species composition, as well as size class and predator-avoidance strategies of visiting species. Mega-herbivores (elephants, giraffes, and hippos) preferred large waterholes. Preference for degree of cover at a waterhole was related to the species’ predator-avoidance strategies: species that flee from predators preferred open waterholes; species that hide from predators preferred abundant cover close to the water’s edge; and impala preferred intermediate cover some distance from the water’s edge as they scatter and hide once predators have been detected. Samevatting: Ons het die voorkeur van groot plantetend diere vir drinkplekke van verskillende grootte en planteryk ondersoek. Opname was uitgedra op nege drinkplekke en die spore wat in een vierkantige meter viekant gevind was, was getel en geidentifiseer. Die viekants was elke vyf meter op die omtrek van die watergat geplaas. Drinkplekke was gevergelyk met betrekking tot persent individueel spesie komposisie, so wel as grootte orde en roofdier ontduiking strategies van spesies wat die watergat gebruik het. Groot plantetend diere het die groter drinkplekkke voorkeur omdat hulle individueel benodigdhede vir afstand en water het. Voorkeur vir die bedrag van planteryk oordekking by ‘n drinkplek was verwant na die spesie se roofdier ontduiking strategies: spesies wat van roofdiere vlug, het drinkplekke in die ooplug voorkeur; spesies wat van roofdiere wegkruip, het drinkplekke met baie planteryk ontdekking voorkeur; en rooibok het ver maar baie planteryk ontdekking van die drinkplek se kant voorkeur omdat hulle hardloop en vegkruip wanneer hulle roofdiere sien.
Tammy Baudains, Megan Eastwood & Govan Pahad SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Tammy Baudains, Megan Eastwood & Govan Pahad SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
large herbivores, predator avoidance, preferences, vegetation cover, water availability, waterhole

All waterholes surveyed in this study were in the region surrounding the Skukuza rest camp in the Kruger National Park, South Africa. The sampling period extended over several days in late February 2004, during the wet season. We sampled tracks at nine waterholes with as great a variation in size and surrounding cover as possible. Quadrates of 1m2 were laid down every 5th meter around the perimeter of the waterholes, so that 20% of the perimeter of each waterhole was sampled regardless of its size. This means that approximately 20% of the tracks around each waterhole should have been sampled, representing the same proportion of animals that had visited each waterhole. As the area directly around the waterhole has the most mud and the least vegetation (both of which are favourable conditions for clear, identifiable tracks) we placed each quadrate as close to the water’s edge as possible. Within each quadrate, we identified and counted the tracks present but only recorded tracks that could be clearly identified as belonging to a particular species. Track field guides and the assistance of guides enabled us to identify more obscure tracks. Cover at each waterhole was assessed in terms of percentage woody cover and distance in meters from the water’s edge to the nearest cover. To assess species’ preference for waterhole types, we calculated the number of tracks found for each species visiting a particular waterhole as a percentage of the total number of tracks of that species seen at all waterholes. This should nullify any bias caused by some species’ tracks lasting longer or being easier to identify than others. We assumed that finding a great deal of a species’ tracks around a particular waterhole type would indicate a preference for waterholes of similar size and cover. Due to the small sample sizes for individual species, we grouped the herbivores together according to: a) predator avoidance strategies and b) size. The groups according to predator avoidance strategies were: those that hide from predators and escape by dodging amongst vegetation (common duiker, steenbok and kudu); those that flee from predators (Burchell’s zebra, blue wildebeest, buffalo and warthog); those that stand up to predators (giraffe, elephant and hippopotamus); and those that scatter into nearby vegetation to escape from predators (impala). The species were divided into these groups according to information from a behavioural guide by Estes (1999). The groups according to mass were: less than 100kg (steenbok, common duiker, warthog and impala); between 100kg and 1000kg (kudu, buffalo, Burchell’s zebra and blue wildebeest); and greater than 1000kg (elephant, hippopotamus and giraffe). The masses were taken from a field guide by Frandsen (2002). We assessed animal communities by using Primer to create a multi-dimensional scaling (MDS) plot (Primer 5).

These data were collected as part of a monitaring programme on habitat use by large herbivores. the numbers and distribution of large herbivores were counted from the roads b the same observer (Peter Novellie). the same road was followed for all counts. the counts were conducted roughly once per mounth from the first on 15 December 2983 and the last on 4 September 1989, there being 98 counts in total. This dataset include the most common ungulate species: Cape mountain zebra, springbok, black wildebeest, blesbok,and red hartebeest. from this study it emetged that there were three areas (termed hotspots), each about 50ha in size, which consistently carried very high herbivore numbers. this dataset recodeds the number of herbivores counted in each of the three areas. follow up surveys could reveal whether these areas are still particulary favoured by large herbivores.

Methods We set up an experiment in the plant nursery in Skukuza using 8 grass species common in the Kruger National Park. After 5 weeks of establishment we exposed the plants to three different nutrient treatments for three weeks after which they were harvested. The treatments were: direct nutrient supply (D), spatially separated nutrient supply (MF), and no nutrient supply (C).We measured photosynthesis (Amax), stomatal conductance (gs), water use efficiency (WUE), with a LICOR6400XT Irga Starting 2 weeks after treatment application on the youngest fully expanded leaf. Nutrient gain and biomass of six grass species were measured after 3 weeks of treatments. Traits were analyses on extra well fertilized plants
Laura Rose University of Freiburg laura.rose@biologie.uni-freiburg.de, PI

Methods We set up an experiment in the plant nursery in Skukuza using 8 grass species common in the Kruger National Park. After 5 weeks of establishment we exposed the plants to three different nutrient treatments for three weeks after which they were harvested. The treatments were: direct nutrient supply (D), spatially separated nutrient supply (MF), and no nutrient supply (C).We measured photosynthesis (Amax), stomatal conductance (gs), water use efficiency (WUE), with a LICOR6400XT Irga Starting 2 weeks after treatment application on the youngest fully expanded leaf. Nutrient gain and biomass of six grass species were measured after 3 weeks of treatments. Traits were analyses on extra well fertilized plants

Basic data quality checks for Mata Mata 0497019 2 GEMSBOKPARK - MATA MATA Lat: -25.81 Long: 20.02 Height: 1,000 m CurOrder: Notes 177.2mm of rain recorded on 7 March 1976 - this is likely an error as only 28mm were recorded at Twee Rivieren There is no 20h wind series January 1975 missing from the temperature and rainfall series - dates added to rainfall April and May missing from 1988 temperature series - added Oct to Dec 2001 also missing from rainfall series - dates added General comments Temperature: There is a strong annual pattern in temperature, with winter temperatures very low (minima) and summer temperatures very high. There is a large gap in the minimum temperature series (Jan 1979, April to Jul 1979 and April 1983 to April 1984) as well as a gap in both series: Jul 2005 to end Dec 2006 and several interspersed months in 2003. April and May missing from 1988. The data after the 2006 gap become patchy. Rainfall: There is a gap in the data from Aug 2005 to Feb 2006 (due to failed readings) - this excludes the rainfall season. There is a strong summer rainfall pattern. 1976 data likely contain an error - see above. January 1975 missing and Oct to Dec 2001 also missing. Wind: Data only available for 1978 and 1979 Basid cata quality checks for Nossb 0535175 5 GEMSBOKPARK - NOSSOB Lat: -25.42 Long: 20.6 Height: 1,000 m THIRD CurOrder: Notes May 1988 missing from the temperature series - added The whole of 1992 and Oct - Dec 2001 missing from the rainfall series 83mm of rain recorded on 5 Jan 1998 - possibly an error - 26mm recorded at Twee Rivieren General comments Temperature: There is a clear annual trend in temperatures and there is a fairly large difference between manima and maxima in all seasons. There are a few gaps in the data, especially towards the end of the series: Maxima: Feb-Mar 197, Sep 1980- Mar 1981, Jun-Aug 1992, Aug ; Minima: May 1990; Both series: several gaps in 1990, several gaps from Jun 1994 to May 1995, Dec 1995. There are no data for Mar-Dec 2006 and data begin again on 1 Jan 2007. Also no data from Feb-Jun 2009. There are also several other small gaps. Rainfall: There are only 14 occurences (0.1%) of failed readings. There is no data for 1992, Oct-Dec 2001 and six days in a row without a reading in Feb 2006, which could affect rainfall measured for the year as this area receives summer rainfall. Wind: Data only available for 1978 and 1979 Basic data qualift checks for Twee Rivieren 0461208 4 TWEE RIVIEREN Lat: -26.47 Long: 20.61 Height: 882 m CurOrder: ELEC_MANUAL Notes 79mm of rain received on 9 Feb 1989 could be an error as 0 mm received at Nossob and 16mm at Mata mata The humidity data are plagued by gaps and seem rather irregular The wind data appear problematic 2003/09/09 and 2003/09/30 repeated in the 8h humidity data series - deleted 2003/09/08 repeated in the 14h and 20h humidity data series - deleted 2003/09/02 repeated in the 8h pressure data series - deleted There were many gaps in the pressure data prior to 1983 and the pattern in these data seems questionable. Outlier in July 2007 pressure data 2003/09/02 repeated in the 8h wind data series - deleted The wind data show highly erratic patterns (which stablize only in 2007) 898.3 deleted from pressure data 20h series on 2002/7/22 - this was a clear outlier May1988 as well as several other data points missing from the temperature data July 1991 missing from the rain data series - added in analysis file General comments Temperature: There are a few small gaps in the data, but the only big one includes a one year gap in minimum temperature from November 1982 to November 1983. There is a strong annual cycle in minimum and maximum temp and there is a relatively large difference between minima and maxima. Rainfall: There is a strong pattern of summer rainfall. July 1991 missing from series. Humidity: The humidity data are plagued by gaps and seem rather irregular Pressure: The first few years of this data were deleted because they were faulty and full of gaps (start now 1983) Wind: The wind data show highly erratic patterns (which stablizes only in 2007) with several inconsistencies.

There are a few gaps in the data, especially towards the end of the series: Maxima: Feb-Mar 197, Sep 1980- Mar 1981, Jun-Aug 1992, Aug ; Minima: May 1990; Both series: several gaps in 1990, several gaps from Jun 1994 to May 1995, Dec 1995. There are no data for Mar-Dec 2006 and data begin again on 1 Jan 2007. Also no data from Feb-Jun 2009. There are also several other small gaps. Commensalism with humans has advantaged many animals, including Hemidactylus mabouia which has spread in association with human settlements. What factors or resources increase fitness for H. mabouia in association with humans? We sampled populations of commensal H. mabouia geckos inside the Punda Maria rest camp in the Kruger National Park and compared body condition and abundance with populations of the same species sampled outside the camp. Association with humans resulted in greater densities supported in campsite buildings and body condition was improved. Insect presence was confirmed to be positively related to proximity to light source and thus prey abundance was enhanced compared with geckos outside the rest camp. Body condition variability in the human-associated population was best explained by bite force controlled for body size; we found no significant role for measured environmental variables. No evidence for sexual dimorphism was obtained and in contrast to current knowledge no evidence of male territoriality was found. Since tail loss was equal in males and females, this was ascribed to predation rather than territoriality.

Methods Study site and species Moreau’s Tropical House Gecko (Hemidactylus mabouia) was sampled for three days from 11 to 13 September 2010 around the Punda Maria campsite, KNP, South Africa. The campsite is located in the more arid north of the KNP, with a mean annual precipitation of 532 mm (Venter et al. 2003). The underlying geology is complex and unique to the park, overlain by. mopane woodland (Colophospermum mopane) which dominates the vegetation (Venter et al. 2003). In order to compare human-associated geckos with those found outside settlements, two study regions were delineated: nine sites (comprising three campsite bathrooms, three kitchens, a laundry, a restaurant and petrol station) within the rest camp [31.018130S; -22.691900E] and two sites outside the camp [31.03818S; -22.70517E]. The body mass of our test species ranged from 1.14 grams – 5.8 grams. Experimental protocol Three sessions of active searching of approximately three hours were conducted outside the camp to sample wild populations of H. mabouia. Nighttime active searching took place for three consecutive evenings and consisted of two phases. Phase 1: two evenings were spent actively searching for two hours from 20h00 to 22h00 with the intention to capture, measure and mark individuals within and outside camp buildings. We measured snout-vent length (SVL) in mm (sensu Quinn and Jones 1974), head width (mm), head height (mm) and head length (mm) using a digital caliper. Mass (g) was determined using a 30 g Pesola scale. Tail status (intact, lost or regrown), scarring and injuries were noted and anecdotally recorded. Geckos were sexed based on the presence or absence of eggs: females of H. mabouia generally carry eggs throughout the year (Branch 1998). Geckos were uniquely numbered at each site on their dorsal surface using a permanent pen before release. Behavioural observations were conducted on the first evening. We drew ten 1 x 1 m chalk quadrats around seven light sources and observed insect abundance and gecko location within the quadrats at 5 minute intervals. Phase 2: a two hour “recapture” period (again between 20h00 and 22h00) took place on the third evening. New individuals were captured, measured and marked as for phase 1, already marked individuals were not recaptured. Predetermined abiotic variables were recorded in association with each individual, whether previously marked or not, including distance to nearest light source (cm), distance to nearest refuge (cm), spot surface temperature (⁰C) and insect presence or absence within a 50 cm radius. Data analyses Individuals with a SVL of less than 45mm were classified as juveniles and discarded from further analysis to ensure only fully grown individuals were used for body condition analyses. An index of body condition was created by dividing body mass by SVL. Bite force may act as a proxy for feeding ability and was considered likely to allometrically scale with SVL. That is, as body length increased, so would head area. Bite force was calculated as the product of head width and head length in mm2.. As SVL was a component of body condition, bite force was controlled for the scaling effect of increased body length by dividing bite force by SVL. Tests of assumptions and statistical and graphical analyses were performed in Statistica 9.0 (StatSoft Inc. 2009). Differences in variables between sexes and between individuals with and without tail loss histories were tested with Student’s t tests. Differences in variables between sample sites were tested using a single factor analysis of variance (ANOVA, test statistic F). The strength of the relationship between two continuous variables was tested using Pearson’s product moment correlation (correlation coefficient r). A general linear model (GLM) was run to test how temperature , distance to nearest light source , distance to nearest refuge , bite force controlled for SVL and insect presence affected body condition.

We assessed the change in (agricultural) grassland functionality at three sites (i.e. Main Camp-section, Colchester-section, Nyati-section) in the Addo Elephant National Park, South Africa. Using landscape function analysis (LFA) we described the landscape organisation of each site, and, using visual surrogates, calculated indices of landscape stability, infiltration and nutrient cycling. The following variables were recorded along transects: (1) number of patches, (2) patch area index (area in m2 covered by vegetative patches along each transect, (3) interpatch lenght (avg length in m of interpatches - i.e. non-vegetative structures like bare ground, logs, rocks, etc.), and (4) % stability, % infiltration, % nutrient cycling (calculated using Tongway and Hindley (2004).
