SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Herpetofauna diversity encompasses a range of environmental habitats from fossorial to aquatic to arboreal, linking the richness and abundance of herpetofauna community assemblages to characteristics in vegetation and habitat structure. Many herpetofauna species rely upon restricted (i.e. micro-habitat) components within their environment. The aims of this study are: 1) to determine if there are differences in herpetofauna diversity between riparian forest and xeric savanna habitat types; 2) to determine which habitat characteristics define the species assemblages and; 3) to assess the accuracy of the 118 herpetofauna sampling methodology. Fieldwork was conducted within Mapungubwe National Park (MNP) located in the Limpopo Province. The structure of the habitat types were assessed along 50m transects for the following characteristics; vegetation height (cm), soil penetration (pressure per cm^2), proximity to rock outcrop (m), woody debris, live trees, burrows, and rocks. Species richness (S), abundance (N) and diversity (H’) within each habitat type were analyzed as well as habitat structure and put into specific species guilds. Overall our results showed that herpetofauna species richness was significantly different when comparing between riparian forest and xeric savanna habitat types.
Dax Mackay, Mary Sparks SANParks, South Africa Independent Research Project 2
Dax Mackay, Mary Sparks SANParks, South Africa Independent Research Project 2
Herpetofauna diversity, conservation, habitat structure, vegetation

Fieldwork was conducted within Mapungubwe National Park (MNP) located in the Limpopo Province during the dates of the eleventh to the nineteenth of November. Trapping was carried out in the summer season to optimize catch rates of Herpetofauna. Two habitat types were selected for the installation of ten trap site arrays; five were placed in riparian habitats and five were placed in xeric savanna (Table A). The riparian habitat type is characterized by its’ close proximity to the Limpopo River, the presence of large trees which provided a closed canopy, a more patchy undergrowth cover and a sparse ground cover. The dominant woody vegetation is composed of Acacia xanthophloea, Faidherbia aldiba, Ficus sycomorus and Xanthocercis zambesiaca, while the understory is made up of patches of shrub vegetation dominated by Croton megalobotrys (0.5m to 2.5m). The soil within this habitat has a high clay content giving it a grey colour as well as a high organic material component. Conversely, the xeric savanna ecotype was characterized as having a patchy distribution of vegetation, both ground cover and canopy cover, which was dominated by Boscia albitrunca, Colophospermum mopane, Combretum mossambicense, Commiphora glandulosa and Dichrostachys cinerea. Sites were in close proximity to sand stone outcroppings which shared approximately 50 % of the landscape. The soil within this habitat type consists of 120 fine grain red sand with low organic materials. Elevation between sites ranged from 504 to 513 meters (m) within the riparian habitat and from 521 to 538 within the savanna habitat. Distances between trap sites within each habitat type were approximately 500m. Herpetofauna sampled The herpetofauna (amphibians and reptiles grouped together) sampled during this survey were analyzed as three separate groups; herpetofauna, amphibians and reptiles combined and; amphibians and reptiles as separate groups. Each of the ten sites contained a trap array, consisting of three arms of drift fencing, four pitfall and six funnel traps (Figure 1). All trap arrays were constructed from three ten meter drift fences of black damp-proofing plastic (30 cm X 40 m) stapled to stakes and with one-third of its width buried. Pitfall traps (plastic buckets) were buried flush with the ground at the end of each drift fence (4 in total). Two different size buckets were used, ten 20 litre (centre) and thirty 9 litre (at ends of each arm). Vegetation from each site and cardboard was used to provide shade for specimens caught in the pitfall traps, while still allowing access to the trap. We used a new technique to construct funnel traps from a single sheet of green mosquito mesh and with a flat base provided more stability for traps to remain flush against each side of each drift fence were. Zippers were also installed in the top of each trap to facilitate easier specimen removal. These funnel traps were also covered with vegetation to provide shade for captured specimens. Trap arrays were checked once per day and both types of trap were successful in collecting small mammals (rodents) and invertebrates (insects, scorpions and arachnids). All captured specimens were identified to species level, classified as adult or juvenile and released 10 metres from the trap array. Habitat structure The structure of the riparian and the savanna habitat types were assessed along 50m transects through the following characteristics; vegetation height (cm), soil penetration (pressure per cm^2), proximity to rock outcrop (m), woody debris, live trees, burrows, and rocks. Soil penetration measures, using a soil penetrometer, were used to relate habitat type soil compactness to the facilitation of fossorial species. Trap site proximity to rock outcroppings and number of live trees were used to impart suitable, stable herpetofauna microhabitat. Woody-debris, burrows and rocks were considered as microhabitats if they were of sufficient size for reptiles (lizards and small snakes) and amphibians to take refuge. Vegetation height was used to characterize the available cover present at each trap site. Transects were walked along a north-south orientation within each trapping area, soil penetration measures were taken every ten meters and the number of live trees, woody debris, burrows, rocks and vegetation height measures were taken every meter along each transect. Data analysis The data collected from the two sets of replicate plots were pooled to determine the herpetofaunal species richness (S), abundance (N) and diversity (H’) within each habitat type. The Shannon-Wiener diversity index (H’) was used in this case as it allows for the incorporation of the number of species as well as the number of individuals of each species in calculating community information. Herpetofaunal measures as well as 121 the measures of habitat structure were run through Primer (v5) to generate similarity matrices. The ordination outputs provided a graphic perspective characterizing the two habitat types based on the species assemblage similarity between the trap sites. Each of the three herpetofaunal groups in addition to the seven habitat structure measures were tested for normality and then compared individually, if normal, between different habitat types using a one-way ANOVA analysis in Statistica (6.0). The richness, abundance and diversity for the three herpetofaunal groups were then compared individually against the seven habitat characters in a regression analysis to determine whether any of the habitat structures measures explained herpetofaunal patterns. Finally the herpetofaunal species list for both habitat types were divided into guilds based on genus similarity and preference for micro-habitat. Amphibian species were grouped into three guilds and reptile species were grouped into four guilds and the abundances were compared in a multi-factorial ANOVA analysis, again in Statistica (6.0).

SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa, Supersites, soil moisture

A multiscale approach was used to study the dynamics of reed patches in a section of the Letaba River flowing through the Kruger National Park (KNP), South Africa's largest conservation area. The valley floor consists of a mosaic of patches of reeds, water, sand and rock. Reed vegetation change in space and time is closely linked to geomorphic change in the rivers of the KNP, because of reciprocal interactions between reeds, flow and sediment. Reeds are thus considered a potentially important species around which to formulate management goals for these rivers. A study of clonal growth characteristics at the scale of individual reedbeds was combined with a study of reed patch dynamics at the river reach scale. Mechanisms affecting clonal expansion across reedbed boundaries were combined with short-term patterns of reed persistence, loss and gain at the reach scale, and longer-term trends in reed cover, to produce a conceptual model of proposed relationships between flow conditions and reed cover in the Letaba River. Reed areal cover increased between 1988 and 1999. Despite this, reed persistence was low, and reeds were a dynamic element of the river landscape in the short term. Turnover of water and reed patches was high, within a matrix of sand. Complex patterns of reed gain and loss occurred at the boundaries of reed patches, with gain exceeding loss throughout the period of study. During a drier period (1988-1996), clonal expansion of patches and establishment of new patches contributed equally (50% each) to the increase in reed cover. During a wetter period (1996-1999), the relative contribution of clonal expansion increased to 90%. Reed persistence was higher in the wetter period due to less reed loss, and reed cover increased more rapidly. The relative proportions of reed, water and sand patches did not remain constant over 3 years or over 8 years in the alluvial section of the river studied. At the time and space scales of this study, therefore, the Letaba River did not display the kind of compositional stability described in other river systems. This points to the difficulty of applying equilibrium concepts of either geomorphology or vegetation dynamics to semi-arid rivers. A clear spatial patchiness was present in the distribution of sediment and nutrient resources on the macro-channel floor. Reed patches were associated with `current shadow' features, the characteristic raised elevation of the central, denser parts of reedbeds suggesting accumulation of sediment within reedbeds. Silt and clay particles accumulated preferentially within reedbeds. The results suggest that this accumulation was achieved primarily by selective retention of nes within reedbeds, and to a lesser extent by selective deposition of stones within reedbeds. Total carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus were all higher beneath reedbeds than in uncolonised sediment. The distributions of total N and total P were not correlated with that of total C, suggesting that nutrient accumulation does not simply reflect breakdown of reed organic matter. It was proposed that the nutrient accumulation recorded in this study was due primarily to interactions between reedbeds and flow, and to a lesser extent to the input of reed organic matter. The fact that surface resource distribution patterns did not always correspond to subsurface patterns illustrates the importance of viewing reed patches as three-dimensional entities. A high stem density and limited plasticity in spacer characteristics of Phragmites mauritianus in the Letaba River were consistent with a consolidation strategy of clonal growth. Physiological integration within within the clone was, however, limiteda notable departure from the consolidation strategy. While Phragmites mauritianus showed little evidence of plasticity in the horizontal spacer characteristics traditionally measured in studies of clonal growth patterns (internode length, branching pattern and bud activity), it was proposed that plasticity in rhizome characteristics related to regenerative capacity is important for reed persistence and clonal expansion in this habitat. The added vertical dimension of the rhizome system in species such as P. mauritianus limits the usefulness of horizontal spacer characteristics in explaining patterns of clonal expansion. Progressive accumulation of sediment above the rhizomes and upgrowth of reeds to the surface was proposed as a mechanism whereby the depth of the rhizome layer is increased, thus increasing the density of reed stems and enhancing the persistence of the reedbed. Rhizomes at reedbed boundaries did not show particular adaptations for rapid expansion into available space. Clonal expansion and consolidation of the space aroud established reedbeds was limited both by features of the rhizomes themselves (high proportion of dormant buds, low branching probability and shallow depth), and by external factors (flow disturbance). Management concerns over reed `encroachment' in the Letaba River appear unfounded. While rapid reed expansion may occur during favourable periods, conditions suitable for large increases in reed cover occur relatively infrequently and persist for short periods of time. It was proposed that wet periods with a high frequency of medium flows and no large floods are most likely to be associated with large increases in reed cover.

Kotschy University of the Witwatesrand School of Animal Plant and Environmental Sciences University of the Witwatesrand
Reeds, clonal expansion, Letaba River, Kruger National Park

Methods Carter and Rogers (1995) analysed changes in reed cover up until 1988. Aerial photographs from 1988, 1996 and 1999 were used to extend their work. A Geographical Information System (GIS), PCI-ILWIS, was used to analyse the aerial photographs. The GIS software made it possible to calculate not only changes in reed cover, but also changes in the distribution of reeds within the macro-channel. It was thus possible to determine the persistence of reedbeds and to assess the relative contributions of clonal expansion and establishment of new patches to changes in reed cover. Spatial and temporal relationships between reed patches, and water and sand patches, could also be investigated. Since the focus of this thesis is on the dynamics of reed patches, an alluvial section of the river was chosen for study. Alluvial channel types have a smaller diversity of patches on the macrochannel oor than other channel types, because of the absence of bedrock and woody vegetation. Reed patches could also be distinguished relatively easily on the aerial photographs. The 25 km llong study section lay between Mingerhout and Engelhard dams (Figure 2.1). The work of Carter and Rogers (1995) showed that landscape state changes taking place in this section reflect the changes taking place in the river as a whole, both in overall pattern and in relative magnitude. Eight subsections were selected from the study section, each approximately 300 m in length. These were chosen subjectively in order to cover both the length of the study section and the range of histories of reed change (increasing reed cover, decreasing reed cover, and no change). Four of the subsections included the study sites at which fieldwork was done (Chapter 5). The aerial photographs were digitized using a scanner, at a resolution of 300 dots per inch (dpi), giving a pixel size of approximately 0.8 m 0.8 m on the ground. The three photographs from each site were then cross-georeferenced using features recognisable on all three photos (mainly trees). Pixels were classified as either reeds, water or sand using unsupervised classification based on grayscale ranges. Woody vegetation could not be uniquely identified on the basis of its grayscale range, and was omitted from the analysis. This was not considered a problem as woody vegetation in this section of the Letaba occurs almost exclusively as a riparian fringe on the macrochannel banks and does not form part of the mosaic of patches on the macro-channel oor. Occasional `problem' patches of woody vegetation were masked using the GIS software and thus ommitted from the analysis. The accuracy of each classification was assessed visually from the photographs and by comparing the maps produced by the GIS with reed distribution at the study sites. The resulting maps of reed distribution for each year were then combined to produce raster maps showing the location of patches (pixels) which had undergone one of nine categories of change, as follows: 1) reeds-> reeds 4) sand-> reeds 7) water-> reeds 2) reeds-> sand 5) sand-> sand 8) water-> sand 3) reeds-> water 6) sand-> water 9) water-> water Two sets of these combined maps were produced, one for each of the two time periods (1988 to 1996, and 1996 to 1999). This made it possible to compare changes taking place over a longer and a shorter period (8 years and 3 years). 3.2.1 Short-term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, Short term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, gain and loss The GIS software was used to calculate the proportion of the macro-channel covered by each of the nine categories of change for each period. Reed cover present at the beginning of a period could then be calculated by combining categories 1, 2 and 3, and that present at the end of a period by combining categories 1, 4 and 7. Changes in the proportion of the macro-channel covered by water and sand were calculated in a similar way. Pattterns of reed persistence, appearance and disappearance were investigated by calculating the frequencies of each type of change involving reeds (categories 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7) as a percentage of the total changes involving reeds. These were compared between the two time periods using two-sample t tests. Reed persistence is a measure of what proportion of reed patches were able to maintain their position on the macro-channel floor, and thus, possibly, undergo clonal expansion. It was calculated as the proportion of reeds which were not lost or gained during a period, in other words, those that maintained their position in space (category 1). Reed turnover was therefore defined as the reciprocal of persistence: the proportion of reed patches which did not maintain their position in space. Reeds which were lost are given by the relative frequencies of categories 2 and 3, while reeds which became established are given by the frequencies of categories 4 and 7. Although this approach differs slightly from that of Arscott et al. (2002), where patch turnover was calculated as the proportional area of new patches present at the end of each time period, it allows patterns of reed loss and reed gain to be distinguished, and therefore allows for a more detailed analysis of reed dynamics. The term turnover, as used by Arscott et al. (2002), is misleading in the sense that it suggests complete removal and re-establishment of patches, whereas in fact it simply indicates the extent of new reed area, which may have arisen either by establishment of new patches or by clonal expansion of existing patches. Patch turnover was, however, also calculated as described above, to allow the results of this study to be compared with those of Arscott et al. (2002), the only other known study of patch turnover in a disturbance-driven river system. It was hypothesised that high reed persistence increases the potential for clonal expansion, and thus produces a greater increase in cover. This hypothesis was tested by relating percentage change in reed cover in each subsection to reed persistence using regression models. The response variable for regression models was always plotted against the fitted values to allow visual inspection of the fit of the model. The model fit was assessed further using the following diagnostic plots: Residuals vs fitted values, useful for identifying outliers and visualising structure in the residuals Normal quantile plot of residuals, to test the assumption that the model's errors are normally distributed Scale-location plot, for measuring spread and identifying pattern in the residuals Cook's distance plot, a measure of the inuence of individual observations on the regression coefficients To determine whether the fate of reed patches depends on their association with other patch types, the probabilities of association between reeds and all the other categories of change were calculated for each river section. This was done by calculating, for each type of reed pixel, the number of neighbouring pixels of each of the 9 categories of change. Reed pixels included reeds which remained (cagegory 1); reeds which were lost (categories 2 and 3); and new reeds which became established (categories 4 and 7). While pixels of a particular type are most likely to be surrounded by pixels of the same type, it is the relationships with neighbouring pixels of different types that can provide insight into the spatial associations between changes involving reeds, and those involving water and sand. Spatial associations between persistent reed patches and areas of reed loss were further quantified by estimating from the maps the proportion of patches of loss which lay within a 5 m radius of persistent reed patches. This made it possible to estimate what proportion of patches were removed completely, and what proportion merely became smaller. Clonal expansion vs establishment of new reed patches Patches of new reeds which are close to persistent reed patches are most probably a result of clonal expansion of the persistent patches, whereas those which are far from persistent patches must have established from seed or clonal progagules. The relative contribution of these two types of reed gain was determined by estimating the proportion of new reed patches found within a 5m radius of persistent patches, as described above for reed loss. Edge:area ratios were also calculated for all types of patches and compared between time periods using two-sample t tests. A decrease in this ratio indicates that patches have become more consolidated, suggesting clonal expansion in the case of reed patches. An increase in edge:area ratio indicates that patches have become smaller and more fragmented. Thus it was possible to determine whether a particular type of change occurred in large contiguous areas or rather in small discontinuous patches. Due to computational constraints, it was not possible to convert the raster maps of whole river subsections into vector format, necessary for calculating edge:area ratios. Instead, two randomly selected smaller areas (approximately 100 m in length) from each subsection map were converted into vector format and used to calculate edge:area ratios. The submaps converted into vector format for the calculation of edge:area ratios were also used to calculate the relative lengths of vegetated and unvegetated channel edge. The fact that new areas of water could be distinguished from older, more persistent ones made it possible to estimate the time required for channel edges to become colonised by reeds. Relationships between reed dynamics and geomorphic change Given the highly dynamic nature of the patch mosaic in semi-arid rivers generally, reed patch dynamics is likely to be related to geomorphic change, which may be quantified by the dynamics of water and sand patches. Relationships between reed patch dynamics and geomorphic change were explored by: Determining probabilities of association between reed patches, and water and sand patches with different histories (neighbour analysis) Comparing the persistence and turnover of reed and water patches in each period Relating reed cover and persistence to water cover and persistence using regression models

These were chosen subjectively in order to cover both the length of the study section and the range of histories of reed change (increasing reed cover, decreasing reed cover, and no change). Four of the subsections included the study sites at which fieldwork was done (Chapter 5). The aerial photographs were digitized using a scanner, at a resolution of 300 dots per inch (dpi), giving a pixel size of approximately 0.8 m 0.8 m on the ground. The three photographs from each site were then cross-georeferenced using features recognisable on all three photos (mainly trees). Pixels were classified as either reeds, water or sand using unsupervised classification based on grayscale ranges. Woody vegetation could not be uniquely identified on the basis of its grayscale range, and was omitted from the analysis. This was not considered a problem as woody vegetation in this section of the Letaba occurs almost exclusively as a riparian fringe on the macrochannel banks and does not form part of the mosaic of patches on the macro-channel oor. Occasional `problem' patches of woody vegetation were masked using the GIS software and thus ommitted from the analysis. The accuracy of each classification was assessed visually from the photographs and by comparing the maps produced by the GIS with reed distribution at the study sites. The resulting maps of reed distribution for each year were then combined to produce raster maps showing the location of patches (pixels) which had undergone one of nine categories of change, as follows: 1) reeds-> reeds 4) sand-> reeds 7) water-> reeds 2) reeds-> sand 5) sand-> sand 8) water-> sand 3) reeds-> water 6) sand-> water 9) water-> water Two sets of these combined maps were produced, one for each of the two time periods (1988 to 1996, and 1996 to 1999). This made it possible to compare changes taking place over a longer and a shorter period (8 years and 3 years). 3.2.1 Short-term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, Short term reed dynamics: changes in cover, persistence, gain and loss The GIS software was used to calculate the proportion of the macro-channel covered by each of the nine categories of change for each period. Reed cover present at the beginning of a period could then be calculated by combining categories 1, 2 and 3, and that present at the end of a period by combining categories 1, 4 and 7. Changes in the proportion of the macro-channel covered by water and sand were calculated in a similar way. Pattterns of reed persistence, appearance and disappearance were investigated by calculating the frequencies of each type of change involving reeds (categories 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7) as a percentage of the total changes involving reeds. These were compared between the two time periods using two-sample t tests. Reed persistence is a measure of what proportion of reed patches were able to maintain their position on the macro-channel floor, and thus, possibly, undergo clonal expansion. It was calculated as the proportion of reeds which were not lost or gained during a period, in other words, those that maintained their position in space (category 1). Reed turnover was therefore defined as the reciprocal of persistence: the proportion of reed patches which did not maintain their position in space. Reeds which were lost are given by the relative frequencies of categories 2 and 3, while reeds which became established are given by the frequencies of categories 4 and 7. Although this approach differs slightly from that of Arscott et al. (2002), where patch turnover was calculated as the proportional area of new patches present at the end of each time period, it allows patterns of reed loss and reed gain to be distinguished, and therefore allows for a more detailed analysis of reed dynamics. The term turnover, as used by Arscott et al. (2002), is misleading in the sense that it suggests complete removal and re-establishment of patches, whereas in fact it simply indicates the extent of new reed area, which may have arisen either by establishment of new patches or by clonal expansion of existing patches. Patch turnover was, however, also calculated as described above, to allow the results of this study to be compared with those of Arscott et al. (2002), the only other known study of patch turnover in a disturbance-driven river system. It was hypothesised that high reed persistence increases the potential for clonal expansion, and thus produces a greater increase in cover. This hypothesis was tested by relating percentage change in reed cover in each subsection to reed persistence using regression models. The response variable for regression models was always plotted against the fitted values to allow visual inspection of the fit of the model. The model fit was assessed further using the following diagnostic plots: Residuals vs fitted values, useful for identifying outliers and visualising structure in the residuals Normal quantile plot of residuals, to test the assumption that the model's errors are normally distributed Scale-location plot, for measuring spread and identifying pattern in the residuals Cook's distance plot, a measure of the inuence of individual observations on the regression coefficients To determine whether the fate of reed patches depends on their association with other patch types, the probabilities of association between reeds and all the other categories of change were calculated for each river section. This was done by calculating, for each type of reed pixel, the number of neighbouring pixels of each of the 9 categories of change. Reed pixels included reeds which remained (cagegory 1); reeds which were lost (categories 2 and 3); and new reeds which became established (categories 4 and 7). While pixels of a particular type are most likely to be surrounded by pixels of the same type, it is the relationships with neighbouring pixels of different types that can provide insight into the spatial associations between changes involving reeds, and those involving water and sand. Spatial associations between persistent reed patches and areas of reed loss were further quantified by estimating from the maps the proportion of patches of loss which lay within a 5 m radius of persistent reed patches. This made it possible to estimate what proportion of patches were removed completely, and what proportion merely became smaller. Clonal expansion vs establishment of new reed patches Patches of new reeds which are close to persistent reed patches are most probably a result of clonal expansion of the persistent patches, whereas those which are far from persistent patches must have established from seed or clonal progagules. The relative contribution of these two types of reed gain was determined by estimating the proportion of new reed patches found within a 5m radius of persistent patches, as described above for reed loss. Edge:area ratios were also calculated for all types of patches and compared between time periods using two-sample t tests. A decrease in this ratio indicates that patches have become more consolidated, suggesting clonal expansion in the case of reed patches. An increase in edge:area ratio indicates that patches have become smaller and more fragmented. Thus it was possible to determine whether a particular type of change occurred in large contiguous areas or rather in small discontinuous patches. Due to computational constraints, it was not possible to convert the raster maps of whole river subsections into vector format, necessary for calculating edge:area ratios. Instead, two randomly selected smaller areas (approximately 100 m in length) from each subsection map were converted into vector format and used to calculate edge:area ratios. The submaps converted into vector format for the calculation of edge:area ratios were also used to calculate the relative lengths of vegetated and unvegetated channel edge. The fact that new areas of water could be distinguished from older, more persistent ones made it possible to estimate the time required for channel edges to become colonised by reeds. Relationships between reed dynamics and geomorphic change Given the highly dynamic nature of the patch mosaic in semi-arid rivers generally, reed patch dynamics is likely to be related to geomorphic change, which may be quantified by the dynamics of water and sand patches. Relationships between reed patch dynamics and geomorphic change were explored by: Determining probabilities of association between reed patches, and water and sand patches with different histories (neighbour analysis) Comparing the persistence and turnover of reed and water patches in each period Relating reed cover and persistence to water cover and persistence using regression models
Patch Dynamics and Clonal Expansion of Reeds in the Letaba River, Kruger National Park

A transect-survey of vegetation composition and structure was conducted in the Main camp-section of the Addo Elephant National Park to monitor the effects of large herbivores, in particular elephant. Transects were permanently marked in 1977, when they were first surveyed, with further monitoring in 1981, 1989 and 2008 (providing temporal coverage of 31 years). Experimental plots were 5 m wide, while plot length scaled inversely with the abundance of the dominant shrub taxa. The following variables were recorded for each plant located along transects: (1) plant species, (2) maximum canopy height, (3) maximum crown diameter [D1], and (4) maximum crown diameter [D2] perpendicular to D1.

The strong influence of fire on vegetation structure and floristics in savannas make it an important tool for managers of preserved areas. Currently, Kruger National Park (KNP) uses a heterogeneous fire regime to promote biodiversity; however the effects of variance in fire return period on vegetation structural and compositional diversity have never been studied. This study recorded structural and floristic data at 16 sites within KNP in order to explore the relationship between variance in fire return period and structural and compositional vegetation diversity. We found variance in fire return period to have little influence over floristic and structural diversity. Average fire return period explained more differences in diversity, and we observed that a fire return period of around 6 years fostered the greatest structural and floristic diversity. These findings may be useful in informing future fire policy in KNP.

vegetation structural diversity, fire regime, floristic diversity, pyrodiversity
SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

Methods Methods Study Site Sixteen sites were selected in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of KNP in South Africa (Figure 1). GIS fire history data provided by Izak Smit of the park’s Scientific Services were used to select sites. Fire scar data from 1941 to 2008 were overlayed in a GIS map, dividing the park into polygons, with each polygon consisting of an area of identical fire history. We selected sites within two kilometers of a road for accessibility. Using the known fire history of each site provided by the GIS data, we selected 16 sites paired by the same average fire return period in order to control for the effects of fire frequency. While each pair had the same overall fire frequency through the past 69 years, one site in each pair had high variance in fire return period and the other had low variance (Table 1). FIGURE 1: Map of the 16 sites selected in Kruger National Park, with pairs labeled 1 through 8. Sites are paired by the same average fire return period, but one site in each pair has high variance in fire return period (shaded dark grey) and the other site has low variance in fire return period (shaded light grey). TABLE 1: Summary of fire history data of the 16 sites evaluated in the Skukuza/Pretoriaskop region of Kruger National Park in South Africa. Sites are arranged in pairs with sites labeled with an A representing the high variance site of each pair and sites labeled with a B representing the low variance site of each pair. Pair Number Number of Fires 1941 – 2006 Average Fire Return Period (years) Maximum Fire Return Period (years) Variance in Fire Return Period (years) Area (hectares) Difference in Variance Between Pairs (years) 1A 16 3.941 23 25.231 2.25323 22.911 1B 25 2.577 8 2.320 32.35122 2A 14 4.467 33 60.109 28.02452 51.330 2B 14 4.467 10 8.779 28.46588 3A 13 4.786 33 63.171 70.66326 54.574 3B 13 4.786 10 8.597 623.39243 4A 10 6.091 36 91.547 20.73223 76.740 4B 10 6.091 17 14.807 45.51266 5A 9 6.700 36 102.820 754.74734 88.810 5B 9 6.700 17 14.010 150.60097 6A 7 8.375 34 100.481 26.73789 84.457 6B 8 7.444 17 16.024 27.37966 7A 8 7.444 36 109.349 40.13838 95.990 7B 8 7.444 17 13.359 4.50639 8A 3 16.750 56 514.700 21.33613 433.520 8B 3 16.750 27 81.180 218.39858 All sites had granitic soil, moderate rainfall (590-640mm per year), and knobthorn/scicklebush thorn thicket vegetation dominated by Grewias, Dichrostachys, Acacias and Combretums. Within each site, a specific study plot was selected on the midslope of a catena, as defined by relative elevation and vegetation type, because vegetation type and structure is known to vary substantially between the crest and valley of a catena (Venter et al. 2003). Experimental Design and Protocol To examine the structural and floristic diversity at each site, we first defined four height classes for woody vegetation. Height class one included all individuals less than one meter to account for recent recruitment of seedlings. Although seedlings may not have experienced fire in their lifetime, the fire history of each site may influence their demographics and species composition. Height class two included all individuals between one and three meters. These individuals represent plants that have made it past the seedling stage, but are still vulnerable to fire. Height classes three and four included individuals greater than three meters to account for trees that have escaped the ‘fire trap.’ Height class three included all individuals greater than three meters and less than six meters, and height class four included trees six meters and greater. We separated height classes three and four to distinguish tall trees from tall shrubs and small trees. In addition to height classes, we identified each individual to species and noted structural characteristics. Each individual was classified as single-stemmed or multi-stemmed based on visual observation. Multi-stemmed individuals are likely to be sprouters, while single-stemmed individuals may be non-sprouters. Sprouters are better equipped to persist through fire (Bond and Midgley 2003), thus a higher number of multi-stemmed individuals relative to single-stemmed may indicate high selective pressure from fire. We also classified the structure of each individual as cage or pole architecture in order to test our hypothesis that sites with more frequent, less variable fires in the past would have more individuals with pole architecture because of the pressure to escape the ‘fire trap.’ Cage architecture was defined as woody vegetation that appeared to be investing in growth by sending stems outward instead of upward. We surveyed vegetation using a modified version of the Walker Transect method (Figure 2; L. Kruger pers. comm.). The transect consisted of a 100 meter straight-line transect running along the catenal mid-slope in order to control for vegetation type because distinct species assemblages dominate different catenal zones (Venter et al. 2003). In zone one, we identified every woody plant to species and recorded its height class and structural characteristics. In zone two, we recorded data for only those woody plants that were one meter or greater in height, and in zone three, we recorded only trees above three meters in height. We used this sampling method instead of identifying all individuals of all sizes in a smaller plot in order to cover a greater area and account for spatial variation in large individuals. FIGURE 2: Structure of the 50 meter x 100 meter Walker Transect used to measure floristic and structural diversity within each of the 16 sites. All woody individuals of all height classes were recorded in Zone 1. Only woody individuals taller than one meter were recorded in Zone 2 and only taller individuals greater than three meters were recorded in Zone 3. Zones 1 – 3 are on both sides of the center line (a 100 meter straight-line transect). For each site, we also recorded horizontal and vertical profiles in order to assess the overall spatial structure of the vegetation, including all plant biomass. We recorded information on horizontal visibility, vertical vegetation biomass, and canopy cover every 10 meters along each transect. A Cody’s vegetation index was used to evaluate horizontal visibility (K. Vickers, pers. comm.). We assessed the visibility of a white sheet of paper held at 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.5 meters above the ground by recording the distance at which 50% of the sheet of paper was no longer visible. This measure allowed us to compare vegetation biomass between sites beyond woody vegetation and to construct an idea of what each site looks like in terms of vegetation density. To establish a vertical vegetation profile, we estimated the percentage of space within a 2 m x 2 m x 2m box that was filled by vegetation at 0-2 m, 2-4 m, 4-6 m, 6-8 m, and so on, as high as was necessary in order to contrust a descriptive measure of the vertical density of biomass. Both the horizontal and vertical profiles were taken to supplement the height class values because height class data does not provide a complete picture of density and distribution of vegetation within each site. Finally, a densiometer was used to asses canopy cover. Analysis The objective of our study was to determine the effects of variance in fire return period on the floristics and structure of sites with similar average fire return periods. In order to make these comparisons, it was necessary to simplify complex measures such as horizontal and vertical profiles and the relative abundance of woody individuals of each species within each site. We used PRIMER–E 5.2.2 (Ltd, 2001) to calculate Shannon-Weiner diversity indices for floristics and for the following measures of structural diversity: height class, vertical profile, horizontal profile, cage and pole architecture, and multi-stemmed and single-stemmed architecture. The Shannon-Weiner Diversity Index was favored over the Simpson’s Index because it places emphasis on evenness rather than rarity. We expected that sites with high variance in fire return period would have higher diversity index scores than sites with low variance in fire return period. Paired T-tests were run on all diversity indices between matched sites using STATISTICA 6.1 (StatSoft, Inc. 1984-2004) in order to discern differences in diversity between sites of high and low variance. Bi-variate regression analyses were conducted to different explanatory factors for structural and floristic diversity across the 16 sites. For regressions of average fire return period against the number of woody individuals in each height class, one site (site 8b) was removed from the dataset due to uncertainty about the accuracy of the fire history (N. Govender, pers. comm.). Between each pair, we also found the difference in the number of woody individuals and calculated an average difference in woody individuals across the eight pairs of sites. We then compared the difference between individuals in each height class, the number of individuals that displayed cage and pole architecture, and the number of single-stemmed and multi-stemmed individuals. Paired t-tests were performed in order to test if the mean difference between pairs was zero.

The African elephant, Loxodonta africana, is a species of great importance in Kruger National Park because of the extensive impact it has on ecological processes. In this study, we focused on the effects of time of day, gender and age on time budgets in elephants. We sought to determine whether there were any activities that were performed more frequently at different times of the day or by elephants of a certain age or gender. Using focal observation, we determined the proportion of total time spent performing various activities. We found that the time budgets did not vary statistically with gender or age, but that there were significant differences in time spent standing still between the morning and afternoon (p=0.0143). More time was spent eating in the afternoon than the morning (p=0.002183), but overall time spent eating was less than previous studies have found. Despite the fact that elephant populations in Kruger are growing, the destruction of trees was not observed in any of our focal studies, indicating elephants in our study did not appear to impact the ecosystem as much as reported in previous literature.
Billy Boysen, Wren Larson, Jodie Reed SANParks, South Africa Independent Field Project 1
Billy Boysen, Wren Larson, Jodie Reed SANParks, South Africa Independent Field Project 1
activity budgets, African elephant (Loxodonta africana), age differences, behavior, gender differences, Kruger National Park

The study focused on the African Elephant, Loxodonta africana, the largest of all land mammals. Adult males can weigh over 6000 kg, with 200 kg contributing to the ivory tusks. When protected, an elephant can live to be over 70 years, constrained only by the irreplaceable six molar pairs that wear down over time (Frandsen 1998). For this behavioral study, we actively searched for elephants twice a day in Open Air Game Viewing Vehicles from September 21-24, 2006. Weather conditions were dry and hot, with temperatures around 30° C. Searching was held in the morning, 7:00 AM-12:00 PM, and afternoon, 12:00 PM-6:00 PM. All searching and observations were conducted along the Shingwedzi River within 30 km of the Shingwedzi Research Camp in Kruger National Park, South Africa (S 23.05682; E 031.34634). The majority of elephants were studied along the riverbank, with observation occurring from the opposite bank. Some individuals were encountered along the road and were observed there. When an elephant was observed, a GPS locator was used to pinpoint the location of the animal. The time of observation was noted and the elephant was classified in terms of age and gender. Three distinct age classes were used to categorize elephants: infant, juvenile, and adult. An infant was defined as any small elephant that had not yet 51 developed tusks. A juvenile was any tusked individual in the herd not yet fully grown, generally 75% or less of the size of the largest animals (adults). Ambiguity in the sexes prevented the identification of genders in the infants and juveniles. As a result, only the adult elephants were classified as male or female. After gender and age classification, activity budgets were determined through observation in focal studies (Altmann 1974). During the ten-minute focal observation, the activity of one elephant was carefully described and timed. One person observed the elephant through binoculars while a second recorded all of the reported observation. These descriptions were used to later classify the behavior into seven categories: eating, standing, drinking, traveling (walking or running), vigilance (looking around, head shaking, ears out), playing (trunk wrestling, shoving, butting, splashing, etc.), and other (mating, scratching, rolling around in the mud, nursing) (Estes 1999). Data were collected from 64 elephants. Because the elephants were observed from a distance, we assumed that our presence did not have an effect on their behavior. We calculated our statistics using Statistica 7.0 (StatSoft, Inc. © 1984-2004). The data were tested for normality using the Lilliefors test and found to be non-normally distributed; therefore we used nonparametric statistical tests in the analysis of our data. To analyze the effect of gender and age on time budgets we used a Kruskal-Wallis oneway ANOVA. If significant differences were detected, a Mann-Whitney U test was performed between adult males and adult females. If no significant differences were detected, these two groups were combined and reclassified as adults. The Kruskal-Wallis test was then performed on the three age groups and if significant differences were detected, this was followed by Mann-Whitney U tests of pairs of age groups per activity, along with a Bonforoni correction. The variability in the activity budgets due to the effect of time of day was analyzed using Mann-Whitney U tests.

The status of small mammal populations reflects ecosystem integrity. This study focused on rodent populations in two different habitats of the Mapungubwe National Park, the mopane savanna and riverine forest. Live trapping and vegetation surveys were performed in an effort to determine a relationship between rodent population presence and habitat structure. We found that there was a greater rodent abundance in the mopane savanna, but that there were no significant differences in diversity and richness between the two habitats. The higher abundance corresponded to areas with a greater understory height, lower soil penetrability, and closer proximity to major rock outcroppings. These findings establish that there is a relationship between habitat characteristics and rodent species abundance. This information can be used by conservationists as a baseline measure to develop conservation goals and plans that reflect the interconnected nature of ecosystems.
William Boysen and Eliza Chamblin SANParks, South Africa Independent Project 2
William Boysen and Eliza Chamblin SANParks, South Africa Independent Project 2
abundance, biodiversity, mopane savanna, riverine forest, rodents, vegetation structure

We conducted our study in the Mapungubwe National Park in the Limpopo Province of South Africa. We utilized ten study sites: five in the riverine forest along the Shashi River and five in the mopane savanna (Appendix 1). We set out ten Sherman traps at each of our ten sites, putting out one hundred traps in total. Within each site, we placed five traps under cover and five in the open. A trap placed under cover, or a closed trap, was placed under tight vegetation, usually a shrub, whereas a trap placed in the open might have been placed along a log or at the bottom of a tree (never totally in the open). In addition, half of the traps were standard size (8 x 9 x 23 cm) and half were long traps (8 x 9.5 x 30 cm). Slade et al. (1993) demonstrated that long traps had a consistently greater capture rate than short traps, and thus are more effective. Due to resource limitations, we were unable to use long traps exclusively. Instead, we used an equal number of long and short traps at each site to ensure that there was an equivalent chance of catching rodents at all sites. For the safety of the animals that we caught, we made sure that all traps were well-shaded by covering them with debris. We baited each trap with a mixture of peanut butter, oats, and honey. We rebaited the traps after each catch and every afternoon, so as to ensure bait freshness. We checked the traps once in the early morning (between 5:30am and 10:30am) and once in the late afternoon (between 3:30pm and 6:30pm) for four consecutive days (Tuesday, 14 November, 2006-Friday, 18 November, 2006) in the beginning of the summer rainy season. If we did find a specimen in one of our traps, we adhered to a uniform catch procedure: We uniquely marked and then released the specimen. We also recorded species weight and sex. We analyzed our collected data using Excel, Statistica and Primer. Vegetation/Habitat Survey To see if there was any relationship between the specific rodent species present and habitat conditions, we conducted habitat/vegetation surveys at each of our ten sites. We walked two 50 meter transects at each site from North to South. The transects were approximately ten meters apart. For each transect, we evaluated and recorded the habitat 86 type at one meter intervals: grass, sand, dirt, woody debris, dung, tree, rock, or shrub. Every five meters, we also estimated the proximity to a major rock outcropping and estimated the visibility at twenty centimeters, alternating to the East and to the West. In order to measure the visibility, one researcher held their head twenty centimeters above ground, while the other moved a notebook in a straight line away from the transect, also twenty centimeters above ground. When the individual at twenty centimeters could only see half of the notebook, we recorded the distance between the two individuals. These measurements were taken with the purpose of determining the level of habitat appeal and availability of protection from predators. Finally, every ten meters within each 50 meter transect, we took a penetrometer measurement of the soil to get a sense of the level of ease with which a rodent could burrow. Additionally, we noted the presence of dung, woody debris, rocks, or live trees within one meter of each transect. We analyzed all data with Excel, Statistica, and Primer.

Some pollinating fig wasp males fight each other for access to females and there is a suite of morphological characters that can be used to predict whether a male fig wasp will fight or not. This experiment tested out the validity of using morphological characters to predict fighting behavior by examining the morphology and observing the behavior of male fig wasps in Ficus sycomorus synconia. Males of each species present in the sycamore figs were examined and their fighting behavior was predicted and then observed. The presence or absence of fighting behavior was correctly predicted for three out of the four species found in the figs, suggesting that fighting syndrome morphology is a good indicator of wasp fighting behavior. Samevatting: Party betstuiwingde vy-perdeby mannetjies baklei met mekaar vir toegang aan vyperdeby wyfies en daar is ŉ reeks morfologiese karakters wat verbriuk kan word om te voorspel as ŉ mannetjie sal baklei of nie. Hierdie eksperiment toets die geldigheid van die verbruik vanaf morfologiese karakters om geveg gedrag te voorspel deur die ondersoek van morfologie en waarneeming van die gedrag van die mannetjie vyperdeby in Ficus sycomorus synconia. Mannetjies van elke spesies wat in die vye gevind is, was geondersoek, hul geveg gedrag was gevoorspel en waargeneem. Die afwesigheid of teenwoordigheid van die geveg gedrag was korrek voorgespel vir drie van die vier spesies van vy-perdebye species wat deel van die eksperiment was. Dit suggereer dat geveg morfologie ŉ goeie aanwyser van perdeby geveg gedrag is.
Stephanie Johnson SANParks,South Africa Independent Project
Stephanie Johnson SANParks,South Africa Independent Project
Agaonidae, fighting, fig wasps, local male competition, synconia

This experiment was conducted from 23-25 February 2004 at the Skukuza camp in Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province South Africa. Ficus sycomorus trees in and around the Skukuza camp were located, the stage of development of the chalcidoid wasps inside the figs was determined, and two trees were found that contained wasps at the fourth or male development stage where mature males emerge from their galls, mate with females, and chew an exit hole out of synconia (Galil et al. 1968). Ten figs were collected from each of the trees. The synconia were bisected with a scalpel and five figs in which males had already emerged or were beginning to emerge in large numbers were selected. The female wasps had not yet begun to emerge from their galls. One specimen of each species of male found inside the fig was removed and examined to determine if the males had any of the traits that are associated with fighting males, including: sickle-shaped mandibles, large head, long antennal scape, antennae not projecting forward, pronotum broader than long, mesonotum, metanotum and propodeum strongly fused (Greeff et al. 2003) (Table 1). After assessing the presence or absence of these traits, I predicted whether the males from the different species would fight. Tentative male species identifications were made using the Galil and Eisikowitch 1968 paper on the biology of the wasps found in the synconia of F. sycomorus trees in East Africa. One half of the synconia was placed in a small petri dish, covered with plastic wrap to prevent desiccation, and allowed to sit undisturbed for 30 minutes to one hour. The males were then observed for any displays of fighting behavior such as pushing a male away from a female, fighting with clear exchanges of bites and displacement of the resident male, biting another’s head, picking up a male and throwing him to the side, attacking a male’s thorax from the bottom, or antennae grabbing and pushing (Greeff et al. 2003). Each fig was observed for 30 minutes and the presence and type of fighting behavior displayed were recorded. Species that did not show any fighting behavior during the observation period were considered to not be fighters.

A juvenile was any tusked individual in the herd not yet fully grown, generally 75% or less of the size of the largest animals (adults). Ambiguity in the sexes prevented the identification of genders in the infants and juveniles. As a result, only the adult elephants were classified as male or female. After gender and age classification, activity budgets were determined through observation in focal studies (Altmann 1974). During the ten-minute focal observation, the activity of one elephant was carefully described and timed. One person observed the elephant through binoculars while a second recorded all of the reported observation. These descriptions were used to later classify the behavior into seven categories: eating, standing, drinking, traveling (walking or running), vigilance (looking around, head shaking, ears out), playing (trunk wrestling, shoving, butting, splashing, etc.), and other (mating, scratching, rolling around in the mud, nursing) (Estes 1999). Data were collected from 64 elephants. Because the elephants were observed from a distance, we assumed that our presence did not have an effect on their behavior. We calculated our statistics using Statistica 7.0 (StatSoft, Inc. © 1984-2004). The data were tested for normality using the Lilliefors test and found to be non-normally distributed; therefore we used nonparametric statistical tests in the analysis of our data. To analyze the effect of gender and age on time budgets we used a Kruskal-Wallis oneway ANOVA. If significant differences were detected, a Mann-Whitney U test was performed between adult males and adult females. If no significant differences were detected, these two groups were combined and reclassified as adults. The Kruskal-Wallis test was then performed on the three age groups and if significant differences were detected, this was followed by Mann-Whitney U tests of pairs of age groups per activity, along with a Bonforoni correction. The variability in the activity budgets due to the effect of time of day was analyzed using Mann-Whitney U tests.
The effects of time of day, gender, and age on time budgets in African Elephants in Kruger National Park
The effects of time of day, gender, and age on time budgets in African Elephants in Kruger National Park
activity budgets, African elephant (Loxodonta africana), age differences, behavior, gender differences, Kruger National Park

The study investigates the effects that changing herbivory patterns in the Northern Plains of Kruger National Park have had on vegetation structure and composition and on soil characteristics, both chemical and physical. Type I herbivores such as zebra and buffalo have encroached into the area, which has been historically inhabited by type II herbivores such as roan and sable. The study found that the more intense and less selective grazing associated with type I herbivores has had a marked effect on vegetation and soil chemical characteristics. Overall grass and tree cover has decreased, and the size of the remaining trees is reduced. Colophospermum mopane seems to thrive especially under disturbance conditions. Calcium, available phosphorus, salinity, and pH have homogenized under the influence of type I grazers, while organic carbon and total nitrogen have diversified. Differential land use patterns and grazing habits of type I and type II herbivores may drive these changes. However, until these patterns are better understood, their role in determining vegetation and soil properties will remain unclear.
Carla Staver SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
Carla Staver SANParks, South Africa Independent Project
herbivory, Northern Plains, soil nutrients, vegetation

The roan enclosure directly north of Shingwedzi provides an ideal location in which to examine the effects of herbivory and vegetation structure on soil characteristics in the Northern Plains. The enclosure lies on olivine-rich basalt in the Karoo geologic sequence and receives between 350 and 450 mm of rainfall per year. The enclosure was established in 1968 in an area upslope from a river; riparian and fluvial zones were added to the enclosure in 1985. This study examined upslope areas, where vegetation structure and soils have had more time to adjust to the exclusion of herbivory. The roan enclosure is divided into four quarters. One lies on black soil, which is dominated by marula (Sclerocarya birrea) and knobthorn (Acacia nigrescens), and was burnt 4-5 years ago. Fifteen sites were sampled in this quarter of the roan enclosure. The remainder of the enclosure lies on mopane-veld (dominated by Colophospermum mopane), characterized by red soils, which extends beyond the fence of the enclosure. Fifteen plots were sampled in the south-west corner of the enclosure, an area dominated by C. mopane, which was burned 4-5 years ago. Corresponding plots were sampled outside the enclosure on each soil type (see Figure 1 for a map of the enclosure with sampling layout). The fifteen plots in each site lie every 30 meters along three transects. These transects run parallel to the slope of the hill in order to minimize bias from effects of down-slope water, nutrient, and small particle flow on soil properties. The following parameters were sampled in each plot: • Trees within 400m2 circle (r=11.3): species, height, DBH • Grasses within circle of 2m radius: species, abundance, total cover • Soil samples at the center of these circles Soil nutrients (total N, available P, Ca) were analyzed at a soil lab according to the standard method. Soil pH was determined using the method outlined by Rowell (1994), using a 1:2.5 ratio of soil to 0.01 M CaCl2 solution. Conductivity was determined with a 1:5 ratio of soil to water and converted to standard-scale conductivity (ECe) using the method outlined by Landon (1991). Volumetric soil moisture content was determined by weighing soil moisture samples and then drying them at 105oC for 24 hours. Porosity was determined in the field using a surrogate measure; I measured the absorption time of 100 mL of water over an area of ~20 cm2. I used a field method for determining soil texture outlined by Tongway and Hindley (1995).

The supersite aerial photography is subsets of imagery collected as part of the National Photography and Imagery Programme by the national mapping agency, National Geo-Spatial Information (NGI) (previously known as Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping). NGI is a component of the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform. Imagery acquired before 2008 was taken at various heights and resolutions using a range of cameras. The pre-2008 imagery are available as non-georeferenced imagery directly from NGI (the job numbers, row numbers and photo numbers are provided below). The imagery collected after 2008 were captured digitally using an Intergraph DMC camera at 12-bits with a ground spacing distance (i.e. resolution) of 0.5m and were provided in a georeferenced format. The southern supersite imagery were collected in 2010, the northern granite supersites in 2008 and the northern basalt supersite in 2008/2009. More detail of the National Photography and Imagery Programme can be found at http://www.ngi.gov.za/index.php/Image-tabs-home/national-aerial-photography-and-imagery-programme.html

Basic data checks for Augrabies Notes 0281760 1 AUGRABIES Lat: -28.67 Long: 20.44 Height: 640 m RAINFALL CurOrder: This region appears incredibly arid, though summer/autumn rains fall annually. 1978 and 1979 were exceptionally dry years. There are no apparent gaps in the data, and there is only one occurrence of a failed reading, though there were some instances were data were accumulated. 1952 had an incredibly rainy day (287.5 mm - 1952/09/25). Basic data checks for Augrabies Falls Notes 0281606A5 AUGRABIES FALLS Lat: -28.6 Long: 20.34 Height: 635 m CurOrder: ELEC_TEMP Different number of days missing between 8h, 14h and 20h in the humidity, pressure and wind data series between 2001/09/04 and 2001/09/12 and again between 2001/09/21 and 2001/0924 - this was corrected There is a 2 month gap in humidity data in Oct/Nov 2006 after which all humidity values seem to be lower by a consistent margin (i.e. a similar annual pattern to the one observed prior to 2006 is seen, but all the values appear to be lower) No records for Nov 2002 (humidity) Questionable temperature records for 2008/10/26 and 27 - min on 26th was 26 with max 38, while the min on 27th was 18 with max 26 - this is out of character with the rest of the data, but I am not sure which of the value(s) would be the incorrect ones Likely change in instrumentation for humidity in 2006: Following data gap in 2006 there is an inconsistency in pattern 2001/09/11 repeated in 14h pressure series - deleted General comments Temperature: There is a strong annual pattern in temperature with a large difference in temperature between the min and max for all seasons. The same gaps occur as for other variables measured at this station (2002 and 2006 have the largest gaps = 2months). Rainfall: There are 219 occurrences of failed readings which equate to 7% of the total data. The period between 2006 and 2009 is particularly poor and it appears that all significant rainfall events have gone unrecorded. Dataset potentially not useful for analysis. Humidity: There is a 2 month gap in humidity data in Oct/Nov 2006 after which all humidity values seem to be lower by a consistent margin (i.e. a similar annual pattern to the one observed prior to 2006 is seen, but all the values appear to be lower). There is also a 2 month gap in data in Nov/Dec 2002. Pressure: The same 2002 and 2006 gaps that are present in the humidity data are present here. The pattern in pressure does not however appear to change after the 2006 gap. There are also some other smaller gaps present in the data as well as some areas with much higher variation in them than is the trend (often in winter) Wind: Gaps present in 2002 and 2006 as in other data series provided by this station, though the length of these gaps is slightly different. The 2006 gap extends from beg Oct 2006 until begin Feb 2007 (4 months). There is an annual pattern in wind speed with highest speed in summer, but wind speed is never particularly high.
